description: The CompTIA Cloud+ Certification is designed for IT professionals tasked with supporting private and public cloud infrastructures that have at least a few years of experience in IT networking. More and more companies are deploying cloud services in addition to, or in place of, traditional server infrastructure. The Cloud+ certification covers all the underlying hardware technologies, software, and logistics of deploying the technology, is designed to provide a well-rounded foundational knowledge of cloud and virtualization technologies and works to certify and validate one’s knowledge in the area of cloud computing.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don kick off the Cloud+ series by explaining some foundational concepts and terms. They start by describing what a cloud service is as well as the ideas of accountability and responsibility. Then they explore the common cloud models which include Software as as Service(SaaS), Platform as a Service(PaaS), and Infrastructure as a Service(IaaS). Finally they look at some of the less common cloud services like CaaS, DaaS, and XaaS.

00:23:58.447 --> 00:24:01.392
you are now managing
the upper part of the stack.

505
00:24:01.392 --> 00:24:05.844
>> That means that if something
goes wrong like the Heartbleed SSL

506
00:24:05.844 --> 00:24:08.707
exploit that happened about a year ago.

507
00:24:08.707 --> 00:24:10.003
When that happened,

508
00:24:10.003 --> 00:24:15.150
you had to update your open SSL
libraries down in your operating system.

509
00:24:15.150 --> 00:24:17.160
Well, the cloud provider doesn't do that.

510
00:24:17.160 --> 00:24:19.650
The cloud provider takes care of
the hardware and the hardware was fine.

511
00:24:19.650 --> 00:24:21.550
It was a problem in your OS.

512
00:24:21.550 --> 00:24:23.540
So you had to go and update that OS and

513
00:24:23.540 --> 00:24:26.530
until you did,
your operating system was vulnerable.

514
00:24:26.530 --> 00:24:28.380
That your web server was vulnerable.

515
00:24:28.380 --> 00:24:31.710
That somebody could have connected,
got a hold of your private keys and

516
00:24:31.710 --> 00:24:33.310
started decrypting your traffic.

517
00:24:33.310 --> 00:24:35.470
You had to manage that, right.

518
00:24:35.470 --> 00:24:38.620
But the tradeoff is that you
do have complete control now.

519
00:24:38.620 --> 00:24:40.940
You manage the OS and the application.

520
00:24:40.940 --> 00:24:44.200
If you need an updated library
installed you just install it.

521
00:24:44.200 --> 00:24:47.170
If you wanna switch from Linux
to Windows you do that, right?

522
00:24:47.170 --> 00:24:51.900
You have that control, but it also means
you're responsible for a lot more stuff.

523
00:24:51.900 --> 00:24:53.760
Now, there's still a lot of benefits here.

524
00:24:53.760 --> 00:24:55.550
I'm not having to buy physical servers.

525
00:24:55.550 --> 00:24:58.550
I'm not having to deal
with a lot of those extra

526
00:24:58.550 --> 00:25:01.070
things that go on when
I run my own equipment.

527
00:25:01.070 --> 00:25:05.000
And we'll talk in another episode about
the benefits of going Cloud that you have.

528
00:25:05.000 --> 00:25:07.350
You really, cost savings,
administration savings and

529
00:25:07.350 --> 00:25:09.790
all this still happen here
with platform as a service.

530
00:25:09.790 --> 00:25:14.470
This is one of the most common models
because you still have that control, but

531
00:25:14.470 --> 00:25:17.230
you are kind of outsourcing
an aspect of it.

532
00:25:17.230 --> 00:25:20.960
So you still get a lot of the benefits
without having to give up the control.

533
00:25:20.960 --> 00:25:23.710
>> And, Don, this doesn't meant
that we are devoid of having any

534
00:25:23.710 --> 00:25:26.980
kind of on premises devices,
you can still have those environments and

535
00:25:26.980 --> 00:25:28.220
you can even mix the two together.

536
00:25:28.220 --> 00:25:33.750
So, it's really give you a lot of
benefits, cost to benefit ratio,

537
00:25:33.750 --> 00:25:37.680
you're getting a lot for your money
when it comes to just about any type.

538
00:25:37.680 --> 00:25:42.410
Of the service when it comes to Cloud
services, very beneficial for us.

539
00:25:42.410 --> 00:25:44.110
I tend to like
the infrastructure as a service.

540
00:25:44.110 --> 00:25:47.300
I like being able to say well, I'm gonna
take care of the operating system,

541
00:25:47.300 --> 00:25:50.080
take care of updates and
little things like that.

542
00:25:50.080 --> 00:25:51.250
But I won't have to buy servers.

543
00:25:51.250 --> 00:25:53.090
I don't have to throw all
that stuff on a rack.

544
00:25:53.090 --> 00:25:54.480
I hate racking servers,

545
00:25:54.480 --> 00:25:58.140
that's one of my banes of my existence is
trying to stick a server in somewhere.

546
00:25:58.140 --> 00:26:03.290
Don, now these are the three main types
of of Cloud models that we're gonna see.

547
00:26:03.290 --> 00:26:06.080
Are there any others that we might see?

548
00:26:06.080 --> 00:26:07.030
Kind of one offs.

549
00:26:07.030 --> 00:26:08.400
>> Sadly there's a ton.

550
00:26:08.400 --> 00:26:11.420
They come up with a new
model every week it seems.

551
00:26:11.420 --> 00:26:15.335
So for the exam COM TA really
stresses Is the ones defined by NIST.

552
00:26:15.335 --> 00:26:16.845
The three that we just saw, right?

553
00:26:16.845 --> 00:26:20.455
Software is a service, platform is
a service, infrastructure is a service.

554
00:26:20.455 --> 00:26:24.405
Memorize those, know those,
use the NIST definition.

555
00:26:24.405 --> 00:26:27.225
If you go out on Google, you'll find
different people define it different ways.

556
00:26:27.225 --> 00:26:30.120
On the exam,
it's the NIST model, all right?

557
00:26:30.120 --> 00:26:33.070
But there are a handful of other
ones that COMT recognizes that

558
00:26:33.070 --> 00:26:34.000
you want to be familiar with.

559
00:26:34.000 --> 00:26:35.710
And I won't spend a ton of time on these,
but

560
00:26:35.710 --> 00:26:38.750
I'll just kind of run through them real
quick, make sure I don't miss any.

561
00:26:38.750 --> 00:26:43.780
There's CAAS, C A A S, which is
communications as a service, right?

562
00:26:43.780 --> 00:26:49.020
A great example of this
would be Ring Central or

563
00:26:49.020 --> 00:26:52.730
Vonage, companies like that where
they give you voice over IP service.

564
00:26:52.730 --> 00:26:54.350
But it doesn't just have
to be voiceover IP.

565
00:26:54.350 --> 00:26:57.550
It could be shared conferencing lines.

566
00:26:57.550 --> 00:27:01.140
It could be screen sharing for
you computers, like join.me, those guys.

567
00:27:01.140 --> 00:27:02.970
Those are communications as a service.

568
00:27:02.970 --> 00:27:04.800
And if you've never heard of these guys,
let me just bring.

569
00:27:04.800 --> 00:27:08.260
I think I've got Ring Central's page open,
here we go, Ring Central.

570
00:27:08.260 --> 00:27:10.510
So if you've never heard of Ring Central,

571
00:27:10.510 --> 00:27:12.610
there's ton of providers
that are like this.

572
00:27:12.610 --> 00:27:16.590
Where what they do is they
basically host a PBX so

573
00:27:16.590 --> 00:27:21.480
a phone exchange for you, and you can
define phone extensions with numbers and

574
00:27:21.480 --> 00:27:24.700
you can have physical phones or
software phones that connect up and

575
00:27:24.700 --> 00:27:27.680
people can call you and
it's your whole phone system in the cloud.

576
00:27:27.680 --> 00:27:31.620
So you can go anywhere in the world and
access your phone line, and make calls and

577
00:27:31.620 --> 00:27:34.340
receive calls and
send text messages and all that.

578
00:27:34.340 --> 00:27:38.860
And they go a little bit further, in that
they don't just do the phone service.

579
00:27:38.860 --> 00:27:41.620
They also do other things,
like online meetings,

580
00:27:41.620 --> 00:27:45.280
so you can do shared screens with video or
digital voice on top.

581
00:27:45.280 --> 00:27:47.020
They do video conferencing too.

582
00:27:47.020 --> 00:27:50.100
They do text messaging and
faxing, and so on.

583
00:27:50.100 --> 00:27:53.200
This is communications as a service, CAAS.

584
00:27:53.200 --> 00:27:56.500
It's very similar to software as a
service, because we don't see the server.

585
00:27:56.500 --> 00:27:57.800
We don't see the application.

586
00:27:57.800 --> 00:27:58.620
We don't see the hardware.

587
00:27:58.620 --> 00:28:00.560
All that's hidden from us, right?

588
00:28:00.560 --> 00:28:02.470
But they're not giving us software.

589
00:28:02.470 --> 00:28:03.770
I guess they sort of do.

590
00:28:03.770 --> 00:28:06.650
But what they're really billing us for
is the communications aspect.

591
00:28:06.650 --> 00:28:08.469
So that's CAAS,
communications as a service.

592
00:28:09.740 --> 00:28:12.770
Desktop as a service, DAAS, right.

593
00:28:12.770 --> 00:28:16.140
Normally when we talk about cloud services
we're talking about servers, right.

594
00:28:16.140 --> 00:28:20.160
The client is gonna be a laptop or
tablet or something that I'm using.

595
00:28:20.160 --> 00:28:23.270
But we can actually have it where
your desktop is the service.

596
00:28:23.270 --> 00:28:26.170
Amazon WorkSpaces is
a great example of that.

597
00:28:26.170 --> 00:28:30.270
Where, as a business person, maybe you've
got business applications that you run.

598
00:28:30.270 --> 00:28:33.470
Maybe it's QuickBooks, so
I need QuickBooks available to me.

599
00:28:33.470 --> 00:28:35.515
But I use 10 different computers, and

600
00:28:35.515 --> 00:28:38.370
QuickBooks does not like you to
install on more than one computer.

601
00:28:38.370 --> 00:28:41.640
You've gotta go and
buy multiple copies and all that.

602
00:28:41.640 --> 00:28:44.160
So instead of installing on my computer,

603
00:28:44.160 --> 00:28:47.840
I can get a desktop that's
hosted in the Cloud.

604
00:28:47.840 --> 00:28:51.400
And then, all I have to do
is install QuickBooks there.

605
00:28:51.400 --> 00:28:56.530
And when I go to any computer, I can
remote into this desktop, see my desktop,

606
00:28:56.530 --> 00:28:59.220
see my applications, and
start to work with it.

607
00:28:59.220 --> 00:29:03.270
So it doesn't matter if I'm on my tablet,
if I'm on my desktop, on my laptop.

608
00:29:03.270 --> 00:29:07.090
I always get the same desktop,
the same applications I'm able to work.

609
00:29:07.090 --> 00:29:08.630
That's Desktop as a service.

610
00:29:08.630 --> 00:29:11.840
Sometimes it's called VDI,
Virtual Desktop Infrastructure.

611
00:29:11.840 --> 00:29:16.389
But desktop as a service is
kind of a newer name for that.

612
00:29:16.389 --> 00:29:19.210
BPAAS, [LAUGH].

613
00:29:19.210 --> 00:29:21.130
If I can keep it straight here,

614
00:29:21.130 --> 00:29:26.840
business process as a service, normally
when we talk about software as a service,

615
00:29:26.840 --> 00:29:31.850
we're talking about some particular
single piece of software, right?

616
00:29:31.850 --> 00:29:34.020
I used email as an example.

617
00:29:34.020 --> 00:29:37.230
But email is just one component
of what a business might do.

618
00:29:37.230 --> 00:29:40.290
And so, in businesses we have
what's called a business process.

619
00:29:40.290 --> 00:29:42.810
Daniel and I, we used to work
at an insurance company and

620
00:29:42.810 --> 00:29:46.030
at the insurance company they
had a claims department.

621
00:29:46.030 --> 00:29:49.670
And when somebody got in a car accident or
a tree fell on their house or

622
00:29:49.670 --> 00:29:51.280
whatever they would do a claim.

623
00:29:51.280 --> 00:29:55.830
And the process of doing a claim
involved more than one system.

624
00:29:55.830 --> 00:29:59.110
You'd get either a phone call or
an email or

625
00:29:59.110 --> 00:30:00.950
a fax that would start the claim process.

626
00:30:00.950 --> 00:30:03.760
Somebody would say look
a tree fell on my house.

627
00:30:03.760 --> 00:30:07.730
And then that would go into one system
where we would dispatch an adjuster.

628
00:30:07.730 --> 00:30:09.170
The adjuster would go in the field,

629
00:30:09.170 --> 00:30:12.770
evaluate the damage and
put that into the adjusting system.

630
00:30:12.770 --> 00:30:16.230
Once that got approved for payout,
it would go to the accounting system.

631
00:30:16.230 --> 00:30:17.730
And the accountants would
generate a check, and

632
00:30:17.730 --> 00:30:21.680
the check would get mailed to the insured.

633
00:30:21.680 --> 00:30:23.150
You'll be able to repair things.

634
00:30:23.150 --> 00:30:25.210
You've got an adjusting system.

635
00:30:25.210 --> 00:30:28.020
An accounting system, a physical mail,
you've got phone lines.

636
00:30:28.020 --> 00:30:32.270
You've got all these different parts
that are part of the business process.

637
00:30:32.270 --> 00:30:35.500
So business process as a service BPAAS.

638
00:30:35.500 --> 00:30:38.450
Is where they put all of those
components in the Cloud.

639
00:30:38.450 --> 00:30:41.700
Not just email, not just phone,
not just adjusting,

640
00:30:41.700 --> 00:30:44.820
not just accounting, but
all of it wrapped together.

641
00:30:44.820 --> 00:30:49.220
So if you are gonna open up
a dentist office and you're like,

642
00:30:49.220 --> 00:30:52.040
boy, I need software to run this dentist
office, managing my patients and

643
00:30:52.040 --> 00:30:54.710
tracking medical records and
issuing prescriptions.

644
00:30:54.710 --> 00:30:58.100
You go online and you can find
somebody that has a BPAAS service for

645
00:30:58.100 --> 00:30:59.150
dentist offices.

646
00:30:59.150 --> 00:31:01.530
And you get all the various components,
all the work flows and so

647
00:31:01.530 --> 00:31:02.770
on wrapped into one.

648
00:31:02.770 --> 00:31:08.180
And there's plenty of examples out there,
Constant Contact is a great one.

649
00:31:08.180 --> 00:31:11.730
If you deal with sales people
they'll know constant contact.

650
00:31:11.730 --> 00:31:17.690
And with Constant Contact what they do
is they let you track your customers,

651
00:31:17.690 --> 00:31:20.420
track your purchase history,
send our marketing emails,

652
00:31:20.420 --> 00:31:25.470
send out communications and kind of manage
everything all in one single location.

653
00:31:25.470 --> 00:31:27.690
So they've taken your marketing,
your sales,

654
00:31:27.690 --> 00:31:32.740
your ERP and it's all just It's all
kind of baked into one solution.

655
00:31:32.740 --> 00:31:37.110
There's plenty of people out there
that provide services just like this.

656
00:31:37.110 --> 00:31:41.825
Alright, that was BPASS- or AAS,
getting my letters all messed up,

657
00:31:41.825 --> 00:31:44.325
>> There are a lot of A-S-Ses going on

658
00:31:44.325 --> 00:31:47.027
>> The only other one that's on the list

659
00:31:47.027 --> 00:31:49.046
is my favorite one, XAAS.

660
00:31:49.046 --> 00:31:53.390
XAAS is anything as a service right?

661
00:31:53.390 --> 00:31:57.460
The x just means anything,
insert something here as a service.

662
00:31:57.460 --> 00:31:59.678
>> They couldn't have made it AAAS.

663
00:31:59.678 --> 00:32:01.734
It's like AARP right?

664
00:32:01.734 --> 00:32:03.255
>> It would be first in the phone book.

665
00:32:03.255 --> 00:32:04.833
[LAUGH]
>> That's right, that's a smart idea.

666
00:32:04.833 --> 00:32:06.872
So anyway, it's XaaS.

667
00:32:06.872 --> 00:32:11.750
And basically what's happening is anything
can be provided as a service nowadays.

668
00:32:11.750 --> 00:32:13.660
Anything can be put up in the cloud.

669
00:32:13.660 --> 00:32:16.560
And so you're starting to see very
odd things kinda jump up there.

670
00:32:16.560 --> 00:32:18.455
And it's hard to categorize it.

671
00:32:18.455 --> 00:32:21.645
But it's usually organizations
that provide more than one thing.

672
00:32:21.645 --> 00:32:25.185
The best example of that would
be Amazon Web Service, right?

673
00:32:25.185 --> 00:32:28.355
So, I've got the Amazon Web Services
page pulled up here, and

674
00:32:28.355 --> 00:32:30.455
when you go into Amazon Web Services and

675
00:32:30.455 --> 00:32:34.315
take a look at their product list, look at
all the different products they've got.

676
00:32:34.315 --> 00:32:39.360
They've got a ton of different
products from databases in the Cloud,

677
00:32:39.360 --> 00:32:43.340
to websites in the Cloud,
applications, desktops.

678
00:32:43.340 --> 00:32:47.500
You got file services in the Cloud,
mobile services, Internet of Things.

679
00:32:47.500 --> 00:32:49.070
That's something new that
they're starting to roll out,

680
00:32:49.070 --> 00:32:51.285
all the little devices
that can communicate.

681
00:32:51.285 --> 00:32:55.150
Elasticsearch, which is just a search and
indexing,

682
00:32:55.150 --> 00:32:58.060
machine learning, data warehousing.

683
00:32:58.060 --> 00:33:03.010
Tons of different components,
all available via the Cloud.

684
00:33:03.010 --> 00:33:07.280
And so this all gets wrapped up under this
one big umbrella term of XaaS, right?

685
00:33:07.280 --> 00:33:08.950
Anything as a service.

686
00:33:08.950 --> 00:33:10.810
And that's another term
that you may see out there.

687
00:33:10.810 --> 00:33:11.410
All right.

688
00:33:11.410 --> 00:33:15.270
Those are all the terms that CompTIA
specifically calls out on the exam.

689
00:33:15.270 --> 00:33:17.080
There's more, right?

690
00:33:17.080 --> 00:33:18.540
There's networking as a service,

691
00:33:18.540 --> 00:33:21.150
there's others like that, but
CompTIA doesn't call those out.

692
00:33:21.150 --> 00:33:24.410
And a lot of these terms are unofficial,
they're not officially defined.

693
00:33:24.410 --> 00:33:27.850
The three big ones, as defined by NIST,
you need to have those memorized,

694
00:33:27.850 --> 00:33:33.800
infrastructure as a service, platform as
a service, and software as a service.

695
00:33:33.800 --> 00:33:35.270
So we've got to have
those three memorized.

696
00:33:35.270 --> 00:33:38.530
Those are gonna be on the exam
according to the NIST definition.

697
00:33:38.530 --> 00:33:40.520
The other ones may turn up also.

698
00:33:40.520 --> 00:33:42.120
And you need to be aware of those, too.

699
00:33:42.120 --> 00:33:43.560
But they're a little less common.

700
00:33:43.560 --> 00:33:44.510
>> Well, awesome stuff, Don.

701
00:33:44.510 --> 00:33:47.430
Obviously, there's a lot for
us to understand, a lot of foundational

702
00:33:47.430 --> 00:33:52.310
knowledge, terminology that goes
along with cloud services per say.

703
00:33:52.310 --> 00:33:53.620
So make sure you go back through those.

704
00:33:53.620 --> 00:33:54.180
Check those out.

705
00:33:54.180 --> 00:33:55.320
Get them burned into the brain,

706
00:33:55.320 --> 00:33:57.830
because we're going to be talking
about them a lot and having that

707
00:33:57.830 --> 00:34:01.140
good foundational knowledge is going to
help you as you move through this series.

708
00:34:01.140 --> 00:34:04.050
Don, is there anything else that we
need to cover before we sign off today?

709
00:34:04.050 --> 00:34:05.290
I think that's it for cloud models.

710
00:34:05.290 --> 00:34:08.370
Obviously we still have a lot more, and I
know this wasn't a very hands on episode.

711
00:34:08.370 --> 00:34:10.450
Its a concept and theory type thing.

712
00:34:10.450 --> 00:34:12.070
But we will get to see a lot more of this.

713
00:34:12.070 --> 00:34:15.120
We're going to be implementing a lot of
these technologies as the course goes on.

714
00:34:15.120 --> 00:34:16.490
But we needed to know those.

715
00:34:16.490 --> 00:34:17.710
That's kinda first off.

716
00:34:17.710 --> 00:34:21.230
We've got more coming up though, because
we've gotta jump into delivery models,

717
00:34:21.230 --> 00:34:22.910
which kinda of go hand and hand with this.

718
00:34:22.910 --> 00:34:24.390
So we'll get a chance to see those next,

719
00:34:24.390 --> 00:34:27.300
but as far as our cloud service models,
those are them.

720
00:34:27.300 --> 00:34:28.970
Those are the ones you need to know for
the exam.

721
00:34:28.970 --> 00:34:30.250
>> All right, well, thank you so much,

722
00:34:30.250 --> 00:34:32.960
Don for joining us today and
explaining these topics for us.

723
00:34:32.960 --> 00:34:34.070
Thank you guys for watching.

724
00:34:34.070 --> 00:34:35.000
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

725
00:34:35.000 --> 00:34:37.580
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

726
00:34:37.580 --> 00:34:38.120
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

727
00:34:38.120 --> 00:34:40.790
>> And we'll see you next time.

00:24:25.682 --> 00:24:26.952
I keep things nice and warm.

517
00:24:26.952 --> 00:24:28.380
So, I've got these five servers running.

518
00:24:28.380 --> 00:24:32.568
We developed, we create this great new
website that everybody's gonna love and

519
00:24:32.568 --> 00:24:36.695
then we release it to the internet and
5 people find out about it, 10 people,

520
00:24:36.695 --> 00:24:37.633
a 100 people.

521
00:24:37.633 --> 00:24:42.232
My five servers are running great and
then it hits Twitter, it hits YouTube,

522
00:24:42.232 --> 00:24:43.380
it hits whatever.

523
00:24:43.380 --> 00:24:46.734
And all of a sudden, I've got hundred
thousand people trying to hit my site

524
00:24:46.734 --> 00:24:48.768
right now and
my five of my servers collapse.

525
00:24:48.768 --> 00:24:52.121
Well, I could have avoided that if I put
it all on the cloud in the first place.

526
00:24:52.121 --> 00:24:54.942
We could have just scaled up,
no big deal, but I wasn't ready for that.

527
00:24:54.942 --> 00:24:57.763
I wanted it to be here with me,
I wanted control.

528
00:24:57.763 --> 00:25:00.782
So, what you could do is you could
leverage a hybrid environment.

529
00:25:00.782 --> 00:25:03.109
I know we talked about hybrid
clouds in another episode, but

530
00:25:03.109 --> 00:25:05.403
we could do a hybrid environment
where my servers are here.

531
00:25:05.403 --> 00:25:10.378
My five servers are right here with me and
they're doing the service,

532
00:25:10.378 --> 00:25:15.457
but as resources run out, I scale by
adding new instances in the cloud.

533
00:25:15.457 --> 00:25:16.803
I do cloud bursting.

534
00:25:16.803 --> 00:25:18.242
So, I have my five servers here.

535
00:25:18.242 --> 00:25:22.485
I'm always gonna have my five servers
here, but I might have one server in

536
00:25:22.485 --> 00:25:26.264
the cloud or a thousand servers in
the cloud as I need that demand.

537
00:25:26.264 --> 00:25:29.061
As I have the viewers hitting my site and
I need to scale up for that, and

538
00:25:29.061 --> 00:25:30.010
then we scale down, and

539
00:25:30.010 --> 00:25:33.486
I might have no servers up in the cloud,
and everything's back here in-house again.

540
00:25:33.486 --> 00:25:37.920
Having cloud bursting is a neat way to
cover a special seasonal activities.

541
00:25:37.920 --> 00:25:38.817
Where from mostly,

542
00:25:38.817 --> 00:25:41.893
you just want in-house service you
wont pay anybody else for those.

543
00:25:41.893 --> 00:25:45.584
But then when you hit that holidays
season, or taxis, whatever it is create

544
00:25:45.584 --> 00:25:48.710
your seasonal business,
you ramp up with servers in the cloud.

545
00:25:48.710 --> 00:25:51.078
And when that season's over,
you take the cloud servers away.

546
00:25:51.078 --> 00:25:53.254
That's cloud bursting,
it's a neat technology,

547
00:25:53.254 --> 00:25:56.320
it does require setting up things like
a VPN between your organization and

548
00:25:56.320 --> 00:25:57.667
the cloud to synchronize data.

549
00:25:57.667 --> 00:26:00.610
There's a lot of other back-end
infrastructure that has to be setup, but

550
00:26:00.610 --> 00:26:01.788
it's a really cool concept.

551
00:26:01.788 --> 00:26:02.417
>> Awesome.

552
00:26:02.417 --> 00:26:05.109
We go through a lot of different
terminology and concepts.

553
00:26:05.109 --> 00:26:08.568
Now, is there anything else that we
need to cover before we close this show?

554
00:26:08.568 --> 00:26:11.655
>> The two last terms we kind
of already talked about.

555
00:26:11.655 --> 00:26:14.676
Rapid deployment, which with the cloud
is one of your big benefits.

556
00:26:14.676 --> 00:26:18.218
You can spin up new servers in
a moment's notice, very rapid.

557
00:26:18.218 --> 00:26:21.965
You can pre-build images that already
have your software configured and you can

558
00:26:21.965 --> 00:26:25.769
roll things into production in a matter
of seconds, that's the rapid deployment

559
00:26:25.769 --> 00:26:29.210
that we get and then the last term that
we need to be aware of is automation.

560
00:26:29.210 --> 00:26:33.781
Automation is where we take any kind of
activity like scaling up or scaling down,

561
00:26:33.781 --> 00:26:35.338
scaling out or scaling in.

562
00:26:35.338 --> 00:26:37.996
Those type of activities,
we can automate them.

563
00:26:37.996 --> 00:26:41.104
We can set it to where your
system monitors CP utilization or

564
00:26:41.104 --> 00:26:42.234
hits on the website.

565
00:26:42.234 --> 00:26:45.709
And when it exceeds a certain amount, then
it scales up or then it scales down or

566
00:26:45.709 --> 00:26:47.147
then it scales out or scales in.

567
00:26:47.147 --> 00:26:50.909
It does something to make it where
that traffic table can be handled and

568
00:26:50.909 --> 00:26:54.055
it can all be automatic, so
we don't have worry about it.

569
00:26:54.055 --> 00:26:56.549
It just happens and
it's done, that's automation.

570
00:26:56.549 --> 00:26:58.511
I know we talked about it
a bit in the last episode.

571
00:26:58.511 --> 00:26:59.707
>> Excellent stuff, Don.

572
00:26:59.707 --> 00:27:01.749
Well, we've covered a lot
of different terms and

573
00:27:01.749 --> 00:27:03.410
we covered a lot of different concepts.

574
00:27:03.410 --> 00:27:07.294
But hopefully now, you are able to
jump into a conversation about cloud

575
00:27:07.294 --> 00:27:11.385
environments and you're fully well
aware of every piece of terminology.

576
00:27:11.385 --> 00:27:14.728
You can have those conversations,
because you're up on the language.

577
00:27:14.728 --> 00:27:17.035
Don, thank you so much for
explaining it to us and

578
00:27:17.035 --> 00:27:20.765
giving us the keys to this little kingdom
here and being able to take part in it.

579
00:27:20.765 --> 00:27:21.683
We appreciate that.

580
00:27:21.683 --> 00:27:23.483
We appreciate our viewers for
joining us today.

581
00:27:23.483 --> 00:27:25.528
We're gonna go and sign off for ITProTV.

582
00:27:25.528 --> 00:27:26.847
I've been your host, Daniel Lowery.

583
00:27:26.847 --> 00:27:27.721
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

584
00:27:27.721 --> 00:27:28.766
>> And we'll see you next time.

585
00:27:28.766 --> 00:27:36.400
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don walk you through common cloud storage concepts. They discuss how cloud providers store your data as well as the benefits of using cloud storage. Then they define cloud storage characteristics, which introduce you to terms like BLOB(Binary Large OBject) and Identifiers, specifically Object ID and Metadata/Extended Metadata. Finally they cover Cloud Storage Security controls. This includes Access Control(permissions), Access Policies, and Replicas.
episodes.title: Object Storage Concepts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.094 --> 00:00:10.094
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.873 --> 00:00:16.309
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.309 --> 00:00:18.165
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and

4
00:00:18.165 --> 00:00:21.753
in today's episode we're moving
on with our Cloud Plus content.

5
00:00:21.753 --> 00:00:23.565
Our series that we've been working so
hard on.

6
00:00:23.565 --> 00:00:27.381
Joining us in the studio today is our good
friend, our mentor, our leader, that is,

7
00:00:27.381 --> 00:00:27.918
Don Pizet.

8
00:00:27.918 --> 00:00:29.254
Don, welcome back to the show sir.

9
00:00:29.254 --> 00:00:31.110
>> Thanks for
having me back on the show, Daniel.

10
00:00:31.110 --> 00:00:33.011
I'm ready to jump right back
into the world of Cloud Plus.

11
00:00:33.011 --> 00:00:37.481
In this episode we're gonna be taking
a look at storage object concepts,

12
00:00:37.481 --> 00:00:39.290
which is kind of a weird name.

13
00:00:39.290 --> 00:00:42.681
But it's important to have a good
understanding before you dive into

14
00:00:42.681 --> 00:00:46.714
the world of virtualization, before you
dive into the world of cloud computing,

15
00:00:46.714 --> 00:00:48.072
on how storage is handled.

16
00:00:48.072 --> 00:00:50.300
Because it's different
than what we're used to.

17
00:00:50.300 --> 00:00:53.621
In traditional virtualization
environments, or in traditional

18
00:00:53.621 --> 00:00:58.750
physical environments, you have dedicated
hard drives assigned to virtual machines.

19
00:00:58.750 --> 00:01:01.940
But, or to physical machines,
I guess, but to virtual machines,

20
00:01:01.940 --> 00:01:05.300
you could have physical drives, but
you normally have virtual drives.

21
00:01:05.300 --> 00:01:08.330
And the virtual drives are designed to
be portable, to move between systems.

22
00:01:08.330 --> 00:01:12.800
And that means they have to be stored
differently than what we're used to.

23
00:01:12.800 --> 00:01:15.150
And so
we're gonna take a look at how that is,

24
00:01:15.150 --> 00:01:19.502
the different concepts around storage,
before we jump into the bigger world of

25
00:01:19.502 --> 00:01:22.238
virtualization which is coming
up in the next couple episodes.

26
00:01:22.238 --> 00:01:25.470
Because if you make a mistake on
how your storage is set up, and

27
00:01:25.470 --> 00:01:29.360
then you build your whole infrastructure
on top of it, it's pretty hard to fix.

28
00:01:29.360 --> 00:01:31.643
So, you wanna make sure you got a good
understanding of this from early on.

29
00:01:31.643 --> 00:01:34.140
And we'll see some of that,
right here today.

30
00:01:34.140 --> 00:01:37.700
>> I know this can definitely
be scary topic for most of us,

31
00:01:37.700 --> 00:01:38.580
to be honest with you.

32
00:01:38.580 --> 00:01:43.230
Even traditional storage concepts are very
frightful in the way cuz, well like Don

33
00:01:43.230 --> 00:01:45.780
said, if you do them wrong then you've
got a lot of backpedaling to do.

34
00:01:45.780 --> 00:01:49.540
And could take you a lot of time,
a lot of effort to make it work correctly.

35
00:01:49.540 --> 00:01:53.440
So we wanna make sure that you have the
proper foundation, get the right storage,

36
00:01:53.440 --> 00:01:56.230
and understand the concepts
behind storage in the cloud so

37
00:01:56.230 --> 00:01:57.990
that you can move forward amicably.

38
00:01:57.990 --> 00:01:59.444
So Don, that leads us to,

39
00:01:59.444 --> 00:02:03.291
I guess you say it's different
than traditional storage concepts.

40
00:02:03.291 --> 00:02:05.060
So let's start there.

41
00:02:05.060 --> 00:02:06.160
What is different about it?

42
00:02:06.160 --> 00:02:09.296
>> All right, so one of they key things
to remember with virtualization is that

43
00:02:09.296 --> 00:02:12.873
instead of having dedicated physical hard
drives, you've got virtual hard drives.

44
00:02:12.873 --> 00:02:15.954
And those virtual hard drives
are gonna be put on real storage,

45
00:02:15.954 --> 00:02:19.630
physical storage, that's typically
shared with other people, right?

46
00:02:19.630 --> 00:02:21.890
It's not exclusive to you.

47
00:02:21.890 --> 00:02:24.750
If it's a private cloud,
if it's your own cloud,

48
00:02:24.750 --> 00:02:28.920
then the hardware is exclusive to you, but
it's multiple virtual machines sharing it.

49
00:02:28.920 --> 00:02:32.890
If it's a public cloud, like Amazon,
or Azure, or somebody like that,

50
00:02:32.890 --> 00:02:37.020
well, in that case, it's shared with
other people that you don't even know.

51
00:02:37.020 --> 00:02:40.920
And it all kind of stems back
from cluster-based storage.

52
00:02:40.920 --> 00:02:44.520
When you have virtualization, it's real
important that you have shared storage.

53
00:02:44.520 --> 00:02:47.968
And if you've never worked with that
before, let me show you a little

54
00:02:47.968 --> 00:02:51.310
diagram here that I worked up that
basically shows how this works.

55
00:02:51.310 --> 00:02:55.186
Now, normally in a non-type SAN
environment whatever if you have just

56
00:02:55.186 --> 00:02:58.749
regular physical servers you
have something like this, right.

57
00:02:58.749 --> 00:03:02.420
I'm gonna have three servers and
they each have their own storage, right.

58
00:03:02.420 --> 00:03:05.630
So Server 1 might have a couple
of hard drives, Server 2,

59
00:03:05.630 --> 00:03:07.198
Server 3 each with their own hard drives.

60
00:03:07.198 --> 00:03:10.370
Maybe they've got one set of hard
drives for their operating system and

61
00:03:10.370 --> 00:03:13.630
another set of hard drives for
their data, right?

62
00:03:13.630 --> 00:03:17.195
So if I'm a database server I might have
my operating system on one drive and

63
00:03:17.195 --> 00:03:18.452
the database on another.

64
00:03:18.452 --> 00:03:20.740
If I'm an email server, same thing.

65
00:03:20.740 --> 00:03:23.960
Operating system on one,
mailbox database on the other.

66
00:03:23.960 --> 00:03:28.470
If I'm a domain controller or whatever,
each server has their own storage needs.

67
00:03:28.470 --> 00:03:32.690
The problem here is if I have some
kind of failure on this server,

68
00:03:32.690 --> 00:03:35.930
I can't just jump it's role
right over to another server.

69
00:03:35.930 --> 00:03:39.660
Because all the storage is
back on that first server.

70
00:03:39.660 --> 00:03:43.430
So when we build up a virtual machine,
we have that same situation.

71
00:03:43.430 --> 00:03:47.100
You've got the virtual server and
it's virtual hard drives.

72
00:03:47.100 --> 00:03:49.674
And if I ever want that virtual
server to move from one piece

73
00:03:49.674 --> 00:03:53.450
of hardware to another, it's gotta be
able to take the storage along with it.

74
00:03:53.450 --> 00:03:56.440
And the easiest way to achieve
that is through the use of

75
00:03:56.440 --> 00:03:59.060
a Storage Area Network or a SAN.

76
00:03:59.060 --> 00:04:04.320
And the way a SAN works is you take
the hard drives out of the servers and

77
00:04:04.320 --> 00:04:08.140
you put them into some kind of
shared infrastructure which is that

78
00:04:08.140 --> 00:04:10.480
Storage Area Network, this guy down here.

79
00:04:10.480 --> 00:04:12.512
And there's any number of
companies that make SANs, right?

80
00:04:12.512 --> 00:04:15.030
EMC is probably the biggest one.

81
00:04:15.030 --> 00:04:16.236
They're heavily partnered with Dell and

82
00:04:16.236 --> 00:04:17.448
they sell a ton of SANs
that are out there.

83
00:04:17.448 --> 00:04:20.745
HP has some huge storage
products that are out there.

84
00:04:20.745 --> 00:04:23.985
And then there's a lot of other
companies that are in that space too.

85
00:04:23.985 --> 00:04:27.025
But they all basically work the same.

86
00:04:27.025 --> 00:04:31.033
What they all do is they allow you to
take a bunch of physical hard drives.

87
00:04:31.033 --> 00:04:33.354
And we might be talking about
3 physical hard drives,

88
00:04:33.354 --> 00:04:37.093
we might be talking about 100, 200,
500, 1,000 hard drives, right?

89
00:04:37.093 --> 00:04:38.532
It can be a lot.

90
00:04:38.532 --> 00:04:42.504
And then all of your servers
connect to that SAN.

91
00:04:42.504 --> 00:04:45.850
And your servers,
I'm talking about your physical servers.

92
00:04:45.850 --> 00:04:47.960
They may have their own hard drives, and

93
00:04:47.960 --> 00:04:49.225
they may not even have
a hard drive at all.

94
00:04:49.225 --> 00:04:52.290
100% of your hard drives
could reside in the SAN.

95
00:04:52.290 --> 00:04:56.580
And when your physical servers boot up,
they could be booting off of the SAN.

96
00:04:56.580 --> 00:04:57.775
But let's just assume for

97
00:04:57.775 --> 00:05:01.258
a moment that each of these physical
servers has mirrored hard drives in it.

98
00:05:01.258 --> 00:05:03.652
Right, so it's just a RAID 1.

99
00:05:03.652 --> 00:05:06.937
They've got mirrored storage and that's
where their operating system resides.

100
00:05:06.937 --> 00:05:12.836
And then maybe these are VMWare VSphere
servers, right, so they're running ESXi.

101
00:05:12.836 --> 00:05:16.986
Or maybe they are Microsoft Hyper-V
servers, or Citrix XenServers,

102
00:05:16.986 --> 00:05:22.820
they're Linux boxes running KVM, but
there's some kind of virtualization host.

103
00:05:22.820 --> 00:05:25.950
And on these,
they're running virtual machines.

104
00:05:25.950 --> 00:05:28.882
So I might have five virtual web
servers running on Server 1, and

105
00:05:28.882 --> 00:05:31.406
another five virtual web
servers running on Server 2.

106
00:05:31.406 --> 00:05:34.650
And I might have some virtual
database servers running on Server 3.

107
00:05:34.650 --> 00:05:40.250
Well those virtual machines that are up
and running, they need storage too.

108
00:05:40.250 --> 00:05:43.372
And the storage is getting
placed down on the SAN.

109
00:05:43.372 --> 00:05:46.774
Not on these local drives but on the SAN.

110
00:05:46.774 --> 00:05:50.485
And the reason we do that is if
this physical server were to die,

111
00:05:50.485 --> 00:05:55.260
if Server 3 were to fail, just outright
it dies, it's off the network, okay.

112
00:05:55.260 --> 00:05:56.951
Well when that happens,

113
00:05:56.951 --> 00:06:02.110
I can bring the virtual machine up over
here on Server 2 or over on Server 1.

114
00:06:02.110 --> 00:06:05.673
And I don't have to worry about
moving storage because Server 2 and

115
00:06:05.673 --> 00:06:09.310
Server 1 both have access to the SAN,
and they can see that storage.

116
00:06:09.310 --> 00:06:12.180
And they can immediately boot it back up,
and off we go.

117
00:06:12.180 --> 00:06:14.400
So you have shared storage.

118
00:06:14.400 --> 00:06:17.310
Not storage exclusive to a single,
physical server, but

119
00:06:17.310 --> 00:06:20.420
storage shared across
multiple physical servers.

120
00:06:20.420 --> 00:06:24.077
And so when you bring up your private
cloud with Hyper-V or VMware,

121
00:06:24.077 --> 00:06:28.183
when you go into Amazon Web Services or
Microsoft Azure, when you go to those

122
00:06:28.183 --> 00:06:32.692
cloud services what you're effectively
doing is adopting this model right here.

123
00:06:32.692 --> 00:06:34.190
You see virtual machines.

124
00:06:34.190 --> 00:06:35.600
That's who you deal with.

125
00:06:35.600 --> 00:06:37.340
But on the backend, on the hardware end,

126
00:06:37.340 --> 00:06:41.060
there's a storage area network
with this net shared storage.

127
00:06:41.060 --> 00:06:45.750
Now that SAN becomes a critical
piece of the network, right?

128
00:06:45.750 --> 00:06:49.650
That if it goes offline, what happens
to all my virtual machines up here?

129
00:06:49.650 --> 00:06:52.310
They all go offline,
everything could die all at the same time.

130
00:06:52.310 --> 00:06:56.927
So these are usually heavily redundant,
very expensive and

131
00:06:56.927 --> 00:07:02.187
just very, very well built and
well designed or crafted solutions.

132
00:07:02.187 --> 00:07:03.338
Because they do need to be up.

133
00:07:03.338 --> 00:07:07.552
So they usually have redundant controllers
in them and redundant network cards,

134
00:07:07.552 --> 00:07:09.660
many, many extra hard drives.

135
00:07:09.660 --> 00:07:11.940
You may even have more than one SAN.

136
00:07:11.940 --> 00:07:17.090
If you start uploading your VMs into
Microsoft Azure, they guarantee

137
00:07:17.090 --> 00:07:21.960
three copies of your data on three
completely separate storage area networks.

138
00:07:21.960 --> 00:07:23.450
AWS, you can do the same thing.

139
00:07:23.450 --> 00:07:27.320
And you can set up geo-replication, where
your data is not just stored here on a SAN

140
00:07:27.320 --> 00:07:31.250
in the US, but maybe on a SAN in Europe or
Australia or somewhere like that.

141
00:07:31.250 --> 00:07:33.874
You can actually setup geo-replication
with this stuff and it's really,

142
00:07:33.874 --> 00:07:34.530
really powerful.

143
00:07:35.610 --> 00:07:39.350
But, the key thing to remember
is that the SAN is very busy.

144
00:07:39.350 --> 00:07:42.750
The more servers attached to it,
the more activities going on on the SAN.

145
00:07:42.750 --> 00:07:46.793
So they have to be highly tuned and
highly optimized to manage your data.

146
00:07:46.793 --> 00:07:51.475
And the way they do that is by handling
data a little differently than what

147
00:07:51.475 --> 00:07:52.566
we're used to.

148
00:07:52.566 --> 00:07:55.390
So let's say you have a drive
that's formatted FAT32.

149
00:07:55.390 --> 00:07:57.108
That's File Allocation Table.

150
00:07:57.108 --> 00:07:59.169
There's a table in
the center of that drive.

151
00:07:59.169 --> 00:08:01.749
And when I wanna find a file
I go to the table first and

it just looks like a folder.

00:29:36.650 --> 00:29:39.800
But if I have permissions,
I can limit based on user group.

612
00:29:39.800 --> 00:29:40.950
Or I can add a bucket policy.

613
00:29:40.950 --> 00:29:44.320
And if I add a bucket policy,
now I can restrict by

614
00:29:44.320 --> 00:29:48.090
all sorts of different things and let me
just go into the sample bucket policy,

615
00:29:48.090 --> 00:29:50.230
cuz Amazon has a couple of
really good samples for this.

616
00:29:50.230 --> 00:29:52.980
And I'll put these in the show
notes if you want them.

617
00:29:52.980 --> 00:29:56.980
But, let's find something
simple like here, an address.

618
00:29:56.980 --> 00:30:02.810
So here they're creating a policy
that basically says we want to allow

619
00:30:02.810 --> 00:30:08.560
certain things and
we want to allow it based on IP address.

620
00:30:08.560 --> 00:30:11.780
So when you look at this it's saying
here we're going to allow access to this

621
00:30:11.780 --> 00:30:16.820
example bucket, and it's examplebucket/*,
so everything inside of that bucket.

622
00:30:16.820 --> 00:30:21.340
And their gonna do that if your
source IP matches this address and

623
00:30:21.340 --> 00:30:23.780
their gonna block it,
if it matches this address.

624
00:30:23.780 --> 00:30:27.810
So being very very specific here
in saying we allow this addresses,

625
00:30:27.810 --> 00:30:29.710
we block this other one's.

626
00:30:29.710 --> 00:30:33.460
No username and password required, just
straight up here's how you can access it.

627
00:30:33.460 --> 00:30:36.890
And they show an example of doing an HTTP
refer also, like I might want people to be

628
00:30:36.890 --> 00:30:39.750
able to access the file only if
they're coming from my website.

629
00:30:39.750 --> 00:30:42.870
This is a great way to stop people from
embedding you content on their own website

630
00:30:42.870 --> 00:30:44.220
and using your bandwidth.

631
00:30:44.220 --> 00:30:45.480
So here they're saying, yes,

632
00:30:45.480 --> 00:30:51.210
you can get to any content in this bucket
as long as you're coming from example.com.

633
00:30:51.210 --> 00:30:53.000
Right?
Or whatever that URL is.

634
00:30:53.000 --> 00:30:58.400
So policies let you go much further than
just filtering on username and password.

635
00:30:58.400 --> 00:30:59.650
Right?
Or group membership.

636
00:30:59.650 --> 00:31:01.630
Now you can do IP address.

637
00:31:01.630 --> 00:31:02.560
You can do all sorts of things.

638
00:31:02.560 --> 00:31:05.060
You can filter based on what
web browser people are using.

639
00:31:05.060 --> 00:31:09.410
In the virtualization world we can filter
based on what virtual machine it is right?

640
00:31:09.410 --> 00:31:14.460
This one VM is allowed to access
this one hard drive, nobody else is,

641
00:31:14.460 --> 00:31:19.020
and that's really important because
remember if we have shared storage,

642
00:31:19.020 --> 00:31:22.180
in theory I can have more than one server

643
00:31:22.180 --> 00:31:26.260
try to access the same virtual hard drive
at the same time Daniel do you know what

644
00:31:26.260 --> 00:31:29.760
happens if two systems access
the same data at the same time?

645
00:31:29.760 --> 00:31:30.880
>> Never crossed the streams.

646
00:31:30.880 --> 00:31:32.352
Total platonic reversal.

647
00:31:32.352 --> 00:31:33.090
>> Exactly.
>> [LAUGH]

648
00:31:33.090 --> 00:31:34.950
>> Yeah, if two systems try and

649
00:31:34.950 --> 00:31:37.440
read from the same drive at the same time,
it's actually not that big of a deal.

650
00:31:37.440 --> 00:31:39.320
I mean it's slow, but it's not a big deal.

651
00:31:39.320 --> 00:31:43.220
But if they try and write at the same
time, it's instant data corruption.

652
00:31:43.220 --> 00:31:44.471
Your data gets corrupted.

653
00:31:44.471 --> 00:31:48.878
So we need some kind of check in place
that stops two systems from writing to

654
00:31:48.878 --> 00:31:52.874
the same data at the same time and
your shared storage will do that.

655
00:31:52.874 --> 00:31:56.474
And it may do it Through policies
that restrict who has access.

656
00:31:56.474 --> 00:31:59.912
Or it may do it through some other
kind of software control like Xsan or

657
00:31:59.912 --> 00:32:04.070
something where it's tracking all that and
who has access to what.

658
00:32:04.070 --> 00:32:06.900
Microsoft's Failover Clustering
does a really good job of it,

659
00:32:06.900 --> 00:32:09.040
restricting that access
to individual machines.

660
00:32:09.040 --> 00:32:12.460
And when you have a failure,
then another machine can take over and

661
00:32:12.460 --> 00:32:14.790
have that right access to
be able to access the disc.

662
00:32:14.790 --> 00:32:19.030
So that's all kind of a part of this
process, all part of cloud storage.

663
00:32:19.030 --> 00:32:20.830
And you guys start to see how this is so
important,

664
00:32:20.830 --> 00:32:24.160
because this is physical
infrastructure we're talking about.

665
00:32:24.160 --> 00:32:27.480
And if we have this set up wrong, and
we start laying a bunch of virtual

666
00:32:27.480 --> 00:32:31.110
infrastructure on top of it, you can't go
back and fix the physical infrastructure

667
00:32:31.110 --> 00:32:33.570
without breaking all of your
virtual infrastructure.

668
00:32:33.570 --> 00:32:36.090
So we need to understand these concepts,
how they work, and

669
00:32:36.090 --> 00:32:38.100
make sure we take that into
account from early on.

670
00:32:38.100 --> 00:32:40.280
>> Yeah,
obviously this is not child's play.

671
00:32:40.280 --> 00:32:43.960
You want to make sure that you have
this under control, under wraps,

672
00:32:43.960 --> 00:32:49.695
in your comprehension as it were,
before you start trying to go too

673
00:32:49.695 --> 00:32:53.480
in-depth with building an infrastructure
based on this type of technology.

674
00:32:53.480 --> 00:32:57.390
But as you can see, Don is showing
you that even though it's different

675
00:32:57.390 --> 00:33:00.240
from traditional models
it's not that difficult.

676
00:33:00.240 --> 00:33:03.140
You just have to start to understand
how it is they do things and

677
00:33:03.140 --> 00:33:04.700
how things are working that way.

678
00:33:04.700 --> 00:33:07.820
Don, that being said, is there anything
else that we need to cover when it comes

679
00:33:07.820 --> 00:33:09.530
to storage in the cloud?

680
00:33:09.530 --> 00:33:11.140
>> I got one last thing
that I forgot to mention,

681
00:33:11.140 --> 00:33:16.200
which is, I said how important this stuff
was and I mentioned how we might want to

682
00:33:16.200 --> 00:33:20.700
replicate our SANs, you know, to have
an extra copy of that data somewhere else.

683
00:33:20.700 --> 00:33:21.960
You definitely want to do that.

684
00:33:21.960 --> 00:33:26.490
And in your own system, if you've
got your own local private cloud,

685
00:33:26.490 --> 00:33:28.620
you buy another SAN,
you stick it somewhere else, and

686
00:33:28.620 --> 00:33:31.170
you set up replication software
to replicate that data.

687
00:33:31.170 --> 00:33:32.770
If you buy EMC SANs,

688
00:33:32.770 --> 00:33:36.780
they have their own replication built
right into them, HP has the same thing.

689
00:33:36.780 --> 00:33:38.760
It's an extra license you have to pay for.

690
00:33:38.760 --> 00:33:41.180
There's third party software
like RepliStore that'll do it.

691
00:33:41.180 --> 00:33:44.050
There's plenty of different ways to
replicate your data from one SAN

692
00:33:44.050 --> 00:33:45.220
to another.

693
00:33:45.220 --> 00:33:48.880
If you're using cloud storage,
like with Amazon Web Services or

694
00:33:48.880 --> 00:33:51.540
Microsoft Azure, they make it really easy.

695
00:33:51.540 --> 00:33:54.260
With Azure,
they're already replicating your data.

696
00:33:54.260 --> 00:33:56.560
With AWS, you just have to turn it on.

697
00:33:56.560 --> 00:33:57.770
Let me show you.

698
00:33:57.770 --> 00:34:02.250
So looking at that ITProTV demo bucket
that I was in a moment ago, when I'm in

699
00:34:02.250 --> 00:34:07.090
it's Properties, if I scroll down a little
bit you've got Cross-Region Replication.

700
00:34:07.090 --> 00:34:10.335
They're backing up your data already,
but I can come in here to

701
00:34:10.335 --> 00:34:14.960
Cross-Region Replication, I can turn on
versioning, and then that'll let me turn

702
00:34:14.960 --> 00:34:20.390
on Cross-Region Replication and
now I can choose to replicate this bucket.

703
00:34:20.390 --> 00:34:25.380
Right now it's in the East US, but I can
choose to replicate it somewhere else and

704
00:34:25.380 --> 00:34:28.590
I might wanna store a copy
of it in the West US.

705
00:34:28.590 --> 00:34:30.150
Maybe Oregon, that one's cheaper.

706
00:34:30.150 --> 00:34:34.051
And so I can throw it over there and
specify a bucket to replicate it to, so

707
00:34:34.051 --> 00:34:37.799
I can now have a second copy of
this data in another region.

708
00:34:37.799 --> 00:34:42.050
If something happens to the east US it
can be available in the west US and

709
00:34:42.050 --> 00:34:43.060
I've got that copy, and

710
00:34:43.060 --> 00:34:46.600
anytime I add new data it's automatically
being replicated and kept in sync.

711
00:34:46.600 --> 00:34:51.970
That's important because if your storage
goes offline, right, if you've got shared

712
00:34:51.970 --> 00:34:55.560
storage and the storage goes offline,
all your virtual machines go offline.

713
00:34:55.560 --> 00:34:58.510
So having that replica really, really key.

714
00:34:58.510 --> 00:34:59.520
>> Yeah, it'll save your bacon.

715
00:34:59.520 --> 00:35:01.810
You don't want to lose your data at all so

716
00:35:01.810 --> 00:35:05.190
turning on any type of replication
that you can get away with, do it,

717
00:35:05.190 --> 00:35:09.100
it's just insurance for your data,
and how much is your data worth?

718
00:35:09.100 --> 00:35:13.170
Well, if you're in business, it's worth
everything, so make sure you employ that.

719
00:35:13.170 --> 00:35:14.540
Don, you've done a great
job with us today.

720
00:35:14.540 --> 00:35:17.050
You've showed us some of the concepts and

721
00:35:17.050 --> 00:35:21.430
the terminologies and even some security
that can help us stay out of the weeds.

722
00:35:21.430 --> 00:35:24.160
We thank you so much for joining us today,
and we thank you guys for watching.

723
00:35:24.160 --> 00:35:26.469
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

724
00:35:26.469 --> 00:35:27.618
I'm your host Daniel Lowery.

725
00:35:27.618 --> 00:35:28.490
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

726
00:35:28.490 --> 00:35:30.579
>> And we'll see you next time.

727
00:35:30.579 --> 00:35:37.470
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore the typical virtualization infrastructure. They start off by discussing some of the benefits of virtualization such as elasticity, network isolation, and hardware consolidation. Then they explain the differences between the Type-II and Type-I hypervisors. Finally, they go over some virtual cloud components like virtual NICs, CPU, RAM, and storage.
episodes.title: Virtualization Infrastructure

episode we're continuing on with that

4

cloud plus from comp T content

Joining us back in the studio to

6

7

8

9

We see the virtual machines, but

it, and some of the differences between

the different software

In the next episode we're

22

Come on let's get in there and

23

24

We gotta understand the foundational
knowledge first before we jump in.

25
00:01:14.220 --> 00:01:16.090
So that's what we're gonna
take a look at right here.

26
00:01:16.090 --> 00:01:20.660
>> Yeah this is really the meat and
potatoes of the Cloud infrastructure.

27

That's what we we're talking about.

28

What do we need to build this to make
it all work, and make it all happen.

29
00:01:25.940 --> 00:01:27.440
Whether it be private,
whether it be pubic.

30
00:01:27.440 --> 00:01:29.920
Or there be a hybrid, or
whatever you have going on.

31
00:01:29.920 --> 00:01:32.740
You gotta understand how
does that even fit together

32
00:01:32.740 --> 00:01:36.520
before you can actually start putting
the blocks on top of each other.

33
00:01:36.520 --> 00:01:38.180
So that's where we're gonna go.

34

And Don, I've been a part of building
a public cloud infrastructure,

35
00:01:41.510 --> 00:01:42.290
I've done that.

36

So I'm really looking
forward to the private cloud.

37

The other way around.

38

I'm sorry.

39

Either way.

40

>> I'll go crowd the cloud.

41

No public cloud.

42
00:01:49.830 --> 00:01:53.630
So, I look forward to seeing how that
works out, and where's a good place for

43
00:01:53.630 --> 00:01:54.690
us to begin with this.

44
00:01:54.690 --> 00:01:56.920
What is the foundations
that we need to know?

45
00:01:56.920 --> 00:01:58.830
>> All right.
Well, let's start with just the benefits

46
00:01:58.830 --> 00:02:00.830
of why we would even bother
with this in the first place?

47
00:02:00.830 --> 00:02:02.200
Because some people might be asking that.

48
00:02:02.200 --> 00:02:05.870
Like hey I have 20 servers, and
each servers dedicated to one task.

49
00:02:05.870 --> 00:02:07.310
They're physical servers,
they do their job.

50
00:02:07.310 --> 00:02:10.210
Why would I even bother
going into virtualization?

51
00:02:10.210 --> 00:02:11.510
And there's a lot of reasons.

52
00:02:11.510 --> 00:02:12.530
So let's talk about that.

53
00:02:12.530 --> 00:02:15.260
The first benefit is shared resources.

54
00:02:15.260 --> 00:02:17.640
And this is a problem I've
bumped into many, many times.

55
00:02:17.640 --> 00:02:20.470
So let's see, I've got a diagram
I kinda whipped up here.

56
00:02:20.470 --> 00:02:24.710
Let's say that I've got three servers,
and one's a DNS server.

57
00:02:24.710 --> 00:02:28.880
One's a Active Directory domain
controller and the other's a file server.

58
00:02:28.880 --> 00:02:32.130
And they each have a terabyte of storage.

59
00:02:32.130 --> 00:02:33.640
Well, a DNS server.

60
00:02:33.640 --> 00:02:35.770
Is it gonna use a terabyte of storage?

61
00:02:35.770 --> 00:02:37.820
No, it's just gonna use
a fraction of that.

62
00:02:37.820 --> 00:02:39.650
An Active Directory domain controller?

63
00:02:39.650 --> 00:02:43.750
Even in the biggest domains, it's rare for
a directory to break one gig in size,

64
00:02:43.750 --> 00:02:44.690
better yet a terabyte.

65
00:02:44.690 --> 00:02:46.120
So that's not gonna use it.

66
00:02:46.120 --> 00:02:47.560
But a file server?

67
00:02:47.560 --> 00:02:49.560
It'll eat that terabyte up real fast.

68
00:02:49.560 --> 00:02:52.290
And what do you do when you run
out of that terabyte of storage?

69
00:02:52.290 --> 00:02:55.250
Well, I've got extra storage here and
I've got extra storage here.

70
00:02:55.250 --> 00:02:57.260
I can just borrow some of that, right?

71
00:02:57.260 --> 00:02:58.170
Not really.

72
00:02:58.170 --> 00:03:01.860
What you end up with is file shares here,
file shares here, file shares here.

73
00:03:01.860 --> 00:03:06.050
Data is all over the place, and you're
trying to back it up and restore it and

74
00:03:06.050 --> 00:03:07.360
it just becomes a mess.

75
00:03:07.360 --> 00:03:10.310
You can't share those resources.

76
00:03:10.310 --> 00:03:11.210
Let's talk about CPU.

77
00:03:11.210 --> 00:03:11.840
Right?

78
00:03:11.840 --> 00:03:14.920
CPU on a domain controller
can get really busy, but

79
00:03:14.920 --> 00:03:17.650
CPU on a file server, CPU on DNS.

80
00:03:17.650 --> 00:03:18.520
No really.

81
00:03:18.520 --> 00:03:21.530
Can I borrow CPUs cycles from one
of these guys to use on server two?

82
00:03:21.530 --> 00:03:23.010
No.

83
00:03:23.010 --> 00:03:24.730
If server two starts getting to slow,

84
00:03:24.730 --> 00:03:28.130
if it states running out of CPU cycles,
I need to scale up.

85
00:03:28.130 --> 00:03:31.320
I need to upgrade that hardware,
I need to add CPUs if I can, or

86
00:03:31.320 --> 00:03:33.250
replace it with a beefier server.

87
00:03:33.250 --> 00:03:37.350
That's tough because I've got wasted
resources in these other systems.

88
00:03:37.350 --> 00:03:41.210
And even if I wasn't wasting resources,
servers have peaks and

89
00:03:41.210 --> 00:03:42.500
valleys of activity.

90
00:03:42.500 --> 00:03:46.600
There'll be times where yes,
this server is at 80% CPU constantly.

91
00:03:46.600 --> 00:03:49.050
But then there'll be times
where it's at 20% CPU.

92
00:03:49.050 --> 00:03:52.350
And I can't share the extra
resources between systems.

93
00:03:52.350 --> 00:03:57.040
So sharing, that's one of the biggest
benefits of going to a cloud, private or

94
00:03:57.040 --> 00:03:58.890
public, is that you have shared resources.

95
00:03:58.890 --> 00:04:02.550
And I know in other episodes I've
talked about shared storage.

96
00:04:02.550 --> 00:04:06.100
Where instead of having one
terabyte dedicated to each server,

97
00:04:06.100 --> 00:04:10.800
I could have three terabytes in the SAN
and I could slice off some data.

98
00:04:10.800 --> 00:04:12.910
Slice off one terabyte and
give it to server three.

99
00:04:12.910 --> 00:04:15.760
And just slice off a 100 megs for
server one.

100
00:04:15.760 --> 00:04:16.950
A 100 gigs.

101
00:04:16.950 --> 00:04:18.130
A 100 gigs for server one.

102
00:04:18.130 --> 00:04:19.320
A 100 gigs for server two.

103
00:04:19.320 --> 00:04:21.990
And if they need more, I can always
slice off more and give it to them.

104
00:04:21.990 --> 00:04:24.530
But now it's a shared resource.

105
00:04:24.530 --> 00:04:27.560
That's one of the biggest advantages
going one of these clouds.

106
00:04:27.560 --> 00:04:29.990
And how that data is shared
is kind of important,

107
00:04:29.990 --> 00:04:31.570
cuz different platforms
handle it different ways.

108
00:04:31.570 --> 00:04:33.880
We're gonna see that
later in this episode.

109
00:04:33.880 --> 00:04:35.900
Another benefit is elasticity, right?

110
00:04:35.900 --> 00:04:39.370
Elasticity is the ability to grow and
contract as needed, and

111
00:04:39.370 --> 00:04:41.510
we talked about that
in an earlier episode.

112
00:04:41.510 --> 00:04:43.710
I might not always need three servers.

113
00:04:43.710 --> 00:04:47.310
Maybe I need three web servers
when I'm at peak activity, but

114
00:04:47.310 --> 00:04:48.750
normally I just need one.

115
00:04:48.750 --> 00:04:52.930
And so when I go to a cloud I can scale
up to three servers when I need it and

116
00:04:52.930 --> 00:04:54.850
scale down to one server when I don't.

117
00:04:54.850 --> 00:04:56.120
And I have that flexibility.

118
00:04:56.120 --> 00:04:59.920
And it's returning the resources into
a pool so they can be reused elsewhere.

119
00:04:59.920 --> 00:05:01.680
Right, and again, benefits of sharing.

120
00:05:03.080 --> 00:05:04.070
Other things.

121
00:05:04.070 --> 00:05:06.200
I can start to isolate applications.

122
00:05:06.200 --> 00:05:08.750
When we run on physical
servers it's really common for

123
00:05:08.750 --> 00:05:11.610
people to say you know what
I'm gonna make server two

124
00:05:11.610 --> 00:05:15.730
an active directory domain controller,
and a DNS server, and DHCP.

125
00:05:15.730 --> 00:05:18.490
I'm gonna load it all in there cuz
the hardware can handle it just fine.

126
00:05:18.490 --> 00:05:19.070
And you're right.

127
00:05:19.070 --> 00:05:20.420
The hardware can handle it just fine.

128
00:05:20.420 --> 00:05:21.540
You're doing the right thing.

129
00:05:21.540 --> 00:05:23.190
You're making the most
use of that hardware.

130
00:05:24.210 --> 00:05:28.059
But what happens if my DHCP server
crashes and I need to reboot it?

131
00:05:29.210 --> 00:05:31.970
Well, that means I gotta reboot
my active directory and my DNS,

132
00:05:31.970 --> 00:05:33.920
also, cuz they're all
on the same hardware.

133
00:05:33.920 --> 00:05:38.710
They're all sharing that operating system,
so one application can affect another.

134
00:05:38.710 --> 00:05:41.600
But when I go virtual, I can divide
these up into separate servers.

135
00:05:41.600 --> 00:05:44.760
I can have a dedicated DNS server and
a dedicated DHTTP server and

136
00:05:44.760 --> 00:05:46.160
a dedicated domain controller.

137
00:05:46.160 --> 00:05:48.750
And if I need to reboot one of
them it doesn't effect the others.

138
00:05:48.750 --> 00:05:51.560
And I can do that cuz in a virtual
environment we're sharing

139
00:05:51.560 --> 00:05:54.850
the hardware anyway and so
they have access to what they need.

140
00:05:54.850 --> 00:05:57.760
But in a physical environment
I don't get sharing.

141
00:05:57.760 --> 00:06:02.690
And so it makes sense to have multiple
roles on one server which makes it more

142
00:06:02.690 --> 00:06:05.960
difficult to troubleshoot and
more sensitive when a failure does happen.

143
00:06:05.960 --> 00:06:07.960
So, it's kind of a weaker model that way.

144
00:06:09.780 --> 00:06:12.210
Other benefits,
consolidating infrastructure.

00:06:12.210 --> 00:06:13.060

00:06:13.060 --> 00:06:15.030

00:06:15.030 --> 00:06:19.350

148
00:06:19.350 --> 00:06:25.200
One of the things I had to work on was

00:06:25.200 --> 00:06:27.750

00:06:27.750 --> 00:06:30.140

00:06:32.080 --> 00:06:34.900

00:06:34.900 --> 00:06:37.640
We were at the maximum weight for

00:06:37.640 --> 00:06:40.590
if we had brought any more servers in,

155
00:06:40.590 --> 00:06:43.750

156
00:06:43.750 --> 00:06:45.335

00:06:45.335 --> 00:06:45.951

00:06:45.951 --> 00:06:48.950
cuz every time we brought in a new server,

00:06:48.950 --> 00:06:52.490
But you had to, this kind of equal,

160
00:06:52.490 --> 00:06:53.910
It was kind of a pain.

161
00:06:53.910 --> 00:06:55.850
So, it was all physical servers.

162
00:06:55.850 --> 00:06:58.960
There were 275 servers,

00:06:58.960 --> 00:07:01.020

00:07:01.020 --> 00:07:04.180
Let's To create a private cloud,

00:07:04.180 --> 00:07:06.900
I don't need three dedicated DNS servers.

00:07:09.870 --> 00:07:13.570
And I don't need this many domain

00:07:13.570 --> 00:07:18.690
And as we started virtualizing

169
00:07:18.690 --> 00:07:24.810
to have 275 physical servers, now we

00:07:24.810 --> 00:07:27.420
Some things had to stay physical right,

00:07:28.500 --> 00:07:32.350
We had just virtualization

00:07:32.350 --> 00:07:36.971

00:07:36.971 --> 00:07:40.270

00:07:40.270 --> 00:07:43.710

We were well below the weight

00:07:46.530 --> 00:07:48.910
We can add new systems and

00:07:48.910 --> 00:07:50.420

00:07:50.420 --> 00:07:55.756

00:07:55.756 --> 00:07:58.837

00:08:02.963 --> 00:08:07.004
Well one day I came in to make a check and

00:08:07.004 --> 00:08:10.109
One unit was at 50% and the other one

00:08:10.109 --> 00:08:12.935
start the maintenance plan like okay

00:08:12.935 --> 00:08:16.810
the other one didn't ramp up to 100%,

185
00:08:16.810 --> 00:08:19.200
Because an air conditioning

Well it turned out we had removed enough

00:08:34.880 --> 00:08:36.860
Cuz you still want the other one running,

00:08:36.860 --> 00:08:38.460
you don't want an AC unit just

00:08:38.460 --> 00:08:40.210
So we ended up having to get that tuned.

00:08:40.210 --> 00:08:43.340
But it was neat cuz we didn't expect that,

195
00:08:43.340 --> 00:08:44.370
Those are benefits.

196
00:08:44.370 --> 00:08:47.120
Some of the reasons why we want
to start virtualizing things.

197
00:08:47.120 --> 00:08:48.731
>> And you lowered your carbon footprint.

[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

00:08:50.700 --> 00:08:52.690
>> Doesn't matter if you're
a Republican or Democrat or

00:08:52.690 --> 00:08:53.230
whatever-
>> That's right.

00:08:53.230 --> 00:08:54.480
>> Everyone likes saving some money and

203
00:08:54.480 --> 00:08:55.038
then-
>> That's right.

[LAUGH]
>> that's what that does.

00:08:56.100 --> 00:08:59.580
So those are some of the reasons why

206
00:08:59.580 --> 00:09:02.528
Now if you choose to virtualize them,
if you choose to go this way and

207
00:09:02.528 --> 00:09:04.150
create a private cloud.

208
00:09:04.150 --> 00:09:09.350
The first thing we've got to
do is select a hypervisor.

209
00:09:09.350 --> 00:09:11.430
All right, now what is a hypervisor?

210
00:09:11.430 --> 00:09:14.850
A hypervisor is the software that
runs on your physical server

211
00:09:14.850 --> 00:09:17.530
that allows it to host virtual machines.

212
00:09:17.530 --> 00:09:20.410
If I wanna take a physical server and
make it a virtual server,

213
00:09:20.410 --> 00:09:22.200
it's gotta run on top of a hypervisor.

214
00:09:22.200 --> 00:09:25.068
And there are many,
many different ones that are out there.

215
00:09:25.068 --> 00:09:26.615
All right.

216
00:09:26.615 --> 00:09:30.970
Well, when you've got a physical server,
this is kind of what it looks like.

217
00:09:30.970 --> 00:09:33.140
And I know I've used this
diagram in other episodes.

218
00:09:33.140 --> 00:09:34.430
It's not anything new.

219
00:09:34.430 --> 00:09:36.440
But you've got your
physical infrastructure.

220
00:09:36.440 --> 00:09:37.240
Right.
That which is

221
00:09:37.240 --> 00:09:38.550
your networking and all that.

222
00:09:38.550 --> 00:09:40.210
And you're gonna have that in
a virtual environment too.

223
00:09:40.210 --> 00:09:42.040
You've always got your
physical infrastructure.

224
00:09:42.040 --> 00:09:45.230
Like UPSs, generators,
you can't virtualize a UPS.

225
00:09:45.230 --> 00:09:47.520
You just have to have one.

226
00:09:47.520 --> 00:09:50.810
But your server hardware that is
something you can virtualize, right?

227
00:09:50.810 --> 00:09:54.120
And your server hardware is then
hosting an operating system and

228
00:09:54.120 --> 00:09:56.840
your operating system then
hosts your application.

229
00:09:56.840 --> 00:10:01.990
And if we're doing this on dedicated
hardware, well all of this represents

230
00:10:01.990 --> 00:10:06.140
one physical server and then they have
other ones that are in place, right?

231
00:10:06.140 --> 00:10:10.020
Well when I virtualize I take
the operating system, and

232
00:10:10.020 --> 00:10:14.000
I take the application software, and I put
that inside of a virtual machine that's

233
00:10:14.000 --> 00:10:19.620
then running on hardware that's no longer
dedicated to just that operating system.

234
00:10:19.620 --> 00:10:22.470
It can be applied to more
than one operating system.

235
00:10:23.580 --> 00:10:26.900
And so
when we do that we choose a hypervisor and

236
00:10:26.900 --> 00:10:29.400
the hypervisors are grouped
into two classes.

237
00:10:29.400 --> 00:10:33.000
You have type one hypervisors and
type two hypervisors.

238
00:10:33.000 --> 00:10:35.180
Type two hypervisors
are actually the original ones.

239
00:10:35.180 --> 00:10:36.480
It's kind of backwards.

240
00:10:36.480 --> 00:10:40.230
But the type two hypervisors are the ones
that really started virtualization.

241
00:10:40.230 --> 00:10:43.050
And they're not very good, but
they serve a particular purpose.

242
00:10:43.050 --> 00:10:44.950
Type one hypervisors are the good ones.

243
00:10:44.950 --> 00:10:46.370
Those are the ones you wanna use.

244
00:10:46.370 --> 00:10:49.440
They're the newer ones, and
by newer I mean in the last 10 years.

245
00:10:49.440 --> 00:10:52.510
But they're the ones you wanna use and
they correct a lot of things.

246
00:10:52.510 --> 00:10:55.140
But I'm gonna start with
type two hypervisors

247
00:10:55.140 --> 00:10:57.800
because these were the original ones,
all right?

248
00:10:57.800 --> 00:11:02.510
What a type two hypervisor was was
really just a software program.

249
00:11:02.510 --> 00:11:03.990
You had your server hardware.

250
00:11:03.990 --> 00:11:07.565
And your server hardware you had CPU,
RAM, Network, Disk, right?

251
00:11:07.565 --> 00:11:09.930
Those were the components you had
when you bought a physical server,

252
00:11:09.930 --> 00:11:11.002
that's what you were buying.

253
00:11:11.002 --> 00:11:14.885
So maybe I had 32 gigs of RAM,
and four CPUs, and

254
00:11:14.885 --> 00:11:19.895
two gigabit network adapters,
and a few terabytes of storage.

255
00:11:19.895 --> 00:11:22.830
Right, that's all in my server hardware.

256
00:11:22.830 --> 00:11:25.410
And on my physical server,
I've gotta run an operating system.

257
00:11:25.410 --> 00:11:29.760
So I run Windows server or
Linux, some application,

258
00:11:29.760 --> 00:11:33.580
or not an application, but operating
system like that on the hardware.

259
00:11:34.780 --> 00:11:40.388
And on top of that operating system,
I then run my hypervisor, right?

260
00:11:40.388 --> 00:11:44.480
But Type two hypervisor is software we
install on top of our operating system.

261
00:11:44.480 --> 00:11:47.070
And it normally comes with management
software to be able to manage it, right,

262
00:11:47.070 --> 00:11:47.840
that's kind of a part.

263
00:11:47.840 --> 00:11:49.860
I put these as one on top of the other,
but

264
00:11:49.860 --> 00:11:51.230
really, they're basically side by side.

265
00:11:51.230 --> 00:11:52.110
You run the hypervisor and

266
00:11:52.110 --> 00:11:55.810
you run the management software
typically on top of the host OS.

267
00:11:57.040 --> 00:12:00.120
Now what that hypervisor does here,

268
00:12:00.120 --> 00:12:05.560
is it then begins to create fake
hardware for virtual machines, right?

269
00:12:05.560 --> 00:12:07.070
Technically it's an emulator.

270
00:12:07.070 --> 00:12:10.980
It's emulating that certain
hardware exists, and so

271
00:12:10.980 --> 00:12:15.370
if I wanna create a virtual machine, the
operating system running on the hardware

272
00:12:15.370 --> 00:12:19.180
is called the host, it's the one
that's hosting this hypervisor.

273
00:12:19.180 --> 00:12:22.570
But every other virtual machine I
stick on there is called a guest,

274
00:12:22.570 --> 00:12:24.290
a guest operating system,
it's like a visitor.

275
00:12:24.290 --> 00:12:26.360
Hey, I'm just gonna come by and
hang out on your hardware.

276
00:12:26.360 --> 00:12:29.290
All right, I like to think of
virtualization as carpooling.

277
00:12:29.290 --> 00:12:31.800
In your car, you've got four,
five seats, right?

278
00:12:31.800 --> 00:12:33.880
So in my car, we've got five seats.

279
00:12:33.880 --> 00:12:36.090
And when I drove to work today,
I drove by myself.

280
00:12:36.090 --> 00:12:38.020
I was the only person in that car.

281
00:12:38.020 --> 00:12:39.380
So I had four more seats that were empty.

282
00:12:39.380 --> 00:12:42.080
I didn't get full utilization
of my resources, right?

283
00:12:42.080 --> 00:12:43.940
But I can have some guests come over.

284
00:12:43.940 --> 00:12:46.570
I can have some other
people hop in the car.

285
00:12:46.570 --> 00:12:48.580
And now I take full advantage of it.

286
00:12:48.580 --> 00:12:50.780
Assuming we're all going
to the same place, right.

287
00:12:50.780 --> 00:12:54.390
Well on a server, it's the same way we
have a lot of wasted resources, and

288
00:12:54.390 --> 00:12:57.092
these guests, they're the people
who are tagging along with you.

289
00:12:57.092 --> 00:13:00.100
They're the people who are carpooling
with you on this server.

290
00:13:00.100 --> 00:13:02.760
But the guest operating system
may not match the host.

291
00:13:02.760 --> 00:13:04.200
My host might be Linux.

292
00:13:04.200 --> 00:13:11.580
I might be running Red Hat Linux and I'm
running a VMware desktop on Red Hat Linux.

293
00:13:11.580 --> 00:13:14.820
Well, if I'm doing that,
I can then start to create guest OSs.

294
00:13:14.820 --> 00:13:18.680
And I might have a guest virtual machine
that's Windows, or one that's Linux.

295
00:13:18.680 --> 00:13:22.040
Maybe it's Red Hat Linux, maybe it's
Ubuntu or Cent OS or something else.

296
00:13:22.040 --> 00:13:23.220
It doesn't matter.

297
00:13:23.220 --> 00:13:26.760
Because when that
operating system boots up,

298
00:13:26.760 --> 00:13:32.730
it's gonna see a virtual CPU, virtual
memory, virtual Network, virtual Disk.

299
00:13:32.730 --> 00:13:36.210
It sees a fake set up hardware all right?

300
00:13:36.210 --> 00:13:37.690
Now why is that important?

301
00:13:37.690 --> 00:13:40.500
Well it's important because
of what happens when we go to

302
00:13:40.500 --> 00:13:42.120
access that hardware.

303
00:13:42.120 --> 00:13:44.040
When you go to access the hardware,

304
00:13:44.040 --> 00:13:48.500
you're installing your applications on
top of that guest operating system.

305
00:13:48.500 --> 00:13:52.030
And, that completely failed to work.

306
00:13:52.030 --> 00:13:55.940
So you're installing that application and
when that application needs to access

307
00:13:55.940 --> 00:13:58.130
something, like maybe it
needs to access the disk.

308
00:13:58.130 --> 00:14:00.550
So it's gotta read from the hard drive.

309
00:14:00.550 --> 00:14:04.130
And when it goes to read from that
hard drive, what's gonna happen there?

310
00:14:04.130 --> 00:14:05.570
Well, it's gonna go.

311
00:14:05.570 --> 00:14:07.880
We'll make this nice and
purple so we can see it.

312
00:14:07.880 --> 00:14:11.920
So it's gonna go and reach out to
that disk, but it's a fake disk.

313
00:14:11.920 --> 00:14:13.590
It's not a real disk.

314
00:14:13.590 --> 00:14:17.020
And so your hypervisor's going
to intercept that call and

315
00:14:17.020 --> 00:14:19.020
say, I see you writing to the disk.

316
00:14:19.020 --> 00:14:21.490
And it's gonna translate that.

317
00:14:21.490 --> 00:14:25.670
And it's gonna turn it into a real call,

318
00:14:25.670 --> 00:14:29.030
where the hypervisor is
going to turn around and

319
00:14:29.030 --> 00:14:35.320
send that to the real physical disk,
like that.

320
00:14:35.320 --> 00:14:38.250
So every call that this
application is doing,

321
00:14:38.250 --> 00:14:41.250
every time it reaches out to hardware
a translation has to happen,

322
00:14:41.250 --> 00:14:43.610
to translate that into
a call to the real hardware.

323
00:14:43.610 --> 00:14:46.410
When it accesses CPU, RAM, Network, Disk,

324
00:14:46.410 --> 00:14:51.000
the big four for performance,
that's all being virtualized, and fake.

325
00:14:52.690 --> 00:14:55.210
And that's where we get a performance hit.

326
00:14:55.210 --> 00:14:59.190
Every call to hardware that would
normally be instantaneously responded to

327
00:14:59.190 --> 00:15:00.440
now has a translation.

328
00:15:00.440 --> 00:15:02.740
And the translation is being
performed in software.

329
00:15:02.740 --> 00:15:06.850
So these become software calls that
get translated to hardware and

330
00:15:06.850 --> 00:15:08.410
it slows them down.

331
00:15:08.410 --> 00:15:11.445
And that was one of the main negatives
of a Type 2 Hypervisor is that

332
00:15:11.445 --> 00:15:15.340
performance-wise, it's not the same
as running on real hardware.

333
00:15:15.340 --> 00:15:16.400
And so in the early days,

334
00:15:16.400 --> 00:15:20.000
like in the early 1990s,
when VMware was just starting, and

335
00:15:20.000 --> 00:15:24.270
they were promoting their VMware software,
it was a Type 2 Hypervisor.

336
00:15:24.270 --> 00:15:27.960
And there were other ones that were
out there, like what was Microsoft's?

337
00:15:27.960 --> 00:15:29.940
Virtual-
>> Virtual PC, wasn't it?

338
00:15:29.940 --> 00:15:32.590
>> Virtual PC, which they bought
from Connectix, or whoever.

339
00:15:32.590 --> 00:15:36.760
So you had Virtual PC,
you had VMWare Desktop,

340
00:15:36.760 --> 00:15:41.950
VMWare Fusion these days, Sun's VirtualBox
which is now Oracle VirtualBox.

566
00:26:58.520 --> 00:26:59.740
well that's an actual server there.

567

But you'll find where different products
have different management software that

568

you can use and it's all just baked
down to what their preference is.

569
00:27:08.950 --> 00:27:10.690
But let's take one of
these virtual machines.

570
00:27:10.690 --> 00:27:12.760
I'll take this CentoS box
that I've got right here.

571
00:27:12.760 --> 00:27:16.490
So I've got a CentoS Linux machine,
and if I go into it's settings,

572
00:27:16.490 --> 00:27:19.740
I can start to customize it's hardware and
if I go under processors and

573
00:27:19.740 --> 00:27:22.720
memory, see how I can
adjust the processor cores.

00:27:22.720 --> 00:27:25.420
Right?
My system has four cores.

575
00:27:25.420 --> 00:27:27.900
So I can go up to four cores

576

578
00:27:31.960 --> 00:27:33.390

579
00:27:33.390 --> 00:27:35.770
I can set how much memory
I want it to have.

580
00:27:35.770 --> 00:27:37.530
You can tweak some really
interesting things.

581
00:27:37.530 --> 00:27:41.890
On the display side I can set
the memory for the video card, and

582
