whether I wanna support 3D acceleration.

583
00:27:44.230 --> 00:27:46.070
So, you could dictate those things.

584
00:27:46.070 --> 00:27:50.790
But if I go to add device, and oops,
and I want to add a hard drive,

585
00:27:50.790 --> 00:27:53.190
so I'm gonna add a new hard disk.

586
00:27:53.190 --> 00:27:56.790
When I go to add it, it's gonna ask some
basic questions here like what do I wanna

587
00:27:56.790 --> 00:27:59.990
name the file, because the hard drive
is actually been stored as a file and

588
00:27:59.990 --> 00:28:01.440
what size I wanted it to be.

589
00:28:01.440 --> 00:28:03.510
But if I go under Advanced,

590
00:28:03.510 --> 00:28:06.510
you can pick other things like what
bus type do I want it to have.

591
00:28:06.510 --> 00:28:09.440
Do I want it to be SCSI, IDE, SATA?

592
00:28:09.440 --> 00:28:10.660
What do I want the machine to see it?

593
00:28:10.660 --> 00:28:15.810
And it's picking SCSI because VMware
Fusion has some SCSI optimizations in it.

594
00:28:15.810 --> 00:28:19.750
You're software may not, your software
may prefer SATA and may prefer IDE.

595
00:28:19.750 --> 00:28:21.650
Doesn't matter that IDE's old.

596
00:28:21.650 --> 00:28:22.870
It's virtual software anyway.

597
00:28:22.870 --> 00:28:24.260
You might get faster
performance out of it.

598
00:28:24.260 --> 00:28:26.660
So you pick whichever one is appropriate.

599
00:28:26.660 --> 00:28:30.640
These are key components cuz this
is part of a virtual system.

600
00:28:30.640 --> 00:28:32.750
On the network side,
you'll have the same thing.

601
00:28:32.750 --> 00:28:37.290
Right?
If I go back to Add Device, and

602
00:28:37.290 --> 00:28:39.190
choose to add a network adapter.

603
00:28:39.190 --> 00:28:42.460
There's all sorts of settings that
pertain to a network adapter when we

00:28:42.460 --> 00:28:43.720
add it to a system.

605
00:28:43.720 --> 00:28:47.040
And so here it's asking me

00:28:47.040 --> 00:28:49.600
Do I wanna connect it to one of
my physical network adapters, or

00:28:49.600 --> 00:28:54.900
do I wanna make this one as part of

00:28:54.900 --> 00:28:58.350
I've got Advanced Options where I can

00:28:58.350 --> 00:29:02.000

you may see where you can define VLANs.

00:29:05.400 --> 00:29:07.200
You might have VLANs in
place on your network and

612
00:29:07.200 --> 00:29:10.520
see you can save this Network Adapter
is connected to these other ones.

00:29:10.520 --> 00:29:15.380
So virtual NICs, virtual Network
Interface Cards, Virtual HBAs, right,

00:29:15.380 --> 00:29:18.120
that's a Virtual Host Bus Adapter.

615
00:29:18.120 --> 00:29:21.840
A virtual HBA we would use if we were
connecting to a SAN or an iSCSI system,

616
00:29:21.840 --> 00:29:24.040
those might be something we add in.

617
00:29:24.040 --> 00:29:26.080
Even things like a virtual router, right?

618
00:29:27.430 --> 00:29:29.390
Sorry, I'm gonna give everybody a seizure.

619
00:29:29.390 --> 00:29:32.120
So for example,
I mentioned networking, right?

620
00:29:32.120 --> 00:29:35.430
In VMware Fusion,
if we go into our preferences you'll see

621
00:29:36.520 --> 00:29:41.180
where you've got this network section
here and I can create virtual networks.

622
00:29:41.180 --> 00:29:44.150
And I can see where I created
several of them right here.

623
00:29:44.150 --> 00:29:46.330
And when I create these, see how it's got,

00:29:46.330 --> 00:29:50.330
allow virtual machines on this network to
connect to external networks using NAT,

625
00:29:50.330 --> 00:29:52.620
and connect this host to the Mac and
so on?

00:29:52.620 --> 00:29:56.650
What this is doing is creating a virtual
router, so that when systems pull in,

00:29:56.650 --> 00:29:59.670
they'll get an IP address
in this range right here.

00:29:59.670 --> 00:30:02.980
And then once they're
connected to that range,

00:30:02.980 --> 00:30:07.000
they can use VMware Fusion as a router
to be able to get out the Internet and

00:30:07.000 --> 00:30:10.980
access it all behind a NATed IP,
the IP of my laptop.

631
00:30:10.980 --> 00:30:14.440
So that kind of functionality is neat,
that you've got virtual network cards,

632
00:30:14.440 --> 00:30:18.860
virtual HPAs, virtual routers, all kind
of functionality provided by this.

633
00:30:18.860 --> 00:30:20.840
And here it's in a type 2 hypervisor.

634
00:30:20.840 --> 00:30:22.650
Type 1 hypervisors have this too,

635
00:30:22.650 --> 00:30:26.200
it's just the configuration screen is
really the same once you get in there,

636
00:30:26.200 --> 00:30:28.410
it's the underlying
infrastructure that's different.

637
00:30:28.410 --> 00:30:30.360
All right.
Some of the other things that I talked

638
00:30:30.360 --> 00:30:35.170
about, shared memory, I talked about
virtual CPUs, shared storage, and

639
00:30:35.170 --> 00:30:37.120
clustered storage, right?

640
00:30:37.120 --> 00:30:40.290
I don't have shared storage,
or clustered storage here, but

641
00:30:40.290 --> 00:30:44.420
when you go to add a virtual hard drive,
they just show up as physical hard drive.

642
00:30:44.420 --> 00:30:47.700
You place your file on that shared
storage and your in business.

643
00:30:47.700 --> 00:30:54.170
So, for example, if I were to go back
to adding hardware to this node,

644
00:30:54.170 --> 00:30:58.750
where I would go into the settings and
go up to add device.

645
00:30:58.750 --> 00:31:04.410
When I go to add that disk I would just
place the disk on that shared storage.

646
00:31:04.410 --> 00:31:08.076
The file name here is defaulting to one
location ,and I might want to move that to

647
00:31:08.076 --> 00:31:11.484
wherever my shared storage is,
it's already attached to this machine.

648
00:31:11.484 --> 00:31:13.803
And that's critical if we have
something like a cluster,

649
00:31:13.803 --> 00:31:15.460
that we needed that redundancy.

650
00:31:15.460 --> 00:31:19.530
When you go with Azure or Amazon AWS, they
take care of all this stuff for you so

651
00:31:19.530 --> 00:31:20.720
you don't have to worry about it.

652
00:31:20.720 --> 00:31:22.770
But, when you're managing it yourself
in a private cloud you've got to

653
00:31:22.770 --> 00:31:24.030
remember to specify this.

654
00:31:25.610 --> 00:31:31.130
One last thing that I want to mention, is
that when you deal with SANs, I mentioned

655
00:31:31.130 --> 00:31:37.812
how with a SAN you can have more than
one physical server accessing the SAN.

656
00:31:37.812 --> 00:31:42.100
All right, I might have a virtual machine
that's up and running on server one.

657
00:31:42.100 --> 00:31:45.420
And its virtual hard drive I store,
on the shared storage.

658
00:31:45.420 --> 00:31:48.265
Right?
And that way, if I ever need to,

659
00:31:48.265 --> 00:31:52.921
I can move that virtual machine
from Server 1 to Server 2.

660
00:31:52.921 --> 00:31:54.398
If I have a physical server failure or

661
00:31:54.398 --> 00:31:56.838
if I just need to take this
server down to do updates, right.

662
00:31:56.838 --> 00:32:00.260
So some new update comes out for
VMware ESX I wanna apply it.

663
00:32:00.260 --> 00:32:03.520
I could move the virtual machines
off somewhere else, right.

664
00:32:03.520 --> 00:32:06.030
But as long as I'm storing
that drive here there's risk

665
00:32:06.030 --> 00:32:09.350
that somebody else could access it and
damage it, right.

666
00:32:09.350 --> 00:32:12.480
So it's up to our software
to protect us from that.

667
00:32:12.480 --> 00:32:15.950
And if you're running Microsoft Hyper-V
in a failover cluster,

668
00:32:15.950 --> 00:32:17.200
it protects you from that.

669
00:32:17.200 --> 00:32:21.730
And if you're running VMware ESX in
a cluster, it protects you from that.

670
00:32:21.730 --> 00:32:24.940
It knows it.
If you've got Citrix XenServer in a pool,

671
00:32:24.940 --> 00:32:26.150
it protects you from that.

672
00:32:26.150 --> 00:32:29.070
It knows that this is shared storage and
it'll protect you.

673
00:32:29.070 --> 00:32:33.840
But not every system does and so
in some systems they don't rely on

674
00:32:33.840 --> 00:32:37.250
the operating system underneath,
they rely on other things to do it.

675
00:32:37.250 --> 00:32:41.010
And one that might turn up ion the exam
for the most part they're not gonna get to

676
00:32:41.010 --> 00:32:45.012
nitty gritty on this stuff but
there's something called a NPIV, right.

677
00:32:45.012 --> 00:32:49.802
And a NPIV,
it's a N_Port ID virtualization.

678
00:32:49.802 --> 00:32:51.338
And what happens is on a SAN,

679
00:32:51.338 --> 00:32:54.540
you can define something called
a world wide name, right.

680
00:32:54.540 --> 00:32:59.652
And a World Wide Name, a WWN, or
in this case it would actually be

681
00:32:59.652 --> 00:33:06.130
a world wide port name, WWPN,
you can define who is allowed to see what.

682
00:33:06.130 --> 00:33:10.370
So this port, the HBA for
Server 1 will have a port id, right.

683
00:33:10.370 --> 00:33:11.800
It's kinda like a MAC address.

684
00:33:11.800 --> 00:33:13.320
It's just an identifier.

685
00:33:13.320 --> 00:33:17.665
And on the SAN, it can identify that id,
that port id, and

686
00:33:17.665 --> 00:33:20.522
it can tie it to a world wide port name.

687
00:33:20.522 --> 00:33:23.941
Where usually you have
a SAN switch in between.

688
00:33:23.941 --> 00:33:25.760
Its the switch doing this,
but the SAN can do it also.

689
00:33:25.760 --> 00:33:29.170
And it says, hey, this identifier
is allowed to access these disks.

690
00:33:29.170 --> 00:33:32.910
And so it might give it access to
just this first virtual disk, right.

691
00:33:32.910 --> 00:33:36.520
Well that's cool, because if I ever unplug
this server and plug it into a different

692
00:33:36.520 --> 00:33:40.380
port, it still has the same ID, and it'll
still be able to access that virtual disk.

693
00:33:40.380 --> 00:33:42.190
And nobody else will be able to access it,

694
00:33:42.190 --> 00:33:43.810
because they don't have the same ID as me,
right.

695
00:33:43.810 --> 00:33:45.440
So it gives us that protection.

696
00:33:45.440 --> 00:33:51.070
But if this server fails Nobody
else can access that, right.

697
00:33:51.070 --> 00:33:57.830
So what NPIV does is it allows each
server to have more than one ID.

698
00:33:57.830 --> 00:34:01.990
And so I could give Server 1 the IDs for
all three servers.

699
00:34:01.990 --> 00:34:04.030
And Server 2 could have the IDs for
all three servers.

700
00:34:04.030 --> 00:34:05.930
And Server 3 could have the IDs for
all three servers.

701
00:34:05.930 --> 00:34:08.390
But they only go active for one.

702
00:34:08.390 --> 00:34:10.310
Server 1 might just go active for
Server 1.

703
00:34:10.310 --> 00:34:13.790
And Server 2 goes active for Server 2,
Server 3 goes active for Server 3.

704
00:34:13.790 --> 00:34:18.730
But if Server 3 fails, one of these
other guys could choose to go active for

705
00:34:18.730 --> 00:34:21.960
both themselves and Server 3.

706
00:34:21.960 --> 00:34:24.560
And that way, they're able to
access Server 3 storage and

707
00:34:24.560 --> 00:34:27.160
power up those VMs and
keep us online in a server failure.

708
00:34:27.160 --> 00:34:29.700
And they do that by virtualizing the ID.

709
00:34:29.700 --> 00:34:31.445
And that's NPIV.

710
00:34:31.445 --> 00:34:37.000
N_Port, that's N underscore Port,
N_Port ID virtualization.

711
00:34:37.000 --> 00:34:41.680
And with NPIV, we just need to
make sure we set those IDs.

712
00:34:41.680 --> 00:34:44.220
If you're running VMware, VMware ESX,

713
00:34:44.220 --> 00:34:45.880
if you're running Hyper-V,
they do this automatically.

714
00:34:45.880 --> 00:34:48.030
You don't even worry about it,
right, it's just done.

715
00:34:48.030 --> 00:34:51.140
But your software might require you to
configure that, and what you would have

716
00:34:51.140 --> 00:34:55.830
to do is, on each of these servers,
you would have to go and get their ID, and

717
00:34:55.830 --> 00:34:59.040
you'd find it in the settings for
whatever your virtualization platform was.

718
00:34:59.040 --> 00:35:02.810
And then, whenever you created a new
hypervisor, when you install that

719
00:35:02.810 --> 00:35:07.670
hypervisor on the system, You would
provide it its ID, or autogenerate it, and

720
00:35:07.670 --> 00:35:11.570
you'd add the ID's for the other hosts,
you'd need to punch those in, all right.

721
00:35:11.570 --> 00:35:13.650
Now on the exam, they don't want
you to know how to configure that,

722
00:35:13.650 --> 00:35:15.340
they just want you to be
aware of that concept.

723
00:35:15.340 --> 00:35:18.930
And these NPIV's are important for
filtering that access, all right.

724
00:35:18.930 --> 00:35:21.230
But you'll see that most products
actually do it automatically and

725
00:35:21.230 --> 00:35:22.280
we don't have to sweat it, right.

726
00:35:22.280 --> 00:35:25.780
And when you're dealing with a type 2
hypervisor, that's where you'd really see

727
00:35:25.780 --> 00:35:30.400
it, because they're not necessarily
aware of all the little ins and outs.

728
00:35:30.400 --> 00:35:33.090
And so
when you start to work with them you may

729
00:35:33.090 --> 00:35:34.570
have to provide some additional settings.

730
00:35:34.570 --> 00:35:40.750
So when you go in here and you start
setting up like here's VMware Fusion.

00:35:40.750 --> 00:35:44.520
If I go back into my preferences,
you may have some storage options in

whether NPIV is supported and

00:35:49.620 --> 00:35:51.380
And you'll see here, I don't have that.

735
00:35:51.380 --> 00:35:55.470
As I look under it, I just have
my regular systems and that's it.

736
00:35:55.470 --> 00:35:57.230
Your software may have NPIV.

737
00:35:57.230 --> 00:36:01.150
>> Awesome stuff, well obviously
we've learned a lot about well, a,

738
00:36:01.150 --> 00:36:04.390
the benefits of virtualization
of our infrastructure.

739

We've talked about the different
hypervisors and the difference between

00:36:07.030 --> 00:36:10.700

00:36:10.700 --> 00:36:13.680
Don, is there anything else that

>> Just remember,
type one hypervisor, good, fast,

type two hypervisor, mediocre, slow,

00:36:21.490 --> 00:36:24.970
There's a place for each of these, we just

00:36:24.970 --> 00:36:28.090
>> It's confusing, because you'd
think type one would be older,

746
00:36:28.090 --> 00:36:29.080
type two would be newer.

747

But type one is the newer,
it's the better.

748
00:36:31.280 --> 00:36:33.110
Type two is the older,
and it's the slower.

749
00:36:33.110 --> 00:36:33.920
>> Awesome stuff.

750
00:36:33.920 --> 00:36:35.910
Well Don, thank you so much for
explaining this to us.

00:36:35.910 --> 00:36:37.780

It will come to you, we promise.

757
00:36:49.130 --> 00:36:50.660
Again, Don, thank you for joining us.

We thank our audience for watching.

759
00:36:52.200 --> 00:36:54.300
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

memory, sometimes you'll see options,

476
00:22:19.360 --> 00:22:23.230
let's see if this one does it,
nope this one doesn't do it.

477
00:22:23.230 --> 00:22:25.710
So you'll see option sometimes

478
00:22:25.710 --> 00:22:28.200
where you can do what's called
Shared Memory, all right?

479
00:22:28.200 --> 00:22:29.390
Let me jump over to the hypervixen.

480
00:22:29.390 --> 00:22:31.460
Pretty sure hyper v does it.

481
00:22:31.460 --> 00:22:33.190
And open if I'm logged in that will do it.

482
00:22:33.190 --> 00:22:36.490
So sometimes you'll see we can
do what's called Shared Memory.

483
00:22:36.490 --> 00:22:39.930
I might assign 8 GB of RAM
to a Virtual Machine, okay?

484
00:22:39.930 --> 00:22:43.430
And if I assign 8 GB of RAM to a virtual
machine when it boots up by default the VM

485
00:22:43.430 --> 00:22:45.500
is gonna try and grab all 8 GB of RAM.

486
00:22:45.500 --> 00:22:46.310
That's what they do.

487
00:22:46.310 --> 00:22:48.090
They grab all that memory.

488
00:22:48.090 --> 00:22:53.000
But if your virtualization
platform supports Shared Memory,

489
00:22:53.000 --> 00:22:56.530
what it can do is it can say
hey i'm gonna grab 8 GB of RAM.

490
00:22:56.530 --> 00:22:59.100
But I'm really only using a gig of it.

491
00:22:59.100 --> 00:22:59.950
So the other 7 GB.

492
00:22:59.950 --> 00:23:03.280
That can kinda just float out there and
be arbitrary, and

493
00:23:03.280 --> 00:23:04.690
maybe I share it with other people.

494
00:23:04.690 --> 00:23:06.990
And other Virtual Machines can use it too.

495
00:23:06.990 --> 00:23:10.000
On a positive side,
you can do what's called Oversubscription.

496
00:23:10.000 --> 00:23:13.670
I can add more memory to my
VMs than I actually have.

497
00:23:13.670 --> 00:23:17.425
On a negative side, if I ever go to use
that memory and it's not there for me.

498
00:23:17.425 --> 00:23:20.830
Right, if it's already in use somewhere
else, then I'm gonna swap down to the hard

499
00:23:20.830 --> 00:23:23.250
drive and
I'm gonna get that big performance hit.

500
00:23:23.250 --> 00:23:26.370
So you may or
may not have that functionality in yours.

501
00:23:26.370 --> 00:23:29.700
So for example,
if I take this machine, and

502
00:23:29.700 --> 00:23:32.335
I can't remember offhand
if Hyper-V let me do it.

503
00:23:32.335 --> 00:23:35.260
Hyper-V actually has a neat
features called NUMA Spanning,

504
00:23:35.260 --> 00:23:37.770
which is kind of memory related also.

505
00:23:37.770 --> 00:23:40.940
Just looking down the list here, I'm not
seeing anything else jump out at me.

506
00:23:40.940 --> 00:23:44.072
NUMA spanning allows you to have
the memory that spans between servers.

507
00:23:44.072 --> 00:23:48.144
So I could have two physical servers
that had 32 GB of RAM each and

508
00:23:48.144 --> 00:23:51.783
I could create one VM that had
50 GB of RAM assigned to it.

509
00:23:51.783 --> 00:23:53.594
And some of the RAM is
coming from one server and

510
00:23:53.594 --> 00:23:55.413
some of the RAM is coming
from another server.

511
00:23:55.413 --> 00:23:58.325
Now you've got to have a network
that's designed to handle that,

512
00:23:58.325 --> 00:24:00.160
cuz that's a high-performance thing.

513
00:24:00.160 --> 00:24:01.900
But you actually can do that.

514
00:24:01.900 --> 00:24:05.305
And see how it says non-uniform
memory architecture?

515
00:24:05.305 --> 00:24:07.420
Non-uniform, the memory
is not all in one system.

516
00:24:07.420 --> 00:24:09.900
It's not necessarily even
the same type of memory.

517
00:24:09.900 --> 00:24:12.442
And it allows us to span across it.

518
00:24:12.442 --> 00:24:17.100
I am not a fan of this technology,
but it is something that is out there.

519
00:24:17.100 --> 00:24:18.930
I'm not a fan of shared memory either,
I don't use it.

520
00:24:18.930 --> 00:24:21.240
So, just because you're not
a fan of a technology, though,

521
00:24:21.240 --> 00:24:23.420
doesn't mean you can choose to ignore it.

522
00:24:23.420 --> 00:24:28.730
You may still have to use that,
even though you don't like it.

523
00:24:28.730 --> 00:24:33.742
But at a minimum, you've gotta know it for
the exam because you wanna pass, right?

524
00:24:33.742 --> 00:24:35.181
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] It would be helpful.

525
00:24:35.181 --> 00:24:35.760
>> So, there is that.

526
00:24:35.760 --> 00:24:38.570
So I'm just gonna whip up a Hyper-V
machine here real quick, and

527
00:24:38.570 --> 00:24:41.800
I'm just gonna use all the defaults,
actually, I'll Gen 2 on this one.

528
00:24:41.800 --> 00:24:44.160
But I'm just gonna use the defaults,
here it is.

529
00:24:44.160 --> 00:24:45.249
Perfect.

530
00:24:45.249 --> 00:24:47.826
So on this machine, I'm creating
a virtual machine in Hyper-V, and

00:24:47.826 --> 00:24:49.590
it's asking me how much
memory I wanna give it.

532
00:24:49.590 --> 00:24:53.770

memory which is practically nothing.

533
00:24:53.770 --> 00:24:56.240
So let's say I make that
four gigs of memory.

534
00:24:56.240 --> 00:24:59.470
Okay, and then, apparently I don't
have that much memory in this machine.

535
00:24:59.470 --> 00:25:00.730
So we'll do one gig of memory.

536
00:25:00.730 --> 00:25:01.540
There.

537
00:25:01.540 --> 00:25:05.190
So then the next think it asks me is
do I want to Use Dynamic Memory for

538
00:25:05.190 --> 00:25:06.840
the virtual machine.

539
00:25:06.840 --> 00:25:10.100
Well, dynamic memory,
that's Microsoft's name for shared memory.

540
00:25:10.100 --> 00:25:13.670
If I do this, I've assigned
a gig of memory to this system.

541
00:25:13.670 --> 00:25:17.580
But I'm not necessarily always
going to have that gig.

542
00:25:17.580 --> 00:25:21.470
That some of it might be in use by other
machines, and I can try and get it.

543
00:25:21.470 --> 00:25:22.580
If it's available, I'll have it.

544
00:25:22.580 --> 00:25:24.890
But if it's not available,
I'll swap to the hard drive.

545
00:25:24.890 --> 00:25:27.060
And so we can see it right there.

546
00:25:27.060 --> 00:25:29.450
And if you run some of their
advanced management software,

547
00:25:29.450 --> 00:25:32.040
it even lets you set
some more crazy things.

548
00:25:32.040 --> 00:25:34.260
Like if I had
System Center Virtual Machine Manager,

549
00:25:34.260 --> 00:25:37.850
you can set a minimum amount of memory for
it to have at any given time and

550
00:25:37.850 --> 00:25:41.300
you can set maximum thresholds, and
you can prioritize your virtual machines,

551
00:25:41.300 --> 00:25:44.360
who gets high priority access to memory,
who's lower, and so on.

552
00:25:44.360 --> 00:25:48.070
So you can really start to get
specific with this stuff and

553
00:25:48.070 --> 00:25:49.700
really do some neat things.

554
00:25:49.700 --> 00:25:51.860
And I don't think it shows
me here in regular Hyper-V,

555
00:25:51.860 --> 00:25:54.550
I'm pretty sure you have to be,
I'm a big, fat liar.

556
00:25:54.550 --> 00:25:57.400
It's right here.
So looking at the virtual machine after

557
00:25:57.400 --> 00:25:59.960
the setup wizard, there's that
dynamic memory I turned on, and

00:25:59.960 --> 00:26:04.790
see how I've got that minimum RAM,
it's 512 MEGS, Maximum RAM is set,

559
00:26:04.790 --> 00:26:07.929
I mean it's, what is that,
like a terrabyte or something?

560
00:26:07.929 --> 00:26:08.811
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

561
00:26:08.811 --> 00:26:11.440
it's some insane number
that we don't need.

00:26:11.440 --> 00:26:13.112
But I assigned it a gig of RAM.

00:26:13.112 --> 00:26:14.490
You can see it right up

00:26:14.490 --> 00:26:16.810
So when it boots up,
it's gonna have a gig of RAM.

565
00:26:16.810 --> 00:26:22.530
But it could reduce down to 500 MEGS or
it could even go higher if needed,

566
00:26:22.530 --> 00:26:24.930
assuming the memory is there,
assuming it's available.

567
00:26:24.930 --> 00:26:26.230
So we can specify that.

568
00:26:26.230 --> 00:26:27.550
That's shared memory.

569
00:26:27.550 --> 00:26:31.990
Shared memory lets you assign more memory
to a virtual machine than you have or

570
00:26:31.990 --> 00:26:33.970
to all of your virtual
machines than what you have.

571
00:26:33.970 --> 00:26:35.070
So if add up your VMs, and

572
00:26:35.070 --> 00:26:38.400
they add up to a number that's
bigger than what your machine has.

573
00:26:38.400 --> 00:26:40.630
On a positive side, it's more efficient.

574
00:26:40.630 --> 00:26:42.830
You can make better use
of the memory you have.

575
00:26:42.830 --> 00:26:46.280
On a negative side,
it can be a performance hit, right?

576
00:26:46.280 --> 00:26:48.350
Any time you go to hit memory
that's not available then you

577
00:26:48.350 --> 00:26:49.170
get swapped to the hard drive.

578
00:26:49.170 --> 00:26:51.770
So in production, I don't use this.

579
00:26:51.770 --> 00:26:53.680
In tests or development, I do.

580
00:26:53.680 --> 00:26:56.350
It's great, if I want to bring up
20 virtual machines on my laptop,

581
00:26:56.350 --> 00:26:57.730
I'm gonna run out of memory.

582
00:26:57.730 --> 00:27:01.340

00:27:01.340 --> 00:27:04.290
I can have high amounts of memory
allocated even though I don't actually

584
00:27:04.290 --> 00:27:05.920
have the physical number to back it up.

585
00:27:05.920 --> 00:27:08.080
So definitely not something

00:27:08.080 --> 00:27:10.220
although it does get better every year,
so who knows?

587
00:27:10.220 --> 00:27:13.630
Maybe one day this will be the norm, but
that's what they mean by shared memory.

588
00:27:13.630 --> 00:27:17.080
>> And the good thing is that
memory prices are dropping left and

00:27:17.080 --> 00:27:22.090
right every day, so it might just be more

00:27:22.090 --> 00:27:24.910
to stick in your server if

591
00:27:24.910 --> 00:27:28.780
these virtual machines keep

00:27:28.780 --> 00:27:31.990
Just grab some more memory, stick it

00:27:31.990 --> 00:27:33.530
>> Yeah.
And on a server,

00:27:35.030 --> 00:27:36.550
>> No.
>> That's one of those things where just,

00:27:36.550 --> 00:27:39.620
whatever your budget can afford,
you get that extra RAM in there.

597
00:27:39.620 --> 00:27:42.900
Cuz you can upgrade down the road,

598
00:27:42.900 --> 00:27:45.350
All right, so that's memory.

00:27:45.350 --> 00:27:46.380
We've got a few other things.

Those two are really important.

602

00:27:52.160 --> 00:27:56.470
But we also need to pay attention

On the network side, things can get a

00:27:59.600 --> 00:28:01.931

00:28:01.931 --> 00:28:03.714

we definitely wanna tackle that.

But, Daniel, we might just
wanna kinda wrap this one and

00:28:07.786 --> 00:28:09.390

00:28:09.390 --> 00:28:10.250
>> I do not mind at all.

00:28:10.250 --> 00:28:14.080
This is all great information, it's

00:28:14.080 --> 00:28:17.020

00:28:17.020 --> 00:28:19.540

00:28:19.540 --> 00:28:22.670

00:28:39.240 --> 00:28:41.140

00:28:41.140 --> 00:28:43.440
we look forward to seeing you
there in part two as well.

00:28:43.440 --> 00:28:44.670
Thanks for watching today.

00:28:44.670 --> 00:28:47.294

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue working toward creating a virtual machine; this time picking up with networking and disk considerations. They start by explaining virtual networks and virtual switches. They show you the many ways which you can connect a VM to your actual network through bridging, NAT, and even VLAN assignment. Then they jump into virtual disks where they explain concepts like fixed vs. dynamic size, IDE/SATA/SCSI virtualization, and virtual Storage Area Networks(SAN).

You just plug them in and

50

51

00:02:53.290 --> 00:02:56.050

The one, you know,

00:21:09.130 --> 00:21:12.110
or up top,
that'll tell you how to release the mouse.

458
00:21:12.110 --> 00:21:15.090
If the mouse is trapped,
here's how you release it to get it out.

459
00:21:15.090 --> 00:21:18.042
And on VMware, it's Ctrl+Alt usually.

460
00:21:18.042 --> 00:21:20.883
Sometimes it's your right Alt key or
your left Alt key,

461
00:21:20.883 --> 00:21:23.313
it just depends on
the platform you're using.

462
00:21:23.313 --> 00:21:24.637
It'll have a different keyboard shortcut.

463
00:21:24.637 --> 00:21:27.720
And it'll release your mouse and
get it out of the virtual machine.

464
00:21:27.720 --> 00:21:31.190
But once you have the tools installed like
I do, you can freely move your mouse in

465
00:21:31.190 --> 00:21:34.860
and out of the install, and it's this
driver here that's letting you do it.

466
00:21:34.860 --> 00:21:38.550
It's removing that edge detection that
allows the mouse to exit the screen.

467
00:21:40.080 --> 00:21:43.920
You'll also see I've got a video card
driver, a sound driver and so on.

468
00:21:43.920 --> 00:21:45.900
This is a Type 2 hypervisor.

469
00:21:45.900 --> 00:21:48.800
On a Type 2 hypervisor all
of your hardware is fake.

470
00:21:48.800 --> 00:21:54.588
So I've got a fake SVGA video card,
a fake audio driver, a fake NIC.

471
00:21:54.588 --> 00:21:57.770
All of this hardware is completely fake,
and

472
00:21:57.770 --> 00:21:59.420
these are the drivers that support that.

473
00:21:59.420 --> 00:22:02.110
I need these tools for
my fake hardware to work.

474
00:22:02.110 --> 00:22:04.270
On a Type 1 hypervisor you might
not have half of this stuff,

475
00:22:04.270 --> 00:22:06.090
because a lot of it's the real hardware.

476
00:22:06.090 --> 00:22:08.900
So those are some of the different
things that you get.

477
00:22:08.900 --> 00:22:12.823

support for snapshots and I've got shared

478
00:22:12.823 --> 00:22:16.482
folder support where I can share files

479
00:22:16.482 --> 00:22:19.872
All of these are provided by the guest

480
00:22:19.872 --> 00:22:24.809
>> Now Don, one of the cool benefits

00:22:24.809 --> 00:22:29.323

that we can have an easily rapidly

00:22:29.323 --> 00:22:33.943

build that we're looking for.

483
00:22:33.943 --> 00:22:36.235
And that can be really helpful

484
00:22:36.235 --> 00:22:40.480
>> Yeah, let's say I'm a developer and

00:22:40.480 --> 00:22:43.140

00:22:43.140 --> 00:22:44.890

00:22:44.890 --> 00:22:47.190

the process of reinstalling the operating

00:22:47.190 --> 00:22:49.745
system and getting everything

00:22:49.745 --> 00:22:53.100
It'd be nice if I could just spin up

00:22:53.100 --> 00:22:54.290

491
00:22:54.290 --> 00:22:57.490
When you create a virtual machine,

492
00:22:57.490 --> 00:23:00.310
And a template can be cloned

493
00:23:00.310 --> 00:23:04.090
So if I wanna spin up more virtual
machines, I can clone them and off I go.

494
00:23:04.090 --> 00:23:06.460
And there's some other technologies too,
like Snapshots and so

495
00:23:06.460 --> 00:23:09.190
on that can help, but
cloning is one of the nice ones.

496
00:23:09.190 --> 00:23:13.270
Now if you're cloning, so for example,
I've got a CentOS box right here, so

497
00:23:13.270 --> 00:23:14.680
a CentOS Linux.

00:23:14.680 --> 00:23:18.977
And if I need a second Linux box,

00:23:18.977 --> 00:23:22.530
Well, if I've got a bunch of stuff
customized and installed on there,

00:23:22.530 --> 00:23:24.317
now it's a very specific machine.

00:23:24.317 --> 00:23:25.803
I might not want a clone of that.

00:23:25.803 --> 00:23:29.876
So what I might choose to do is do
an install of Linux that's just a base

00:23:29.876 --> 00:23:30.700
install.

00:23:30.700 --> 00:23:33.160
Here's the basic installation that I need.

505
00:23:33.160 --> 00:23:35.350
And whenever I need new ones,
I can just clone it.

506
00:23:35.350 --> 00:23:36.360
I've actually done that.

00:23:36.360 --> 00:23:39.630

00:23:39.630 --> 00:23:44.208

00:23:44.208 --> 00:23:45.565

00:23:45.565 --> 00:23:49.534

00:23:49.534 --> 00:23:50.684

00:23:50.684 --> 00:23:55.431

00:23:55.431 --> 00:23:58.927

00:23:58.927 --> 00:24:01.492

00:24:01.492 --> 00:24:03.664
probably cuz I'm out of hard drive space,
but a.

00:24:03.664 --> 00:24:08.480
[LAUGH] So, but you can create a clone and
that will create that second machine.

517
00:24:08.480 --> 00:24:10.920
I'm using this as a template.

518
00:24:10.920 --> 00:24:13.470
Now for a Linux machine,
you can clone anything you want, right?

519
00:24:13.470 --> 00:24:16.650
So I could take like this CentOS box,
and I could go in and

520
00:24:16.650 --> 00:24:20.010
create that full clone right there and
it's ready to go, all right?

521
00:24:20.010 --> 00:24:23.520
And it's a smaller image, I guess,
so I got my option right there.

00:24:23.520 --> 00:24:25.330
But on a Windows machine,
it's a little different.

00:24:25.330 --> 00:24:29.070
On a Windows machine you have a security

00:24:29.070 --> 00:24:32.120
and if I just go and clone this one

00:24:32.120 --> 00:24:35.430
I'm gonna have a bunch of computers

526
00:24:35.430 --> 00:24:37.395
So if you're gonna create a template,

00:24:37.395 --> 00:24:41.098
one of the things you need to do is
what's called generalizing your data.

528
00:24:41.098 --> 00:24:44.535
You need to make that install nice and
generic, right?

529
00:24:44.535 --> 00:24:49.163
And if we take my Windows 10 install,
which I stopped that one, didn't I?

530
00:24:49.163 --> 00:24:52.135
Shoot, well I can take
this Windows 7 machine.

531
00:24:52.135 --> 00:24:57.195
If I had this Windows 7 machine and I
wanted to turn this into a template that I

00:24:57.195 --> 00:25:02.275
could use, or I think I've got a Server
machine fired up, here sever 03.

00:25:02.275 --> 00:25:04.412
Let's tackle one of my other servers,
or server 02,

00:25:04.412 --> 00:25:06.370
I don't even know what this server does.

00:25:06.370 --> 00:25:07.230
So I'll take this server.

00:25:07.230 --> 00:25:08.650
It's running Windows Server 2012 R2.

00:25:08.650 --> 00:25:09.890
I wanna make it a template.

00:25:09.890 --> 00:25:14.510
So I boot it up, I get it all installed
and configured, I do all the Windows

00:25:14.510 --> 00:25:18.490
updates, maybe I've got some antivirus
software that I use in my company so

00:25:18.490 --> 00:25:21.150
I install that, or
whatever it is that we use in our company,

00:25:21.150 --> 00:25:23.220
we get it all installed,
even the wallpaper.

542
00:25:24.340 --> 00:25:29.650
Then, if I want to make it a template,
I need to shut it down and

00:25:29.650 --> 00:25:32.220
stop using it and
then I can clone it as I want.

544
00:25:32.220 --> 00:25:34.060
And in Zen Center, Citrix Zen Center,

00:25:34.060 --> 00:25:36.630
they have a neat feature where you can

00:25:36.630 --> 00:25:38.210
then you can clone it out of

00:25:38.210 --> 00:25:39.470
That stops people from turning it on,

548
00:25:39.470 --> 00:25:42.330

turn this on whenever you want.

00:25:42.330 --> 00:25:44.880
I like to leave it where I can turn it on
cuz I might wanna continue to do updates

00:25:44.880 --> 00:25:46.810
to it, right, tweaks to that image.

00:25:46.810 --> 00:25:48.730
But it's not generalized.

552
00:25:48.730 --> 00:25:50.188
This server's got a name, right?

553
00:25:50.188 --> 00:25:53.762
It's got a name, which we can no
longer see, of Server03, and so

554
00:25:53.762 --> 00:25:56.548
if I start cloning it,
I'm gonna, or server 02.

555
00:25:56.548 --> 00:25:59.648
I'm gonna have a fleet of computers
that are all called server 02.

556
00:25:59.648 --> 00:26:03.088
And, this one's joined to a domain, right?

557
00:26:03.088 --> 00:26:04.868
So it's tied to an active
directory domain.

558
00:26:04.868 --> 00:26:07.606
And if I clone this, now I've got two
machines with the same name in the same

00:26:07.606 --> 00:26:09.930
domain, it's gonna screw everything up.

560
00:26:09.930 --> 00:26:13.530
So I need to generalize this machine,
I need to make it generic.

561
00:26:13.530 --> 00:26:17.090
And the way you do that in Windows is
by using Sysprep, Sysprep's a utility,

562
00:26:17.090 --> 00:26:21.580
it's actually built into the system
if I browse on my hard drive here.

563
00:26:23.630 --> 00:26:27.326
I'm gonna browse into Windows and
system32 and

564
00:26:27.326 --> 00:26:32.166
sysprep if I remember right,
there it is, and I can run sysprep.

565
00:26:32.166 --> 00:26:32.836
And what it is,

566
00:26:32.836 --> 00:26:35.983
a little utility that basically digs
through the registry of Windows and

567
00:26:35.983 --> 00:26:39.298
all the other settings, it looks for
anything that would be a unique value.

568
00:26:39.298 --> 00:26:41.549
Something that would apply
just to this server and

569
00:26:41.549 --> 00:26:43.280
it strips it out and gets rid of it.

570
00:26:43.280 --> 00:26:44.850
Throws it away, right?

571
00:26:44.850 --> 00:26:49.220
And so, if I do that, if I tell
it to generalize this system, and

572
00:26:49.220 --> 00:26:54.930
then shut down, when that's done, this
machine will have no unique data anymore,

573
00:26:54.930 --> 00:26:58.230
but it'll have a full install
of Windows with all the updates,

574
00:26:58.230 --> 00:27:01.350
with my third-party software installed,
and now I can just clone it

575
00:27:01.350 --> 00:27:05.590
to my heart's content and spin up new
ones and kind of run with that, right?

576
00:27:05.590 --> 00:27:08.750
So, if I do that, here's Sysprep running,
and then as soon as it's done,

577
00:27:08.750 --> 00:27:10.540
it's gonna shut the machine down.

578
00:27:10.540 --> 00:27:13.680
And then once it's shut down,
I just clone it out.

579
00:27:13.680 --> 00:27:15.930
Whenever I clone it and spin up a new
machine, it's gonna ask me, hey,

580
00:27:15.930 --> 00:27:17.310
what do you wanna name this machine?

581
00:27:17.310 --> 00:27:19.405
Well actually Windows will generate
a fake name now, but you know,

582
00:27:19.405 --> 00:27:20.460
you can reassign it.

583
00:27:20.460 --> 00:27:23.860
It'll ask you for, you know, a couple
other basic settings before it fires up,

584
00:27:23.860 --> 00:27:27.380
and now you can quickly provision
those machines, and that's a really

585
00:27:27.380 --> 00:27:30.930
nice feature of doing cloud services
like this, rapid provisioning.

586
00:27:30.930 --> 00:27:32.870
And you see that in the big
cloud services too,

00:27:32.870 --> 00:27:39.450
like in Windows Azure or let's see,

00:27:39.450 --> 00:27:41.050
Somewhere around here.

00:27:41.050 --> 00:27:44.540
Here, so I'm in Amazon AWS,
Amazon Web Services.

If I need a Linux server,

When I jump into EC2 and

I'm gonna pick from the images and

00:28:00.108 --> 00:28:04.578
I'm gonna pick a Windows server right
here, Windows Server 2012 R2 base.

596
00:28:04.578 --> 00:28:06.098
So I'm going to select that one.

597
00:28:06.098 --> 00:28:08.230
I'm not going to install Windows,
they've already done it for me.

00:28:08.230 --> 00:28:10.440
They have an image that's
already got it installed,

599
00:28:10.440 --> 00:28:12.218
that's already got the updates applied.

600
00:28:12.218 --> 00:28:18.042
And so I can come in and pick what I want
that image to be, and we can launch it,

601
00:28:18.042 --> 00:28:23.229
and when it does that its going to
deploy very, very quickly because

602
00:28:23.229 --> 00:28:28.428
its not having to install Windows
its just having to clone an image.

603
00:28:28.428 --> 00:28:30.935
And so there it is and
its initializing right now,

604
00:28:30.935 --> 00:28:35.050
that means its cloning the image and
then I'm gonna see it go and start up.

605
00:28:35.050 --> 00:28:37.520
And it'll start up, and then when
it's done I'll have Windows up and

606
00:28:37.520 --> 00:28:39.750
running ready for
me to access it and use it.

607
00:28:39.750 --> 00:28:43.150
That's one of the really cool parts
about doing virtualization like this,

608
00:28:43.150 --> 00:28:44.540
is we can rapidly deploy it.

609
00:28:44.540 --> 00:28:46.716
So if I need a new web
server to test with, or

00:28:46.716 --> 00:28:50.041

00:28:50.041 --> 00:28:53.148

I can just clone one,

00:28:55.848 --> 00:28:59.048
I don't have to do the install and

00:28:59.048 --> 00:29:02.028

00:29:02.028 --> 00:29:03.248

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore some of the reasons and methods for migration in a virtual environment. They being by looking at motives that could necessitate a migration, reasons like testing, upgrading, and/or performance issues. Then they discuss some of the migration variations, including physical to virtual, virtual to virtual, and virtual to physical. Also covered are some of caveats and considerations that need to be addressed before migrating.

Did the permissions stay?

706
00:34:04.680 --> 00:34:07.380
Are all the things that were
protected before still protected?

707
00:34:07.380 --> 00:34:10.860
You've got to check and make sure that
all of that stuff is still there and

708
00:34:10.860 --> 00:34:15.430
functional and that things are working
the way that they're intended to work.

709
00:34:15.430 --> 00:34:18.180
If they aren't, then you need to
go back to your physical server,

710
00:34:18.180 --> 00:34:20.950
which fortunately your physical server
should just be shut down now, so

711
00:34:20.950 --> 00:34:25.110
you just delete the VM and power up the
physical server and you're in business.

712
00:34:25.110 --> 00:34:30.510
Shoot, the vCenter converter is installed
on here so it's getting upset about that.

713
00:34:30.510 --> 00:34:33.158
So I really need to uninstall
that converter to do it.

714
00:34:33.158 --> 00:34:36.790
But once the agent's installed,
we can reach out and see that,

715
00:34:36.790 --> 00:34:40.297
and back here it'll find it and
it'll start that migration.

716
00:34:40.297 --> 00:34:43.299
And like I said, we have to sit here for
a couple of hours, usually,

717
00:34:43.299 --> 00:34:46.829
while it takes that image and brings it in
here, but at the end of the day you end up

718
00:34:46.829 --> 00:34:51.090
with a virtual machine that has the same
hardware profile as the physical machine.

719
00:34:51.090 --> 00:34:54.570
It restores that system into and it comes
online, should have the same IP address,

720
00:34:54.570 --> 00:34:58.420
should have the same Mac address,
should have the same configuration, and

721
00:34:58.420 --> 00:34:59.180
off it goes.

722
00:34:59.180 --> 00:35:03.680
Now, one of the considerations I want to
throw in before we wrap the episode up,

723
00:35:03.680 --> 00:35:06.780
is if you're running Microsoft Windows,
it will have to reactivate.

724
00:35:06.780 --> 00:35:09.530
And so you have a license key in Windows
that you activate when you first

725
00:35:09.530 --> 00:35:10.310
install it.

726
00:35:10.310 --> 00:35:13.410
When it becomes virtual, it's gonna see
that as new hardware or a new install, so

727
00:35:13.410 --> 00:35:14.470
you'll have to reactivate.

728
00:35:14.470 --> 00:35:16.550
So be aware of that on the licensing side.

729
00:35:16.550 --> 00:35:18.340
If it's Linux, it's not a big deal.

730
00:35:18.340 --> 00:35:20.930
But if it's Windows, you've always
got that licensing to worry about.

731
00:35:20.930 --> 00:35:23.300
>> Well,
this has been excellent stuff, Don.

732
00:35:23.300 --> 00:35:26.209
We've taken a look at all the reasons
why we would wanna migrate.

733
00:35:26.209 --> 00:35:30.368
Some of the considerations we would need
to take in account before we even start

734
00:35:30.368 --> 00:35:31.132
a migration.

735
00:35:31.132 --> 00:35:34.170
And now we've actually even looked at how
some of the ways we can go through and

736
00:35:34.170 --> 00:35:36.507
actually do a migration, and
now Don's at the part where,

737
00:35:36.507 --> 00:35:39.200
really, we would just wait for it,
and we might be that committed.

738
00:35:39.200 --> 00:35:40.510
Everybody ready for an hour show?

739
00:35:40.510 --> 00:35:43.070
No. [LAUGH] >> [LAUGH]
>> But you just wait until it's done,

740
00:35:43.070 --> 00:35:46.500
and then once it says, hey,
here's your virtual machine, you press go,

741
00:35:46.500 --> 00:35:49.130
you press start, you press play,
whatever the option is they give you, and

742
00:35:49.130 --> 00:35:50.230
there is your machine.

743
00:35:50.230 --> 00:35:53.470
Like Don says, make sure that everything
is working before you say, hey,

744
00:35:53.470 --> 00:35:55.880
that production server is back up and
ready to rock.

745
00:35:55.880 --> 00:35:59.920
You wanna verify that before you
tell anyone to start using it again.

746
00:35:59.920 --> 00:36:02.750
And in case something happens you got the
old guy still sitting there waiting for

747
00:36:02.750 --> 00:36:04.440
you so that you can restore to that.

748
00:36:04.440 --> 00:36:06.640
Don, anything else we need to cover
before we close this episode?

749
00:36:06.640 --> 00:36:08.220
>> That's all about it,
that's all I've got.

750
00:36:08.220 --> 00:36:10.810
>> All right, well thank you so
much for explaining this to us.

751
00:36:10.810 --> 00:36:11.930
I'm sure our viewers appreciate it.

752
00:36:11.930 --> 00:36:12.780
I know I did.

753
00:36:12.780 --> 00:36:14.330
Even though I've dealt with this before,

754
00:36:14.330 --> 00:36:18.260
it's always good to refresh and
to reassess this kind of things.

755
00:36:18.260 --> 00:36:19.470
Thank you guys for watching.

756
00:36:19.470 --> 00:36:21.160
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

757
00:36:21.160 --> 00:36:23.000
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

758
00:36:23.000 --> 00:36:23.580
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

759
00:36:23.580 --> 00:36:25.555
>> We'll see you next time.

760
00:36:25.555 --> 00:36:33.216
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain one of the most useful features of any virtualization platform and that is snapshots. They begin by explaining what a snapshot is and then show you how they can be used to quickly restore a VM to a specific point in time. Then they cover taking backups in a virtualized environment, looking at both image and file backups.
episodes.title: Snapshots and Backups
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.796 --> 00:00:16.880
All right greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.880 --> 00:00:20.689
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode well we're moving

4
00:00:20.689 --> 00:00:23.310
forward with our Cloud Plus series for
CompTIA.

5
00:00:23.310 --> 00:00:26.900
Hopefully you've been enjoying it so
far because joining us again in the studio

6
00:00:26.900 --> 00:00:30.405
again today, well, it's none other
than our good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

7
00:00:30.405 --> 00:00:32.320
Don welcome back to the show and
how are you doing?

8
00:00:32.320 --> 00:00:33.580
>> I am doing great Daniel,

9
00:00:33.580 --> 00:00:35.650
ready to jump right back into
the world of virtualization.

10
00:00:35.650 --> 00:00:39.260
And in this episode we're gonna talk about
a neat feature that has saved my bacon

11
00:00:39.260 --> 00:00:42.670
more than once and that is,
snapshots of virtual machines.

12
00:00:42.670 --> 00:00:44.990
We'll talk a little bit about backup and
restore also, but

13
00:00:44.990 --> 00:00:50.900
snapshots are just a great way to
protect ourselves from bad changes or

14
00:00:50.900 --> 00:00:53.790
things that would normally
bring a physical machine down.

15
00:00:53.790 --> 00:00:56.660
But allow us to quickly
recover a virtual machine and

16
00:00:56.660 --> 00:01:00.440
have it back online in a matter of seconds
and really achieve some cool stuff.

17
00:01:00.440 --> 00:01:03.160
So that's what we're going to be
taking a look at in this episode.

18
00:01:03.160 --> 00:01:07.820
>> That's right, the snapshot in
the VM environment is a god send.

19
00:01:07.820 --> 00:01:11.270
It is probably in my opinion
one of the best features

20
00:01:11.270 --> 00:01:15.820
that they offer in virtualization because
like Don has said it saved his bacon,

21
00:01:15.820 --> 00:01:17.650
it saved my bacon plenty of times.

22
00:01:17.650 --> 00:01:20.600
It's really protecting us from
ourselves to be honest with you.

23
00:01:20.600 --> 00:01:23.980
You make a bad change, you install
a patch and things don't go right.

24
00:01:23.980 --> 00:01:25.840
The server is not working correctly.

25
00:01:25.840 --> 00:01:26.740
What do we do?

26
00:01:26.740 --> 00:01:30.450
Well I could go on and try and
uninstall or maybe go from backup.

27
00:01:30.450 --> 00:01:33.820
But if I've made a snapshot,
my life just got a whole lot easier.

28
00:01:33.820 --> 00:01:36.840
So Don, explain to us, what is a snapshot?

29
00:01:36.840 --> 00:01:39.415
How can we use this miracle of modern man?

30
00:01:39.415 --> 00:01:41.714
[LAUGH]
>> I love your example of updates cuz

31
00:01:41.714 --> 00:01:46.321
that's really where it's helped me a lot,
and if you've worked with Windows for

32
00:01:46.321 --> 00:01:49.614
a long time,
I really cut my teeth with Windows NT 4.0.

33
00:01:49.614 --> 00:01:53.065
And in Windows NT 4,
when a new service pack came out, and

34
00:01:53.065 --> 00:01:54.620
they use to come out a lot.

35
00:01:54.620 --> 00:01:56.840
And even now, your lucky to get
two service packs on an OS.

36
00:01:56.840 --> 00:01:58.750
But back then, you'd get six.

37
00:01:58.750 --> 00:02:02.220
And, when an update pack would come out,
you'd take your server,

38
00:02:02.220 --> 00:02:04.090
you'd install the update.

39
00:02:04.090 --> 00:02:04.940
And then it would reboot.

40
00:02:04.940 --> 00:02:08.050
And that reboot was always this like
nail-biting moment because your odds of

41
00:02:08.050 --> 00:02:09.940
having a blue screen on
boot were pretty high.

42
00:02:09.940 --> 00:02:14.040
And if you did, if it blue screened on
boot, what you had to do was hope you had

43
00:02:14.040 --> 00:02:16.820
taken a backup of that server cause you
were about to have to restore it right?

44
00:02:16.820 --> 00:02:20.440
There was no way to uninstall that
service pack, you were just screwed.

45
00:02:20.440 --> 00:02:23.130
And even when you had a way to
uninstall the service pack,

46
00:02:23.130 --> 00:02:26.000
sometimes if it was blue screening on
boot, you couldn't even get past that.

47
00:02:26.000 --> 00:02:28.510
So you had to format the machine,
restore from backup, and

48
00:02:28.510 --> 00:02:30.430
it was gonna be a couple hours to do it.

49
00:02:30.430 --> 00:02:34.410
So updates like that were always, really,
really tenuous, you just didn't know what

50
00:02:34.410 --> 00:02:36.910
was gonna happen, you had to test
them out in a test environment.

51
00:02:36.910 --> 00:02:39.870
But no matter how well you would test it,
there was always that moment of

52
00:02:39.870 --> 00:02:42.470
trepidation when you applied
an update to a production machine.

53
00:02:43.510 --> 00:02:46.380
In the virtual world,
it's really all still the same, right?

54
00:02:46.380 --> 00:02:49.680
You still have the same operating systems
that are running in the virtual machines,

55
00:02:49.680 --> 00:02:53.590
except we can use snapshots to protect us.

56
00:02:53.590 --> 00:02:56.900
What a snapshot does is it takes,
like a picture,

57
00:02:56.900 --> 00:03:00.380
it takes an image of your machine
as it is right at that moment.

58
00:03:00.380 --> 00:03:03.440
It freezes it in time and

59
00:03:03.440 --> 00:03:07.500
then from that point on every change
you make is written separately.

60
00:03:07.500 --> 00:03:10.605
It writes those changes to
a separate set of files.

61
00:03:10.605 --> 00:03:14.380
And if something goes wrong you can just
delete those separate set of files and

62
00:03:14.380 --> 00:03:16.655
it puts you right back
to the way things were.

63
00:03:16.655 --> 00:03:19.950
And so you can quickly and
easily recover from what you did.

64
00:03:19.950 --> 00:03:22.400
Now, there's positives and
negatives to snapshots.

65
00:03:22.400 --> 00:03:25.618
So, they sound great, they're awesome,
they're easy to use, but

66
00:03:25.618 --> 00:03:28.520
they're not the be all end all
of solutions that are out there.

67
00:03:28.520 --> 00:03:29.960
And I'll talk about that
as the episode goes on,

68
00:03:29.960 --> 00:03:32.220
some of the different things
we have to watch out for.

69
00:03:32.220 --> 00:03:35.765
But I've kind of explained it, but
it's hard to grasp that right.

70
00:03:35.765 --> 00:03:38.875
So I want to show you guys
this kind of thing in action.

71
00:03:38.875 --> 00:03:40.795
How these snapshots work.

72
00:03:40.795 --> 00:03:43.465
The first thing I wanna show you is,
snapshots can be a little different

73
00:03:43.465 --> 00:03:46.765
depending on whether the machine is on or
if the machine is off.

74
00:03:46.765 --> 00:03:50.905
If the machine is off,
a snapshot is really, really quite simple.

75
00:03:50.905 --> 00:03:51.855
Let me show you here.

76
00:03:51.855 --> 00:03:52.625
I'll take this machine.

77
00:03:52.625 --> 00:03:55.785
So here's a Windows 7 machine that's
up and running on VMware Fusion.

78
00:03:55.785 --> 00:03:57.060
I'm just gonna shut it down.

79
00:03:57.060 --> 00:03:58.710
And we'll turn it off all right.

80
00:03:58.710 --> 00:04:02.240
When a machine is off if I
wanna take a snapshot of it

81
00:04:02.240 --> 00:04:05.410
there's really only two pieces of
information that I need to snapshot.

82
00:04:05.410 --> 00:04:10.230
There's my hardware configuration and
there's the hard drive, right?

83
00:04:10.230 --> 00:04:13.460
If I come in here and take that
machine and I'm just gonna go and

84
00:04:13.460 --> 00:04:14.500
take a look at it's files.

85
00:04:14.500 --> 00:04:16.980
The files that are actually
a part of that machine.

86
00:04:18.610 --> 00:04:21.226
All right, so
looking inside of that virtual machine,

87
00:04:21.226 --> 00:04:23.239
I can start to see
the files that make it up.

88
00:04:23.239 --> 00:04:24.238
And so here's the disk, right.

89
00:04:24.238 --> 00:04:28.525
So I've got Virtual Disk-cl3-s001 and
so on.

90
00:04:28.525 --> 00:04:32.510
VMWare Fusion likes to break up
your disks into four gig files,

91
00:04:32.510 --> 00:04:36.050
so that when you copy to other files
systems they'll actually survive the copy.

92
00:04:36.050 --> 00:04:39.540
So this is my virtual hard drive and you
can see I've got files 1 through 16 and

93
00:04:39.540 --> 00:04:42.830
then the base file of the hard
drive itself right there,

94
00:04:42.830 --> 00:04:44.840
which is actually only 1 K in size,
very small.

95
00:04:44.840 --> 00:04:47.010
All right so
those are the files that I've got for it.

96
00:04:47.010 --> 00:04:50.450
And then as I look down
I've got an nvram file

97
00:04:50.450 --> 00:04:54.940
which is where the fake BIOS
is storing its configuration.

98
00:04:54.940 --> 00:04:58.160
I've got a vmx file,
that's the configuration for

99
00:04:58.160 --> 00:04:59.620
my virtual machine right.

100
00:04:59.620 --> 00:05:02.790
So do I have four gigs of ram or
two gigs of ram?

101
00:05:02.790 --> 00:05:05.230
Do I have two cores of CPU or one core?

102
00:05:05.230 --> 00:05:07.620
That's stored in the vmx file.

103
00:05:07.620 --> 00:05:09.890
And then I've got a lock file for
when it's running, and

104
00:05:09.890 --> 00:05:11.910
a few of the little files for
configuration.

105
00:05:11.910 --> 00:05:16.250
But when a machine is turned off, this vmx
file, that's my hardware configuration.

106
00:05:16.250 --> 00:05:20.880
And these vmdks,
that's my virtual machine disk, right?

107
00:05:20.880 --> 00:05:25.211
So if I take a snapshot of this machine
right now, it's gonna freeze the disk and

108
00:05:25.211 --> 00:05:29.752
it's gonna freeze the configuration as
they are right at this very moment, okay.

109
00:05:29.752 --> 00:05:32.983
So I'm gonna go back here and
I'm gonna take my virtual machine,

110
00:05:32.983 --> 00:05:34.231
this WIN-CLIENT01.

111
00:05:34.231 --> 00:05:36.715
And I'm gonna right-click on it and
go to Snapshots.

112
00:05:36.715 --> 00:05:41.138
And I'm gonna see all the snapshots
that I have right now, which are none.

113
00:05:41.138 --> 00:05:42.700
I don't have a single snapshot.

114
00:05:42.700 --> 00:05:44.720
All I have is the Current State.

115
00:05:44.720 --> 00:05:48.960
This is how the machine is right now,
at this very moment, okay.

116
00:05:48.960 --> 00:05:51.020
If I turn it on, that changes, right?

117
00:05:51.020 --> 00:05:52.330
Now it's how it is at that moment.

118
00:05:52.330 --> 00:05:53.520
So this is constantly changing.

119
00:05:53.520 --> 00:05:55.410
Current state is constantly changing.

120
00:05:55.410 --> 00:05:58.046
But I can go up here and I can hit
Take and I'm gonna take a snapshot.

121
00:05:58.046 --> 00:06:04.977
And so
maybe I call this Prior to Installing SP1.

122
00:06:04.977 --> 00:06:06.580
So I'm not seeing installed service pack.

123
00:06:06.580 --> 00:06:08.710
And so I'm gonna take a snapshot
of this thing right now.

124
00:06:09.800 --> 00:06:11.020
And so now I've got two.

125
00:06:11.020 --> 00:06:13.300
I've got prior to installing
the service pack, and

126
00:06:13.300 --> 00:06:15.080
I've got the current state, right.

127
00:06:15.080 --> 00:06:17.260
How the machine is, right now.

128
00:06:17.260 --> 00:06:20.100
Now let's go back and take a look at
those files and see what's changed.

129
00:06:20.100 --> 00:06:23.680
So if I go back to my files,

130
00:06:23.680 --> 00:06:27.250
what I should see is things
are a little bit different now, okay.

131
00:06:27.250 --> 00:06:31.264
Remember how I had my
virtual disk earlier and

132
00:06:31.264 --> 00:06:35.320
-s001 all the way through 16.vmdk.

133
00:06:35.320 --> 00:06:38.030
But now, I've got some extra
numbers thrown in there.

134
00:06:38.030 --> 00:06:39.105
All those files changed the name.

135
00:06:39.105 --> 00:06:42.450
This is my first snapshot,
right, so I took a snapshot.

136
00:06:42.450 --> 00:06:43.734
Those are now tied to that first snapshot.

137
00:06:43.734 --> 00:06:48.843
And then here's the disk
files without the 0001.

138
00:06:48.843 --> 00:06:53.858
So I've got snapshot files and
ones without 0001, right.

139
00:06:53.858 --> 00:06:55.400
These are the originals, okay.

140
00:06:55.400 --> 00:07:00.000
Notice how I've got 16 original files,
and I've got 16 snapshot files.

141
00:07:00.000 --> 00:07:05.060
When I look at the original files,
they're 4 gigs each, 4.25 gigs each.

142
00:07:05.060 --> 00:07:10.630
When I look at the snapshot files,
they're only 524 K each, they're empty.

143
00:07:10.630 --> 00:07:14.140
It created duplicate files that are empty.

144
00:07:14.140 --> 00:07:19.240
And as I make changes, the changes will
get written to these files, right.

145
00:07:19.240 --> 00:07:21.380
The changes won't get
written to the original.

146
00:07:21.380 --> 00:07:24.800
The originals will be preserved
in their original format so

147
00:07:24.800 --> 00:07:26.970
that I can roll back, all right.

148
00:07:26.970 --> 00:07:30.400
And then if I continue to look down,
there's my vmx file,

149
00:07:30.400 --> 00:07:32.340
my virtual hardware right?

150
00:07:32.340 --> 00:07:35.491
But the virtual hardware's also being
store as part at that snapshot.

151
00:07:35.491 --> 00:07:40.990
And so if I look right here,
WIN-CLIENT01-Snapshot.vmsn,

152
00:07:40.990 --> 00:07:46.780
that's defining the snapshot and
the hardware configuration.

153
00:07:46.780 --> 00:07:49.514
And it's considerably larger
than the actual config file.

154
00:07:49.514 --> 00:07:52.614
The actual config file was weighing
in at like four kilobytes in size.

155
00:07:52.614 --> 00:07:55.545
This one's 33 kilobytes, so
it's significantly bigger.

156
00:07:55.545 --> 00:07:57.642
But it's got a lot more information for
that snapshot.

157
00:07:57.642 --> 00:08:01.959
Now, if I boot the machine up and start
to change things, right, so let's, oops.

158
00:08:01.959 --> 00:08:03.399
Let's not take another snapshot.

159
00:08:03.399 --> 00:08:04.334
Let's just turn it on.

160
00:08:04.334 --> 00:08:09.405
So I'm gonna boot this machine up and as
it boots, I'm immediately making changes.

161
00:08:09.405 --> 00:08:12.820
Because Windows has a page file that
it updates, and a hibernation file,

162
00:08:12.820 --> 00:08:14.220
and temporary files.

163
00:08:14.220 --> 00:08:15.900
It writes during boot time.

164
00:08:15.900 --> 00:08:18.470
And so it's making changes already.

165
00:08:18.470 --> 00:08:21.920
But those changes aren't be written to
the original files they are being written

166
00:08:21.920 --> 00:08:23.880
to the snapshot files.

00:19:52.520 --> 00:19:55.310
not every product out there does.

391
00:19:55.310 --> 00:19:57.337
And so
if you don't have the agents installed for

392
00:19:57.337 --> 00:19:59.224
that you can end up with
some problems there.

393
00:19:59.224 --> 00:20:03.476
I think Virtual Box does too,
let me fire up Virtual Box.

394
00:20:03.476 --> 00:20:05.947
And, does it say it?

395
00:20:05.947 --> 00:20:07.677
Actually it's not calling it out here, but

396
00:20:07.677 --> 00:20:11.093
sometimes you'll see it like this where
we've got Hyper-V Paravirtualizaton where

397
00:20:11.093 --> 00:20:13.073
it will actually interact
with Lime Shadow Copy.

398
00:20:13.073 --> 00:20:14.711
Some of them do, some of them don't,

399
00:20:14.711 --> 00:20:18.297
definitely test it in your environment to
see if it works with your software because

400
00:20:18.297 --> 00:20:20.930
you don't want corrupt data
in your snapshots, all right.

401
00:20:20.930 --> 00:20:26.030
Now, all of these snapshots were taken
while the system was up and running, okay.

402
00:20:27.130 --> 00:20:29.290
So if I go over here and
take this virtual machine, and

403
00:20:29.290 --> 00:20:30.830
I'm just gonna shut it down, right.

404
00:20:31.960 --> 00:20:33.220
Shoot, what is it doing.

405
00:20:33.220 --> 00:20:34.220
Just cancel that.

406
00:20:34.220 --> 00:20:37.400
So I'm gonna go ahead and
shut it down, and wonderful,

407
00:20:37.400 --> 00:20:38.720
it's gonna apply some updates.

408
00:20:38.720 --> 00:20:40.133
Well I definitely want that, right.

409
00:20:40.133 --> 00:20:43.820
So I actually don't want the updates,
so maybe I'll do a hard shutdown.

410
00:20:43.820 --> 00:20:46.981
I'm gonna take the machine and
just yank its power, right.

411
00:20:46.981 --> 00:20:52.692
So let see, it's gonna make me shut down.

412
00:20:52.692 --> 00:20:54.410
It's still gonna do a graceful
shut down isn't it?

413
00:20:54.410 --> 00:20:57.190
Shoot, all right, well I'll let
it do its graceful shut down.

414
00:20:57.190 --> 00:21:02.194
And when it shuts down, it's gonna power
off, and the RAM is gonna empty out, okay.

415
00:21:02.194 --> 00:21:04.490
So the machine will be off, and
that will be the end of it.

416
00:21:04.490 --> 00:21:06.580
So in a second I should
see my big play button.

417
00:21:06.580 --> 00:21:07.360
There it is.

418
00:21:07.360 --> 00:21:08.780
And now I'm off.

419
00:21:08.780 --> 00:21:09.890
Well, if I go back here and

420
00:21:09.890 --> 00:21:15.160
I restore my snapshot, when I restore
it it's got what was in RAM also.

421
00:21:15.160 --> 00:21:17.520
So when I come in here and
restore that snapshot,

422
00:21:17.520 --> 00:21:19.950
I'm not going to say
what's going on right now.

423
00:21:19.950 --> 00:21:24.230
It's going to restore, and
then the machine is on again.

424
00:21:24.230 --> 00:21:26.054
And not only is it on, there's Notepad and

425
00:21:26.054 --> 00:21:29.565
there's my document I never saved in
the first place, that's coming out of RAM.

426
00:21:29.565 --> 00:21:32.560
And see how it's taking a longer time to
apply the snapshot because it's having to

427
00:21:32.560 --> 00:21:35.920
copy what it save from
RAM into actual RAM.

428
00:21:35.920 --> 00:21:39.250
And now it's here and I can start
working with this document again

429
00:21:39.250 --> 00:21:43.420
just like it never rebooted,
right, that's the cool part.

430
00:21:43.420 --> 00:21:45.480
But just remember that
RAMis taking up space.

431
00:21:45.480 --> 00:21:46.640
If I browse on my hard drive and
look at my system,

432
00:21:46.640 --> 00:21:50.870
I've got some snapshot files
again just like before, right.

433
00:21:50.870 --> 00:21:52.400
So here's those snapshot files for

434
00:21:52.400 --> 00:21:57.660
the disk, and we've got snapshot files
that are containing what was in memory.

435
00:21:57.660 --> 00:22:02.920
So if I look down here,
see these Snapshot3.vmem, Snapshot4.vmem.

436
00:22:02.920 --> 00:22:04.480
That's the virtual memory files.

437
00:22:04.480 --> 00:22:08.650
And if I look over here at the size
of those, 4.29 gigs, right.

438
00:22:08.650 --> 00:22:11.745
Because I've assigned four gigs of
memory to this virtual machine and

439
00:22:11.745 --> 00:22:14.007
it had to snapshot the whole
four gig file, right.

440
00:22:14.007 --> 00:22:16.690
Now some of that memory's empty,
so it writes that very fast.

441
00:22:16.690 --> 00:22:18.930
But some of the memory is full and
that's going to take a little longer so

442
00:22:18.930 --> 00:22:21.800
these snapshots are a little
more intensive, all right.

443
00:22:21.800 --> 00:22:24.070
So pretty neat little system there.

444
00:22:24.070 --> 00:22:27.060
We can take those snapshots and put them
in place, and they can save your bacon.

445
00:22:27.060 --> 00:22:28.610
They've saved me more than once.

446
00:22:28.610 --> 00:22:31.270
Something goes wrong, no big deal
I'll just roll back to snapshot.

447
00:22:31.270 --> 00:22:32.710
Problem solved, right.

448
00:22:32.710 --> 00:22:35.600
But there are a few other considerations
that we need to be aware of.

449
00:22:35.600 --> 00:22:39.190
There's some systems that do not
play well with snapshots, right.

450
00:22:39.190 --> 00:22:41.990
Microsoft Active Directory domain
controllers do not play well

451
00:22:41.990 --> 00:22:42.500
with snapshots.

452
00:22:42.500 --> 00:22:44.630
Don't use them on a domain controller.

453
00:22:44.630 --> 00:22:46.260
If a change occurs on a domain controller,

454
00:22:46.260 --> 00:22:48.460
it's replicated to other
domain controllers.

455
00:22:48.460 --> 00:22:50.840
And when you restore a snapshot,
it's like you took your DC and

456
00:22:50.840 --> 00:22:52.430
just rolled it back in time.

457
00:22:52.430 --> 00:22:55.280
And all the other domain controllers
out there, they're gonna

458
00:22:55.280 --> 00:22:58.800
see that happening and they're just gonna
push the changes back onto it and so

459
00:22:58.800 --> 00:23:00.530
you just lost the effect
of having that snapshot.

460
00:23:00.530 --> 00:23:03.800
There's not a whole lot of point
doing it on a domain controller.

461
00:23:03.800 --> 00:23:06.910
The other thing to think
about is that snapshots might

462
00:23:06.910 --> 00:23:09.750
at first look like a substitute for
backups.

463
00:23:09.750 --> 00:23:10.960
I don't need to back
up the server anymore,

464
00:23:10.960 --> 00:23:12.430
I'm gonna take a snap shot, right.

465
00:23:13.740 --> 00:23:15.540
Sort of, right.

466
00:23:15.540 --> 00:23:16.970
If I have a bad service pack,

467
00:23:16.970 --> 00:23:19.560
I can roll back to a snapshot instead of
going to my backup and doing a restore.

468
00:23:19.560 --> 00:23:22.280
So in that aspect, yes, it replaces it.

469
00:23:22.280 --> 00:23:24.870
But there's a few other problems,
like our physical hardware.

470
00:23:24.870 --> 00:23:27.230
Snapshots don't protect you
from physical hardware.

471
00:23:27.230 --> 00:23:29.460
Where's the snapshot file stored?

472
00:23:29.460 --> 00:23:33.090
Right in the same place as the regular
VHD, the regular virtual hard drive.

473
00:23:33.090 --> 00:23:35.650
So if I lose my virtual hard drive,
I lose the Snapshot too.

474
00:23:35.650 --> 00:23:36.800
So there's that.

475
00:23:36.800 --> 00:23:41.330
Also the snapshot is not a full complete
picture of the virtual machine.

476
00:23:41.330 --> 00:23:44.610
You need a snapshots in
addition to the regular drive

477
00:23:44.610 --> 00:23:47.220
to put them together to
get your current state.

478
00:23:47.220 --> 00:23:49.930
And so if you don't have both,
you can't recover.

479
00:23:49.930 --> 00:23:53.263
So snapshots are not a replacement for
backups.

480
00:23:53.263 --> 00:23:57.218
You still need to back up your virtual
machines, otherwise you're gonna run that

481
00:23:57.218 --> 00:24:00.590
risk of having a failure and
losing the machine as a whole.

482
00:24:00.590 --> 00:24:02.180
Don't stop running back ups.

483
00:24:02.180 --> 00:24:04.200
>> Yeah, and
just because we have the snapshots and

484
00:24:04.200 --> 00:24:05.880
not that we're saying don't use them.

485
00:24:05.880 --> 00:24:07.300
Obviously, we're saying use them.

486
00:24:07.300 --> 00:24:10.380
They are a great,
great feature for you to employ.

487
00:24:10.380 --> 00:24:15.030
Just you gotta know when and where
it's appropriate to employ snapshots.

488
00:24:15.030 --> 00:24:17.950
And as great as they are, if you're doing
it wrong, you're going to lose data,

489
00:24:17.950 --> 00:24:20.950
and then you're going to have that lovely,
what do you call that Don?

490
00:24:20.950 --> 00:24:23.985
A resumed generating event, RGE?

491
00:24:23.985 --> 00:24:24.640
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

492
00:24:24.640 --> 00:24:25.680
It's not a good thing.

493
00:24:25.680 --> 00:24:27.100
You don't want to lose that data.

494
00:24:27.100 --> 00:24:31.455
And on the exam, at CompTIA they
actually call out in the exam objectives

495
00:24:31.455 --> 00:24:34.100
file-based back up versus
image-based back up.

496
00:24:34.100 --> 00:24:36.276
So let me talk about that for a second.

497
00:24:36.276 --> 00:24:40.370
An image-based back up is where we
take an image of a virtual machine

498
00:24:40.370 --> 00:24:43.890
as it is right at that moment,
we just take an image of the whole thing,

499
00:24:43.890 --> 00:24:48.540
very similar to a snapshot, except the
image contains the whole machine, right?

500
00:24:48.540 --> 00:24:51.560
And then you can take them and
you can restore it wherever you want,

501
00:24:51.560 --> 00:24:53.720
you can import it back
into another system.

502
00:24:53.720 --> 00:24:57.576
Those image-based backups are really
nice cuz you can restore very,

503
00:24:57.576 --> 00:24:59.416
very quickly from them, right?

504
00:24:59.416 --> 00:25:03.700
But they take a long time to make because
you're imaging the entire machine, and

505
00:25:03.700 --> 00:25:05.590
if the machine is on while you do it,

506
00:25:05.590 --> 00:25:08.840
you run that risk of getting
corruptible data, right?

507
00:25:08.840 --> 00:25:11.610
So imag- based backups really
expect you to have the machine off.

508
00:25:11.610 --> 00:25:13.920
You power the machine off,
you take an image-based backup of it,

509
00:25:13.920 --> 00:25:15.650
then you can quickly
restore it anywhere else.

510
00:25:15.650 --> 00:25:17.690
You've got the whole thing right there.

511
00:25:17.690 --> 00:25:20.250
A file-based backup though.

512
00:25:21.270 --> 00:25:24.010
That's the one we run from inside
of the guest operating system.

513
00:25:24.010 --> 00:25:27.480
So in the guest OS, like Windows has
the Windows server backup utility, and

514
00:25:27.480 --> 00:25:29.480
you can use that to backup your files.

515
00:25:29.480 --> 00:25:33.950
In Linux you might run Bacula or
just rSync, or

516
00:25:33.950 --> 00:25:36.130
whatever it is you want to
do to back up your files.

517
00:25:36.130 --> 00:25:38.040
By doing that,
you're backing up individual files, and

518
00:25:38.040 --> 00:25:41.940
if you have some kind of disaster, you've
gotta reinstall your operating system,

519
00:25:41.940 --> 00:25:42.950
you gotta build that up,

520
00:25:42.950 --> 00:25:45.700
and then you can restore the backup
to get all your data back.

521
00:25:45.700 --> 00:25:49.060
It takes a lot more work, it's slower,
it takes longer to recover.

522
00:25:49.060 --> 00:25:52.140
But you don't have to turn the machine
off to do a file-based backup,

523
00:25:52.140 --> 00:25:55.280
you can do online backups,
you can do them regularly, routinely.

524
00:25:55.280 --> 00:25:57.270
And so, what I normally
recommend to people is that

525
00:25:57.270 --> 00:25:59.160
you do a mixture of the two.

526
00:25:59.160 --> 00:26:03.840
Maybe once a month you do an image-based
backup where you back up the whole server.

527
00:26:03.840 --> 00:26:07.950
And then every single day or even every
single hour, you do file-based backups.

528
00:26:07.950 --> 00:26:10.950
And that way when a disaster happens
you can take your image-based backup

529
00:26:10.950 --> 00:26:13.270
to get the server up and
running really quick and

530
00:26:13.270 --> 00:26:17.030
then you use your file-based backup to
restore the files that have changed,

531
00:26:17.030 --> 00:26:18.860
to get you right back up
to the point of failure.

532
00:26:18.860 --> 00:26:21.490
So, it's not a matter of picking
one technology over another one,

533
00:26:21.490 --> 00:26:22.970
although you certainly can.

534
00:26:22.970 --> 00:26:26.680
It's better to use them both and
get the best of both worlds.

535
00:26:26.680 --> 00:26:29.930
And for that image-based backup,
I don't necessarily need special software.

536
00:26:29.930 --> 00:26:30.520
I mean, you can.

537
00:26:30.520 --> 00:26:34.530
You can use Acronis True Image, which is
a great product, a Paragon Drive back up,

538
00:26:34.530 --> 00:26:35.750
I love that one.

539
00:26:35.750 --> 00:26:39.450
There's other vendors, Symantec Ghost,
I don't care for that one anymore.

540
00:26:39.450 --> 00:26:42.590
They used to be the go-to one,
yeah, and now not so much.

541
00:26:42.590 --> 00:26:45.010
Microsoft has Image X or
whatever they call it now,

542
00:26:45.010 --> 00:26:48.557
it's got of a different name now, so
you've got all these different other

543
00:26:48.557 --> 00:26:52.443
products that are out there that you can
use, but your virtualization platform,

544
00:26:52.443 --> 00:26:55.169
more than likely,
has functionality built into it too.

545
00:26:55.169 --> 00:26:57.540
They normally just call it import and
export though, right?

546
00:26:57.540 --> 00:27:01.260
So, like VMware Fusion,
if I get back to my little panel here,

547
00:27:02.740 --> 00:27:07.290
I could take a machine like this
Windows client and if you take it,

548
00:27:07.290 --> 00:27:09.430
you'll usually see like an export option.

549
00:27:09.430 --> 00:27:11.300
I've got creating a clone or a link clone.

550
00:27:11.300 --> 00:27:13.530
We talked about clones in another episode.

551
00:27:13.530 --> 00:27:18.160
I've got my snapshots, which is exciting,
but I"m not seeing an export option,

552
00:27:18.160 --> 00:27:20.180
which I could have swore that we had.

553
00:27:20.180 --> 00:27:21.080
Let me see if we've got.

554
00:27:21.080 --> 00:27:22.770
There's import.

555
00:27:22.770 --> 00:27:25.190
It may not support exporting.

556
00:27:25.190 --> 00:27:28.349
It's got this export to OVF,
which maybe because the machine is on,

557
00:27:28.349 --> 00:27:29.229
it's not giving.

558
00:27:29.229 --> 00:27:30.740
That's it.
It's the machine's on.

559
00:27:30.740 --> 00:27:32.620
So if I were to power off the machine, so

560
00:27:32.620 --> 00:27:35.300
like I've got this Windows
server here that's powered off.

561
00:27:35.300 --> 00:27:40.562
I can go up here to file and
under file I've got Export OVF, okay.

562
00:27:40.562 --> 00:27:44.309
An OVF is an open virtual machine
format file and what it does,

563
00:27:44.309 --> 00:27:47.930
is it lets you export your
virtual machine as a single file.

564
00:27:47.930 --> 00:27:50.900
It's the entire machine in this
configuration and then you go and

565
00:27:50.900 --> 00:27:56.870
import it and Citrix Xen Server,
KVM, VM Ware all support OVF's.

566
00:27:56.870 --> 00:28:00.840
So I could build a virtual machine here in
VM Ware Fusion, export it as an OVF and

567
00:28:00.840 --> 00:28:04.840
then go and import it into ESX, and
have it up and running in short order.

568
00:28:04.840 --> 00:28:06.860
But I could use that as
an image-based back up and

569
00:28:06.860 --> 00:28:08.810
I don't have to go buy third
party back up software.

570
00:28:08.810 --> 00:28:11.540
Third party software's nice but
I don't necessarily have to have it.

571
00:28:11.540 --> 00:28:12.630
I could use this.

572
00:28:12.630 --> 00:28:14.160
The export though does take some time.

573
00:28:14.160 --> 00:28:16.590
I can't schedule it like I could
with other backup software, so

574
00:28:16.590 --> 00:28:18.060
that might be a reason you go and
do it with another one.

575
00:28:18.060 --> 00:28:21.900
And then if I have a problem I can go to
any of my virtualization infrastructure,

576
00:28:21.900 --> 00:28:23.420
and I can choose to import.

577
00:28:23.420 --> 00:28:26.705
And I can specify that OVF file that was
generated, it will import the machine with

578
00:28:26.705 --> 00:28:30.840
this configuration, bring it online,
and now we're back in business.

579
00:28:30.840 --> 00:28:34.280
So that type of backup would
be an image-based backup.

580
00:28:34.280 --> 00:28:37.460
If I want a file-based backup,
it would depend on my guest OS.

581
00:28:37.460 --> 00:28:40.710
So whatever guest operating system it is
that I'm running, I'd go in there, I'd

582
00:28:40.710 --> 00:28:43.560
fire up the backup software in there and
do my backups just like a physical server.

583
00:28:43.560 --> 00:28:44.910
Really no different.

584
00:28:44.910 --> 00:28:46.680
And then, off to the races, right?

585
00:28:46.680 --> 00:28:51.310
So backups are important, snapshots
are not a replacement for backups.

586
00:28:51.310 --> 00:28:53.250
You really need to use both.

587
00:28:53.250 --> 00:28:55.730
And then, I can't emphasize this enough.

588
00:28:55.730 --> 00:28:56.880
When you're done with your snapshots,

589
00:28:56.880 --> 00:28:59.820
make sure you delete them cuz they
are hurting your performance.

590
00:28:59.820 --> 00:29:03.040
>> Yeah, it's a good way to get a call
into the office of the boss there.

591
00:29:03.040 --> 00:29:05.870
Gonna be like,
what is going on with these snapshots.

592
00:29:05.870 --> 00:29:06.780
You just start deleting.

593
00:29:06.780 --> 00:29:10.162
Not that I'm speaking from experience or
anything like that at all.

594
00:29:10.162 --> 00:29:11.060
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right Don,

595
00:29:11.060 --> 00:29:14.510
well we covered a lot of ground when
it comes to the Snapshots and backups.

596
00:29:14.510 --> 00:29:17.840
Is there anything else that
we need to go over as far as

597
00:29:17.840 --> 00:29:20.460
trying to maintain our data's
integrity in that way?

598
00:29:20.460 --> 00:29:22.630
>> I think that's really about it for
Snapshots.

599
00:29:22.630 --> 00:29:25.150
Obviously we've got a lot more storage
technologies that we're gonna get into.

600
00:29:25.150 --> 00:29:27.880
We have a whole section on storage
technology we'll get into later.

601
00:29:27.880 --> 00:29:29.620
But the snapshots
are pretty straightforward.

602
00:29:29.620 --> 00:29:30.520
They are a great technology.

603
00:29:30.520 --> 00:29:33.620
Don't be afraid to use them, just remember
to clean up your mess afterwards.

00:29:35.670 --> 00:29:39.690

00:29:39.690 --> 00:29:43.210
that is not only good for the exam,

We also thank you guys for watching.

00:29:44.710 --> 00:29:46.300
