episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain some of the foundational information that is needed when working with attached storage in a private cloud environment. They begin by going through the common attached storage solutions like Network Attached Storage(NAS), Direct Attached Storage(DAS), and Storage Area Networks(SAN). They also cover some of the protocols and media used to connect attached storage. This includes Fibre Channel Protocol(FPC), Fiber Channel over Internet Protocol(FPIC), and Fibre Channel over Ethernet.
episodes.title: Storage Configuration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.759 --> 00:00:12.375
All right.

3
00:00:12.375 --> 00:00:13.084
Greetings, everyone.

4
00:00:13.084 --> 00:00:17.010
Everyone and welcome to another
great episode of IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:17.010 --> 00:00:19.660
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

6
00:00:19.660 --> 00:00:23.650
well we are continuing on with
our Cloud+ series for CompTIA.

7
00:00:23.650 --> 00:00:25.680
Joining us yet again today is our mentor.

8
00:00:25.680 --> 00:00:26.915
You know, you love him.

9
00:00:26.915 --> 00:00:27.670
He is the man.

10
00:00:27.670 --> 00:00:28.735
Mr. Don Pezet.

11
00:00:28.735 --> 00:00:30.005
Don welcome to the show.

12
00:00:30.005 --> 00:00:32.585
>> Thank you for
the amazing intro as always, Daniel.

13
00:00:32.585 --> 00:00:34.020
>> I like to build you up.

14
00:00:34.020 --> 00:00:35.485
[LAUGH]
>> So we can all watch it fall.

15
00:00:35.485 --> 00:00:37.845
Ready to jump back into
the world of virtualization.

16
00:00:37.845 --> 00:00:41.105
And in this episode we're
gonna start tackling storage.

17
00:00:41.105 --> 00:00:44.655
And I know most of you guys have with
computers and service for quite some time.

18
00:00:44.655 --> 00:00:48.135
And so the idea of talking about
hard drives is somewhat boring.

19
00:00:48.135 --> 00:00:51.920
But in a virtualized
environment it is very,

20
00:00:51.920 --> 00:00:55.070
very common that you are gonna have a SAN,
a Storage Area Network.

21
00:00:55.070 --> 00:00:57.770
And for those of you that haven't
worked with SANs before I wanna

22
00:00:57.770 --> 00:01:01.450
take some time to explain, what is a SAN,
what it does, how they work.

23
00:01:01.450 --> 00:01:04.120
And some of the different components and
infrastructure we've gotta be aware of

24
00:01:04.120 --> 00:01:06.490
especially when deploying
in a virtual environment.

25
00:01:06.490 --> 00:01:08.460
So that's what this episode
is gonna be all about,

26
00:01:08.460 --> 00:01:10.910
just kinda figuring out those SANs and
how they work.

27
00:01:10.910 --> 00:01:12.940
>> That's right.
Everybody put your big boy, or

28
00:01:12.940 --> 00:01:16.150
big girl pants on today,
because SANs is where it's at.

29
00:01:16.150 --> 00:01:20.520
It is, just an industry standard inside
of any enterprise level system, so

30
00:01:20.520 --> 00:01:22.280
we're gonna have to work with them.

31
00:01:22.280 --> 00:01:26.335
But, that being said Don, they're not
the only like game in town SANs per se.

32
00:01:26.335 --> 00:01:28.435
There's some other types
of stories as well.

33
00:01:28.435 --> 00:01:29.935
>> Yeah you certainly
don't have to have them.

34
00:01:29.935 --> 00:01:32.745
You can always go with the original
type of storage and there's several

35
00:01:32.745 --> 00:01:35.260
middle grounds that you can go with
that all suck but they're there.

36
00:01:35.260 --> 00:01:37.715
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] That you can use.

37
00:01:37.715 --> 00:01:41.155
They are appropriate in some small
business type environments but

38
00:01:41.155 --> 00:01:42.205
in the enterprise world and

39
00:01:42.205 --> 00:01:45.075
large business world it's gonna
be about storage area networks.

40
00:01:45.075 --> 00:01:48.490
So let's talk a little about the old
solution, the old way of doing things.

41
00:01:48.490 --> 00:01:52.090
So, the old way of doing things was to use
what was called direct attached storage.

42
00:01:52.090 --> 00:01:55.750
And that's where if you had a server,
its storage was directly attached to it,

43
00:01:55.750 --> 00:01:57.702
much like my laptop here, right.

44
00:01:57.702 --> 00:01:59.980
So, I've got a drive
inside of my laptop and

45
00:01:59.980 --> 00:02:03.465
it's directly attached inside
the laptop and that's it.

46
00:02:03.465 --> 00:02:05.895
I have access to it,
nobody else does, all right.

47
00:02:05.895 --> 00:02:08.655
If somebody else wants access to
the storage inside of my laptop I have to

48
00:02:08.655 --> 00:02:10.855
share it over the network.

49
00:02:10.855 --> 00:02:13.590
And then they can browse to it over
the network and gain access to it.

50
00:02:13.590 --> 00:02:16.550
Then it's what's called
network attach storage right?

51
00:02:16.550 --> 00:02:19.320
So direct attach is plugged
directly into my system,

52
00:02:19.320 --> 00:02:22.310
network attached it's available
over the network right?

53
00:02:22.310 --> 00:02:25.050
So I've got a little diagram
kind of whipped up here and

54
00:02:25.050 --> 00:02:27.520
I've got four virtual machine hosts right.

55
00:02:27.520 --> 00:02:30.040
So VMHOST01 through 04.

56
00:02:30.040 --> 00:02:33.610
So let's say that these guys
are all running VMware ESX, or

57
00:02:33.610 --> 00:02:36.310
they're all running Hyper-V or
whatever product it is.

58
00:02:36.310 --> 00:02:39.530
And they've all got a terabyte
of storage each, so

59
00:02:39.530 --> 00:02:42.370
they've each got terabyte
drives directly attached.

60
00:02:42.370 --> 00:02:46.080
And I bring up a virtual machine
like this guy, VM WEB01.

61
00:02:46.080 --> 00:02:50.170
And VM WEB01 is right here on the direct
attached storage on VMHOST01.

62
00:02:50.170 --> 00:02:52.180
And it's running great.

63
00:02:52.180 --> 00:02:54.759
And then one day, VMHOST01 fails, right.

64
00:02:54.759 --> 00:02:56.730
Maybe it's not even a failure,

65
00:02:56.730 --> 00:03:00.350
maybe I need to reboot VMHOST01
to apply some updates.

66
00:03:00.350 --> 00:03:02.080
Let's go a little less nefarious here,

67
00:03:02.080 --> 00:03:04.500
something that we know is gonna
happen at least once a month.

68
00:03:04.500 --> 00:03:08.490
I need to update that host and
I've gotta reboot it.

69
00:03:08.490 --> 00:03:12.325
Well, if WEB01 is running right here
on the direct attached doors for

70
00:03:12.325 --> 00:03:15.160
VMHOST01 when I reboot it
what's gonna happen to WEB01?

71
00:03:15.160 --> 00:03:17.550
It's going to go offline,
I'm going to have to take it offline.

72
00:03:17.550 --> 00:03:22.308
Now, I can probably suspend the machine,
right, freeze it in time,

73
00:03:22.308 --> 00:03:25.547
reboot VMHOST01 and then unfreeze WEB01.

74
00:03:25.547 --> 00:03:28.730
And when you do that WEB01 won't
even realize that it went down.

75
00:03:28.730 --> 00:03:31.500
But, your end users will realize it went
down because it wont be available during

76
00:03:31.500 --> 00:03:32.910
that whole reboot.

77
00:03:32.910 --> 00:03:35.320
Wouldn't it be nice to say hey
I'm about to reboot VMHOST01, so

78
00:03:35.320 --> 00:03:40.030
let me just move WEB01 over to one
of these other servers, right?

79
00:03:40.030 --> 00:03:40.835
So I"ll just move it over here.

80
00:03:40.835 --> 00:03:43.640
And when we do that,
it's up and going, right.

81
00:03:43.640 --> 00:03:47.610
But the problem is,
the virtual hard drives are stored

82
00:03:47.610 --> 00:03:51.029
right here in this direct attach storage
that is only available on VMHOST01 and

83
00:03:51.029 --> 00:03:54.010
that's it like I described earlier.

84
00:03:54.010 --> 00:03:57.350
Now if I choose to make that
available on the network so

85
00:03:57.350 --> 00:04:00.590
that other people can get to it, then it
would be network attached storage, right.

86
00:04:00.590 --> 00:04:03.070
And network attached storage
looks something like this.

87
00:04:03.070 --> 00:04:08.310
Now I've got my hosts, and they're all
plugged into a switch, into a network.

88
00:04:08.310 --> 00:04:10.670
And so they can see each other's storage.

89
00:04:10.670 --> 00:04:14.440
But if I review VMHOST01,
what's going to happen with this storage?

90
00:04:14.440 --> 00:04:16.370
It's gonna go offline, doesn't
matter if it's on a network or not,

91
00:04:16.370 --> 00:04:18.600
when the machines rebooting,
I'm gonna lose that storage.

92
00:04:18.600 --> 00:04:23.630
So it doesn't quite work,
unless we buy something like a NAS.

93
00:04:23.630 --> 00:04:26.750
NAS is network attached
storage in a true form.

94
00:04:26.750 --> 00:04:28.740
It's not a server that's
doing other things,

95
00:04:28.740 --> 00:04:30.900
it's not running virtualization software.

96
00:04:30.900 --> 00:04:34.510
It's just a box with hard drives in it
that's plugged into the network that's

97
00:04:34.510 --> 00:04:36.750
visible as long as it's been turned on.

98
00:04:36.750 --> 00:04:41.140
And so, I could put my virtual hard drives
here on direct attach storage that's

99
00:04:41.140 --> 00:04:45.080
inside of the NAS and then everybody
could access it over the network.

100
00:04:45.080 --> 00:04:46.900
All right?
So that is an option that's out there and

101
00:04:46.900 --> 00:04:48.160
it's an inexpensive option.

102
00:04:48.160 --> 00:04:53.490
These NAS boxes, for network attach
storage like this you can get

103
00:04:53.490 --> 00:04:57.620
Buffalo TeraStations,
QNAP has some great stuff.

104
00:04:57.620 --> 00:05:00.970
There are several vendors out there
that make great network attached

105
00:05:00.970 --> 00:05:01.810
storage like this.

106
00:05:01.810 --> 00:05:05.080
And it's inexpensive, it's great for
small and medium businesses.

107
00:05:05.080 --> 00:05:08.290
Notice I didn't say larger enterprise,
why not?

108
00:05:08.290 --> 00:05:12.380
Well performance on a NAS
is not very good, right.

109
00:05:12.380 --> 00:05:15.380
When I'm reading and
writing from direct attached storage, so

110
00:05:15.380 --> 00:05:19.300
like in this example here when this VMHOST
is reading and writing through its direct

111
00:05:19.300 --> 00:05:24.300
attached storage that might be SCSI it
might be SATA, it might be IDE who knows.

112
00:05:24.300 --> 00:05:26.940
But it's probably SCSI or
SATA and it's able to right and

113
00:05:26.940 --> 00:05:30.750
write to this directly connected
storage and it works great.

114
00:05:30.750 --> 00:05:35.930
But the instant we bring the network
into the picture, I can't send SCSI or

115
00:05:35.930 --> 00:05:39.000
SATA over the network in its true form,
can I?

116
00:05:39.000 --> 00:05:41.160
No, it's an Ethernet-based network.

117
00:05:41.160 --> 00:05:45.420
And so I'm gonna have to either use
a different protocol altogether, or

118
00:05:45.420 --> 00:05:48.080
I'm gonna have to take SCSI or
SATA or whatever, and

119
00:05:48.080 --> 00:05:50.060
encapsulate it to travel over the network.

120
00:05:50.060 --> 00:05:53.680
Either way, I've gotta modify my
traffic to work on this network.

121
00:05:53.680 --> 00:05:55.520
And that modification takes time.

122
00:05:55.520 --> 00:05:59.080
Remember several episodes ago where
I talk about type two hypervisors and

123
00:05:59.080 --> 00:06:01.520
how they were bad because they had
to translate your hardware calls?

124
00:06:01.520 --> 00:06:04.570
Well, using network attach storage for
your virtual machine storage will

125
00:06:04.570 --> 00:06:07.070
also have to translate those calls and
hurt your performance.

126
00:06:08.090 --> 00:06:12.870
Stack on top of that that this network
is just your traditional, regular,

127
00:06:12.870 --> 00:06:14.650
run of the mill Ethernet network.

128
00:06:14.650 --> 00:06:16.100
It might be a gigabit network.

129
00:06:16.100 --> 00:06:17.860
Let's just say it's a gigabit network.

130
00:06:17.860 --> 00:06:22.480
Well, when you buy SATA drives these
days they're three, six gigabit drives.

131
00:06:22.480 --> 00:06:26.560
So now my drive has an access speed
that's higher than the network speed.

132
00:06:26.560 --> 00:06:29.980
I can't realize the full
potential of my disks, right?

133
00:06:29.980 --> 00:06:32.330
The network is slower than
the disks themselves and

134
00:06:32.330 --> 00:06:34.330
the network becomes the bottleneck.

135
00:06:34.330 --> 00:06:38.000
So, the other thing to think about is that
not only am I having to translate these

136
00:06:38.000 --> 00:06:41.140
calls, but this is just a run
of the mill network, right?

137
00:06:41.140 --> 00:06:44.810
If we look at the diagram again, this is
just a regular switch, Ethernet switch.

138
00:06:44.810 --> 00:06:47.580
I'm probably using TCPIP
to communicate here.

139
00:06:47.580 --> 00:06:52.120
This network attached storage, that might
be an Apple box doing Apple file protocol.

140
00:06:52.120 --> 00:06:55.900
It could be a Windows box using CIFS,

141
00:06:55.900 --> 00:07:00.270
the common internet file sharing, or
SMB, server message block technology.

142
00:07:00.270 --> 00:07:03.580
It could be a Unix box running NFS,
the network file system.

143
00:07:03.580 --> 00:07:06.250
But either way, it's all running
over a traditional network.

144
00:07:06.250 --> 00:07:08.980
Which means, the network could be used for
other things.

145
00:07:08.980 --> 00:07:13.260
might have,
Tom in accounting plugs in his laptop, and

146
00:07:13.260 --> 00:07:15.110
starts running bit torrents
out to the Internet, right.

147
00:07:15.110 --> 00:07:17.960
Or just starts doing other things,
checking his email, right.

148
00:07:17.960 --> 00:07:19.790
It doesn't necessarily
have to be something bad.

149
00:07:19.790 --> 00:07:22.430
But now Tom is using some
of that bandwidth and

150
00:07:22.430 --> 00:07:24.490
your servers are competing against it.

151
00:07:24.490 --> 00:07:27.785
Network attached storage does
not give you good performance.

152
00:07:27.785 --> 00:07:29.730
It's quick and easy storage so

153
00:07:29.730 --> 00:07:32.860
you can throw on a regular network
when you're on a shoestring budget.

154
00:07:32.860 --> 00:07:34.285
That's what it's designed for.

155
00:07:34.285 --> 00:07:36.080
It's not designed for performance.

156
00:07:36.080 --> 00:07:39.830
So you don't normally see this used for
hosting virtual machines.

157
00:07:39.830 --> 00:07:44.410
In fact, if you fire up something like
Citrix Xen server, Citrix Xen Server

158
00:07:44.410 --> 00:07:48.070
will let you mount network attached
storage to one of your VM hosts.

159
00:07:48.070 --> 00:07:50.909
But you can only use it to
store ISO images, right?

160
00:07:50.909 --> 00:07:54.369
Images of CDs, so you can boot computers
and install operating systems.

161
00:07:54.369 --> 00:07:55.648
The virtual hard drives for

162
00:07:55.648 --> 00:07:59.547
the VMs themselves aren't allowed to be
able to be stored on that network storage.

163
00:07:59.547 --> 00:08:03.614
They have to be stored either on
direct-attached storage or a true SAN,

164
00:08:03.614 --> 00:08:04.290
all right?

165
00:08:05.340 --> 00:08:07.965
And network-attached
storage is not a true SAN.

166
00:08:07.965 --> 00:08:09.690
It's just running over
the regular network.

167
00:08:09.690 --> 00:08:10.605
They're shared folders.

168
00:08:10.605 --> 00:08:13.374
It's really no different than
taking a Windows or Mac machine,

169
00:08:13.374 --> 00:08:15.799
creating a shared folder and
sharing it on the network.

170
00:08:15.799 --> 00:08:17.675
That's all a NAS does.

171
00:08:17.675 --> 00:08:21.139
It's not very sophisticated and
it's definitely not tuned for performance.

172
00:08:21.139 --> 00:08:25.790
>> Well, Don, we've got NASs, they're
great for when we need them, obviously.

173
00:08:25.790 --> 00:08:28.970
Is there anything else about them that
we need to know as far as, obviously,

174
00:08:28.970 --> 00:08:33.040
as you've been saying, they're meant for
a smaller or shoestring budget, just for

175
00:08:33.040 --> 00:08:35.970
a specific pointed purposes.

176
00:08:35.970 --> 00:08:39.270
Otherwise, we wanna go with the direct
access or, better yet, a SAN.

177
00:08:39.270 --> 00:08:41.310
>> Right, now there is a little
bit of a middle ground there.

178
00:08:41.310 --> 00:08:43.520
There are some NAS boxes,
like we have one here.

179
00:08:43.520 --> 00:08:45.968
It's, I don't know why I'm even looking
around, it's behind some wall here.

180
00:08:45.968 --> 00:08:46.826
>> [LAUGH] It's through the wall.

181
00:08:46.826 --> 00:08:49.607
[LAUGH]
>> We have a QNAP NAS here that we store

182
00:08:49.607 --> 00:08:50.915
a bunch of videos on.

183
00:08:50.915 --> 00:08:54.206
And QNAP, they're really good about
building a ton of extra features into

184
00:08:54.206 --> 00:08:55.000
their NAS boxes.

185
00:08:55.000 --> 00:08:57.186
They are just NAS boxes at
the end of the day, but

186
00:08:57.186 --> 00:08:59.785
it's got a lot of advanced
functionality in it.

187
00:08:59.785 --> 00:09:02.285
And it supports a technology called iSCSI.

188
00:09:02.285 --> 00:09:03.855
iSCSI is one you'll hear about a lot.

189
00:09:03.855 --> 00:09:06.515
And for those of you that are just
learning and getting into virtualization,

190
00:09:06.515 --> 00:09:10.245
you'll probably set up iSCSI yourself,
cuz it is a neat one to work with.

191
00:09:10.245 --> 00:09:12.525
You can create a fake SAN, right?

192
00:09:12.525 --> 00:09:15.655
And I'm being very clear there,
it's a fake SAN.

193
00:09:15.655 --> 00:09:20.200
You'll see a lot of vendors out there
that say, here's our iSCSI SAN solution.

194
00:09:20.200 --> 00:09:22.077
Because they don't want to say,
here's our iSCSI fake SAN solution.

195
00:09:22.077 --> 00:09:24.150
Well, that's what it is.

196
00:09:24.150 --> 00:09:29.130
iSCSI is a way where you can get cheap
NAS, cheap network-attached storage,

197
00:09:29.130 --> 00:09:32.630
plugged into your TCP/IP
based Ethernet network and

198
00:09:32.630 --> 00:09:35.730
it can look like a SAN and
it can act like a SAN.

199
00:09:35.730 --> 00:09:39.740
And you can push SCSI,
SCSI encapsulated over Ethernet,

200
00:09:39.740 --> 00:09:43.840
that's what iSCSI is, you can push
that over your regular network.

201
00:09:43.840 --> 00:09:47.840
But at the end of the day,
it's still your regular network.

202
00:09:47.840 --> 00:09:51.240
You're still taking a performance hit cuz
you're having to encapsulate your data.

203
00:09:51.240 --> 00:09:54.520
You're still taking a performance hit cuz
you're competing against everybody else on

204
00:09:54.520 --> 00:09:55.520
the network.

205
00:09:55.520 --> 00:09:59.460
And you're still taking a performance
hit because even if no one else is using

206
00:09:59.460 --> 00:10:03.710
the network,
TCP/IP itself has a lot of overhead.

207
00:10:03.710 --> 00:10:06.260
You have to generate checksums and
sequence numbers and

208
00:10:06.260 --> 00:10:09.060
things have to be broken
up into packets and frames.

209
00:10:09.060 --> 00:10:12.090
And that's stuff that SCSI
doesn't normally have to do.

210
00:10:12.090 --> 00:10:13.760
But now we're forcing it to do it.

211
00:10:13.760 --> 00:10:16.430
And we're going over a gigabit network,
maybe a ten gigabit network, but

212
00:10:16.430 --> 00:10:17.790
normally a gigabit network.

213
00:10:17.790 --> 00:10:19.660
And we're just not getting
those same performance levels.

214
00:10:19.660 --> 00:10:25.070
So iSCSI is a fake SAN, but
it looks a little more like a real SAN.

215
00:10:25.070 --> 00:10:28.120
So here we've got a,
I'm going to call it a SAN, right?

216
00:10:28.120 --> 00:10:32.440
And it's plugged into that regular
TCP/IP Ethernet based network.

217
00:10:32.440 --> 00:10:36.550
My servers connect up to it, VMHOST01
through 04, and they're able to store

218
00:10:36.550 --> 00:10:43.420
things like the hard drive for the WEB01
VM, and they can access and boot from it.

219
00:10:43.420 --> 00:10:47.501
Now, the cool part here is I could
have that virtual machine running

220
00:10:47.501 --> 00:10:48.656
from VMHOST01.

221
00:10:48.656 --> 00:10:52.013
And then if I need to
take VMHOST01 offline,

222
00:10:52.013 --> 00:10:56.770
I can just migrate WEB01 over
to one of these other hosts.

223
00:10:56.770 --> 00:11:00.240
And when I do that, it can jump over and
start running from that other host, and

224
00:11:00.240 --> 00:11:04.560
the other host can see the storage
right there on the iSCSI SAN.

225
00:11:04.560 --> 00:11:07.840
And it's doing it via
the Ethernet network,

226
00:11:07.840 --> 00:11:11.110
via your TCP/IP based network,
and it's just running it.

227
00:11:11.110 --> 00:11:15.440
All right, now, iSCSI was designed to
create test and development environments.

228
00:11:15.440 --> 00:11:17.270
I know some people who
are using it in production.

229
00:11:17.270 --> 00:11:18.930
You certainly can do that.

230
00:11:18.930 --> 00:11:20.790
I typically try not to, right?

231
00:11:20.790 --> 00:11:22.689
If you've got the budget to do a real SAN,
you need to do a real SAN.

232
00:11:22.689 --> 00:11:25.413
If you don't have the budget
to do a real SAN,

233
00:11:25.413 --> 00:11:29.216
you need to go to something like
Microsoft Azure or Amazon AWS,

234
00:11:29.216 --> 00:11:33.500
where you will be on a real SAN but
you don't have to pay for it, right?

235
00:11:33.500 --> 00:11:35.030
But iSCSI I use in test and

236
00:11:35.030 --> 00:11:37.850
dev environments, environments where
performance is not my primary concern.

237
00:11:37.850 --> 00:11:39.960
That's really where it has a good fit.

238
00:11:39.960 --> 00:11:43.220
But it is well established,
it's been around a long time.

239
00:11:43.220 --> 00:11:45.840
Let's say that you're watching this and
you say, well, that's great, Don, but

240
00:11:45.840 --> 00:11:47.660
I don't have that budget,
I gotta go iSCSI.

241
00:11:47.660 --> 00:11:50.030
There are some things you can do
to make iSCSI work better, right?

242
00:11:50.030 --> 00:11:51.720
So let me give you just a few tips.

243
00:11:51.720 --> 00:11:55.240
First off, create a dedicated
network just for iSCSI, right?

244
00:11:55.240 --> 00:11:58.300
Just because it supports TCP/IP and
it runs over a regular network

245
00:11:58.300 --> 00:12:00.830
doesn't mean you should put
it on the regular network.

246
00:12:00.830 --> 00:12:03.790
Get a dedicated switch,
run dedicated cables,

247
00:12:03.790 --> 00:12:06.510
have dedicated network cards in
your servers just for iSCSI.

248
00:12:06.510 --> 00:12:08.590
That'll help out a lot, all right?

249
00:12:08.590 --> 00:12:11.550
The second thing is don't just
buy any old network card.

250
00:12:11.550 --> 00:12:13.900
There's a lot of network
cards that are out there, but

251
00:12:13.900 --> 00:12:17.660
only some of them have
iSCSI support built in.

252
00:12:17.660 --> 00:12:21.057
If you go to Intel's website, they have
some Intel network adaptors that have

253
00:12:21.057 --> 00:12:22.916
iSCSI accelerators built into the board.

254
00:12:22.916 --> 00:12:25.476
That will help out a lot
with taking your iSCSI or

255
00:12:25.476 --> 00:12:29.572
taking regular SCSI communications and
encapsulating them for TCP/IP and

256
00:12:29.572 --> 00:12:33.092
de-encapsulating, unencapsulating,
whatever the word is,

257
00:12:33.092 --> 00:12:36.426
unwrapping the thing, and
bringing it back into the server.

258
00:12:36.426 --> 00:12:37.866
That'll make a big difference also.

259
00:12:37.866 --> 00:12:41.105
Okay, so dedicated switch,
dedicated network,

260
00:12:41.105 --> 00:12:44.310
special network cards
with iSCSI acceleration.

261
00:12:44.310 --> 00:12:45.120
Those three things,

262
00:12:45.120 --> 00:12:48.360
if you do that, you can actually
get iSCSI running pretty well.

263
00:12:48.360 --> 00:12:51.868
And so if you've only got 10 or
20 VMs running on a handful of hosts,

264
00:12:51.868 --> 00:12:54.720
iSCSI can actually work and
you could save a lot of money.

265
00:12:54.720 --> 00:12:55.960
But I don't like to do it.

266
00:12:55.960 --> 00:12:57.660
If I can avoid it, I'm not gonna do it.

267
00:12:57.660 --> 00:13:00.051
I'm gonna go with a true SAN,
a true fibre channel SAN.

268
00:13:00.051 --> 00:13:04.814
All right, now, that word that I just
said there, fibre channel, right?

269
00:13:04.814 --> 00:13:10.053
Fibre channel SANs are really
the standard in virtualization storage.

270
00:13:10.053 --> 00:13:13.520
We know with virtualization we want
shared storage between all of our hosts.

271
00:13:13.520 --> 00:13:17.470
We need our hosts to be able to see
that storage and share it, okay?

272
00:13:17.470 --> 00:13:17.979
But we need it to be fast.

273
00:13:17.979 --> 00:13:21.632
And preferably,
if we're talking to the drives using SCSI,

274
00:13:21.632 --> 00:13:23.750
we'd like to just keep using SCSI.

275
00:13:23.750 --> 00:13:26.830
And a fibre channel SAN
allows you to do that.

276
00:13:26.830 --> 00:13:28.330
All right, let me show you a diagram here.

277
00:13:28.330 --> 00:13:30.590
This is what a typical fibre
channel SAN looks like.

278
00:13:30.590 --> 00:13:32.040
We've got a SAN, right?

279
00:13:32.040 --> 00:13:34.140
It's a giant box that's got
a bunch of hard drives in it.

280
00:13:34.140 --> 00:13:36.420
It could have 144, it could have 250
hard drives, however many you need,

281
00:13:36.420 --> 00:13:38.880
it could have 8 hard drives, right?

282
00:13:38.880 --> 00:13:40.880
But it's got a bunch of hard drives in it.

283
00:13:40.880 --> 00:13:43.480
And in that SAN,
we're slicing up the storage

284
00:13:43.480 --> 00:13:47.310
to give out to our virtual machines and
virtual machine hosts.

285
00:13:47.310 --> 00:13:50.950
And it plugs into a switch,
but not just any old switch.

286
00:13:50.950 --> 00:13:55.000
This is a fiber optic switch
that is designed for SANs.

287
00:13:55.000 --> 00:14:00.720
It's not designed for TCP/IP and Ethernet,
it's designed for Fibre Channel Protocol.

288
00:14:00.720 --> 00:14:02.660
FCP, Fibre Channel Protocol.

289
00:14:02.660 --> 00:14:06.292
Fibre Channel Protocol allows us to
send SCSI traffic over the network,

290
00:14:06.292 --> 00:14:08.078
just regular SCSI, SCSI traffic,

291
00:14:08.078 --> 00:14:11.870
right over the network without
having to translate it, right?

292
00:14:11.870 --> 00:14:15.540
Really, really cool stuff there
because it acts like a switch

293
00:14:15.540 --> 00:14:19.850
without all the TCP/IP overhead and
as a result it can go much faster.

294
00:14:19.850 --> 00:14:23.594
The cheapest fibre channel switches that
you can get these days are 6 gigabit per

295
00:14:23.594 --> 00:14:24.590
port, right?

296
00:14:24.590 --> 00:14:27.300
But a lot of them are 8 or
even 12 gigabit per port.

297
00:14:27.300 --> 00:14:29.090
Notice that doesn't match
up with the Ethernet side.

298
00:14:29.090 --> 00:14:29.770
On the Ethernet side,

299
00:14:29.770 --> 00:14:34.400
we went from 10 megabit to 100
megabit to a gigabit to 10 gigabit.

300
00:14:34.400 --> 00:14:37.290
But on the fibre channel side,
they started at 2 gigabit,

301
00:14:37.290 --> 00:14:40.760
I guess there were some older ones, but
2 gigs is the smallest you'll see today.

302
00:14:40.760 --> 00:14:44.007
And then they went to 4 gig,
then 6 gig, then 8 gig, now 12 gig.

303
00:14:44.007 --> 00:14:46.410
I don't know why they skipped 10,
but they did.

304
00:14:46.410 --> 00:14:48.820
So you get these kind of intervals, and

305
00:14:48.820 --> 00:14:51.750
you buy the switch that has
the speed that you need it.

306
00:14:51.750 --> 00:14:56.703
And then on your servers, instead of using
a regular network card like you would with

307
00:14:56.703 --> 00:15:00.211
iSCSI, you use what's called an HBA,
a host bus adapter.

308
00:15:00.211 --> 00:15:03.190
And the host bus adapter looks
just like a network card.

309
00:15:03.190 --> 00:15:06.160
It looks like a network card
with a fiber jack on it.

310
00:15:06.160 --> 00:15:09.450
Except when you put it in, your computer
doesn't see it as a network card.

311
00:15:09.450 --> 00:15:11.450
It sees it as a hard drive controller.

312
00:15:11.450 --> 00:15:12.984
It thinks that it's a SCSI
hard drive controller.

313
00:15:12.984 --> 00:15:14.920
That's what it sees.

314
00:15:14.920 --> 00:15:19.180
It has no idea that it's actually plugging
into a fibre channel network, right?

315
00:15:19.180 --> 00:15:22.820
The fibre channel network is
normally called your switch fabric.

316
00:15:22.820 --> 00:15:27.270
So the fabric would be this network
that's created around it and

317
00:15:27.270 --> 00:15:29.090
the HPA plugs right into that fabric.

318
00:15:29.090 --> 00:15:32.914
They like to use the term fabric as
opposed to a network, because networks

319
00:15:32.914 --> 00:15:37.128
assume you have addressing and hosts and
management, but a fabric just exists.

320
00:15:37.128 --> 00:15:39.391
All these things run through it and
they all interconnect.

321
00:15:39.391 --> 00:15:43.400
So this would be running
to a dedicated connection.

322
00:15:43.400 --> 00:15:44.540
We'll still have networks, right?

323
00:15:44.540 --> 00:15:46.430
This blue line here,
that would be my regular network, and

324
00:15:46.430 --> 00:15:47.790
that would be a separate card, right?

325
00:15:47.790 --> 00:15:50.400
I kinda drew them close together here,
but that would be separate.

326
00:15:50.400 --> 00:15:52.496
And it would run to a network switch.

327
00:15:52.496 --> 00:15:54.747
So your network communications
happen on their own side.

328
00:15:54.747 --> 00:15:56.558
Your fibre channel network is separate.

329
00:15:56.558 --> 00:15:58.451
It's not suitable for
things like browsing the Internet.

330
00:15:58.451 --> 00:16:00.494
Cuz we're not running TCP/IP on it.

331
00:16:00.494 --> 00:16:03.268
You're running FCP,
Fibre Channel Protocol.

332
00:16:03.268 --> 00:16:05.660
There's actually a few different
protocols you can run, but

333
00:16:05.660 --> 00:16:07.610
Fibre Channel Protocol is the most common.

334
00:16:07.610 --> 00:16:11.060
>> So the only data that's running
across that Fiber Channel will be

335
00:16:11.060 --> 00:16:13.840
the VM data that's trying to
connect with the storage.

336
00:16:13.840 --> 00:16:15.780
>> Yep.
Storage, communications, and that's it.

337
00:16:15.780 --> 00:16:21.368
That's part of what a SAN brings us,
and having that true fibre channel SAN.

338
00:16:21.368 --> 00:16:25.030
Now, what Fibre Channel Protocol does,
what FCP does, is it allows you to

339
00:16:25.030 --> 00:16:28.650
take this communication and send it over
the line without having to translate it.

340
00:16:28.650 --> 00:16:30.520
And it does that by creating layers.

341
00:16:30.520 --> 00:16:33.640
And I've got just a quick
kind of chart here.

342
00:16:33.640 --> 00:16:35.300
In a Fibre Channel SAN,
you have five layers.

343
00:16:35.300 --> 00:16:37.990
Let me comment on one thing
that always bugged me.

344
00:16:37.990 --> 00:16:40.760
Notice how I wrote fibre, F-I-B-R-E.

345
00:16:40.760 --> 00:16:44.225
I'm not European,
I'm not feeling sophisticated today.

346
00:16:44.225 --> 00:16:46.230
You'll see this in real life.

347
00:16:46.230 --> 00:16:48.580
When people are talking
about the standard, right,

348
00:16:48.580 --> 00:16:54.740
about the protocol standard itself,
they'll write F-I-B-R-E, fibre like that.

349
00:16:54.740 --> 00:16:56.831
But when they're talking
about the actual media for

350
00:16:56.831 --> 00:17:00.221
communicating across like a fiber cable,
they'll write F-I-B-E-R, right.

351
00:17:00.221 --> 00:17:02.790
So a little bit of differentiation there,
one for the standard, one for

352
00:17:02.790 --> 00:17:04.540
the physical media.

353
00:17:04.540 --> 00:17:06.695
In real life, if you mix them up,
it's no big deal, nobody really cares.

354
00:17:06.695 --> 00:17:10.887
But if you ever wonder why you keep seeing
the two different spellings, that's why.

355
00:17:10.887 --> 00:17:12.770
Although it does give you
that European flair, so.

356
00:17:12.770 --> 00:17:13.699
>> It does that.

357
00:17:13.699 --> 00:17:14.858
>> Makes you seem smart.

358
00:17:14.858 --> 00:17:16.230
>> [INAUDIBLE] a shirt with big lapels.

359
00:17:16.230 --> 00:17:18.544
[LAUGH]
>> There you go, fashion forward.

360
00:17:18.544 --> 00:17:21.847
All right, so Fibre Channel Protocol,
it takes the communication and

361
00:17:21.847 --> 00:17:25.644
it breaks it up into five layers, right,
starting with FC0, fiber channel 0,

362
00:17:25.644 --> 00:17:26.706
all the way up to FC4.

363
00:17:26.706 --> 00:17:28.888
FC0 refers to the physical
interface itself.

364
00:17:28.888 --> 00:17:32.671
And on a regular system, it's normally
gonna be like an LC connector,

365
00:17:32.671 --> 00:17:35.590
just your fiber optic plug,
the really tiny one.

366
00:17:35.590 --> 00:17:36.260
That's what it's gonna be.

367
00:17:36.260 --> 00:17:38.900
But it could be something else,
it could be SC or ST,

368
00:17:38.900 --> 00:17:42.170
it could be a GBIC that you're
plugging into or whatever.

369
00:17:42.170 --> 00:17:43.972
But you'll have that physical interface.

370
00:17:43.972 --> 00:17:47.100
FC1, that's the encoding and decoding.

371
00:17:47.100 --> 00:17:49.940
When you're sending data to your SCSI bus,
it's electricity, right?

372
00:17:49.940 --> 00:17:53.097
And you're sending ones and
zeros over an electronic line.

373
00:17:53.097 --> 00:17:55.600
But when you hit the fiber,
it's light, right?

374
00:17:55.600 --> 00:17:58.600
We're doing light pulses to represent it,
so we've got to encode and decode and

375
00:17:58.600 --> 00:18:00.920
we've got to change our data to fit that.

376
00:18:00.920 --> 00:18:03.390
At FC2,
that's where we have our exchanges.

377
00:18:03.390 --> 00:18:05.950
And our exchanges, this is where we're
talking about things like our frames and

378
00:18:05.950 --> 00:18:07.130
our sequences.

379
00:18:07.130 --> 00:18:10.490
If I'm sending a collection of data
it's all in multiple frames and

380
00:18:10.490 --> 00:18:12.510
they have sequence numbers to
put them in the right order.

381
00:18:12.510 --> 00:18:15.210
And so that's what's happening there
at FC2 to make sure the exchange

382
00:18:15.210 --> 00:18:16.660
goes properly.

383
00:18:16.660 --> 00:18:19.040
At FC3,
that's where we have our common services.

384
00:18:19.040 --> 00:18:22.380
Things like multicast,
how we can find the SAN, and hunt groups,

385
00:18:22.380 --> 00:18:24.680
where if one SAN dies,
we look for the next one.

386
00:18:24.680 --> 00:18:26.320
Those technologies are there.

387
00:18:26.320 --> 00:18:28.330
But the most important layer is FC4.

388
00:18:28.330 --> 00:18:29.909
This is the application layer.

389
00:18:29.909 --> 00:18:32.507
And on a fibre channel SAN
using Fibre Channel Protocol,

390
00:18:32.507 --> 00:18:36.308
there's typically only one application
we really care about, and that's SCSI.

391
00:18:36.308 --> 00:18:38.522
SCSI runs as an application on top of it,
so

392
00:18:38.522 --> 00:18:42.828
we're able to send the SCSI communications
and these other layers help to make sure

393
00:18:42.828 --> 00:18:46.550
it gets to the right place without
us having to mess with it, right.

394
00:18:46.550 --> 00:18:49.050
We're not having to reencapsulate or
reencode or anything like that.

395
00:18:49.050 --> 00:18:52.890
It's designed to handle that traffic,
which means you get wire speeds.

396
00:18:52.890 --> 00:18:54.765
You actually get better than
wire speeds in some case,

397
00:18:54.765 --> 00:18:57.530
s cuz you've got an electric impulse.

398
00:18:57.530 --> 00:19:00.750
Technically, I read this somewhere,
in a vacuum with pure metals,

399
00:19:00.750 --> 00:19:03.590
the electrical impulse will cross
the line at the same speed as light.

400
00:19:03.590 --> 00:19:06.360
And so fiber and
copper are really no different.

401
00:19:06.360 --> 00:19:08.730
But the problem is, in real life,
you have impurities in copper.

402
00:19:08.730 --> 00:19:10.790
The length of the copper
degrades the signal.

403
00:19:10.790 --> 00:19:14.093
You have resistance and, impedance?

404
00:19:14.093 --> 00:19:15.327
>> Impedance.
>> [INAUDIBLE] Say it right now,

405
00:19:15.327 --> 00:19:15.858
impedance, and.

406
00:19:15.858 --> 00:19:17.410
>> [LAUGH]
>> And so you have these different

407
00:19:17.410 --> 00:19:20.716
things that cause that copper line to
not perform at the same level as fiber,

408
00:19:20.716 --> 00:19:22.989
whereas fiber still performs
at that same level, so

409
00:19:22.989 --> 00:19:26.740
you actually get better performance
than you would off of copper solutions.

410
00:19:26.740 --> 00:19:31.110
So when we have this in place, we get
a very reliable, scalable solution, and

411
00:19:31.110 --> 00:19:32.930
that's Fibre Channel Protocol, or FCP.

412
00:19:33.940 --> 00:19:38.070
It's really pretty powerful stuff,
it's also pretty expensive.

413
00:19:38.070 --> 00:19:41.420
With iSCSI, we use our traditional
network, and so regular switches,

414
00:19:41.420 --> 00:19:42.910
regular cables, regular stuff.

415
00:19:42.910 --> 00:19:45.690
It's slower, but it's cheap and
you probably already have it.

416
00:19:45.690 --> 00:19:48.707
You could deploy iSCSI right now without
having to go out and buy new hardware.

417
00:19:48.707 --> 00:19:52.274
But with a Fibre Channel SAN, you gotta
get a SAN that supports Fibre Channel,

418
00:19:52.274 --> 00:19:56.220
you gotta get a Fibre Channel switch,
at least one, probably more than one.

419
00:19:56.220 --> 00:19:57.970
You need to get fiber-optic cables.

420
00:19:57.970 --> 00:20:01.220
You need to get dedicated fibre HBAs,
not just fiber network cards,

421
00:20:01.220 --> 00:20:03.750
but fibre HBAs for each of your hosts.

422
00:20:03.750 --> 00:20:05.480
Each of your host machines
have to have that.

423
00:20:05.480 --> 00:20:08.250
And so all of that equipment adds up and
it gets expensive.

424
00:20:08.250 --> 00:20:12.264
And it's pretty rare that you'd get
a good Fibre Channel SAN deployment for

425
00:20:12.264 --> 00:20:14.155
less than like $50,000 US.

426
00:20:14.155 --> 00:20:15.351
It's a lot of money.

427
00:20:15.351 --> 00:20:17.420
If you're a small business,
you can't afford that.

428
00:20:17.420 --> 00:20:19.370
We don't have a Fibre Channel
here in the building with us.

429
00:20:19.370 --> 00:20:21.930
We also don't have a server,
so it makes sense.

430
00:20:21.930 --> 00:20:22.480
>> There's that.

431
00:20:22.480 --> 00:20:25.310
>> But even if we wanted to,
I'd probably go iSCSI here,

432
00:20:25.310 --> 00:20:29.520
because it would make sense, that with the
budget, with the systems that you have,

433
00:20:29.520 --> 00:20:31.440
with the resources you need,
that's what you've got.

434
00:20:31.440 --> 00:20:33.990
But if performance is your main concern,
you're gonna go fiber.

435
00:20:33.990 --> 00:20:37.308
And that's one of the big advantages
of going with Amazon Web Services, or

436
00:20:37.308 --> 00:20:40.361
Microsoft Azure, or Google Compute,
Rackspace, all those guys,

437
00:20:40.361 --> 00:20:44.225
is they've got massive Fibre Channel SANs
they've dumped millions of dollars into.

438
00:20:44.225 --> 00:20:47.410
Stuff that you couldn't afford yourself,
but you can use, right?

439
00:20:47.410 --> 00:20:50.830
You can rent, and tack onto it,
and really get those benefits.

440
00:20:50.830 --> 00:20:51.940
So that's what I always tell people.

441
00:20:51.940 --> 00:20:55.120
If you're at that in-between state, don't
do iSCSI, just send it up to the cloud,

442
00:20:55.120 --> 00:20:56.420
and that's exactly what we have done.

443
00:20:56.420 --> 00:20:58.720
The servers that we do have
are all up in the cloud, and

444
00:20:58.720 --> 00:21:00.740
they are running on Fibre Channel SANs.

445
00:21:00.740 --> 00:21:03.970
>> Now Don, you've talked about the FCP,
the Fibre Channel Protocol, but

446
00:21:03.970 --> 00:21:09.270
I've also heard of the FCIP, the Fibre
Channel over the Internet Protocol.

447
00:21:09.270 --> 00:21:11.140
And that's,
is that a little bit different,

448
00:21:11.140 --> 00:21:13.506
or, why would we want to use one or
the other?

449
00:21:13.506 --> 00:21:16.695
>> All right, so
the thing about Fibre Channel SANs,

450
00:21:16.695 --> 00:21:20.192
is they expect the SAN to be
right there beside systems.

451
00:21:20.192 --> 00:21:22.742
Right, so even in my diagram,
I've got servers, and

452
00:21:22.742 --> 00:21:25.500
they're plugged directly into this switch,
right.

453
00:21:25.500 --> 00:21:27.790
So I'm assuming a cable here.

454
00:21:27.790 --> 00:21:29.710
Now, how far can I run that cable?

455
00:21:29.710 --> 00:21:31.060
Well, fiber optic cable,

456
00:21:31.060 --> 00:21:33.580
you can actually run it a couple of
kilometers if you wanna go crazy.

457
00:21:33.580 --> 00:21:36.860
But the way this is implemented it's
expecting all the equipment to be

458
00:21:36.860 --> 00:21:38.410
right next to each other.

459
00:21:38.410 --> 00:21:41.000
But one thing that you learn in IT

460
00:21:41.000 --> 00:21:43.740
pretty quick is that no system
is completely reliable, so

461
00:21:43.740 --> 00:21:47.590
a lot of times you're going to want to
set up not one SAN but multiple SANs.

462
00:21:47.590 --> 00:21:50.332
So I might have a SAN here in my local
area network with a couple of nodes

463
00:21:50.332 --> 00:21:52.935
attached to it and that shared storage and
everything's great,

464
00:21:52.935 --> 00:21:55.380
but I might want to have
another SAN somewhere else.

465
00:21:55.380 --> 00:21:58.000
And so here I've got a SAN in
a separate location, right?

466
00:21:58.000 --> 00:22:02.282
So I have SAN 1 and SAN 2, and I've got
nodes over here and nodes on each side.

467
00:22:02.282 --> 00:22:06.860
This way, if one location completely dies,
the other location can be up and running.

468
00:22:06.860 --> 00:22:10.118
Well, I need to replicate
data between those SANs.

469
00:22:10.118 --> 00:22:13.394
And so a lot of the SANs that
are out like, if you get an EMC SAN,

470
00:22:13.394 --> 00:22:15.922
they support replicating
between each other.

471
00:22:15.922 --> 00:22:20.183
And they way they replicate is by
doing Fibre Channel over IP, FCIP.

472
00:22:20.183 --> 00:22:23.630
And that allows you to replicate
the data but at a performance hit.

473
00:22:23.630 --> 00:22:24.810
Obviously it's less bandwidth,

474
00:22:24.810 --> 00:22:28.490
there's more latency,
there's overhead from TCP/IP.

475
00:22:28.490 --> 00:22:29.990
So they don't stay in lockstep.

476
00:22:29.990 --> 00:22:32.770
It's not like the changes can
be instantaneously synchronized.

477
00:22:32.770 --> 00:22:35.481
If these two SANs were right next to
each other, I could plug them both into

478
00:22:35.481 --> 00:22:38.468
the same Fibre Channel switch, and I could
replicate data and do it in real time.

479
00:22:38.468 --> 00:22:41.400
When you write to one SAN,
you write to the other, and it's done.

480
00:22:41.400 --> 00:22:44.170
Cisco MDS switches have this really
cool feature that does that.

481
00:22:44.170 --> 00:22:46.170
It intercepts the writes, and
it just sends them two places.

482
00:22:46.170 --> 00:22:47.260
It's pretty awesome.

483
00:22:47.260 --> 00:22:51.570
So depending on the vendor of equipment
you have, you'll have different features.

484
00:22:51.570 --> 00:22:54.830
But when you replicate across a wide
area network like this, right,

485
00:22:54.830 --> 00:22:57.810
different geographic regions
are passing through a router,

486
00:22:57.810 --> 00:23:00.080
you need some way to route it,
and SCSI doesn't have routing.

487
00:23:00.080 --> 00:23:01.890
SCSI, you just see hard drives and
you write to them.

488
00:23:01.890 --> 00:23:04.350
There's no routing and
subnets or whatever.

489
00:23:04.350 --> 00:23:07.300
So we can use Fibre Channel
over IP to do it.

490
00:23:07.300 --> 00:23:11.541
And what FCIP does is it basically takes
the same stuff that we have here, but

491
00:23:11.541 --> 00:23:15.785
it takes Fibre Channel zero and
Fiber Channel one, these first two layers,

492
00:23:15.785 --> 00:23:18.058
and it replaces them with TCIP, right.

493
00:23:18.058 --> 00:23:20.554
So instead of encoding for
light or whatever,

494
00:23:20.554 --> 00:23:24.652
we're just gonna be breaking these up
into packets and frames for TCP/IP.

495
00:23:24.652 --> 00:23:27.512
And our physical interface,
that's gonna be our copper media or

496
00:23:27.512 --> 00:23:30.840
maybe even fiber optic media that
runs through an Ethernet network.

497
00:23:30.840 --> 00:23:33.130
So you get Ethernet combined with TCP/IP.

498
00:23:33.130 --> 00:23:37.623
But everything above it,
F2, F3, F4, FC 2, 3, and 4.

499
00:23:37.623 --> 00:23:38.610
They all stay the same.

500
00:23:38.610 --> 00:23:41.453
So you still have your regular exchanges,
your services, and your application,

501
00:23:41.453 --> 00:23:43.621
they're just being wrapped up
inside of TCP/IP, all right.

502
00:23:44.760 --> 00:23:46.940
But you're not really going to use this.

503
00:23:46.940 --> 00:23:49.408
Nobody uses this to say, I'm going to
connect this server to my SAN, and

504
00:23:49.408 --> 00:23:50.508
I'm going to use FCIP, right.

505
00:23:50.508 --> 00:23:52.453
Because at that point,
you might as well use iSCSI,

506
00:23:52.453 --> 00:23:53.923
it's gonna stink just as bad, right?

507
00:23:53.923 --> 00:23:58.264
So FCIP is really designed for
replicating in a multi-SAN environment.

508
00:23:58.264 --> 00:24:03.119
When you're replicating between different
geographical locations, because regular

509
00:24:03.119 --> 00:24:07.725
FCP can't be routed, FCIP can and because
it's leveraging the TCP/IP protocol.

510
00:24:07.725 --> 00:24:09.780
So, pretty neat stuff there.

511
00:24:09.780 --> 00:24:12.220
You know, I was able to tackle that and
kind of push it in place.

512
00:24:12.220 --> 00:24:15.550
Now this whole time I've been
talking about SCSI a lot, right?

513
00:24:15.550 --> 00:24:19.110
When you do fibre channel SANs,
they really do build all this off of SCSI.

514
00:24:19.110 --> 00:24:23.190
So you might have SATA, like Serial ATA,
you may have IDE, hopefully not, but

515
00:24:23.190 --> 00:24:24.310
maybe you do.

516
00:24:24.310 --> 00:24:27.140
Those technologies are still out there,
but they're not used on SANs, and

517
00:24:27.140 --> 00:24:30.780
it's because they don't, there's a couple
reasons, but the main thing is that they

518
00:24:30.780 --> 00:24:35.350
don't perform as well, and
they can't address as many drives, right?

519
00:24:35.350 --> 00:24:38.100
Remember on an IDE channel you can
only have two drives, a primary and

520
00:24:38.100 --> 00:24:39.160
a secondary.

521
00:24:39.160 --> 00:24:42.690
On a SATA channel you can only have
one drive, and that's it, right?

522
00:24:42.690 --> 00:24:47.185
But on SCSI, you can have, and I always
screw this up cuz of the reserve numbers,

523
00:24:47.185 --> 00:24:48.235
but it's like 15, or

524
00:24:48.235 --> 00:24:52.335
14 drives on a single SCSI channel,
so you can address a lot more drives.

525
00:24:52.335 --> 00:24:54.755
And on a SAN, you're creating
a bunch of virtual drives, and

526
00:24:54.755 --> 00:24:56.305
you really need to be
able to address that.

527
00:24:56.305 --> 00:24:59.248
When you're talking about direct attach
doors, how many hard drives are you really

528
00:24:59.248 --> 00:25:01.121
gonna have in one server
with direct attach storage?

529
00:25:01.121 --> 00:25:02.503
Not that many.

530
00:25:02.503 --> 00:25:06.643
But when you do a SAN, and you've got
a rack of 250 drives, or maybe you've got

531
00:25:06.643 --> 00:25:10.585
three of these racks, you've got
over 700 drives in there, right?

532
00:25:10.585 --> 00:25:12.910
You're slicing out drives,
creating virtual drives.

533
00:25:12.910 --> 00:25:17.220
You might have a 100 virtual drives and
trying to address that with IDE would

534
00:25:17.220 --> 00:25:19.779
be pretty hard, so
that's why they do it with SCSI.

535
00:25:19.779 --> 00:25:22.640
You get better performance,
it's a well support protocol,

536
00:25:22.640 --> 00:25:24.090
it's gonna be around a long time.

537
00:25:24.090 --> 00:25:26.670
But that's basically
the way that it works and

538
00:25:26.670 --> 00:25:29.250
fibre channel is just a great
way to communicate that.

539
00:25:29.250 --> 00:25:32.980
Now, on the switch side, there's a couple
of big vendors that are out there.

540
00:25:32.980 --> 00:25:37.180
Cisco has a big stake in it with their
MDS switches, you also have Brocade,

541
00:25:37.180 --> 00:25:39.040
which is one of the bigger
ones that are out there.

542
00:25:39.040 --> 00:25:42.370
There's a few other vendors that have kind
of come and gone, and they get acquired,

543
00:25:42.370 --> 00:25:45.320
like EMC or Dell will buy one,
HP will buy one, so

544
00:25:45.320 --> 00:25:48.980
you'll find a lot of people that have
their own house brand of switches.

545
00:25:48.980 --> 00:25:50.630
At the end of the day it
comes down to features.

546
00:25:50.630 --> 00:25:52.520
And I know I'm short on
time in this episode.

547
00:25:52.520 --> 00:25:55.040
I have some other features I wanna
talk about like LUN masking and

548
00:25:55.040 --> 00:25:59.920
stuff that we'll have to get into in the
next episode, but when you buy the switch,

549
00:25:59.920 --> 00:26:02.510
the base functionality is the same
no matter what vendor it is.

550
00:26:02.510 --> 00:26:04.286
But you've gotta pay
attention to throughput.

551
00:26:04.286 --> 00:26:07.987
The more systems you connect,
the more throughput you need, and

552
00:26:07.987 --> 00:26:10.352
you can exceed what your SAN has, right?

553
00:26:10.352 --> 00:26:12.372
And then after that you
worry about features, right?

554
00:26:12.372 --> 00:26:14.856
Do I get these bells and whistles, or do I
get those bells and whistles or whatever?

555
00:26:14.856 --> 00:26:16.720
But throughput is key.

556
00:26:16.720 --> 00:26:19.230
And I didn't really show it in my diagram.

557
00:26:19.230 --> 00:26:22.420
I should update this, but
notice how each server here

558
00:26:22.420 --> 00:26:25.550
has a dedicated link that's
running down to this switch.

559
00:26:25.550 --> 00:26:28.590
If I want redundancy, I really need
two switches, and two links so

560
00:26:28.590 --> 00:26:33.070
they have, what's called multipathing,
or MPIO, multi path input output, so

561
00:26:33.070 --> 00:26:36.790
that they can get to the network, or get
to the SAN, through two different paths.

562
00:26:36.790 --> 00:26:39.060
If one path fails,
the other one's still up.

563
00:26:39.060 --> 00:26:41.010
But your SAN needs the same thing.

564
00:26:41.010 --> 00:26:44.440
So when you buy a storage area network,
it's normally gonna have two, or sometimes

565
00:26:44.440 --> 00:26:48.050
four connectors on the back to be able
to run the switches to increase your

566
00:26:48.050 --> 00:26:52.470
bandwidth and increase your redundancy,
and you can really take advantage of that.

567
00:26:52.470 --> 00:26:53.920
That way if you have a link failure,
you're safe.

568
00:26:53.920 --> 00:26:57.769
There's a lot of other bells and whistles
that are out there, but if the server,

569
00:26:57.769 --> 00:27:01.110
if the SAN only has one connector,
and a server has one connector, and

570
00:27:01.110 --> 00:27:04.693
that server is running at 100%,
now your SAN's running at 100%.

571
00:27:04.693 --> 00:27:08.440
What about these other three servers?

572
00:27:08.440 --> 00:27:09.910
They're out of luck, right?

573
00:27:09.910 --> 00:27:12.870
So if I'm going to be hooking four servers
up, I've got to make sure that I've got

574
00:27:12.870 --> 00:27:15.470
the throughput to the SAN
to be able to handle that.

575
00:27:15.470 --> 00:27:19.910
And so, I might want to limit the disk IO
allowed from each server to correct for

576
00:27:19.910 --> 00:27:23.690
that to create balance, or I can just
let it go and see how it works out.

577
00:27:23.690 --> 00:27:26.620
But you can oversubscribe the bandwidth
on your stand pretty easy.

578
00:27:26.620 --> 00:27:30.640
So, instead of having one SAN
with 750 drives, you might choose

579
00:27:30.640 --> 00:27:35.580
to have three SANs with 250 drives each to
handle that throughput and performance.

580
00:27:35.580 --> 00:27:38.690
So that's all a part of sizing
the solution for your environment, and

581
00:27:38.690 --> 00:27:40.700
it's stuff you'll have to think
about when you implement a SAN.

582
00:27:40.700 --> 00:27:44.890
>> Yeah, well obviously SANs are not
a child's play thing, it is definitely

583
00:27:44.890 --> 00:27:48.300
a more complex type of technology that
we need to wrap our heads around.

584
00:27:48.300 --> 00:27:51.930
But Don, you've done a great job of
at least explaining what a SAN is and

585
00:27:51.930 --> 00:27:56.110
kind of how SANs work, so
that we can go into the next step, which

586
00:27:56.110 --> 00:27:59.070
obviously we have a whole lot more we need
to speak about when it comes to SANs.

587
00:27:59.070 --> 00:28:01.940
Well, I guess we'll have to do
a Part 2 on this, look for it.

588
00:28:01.940 --> 00:28:06.460
Any parting words of wisdom so
far as this episode goes?

589
00:28:06.460 --> 00:28:08.720
>> Just that if you're wondering
about security this whole time,

590
00:28:08.720 --> 00:28:11.220
we really didn't address security at all,
we'll do that in part two.

591
00:28:11.220 --> 00:28:14.260
We need to talk about that because you
have, with direct attached storage,

592
00:28:14.260 --> 00:28:17.660
a hard drive's attached to one server,
so it's got exclusive access.

593
00:28:17.660 --> 00:28:20.620
But when it's attached to a SAN,
technically more than one server has

594
00:28:20.620 --> 00:28:22.960
access and you have some risks,
some issues there.

595
00:28:22.960 --> 00:28:25.840
We'll talk about those, how to address
them, how to fix them in the next part.

596
00:28:25.840 --> 00:28:26.990
>> All right, Don,
well thank you so much, and

597
00:28:26.990 --> 00:28:28.032
I look forward to seeing you in part two.

598
00:28:28.032 --> 00:28:30.969
We look forward to seeing everybody
out there in part two as well.

599
00:28:30.969 --> 00:28:33.297
This is really good content,
but as for this episode goes,

600
00:28:33.297 --> 00:28:34.750
we're gonna go ahead and wrap it up.

601
00:28:34.750 --> 00:28:35.910
Signing off for ITPRO TV,

602
00:28:35.910 --> 00:28:38.045
I've been your host Daniel Lowery
>> And i'm Don Pizzette.

603
00:28:38.045 --> 00:28:38.940
>> And we'll see you next time.

604
00:28:38.940 --> 00:28:48.280

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don go over the common storage media, or drives, that you will work with when using a Storage Area Network(SAN) device. First they explain the different disk types. This includes SSD, spinning, USB, and tape. Then they cover the different connectors and data transfer speed for SATA and SAS. Finally they discuss tiering which allows you to use a variety of drives while optimizing storage through policies.
episodes.title: Storage Media

I wanted to cover that went well

In this episode, we're gonna focus

18
00:00:57.960 --> 00:01:00.950
Whether you have direct attached storage,
or network attached storage or

19

a storage area network, any of those.

You're gonna have physical
hard drives in them and

the drives that you select are important

So we're gonna talk a little bit about the
different drives that are available out

00:01:12.860 --> 00:01:16.250
there, and some of the things we

24

>> Well I'm very impressed with Don's
ability to skirt the fact that's

25

he's just very verbose [LAUGH].

>> [LAUGH]
>> Well we were gonna do a part two, but

[SOUND] this is really another episode.

29

>> That's right, but the good thing is

31

And knowing how these disks work is going
to be something that will benefit you

as someone who has to

33

So Don, let's just jump right in with both

34
00:01:41.980 --> 00:01:44.720
>> All right, so
when you buy a storage appliance, and

35
00:01:44.720 --> 00:01:48.340
really it's going to be anything
whether it's a true SAN or

36
00:01:48.340 --> 00:01:50.950
whether it's the cheapest
naz out there on the street.

37
00:01:50.950 --> 00:01:52.860
You're gonna have some choices
you're gonna have to make as far as

38
00:01:52.860 --> 00:01:54.390
the drives that go inside of it.

39
00:01:54.390 --> 00:01:56.080
And you've gotta be really careful.

40
00:01:56.080 --> 00:01:58.840
You could go on Amazon, or
New Egg or somewhere like that and

41
00:01:58.840 --> 00:02:00.500
buy the cheapest drives you can find.

42
00:02:00.500 --> 00:02:03.230
But not all drives are created equal.

43
00:02:03.230 --> 00:02:06.750
You'll find that in a storage appliance,
in a SAN or

44
00:02:06.750 --> 00:02:10.760
a NAS, the hard drives
are spinning 24 hours a day,

45
00:02:10.760 --> 00:02:15.630
7 days a weeks, 365 days a year, most
hard drives aren't designed to do that.

46
00:02:15.630 --> 00:02:19.770
Most of them are designed for laptops and
desktops, where they spin for

47
00:02:19.770 --> 00:02:21.980
a while while you're using the machine,
and then you turn the machine off and

48
00:02:21.980 --> 00:02:26.890
they're at rest, constantly being turned
on and off, on and off, and over time,

49
00:02:26.890 --> 00:02:29.470
they're designed to handle that so
they're okay with it, it's no big deal,

50
00:02:29.470 --> 00:02:32.520
even on a desktop that you leave on all
the time, your computer goes to sleep or

51
00:02:32.520 --> 00:02:35.350
the hard drives themselves
will power down to save power.

52
00:02:35.350 --> 00:02:38.360
And that's what they're designed for,
not running 24 7.

53
00:02:38.360 --> 00:02:41.000
But in a SAN you need that
storage available all the time,

54
00:02:41.000 --> 00:02:45.040
because if the storage goes offline,
what happens to your virtual machines?

55
00:02:45.040 --> 00:02:46.910
They go offline and
you don't want that, right.

56
00:02:46.910 --> 00:02:48.500
We need reliable storage.

00:25:31.710 --> 00:25:32.690
They've built the back

501
00:25:32.690 --> 00:25:35.460
planes to be able to handle
the maximum traffic and throughput.

502
00:25:35.460 --> 00:25:38.398
So if you have 15 drives and
it supports 12 gig SAS,

503
00:25:38.398 --> 00:25:43.132
it'll have a back plane that supports
whatever 15 times 12 is, and

504
00:25:43.132 --> 00:25:47.060
[LAUGH] so they'll support that and you'll
have that bandwidth on the back end.

505
00:25:47.060 --> 00:25:50.100
So I think it's what,
over 180 gigabytes or something.

506
00:25:50.100 --> 00:25:53.120
So you'll have that access, they've
planned for it, they've designed it, and

507
00:25:53.120 --> 00:25:54.490
it's set to cover it, right?

508
00:25:54.490 --> 00:25:57.713
But these are all considerations we have
to make when we go to set up one of these

509
00:25:57.713 --> 00:25:58.662
SANs and what we need.

510
00:25:58.662 --> 00:25:59.930
>> Yeah, Don, quick question.

511
00:25:59.930 --> 00:26:03.740
You were talking about the tiering and
my mind was wandering off on about that.

512
00:26:03.740 --> 00:26:07.052
How does it know, how does the SAN
know this is critical data,

513
00:26:07.052 --> 00:26:11.890
this is not as critical data and this low
priority data so they can do that tiering?

514
00:26:11.890 --> 00:26:13.680
>> So by default,

515
00:26:13.680 --> 00:26:17.620
most of the devices that do it will
do it just based on access, right?

516
00:26:17.620 --> 00:26:20.380
What's being accessed frequently,
what's not being accessed frequently.

517
00:26:20.380 --> 00:26:23.740
But they usually support what's
called a tiering policy.

518
00:26:23.740 --> 00:26:27.020
And with the tiering policy, you can go in
and you can define what you want it to be.

519
00:26:27.020 --> 00:26:28.330
So, for example,

520
00:26:28.330 --> 00:26:31.920
let's say that you've got a SAN that's
powered by Windows Storage Spaces, right.

521
00:26:31.920 --> 00:26:35.140
So you can get an EMC SAN that's
powered by Windows Storage Spaces.

522
00:26:35.140 --> 00:26:39.640
And in Windows Storage Spaces
you can write a policy that says

523
00:26:39.640 --> 00:26:42.370
if I tag a document,
because you have document tags,

524
00:26:42.370 --> 00:26:46.840
if I tag a document as top secret,
right, I want that to be high tier.

525
00:26:46.840 --> 00:26:50.280
But if I tag it as archive,
then put it in low tier.

526
00:26:50.280 --> 00:26:53.090
And so you can start tagging your
own documents with the metadata of

527
00:26:53.090 --> 00:26:56.130
the documents and the SAN can read
that metadata and make a decision.

528
00:26:56.130 --> 00:26:57.980
It's all based on that.

529
00:26:57.980 --> 00:27:00.560
It's kind of up to you how
you want to set that up and

530
00:27:00.560 --> 00:27:02.510
if you want those resources in there.

531
00:27:02.510 --> 00:27:05.710
I'm trying to double check real quick and
see if I can show you guys this.

532
00:27:05.710 --> 00:27:08.410
I've got a little EMC SAN pulled up here.

533
00:27:08.410 --> 00:27:12.087
Let me show you guys.

534
00:27:12.087 --> 00:27:12.887
We can see it.

535
00:27:12.887 --> 00:27:14.567
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm confident that we can see this.

536
00:27:14.567 --> 00:27:19.470
So, in this SAN, we've actually got
a mixture of SAS and SATA discs.

537
00:27:19.470 --> 00:27:21.600
So we've got tiered storage,

538
00:27:21.600 --> 00:27:25.290
different levels of discs kind
of buried inside of this thing.

539
00:27:25.290 --> 00:27:29.920
So if I go up into my storage, and
inside of storage I'm gonna down into

540
00:27:29.920 --> 00:27:33.970
my storage configuration,
I'm gonna go into my storage pools.

541
00:27:33.970 --> 00:27:37.050
So, right here inside of my storage
pool I've got a pool that's just called

542
00:27:37.050 --> 00:27:40.110
MultiTier and
you see it's got 10 TB of space.

543
00:27:40.110 --> 00:27:41.702
I'm currently using 1 TB of it.

544
00:27:41.702 --> 00:27:47.980
So, this is my kinda storage as
I've got it right now, all right?

545
00:27:47.980 --> 00:27:52.960
And if I pull up its details,
let's get into that.

546
00:27:52.960 --> 00:27:57.690
So here's my multitier pool details,
and I go into Disks.

547
00:27:57.690 --> 00:27:59.400
Here's my disks, okay?

548
00:27:59.400 --> 00:28:02.080
And looking as the disks,
actually, I lied, didn't I?

549
00:28:02.080 --> 00:28:04.150
It's all SAS on this one.

550
00:28:04.150 --> 00:28:07.670
So we've got some disks in here,
just different levels of disks, though.

551
00:28:07.670 --> 00:28:11.730
Some are higher quality than others, but
basically we've got these SAS disks right

552
00:28:11.730 --> 00:28:16.710
across, and notice how some of them
are 1.8 terabyte and some are 820 gigs,

553
00:28:16.710 --> 00:28:19.590
so just different kind of
levels of quality disk.

554
00:28:19.590 --> 00:28:22.540
And here's the difference, I knew
there was a difference of some sort.

555
00:28:22.540 --> 00:28:26.930
The top ones are 7,200 RPM,
the bottom ones are 10,000 RPM, so

556
00:28:26.930 --> 00:28:29.610
I've got slower and faster disks.

557
00:28:29.610 --> 00:28:33.130
And so I want critical data to be
on these faster disks down here.

558
00:28:33.130 --> 00:28:36.210
And I want non-critical data to
be on these slower disks up here.

559
00:28:36.210 --> 00:28:38.320
Now, if I just leave
it at the defaults and

560
00:28:38.320 --> 00:28:41.110
EMC SAN is actually set to just
monitor for data activity.

561
00:28:41.110 --> 00:28:44.300
And so, if it's frequently accessed data
it'll try and transition it down to these

562
00:28:44.300 --> 00:28:48.260
disks and if it's infrequently accessed
data it'll move it up to these disks and

563
00:28:48.260 --> 00:28:50.480
it can move and react based on our needs.

564
00:28:51.650 --> 00:28:55.230
Or I can go up here to
what's called FAST VP.

565
00:28:55.230 --> 00:28:57.430
Now, that's just EMC's name, right, so

566
00:28:57.430 --> 00:29:00.420
your software may have
a completely different name.

567
00:29:00.420 --> 00:29:03.870
Microsoft actually calls
them storage tier policies.

568
00:29:03.870 --> 00:29:06.430
Anyhow, they all have different names for
it, but at the end of the day,

569
00:29:06.430 --> 00:29:07.630
it's just a policy.

570
00:29:07.630 --> 00:29:12.440
And you come in here, and you define how
you want that relocation to occur and

571
00:29:12.440 --> 00:29:14.380
what those categories are.

572
00:29:14.380 --> 00:29:18.930
And so notice down here we've got this
performance tier and capacity tier.

573
00:29:18.930 --> 00:29:22.180
Performance tier,
that's the high speed, the good stuff.

574
00:29:22.180 --> 00:29:23.800
Capacity tier, that's the low side.

575
00:29:23.800 --> 00:29:26.930
And we set how much data we
want to allow it to move.

576
00:29:26.930 --> 00:29:29.090
And actually, it looks like I've got
it disabled right now which just

577
00:29:29.090 --> 00:29:30.910
kind of defeats the whole purpose.

578
00:29:30.910 --> 00:29:35.565
But you can set how many gigs you want to
move over to one side versus the other and

579
00:29:35.565 --> 00:29:40.120
kinda allocate that and
how closely you want to rebalance and

580
00:29:40.120 --> 00:29:40.980
how much space you've got.

581
00:29:40.980 --> 00:29:43.130
You can see all of that
laid out right here.

582
00:29:43.130 --> 00:29:48.700
And if you look at mine, notice how my
performance tier has 1.2 terabytes used.

583
00:29:48.700 --> 00:29:50.060
I've got 2 terabytes free.

584
00:29:50.060 --> 00:29:53.260
My lower tier isn't used at all.

585
00:29:53.260 --> 00:29:56.880
It's gonna write everything to the high
performance tier until it's full and

586
00:29:56.880 --> 00:29:58.480
then it has to start making decisions,
right?

587
00:29:58.480 --> 00:30:00.410
Why leave that empty if
you've got it available?

588
00:30:00.410 --> 00:30:03.100
So it is doing that, so
I'm not completely disabled here.

589
00:30:03.100 --> 00:30:04.750
But it's got it in place.

590
00:30:04.750 --> 00:30:07.670
And you can come up here and dictate how
you want those reallocations to happen.

591
00:30:07.670 --> 00:30:09.420
Do you want it to happen on a schedule so

592
00:30:09.420 --> 00:30:11.560
every night at midnight
move things around?

593
00:30:11.560 --> 00:30:13.640
Or do you want to have
it happen all the time?

594
00:30:13.640 --> 00:30:16.680
It's a better idea to put it after hours
so you don't affect people's performance

595
00:30:16.680 --> 00:30:20.150
while you're moving files around, but you
might wanna go a little more frequently.

596
00:30:20.150 --> 00:30:24.270
And so you can jump into this and
really tweak these settings and

597
00:30:24.270 --> 00:30:25.220
customize quite a bit.

598
00:30:25.220 --> 00:30:28.680
So here you can see mine's scheduled
to happen at, it looks like

599
00:30:28.680 --> 00:30:32.990
in between 5 PM and 1 AM, it's gonna go
through and start reallocating that data.

600
00:30:32.990 --> 00:30:36.640
So depending on the saying you choose
it'll likely have something like this for

601
00:30:36.640 --> 00:30:38.070
defining a data tier.

602
00:30:38.070 --> 00:30:41.803
And you might have SSD disks for
your performance tier and then SAS or

603
00:30:41.803 --> 00:30:44.890
even SATA disks for
your non-performance tier.

604
00:30:44.890 --> 00:30:47.487
And that way if you have stuff
that's just not being used,

605
00:30:47.487 --> 00:30:49.882
move it off to cheap storage
that you can have a ton of.

606
00:30:49.882 --> 00:30:52.832
But your frequently accessed stuff
goes on really fast and your users,

607
00:30:52.832 --> 00:30:54.940
when they access the SAN,
they think it's blazing fast.

608
00:30:54.940 --> 00:30:59.980
As far as they know,
the whole thing is SSD SAS drives, right?

609
00:30:59.980 --> 00:31:02.680
They don't know that there's
archive drives that are cheap and

610
00:31:02.680 --> 00:31:05.770
crappy that we have our old data
on that we don't care about.

611
00:31:05.770 --> 00:31:08.970
And the SAN is taking care of reallocating
all that for us, really cool stuff.

612
00:31:08.970 --> 00:31:10.440
>> It is very cool stuff.

613
00:31:10.440 --> 00:31:13.995
And as you can see, when you're
working with a SAN, it's not just, let

614
00:31:13.995 --> 00:31:17.774
me grab some disks and throw it in a box
and connect it through a fiber channel.

615
00:31:17.774 --> 00:31:18.404
That was easy.

616
00:31:18.404 --> 00:31:19.590
Now I'm off to the races.

617
00:31:19.590 --> 00:31:24.205
You have to really kind of take a look and
plan out and figure out what is

618
00:31:24.205 --> 00:31:28.514
the best way to organize your data,
what drives do I need to use.

619
00:31:28.514 --> 00:31:29.755
It takes a little bit.

620
00:31:29.755 --> 00:31:33.492
But I'm confident, Don, you did
a great job at explaining this to us.

621
00:31:33.492 --> 00:31:37.552
I'm confident that our viewers after this
episode will be much more equipped to

622
00:31:37.552 --> 00:31:38.532
handle that task.

623
00:31:38.532 --> 00:31:40.772
Now is there anything else that we
need to cover for this episode?

624
00:31:40.772 --> 00:31:43.503
>> Well, once we picked our drives,
the next thing is to get them set up, and

625
00:31:43.503 --> 00:31:44.532
we haven't seen that yet.

626
00:31:44.532 --> 00:31:47.206
We will get a chance to see that in our
next episode when we jump in to our RAID

627
00:31:47.206 --> 00:31:50.370
levels which is an important decision
to make when you implement your drives.

628
00:31:50.370 --> 00:31:53.003
And then we'll start talking about
creating the LUNS and all the other

629
00:31:53.003 --> 00:31:56.184
technology we need to get in place to make
it where these drives are actually useful.

630
00:31:56.184 --> 00:31:59.210
But I think we've covered everything you
need to know as far as your shopping list

631
00:31:59.210 --> 00:32:00.650
when you go to buy the storage.

632
00:32:00.650 --> 00:32:03.800
>> All right, well, thanks a lot again,
Don, and we thank you guys for watching.

633
00:32:03.800 --> 00:32:05.680
We'll go ahead and sign off for ITProTV.

634
00:32:05.680 --> 00:32:07.660
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

635
00:32:07.660 --> 00:32:08.464
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

636
00:32:08.464 --> 00:32:10.922
>> And we'll see you next time.

637

They give you a detailed rundown on RAID levels 0, 1, 5, 6, 1+0, and 0+1. They then explain some of the different filesystems that you may encounter, like EXT, NTFS, and ZFS.

1

2

All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3

I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode, well,

4
00:00:19.680 --> 00:00:22.220
we're continuing on
with Cloud Plus Series.

5
00:00:22.220 --> 00:00:25.300
And joining us back in the studio
today is our good friend,

6
00:00:25.300 --> 00:00:28.000
our mentor, the guiding light
that is showing us the way.

7
00:00:28.000 --> 00:00:29.120
That is Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:29.120 --> 00:00:30.520
Don, welcome to the show.

9
00:00:30.520 --> 00:00:31.580
>> Thanks for having me, Daniel.

10
00:00:31.580 --> 00:00:32.740
Excellent intro, as always.

11
00:00:32.740 --> 00:00:35.580
[LAUGH] Ready to jump back in
to the world of Cloud Plus.

12
00:00:35.580 --> 00:00:38.100
And in our last episode if,
you're watching these in order,

13
00:00:38.100 --> 00:00:40.850
we talked a bit about storage, and
the different types of drives and

14
00:00:40.850 --> 00:00:45.050
media that you might pop into the storage
for your virtualization environment.

15
00:00:45.050 --> 00:00:47.840
Well once you have the drives
popped into your servers, or

16
00:00:47.840 --> 00:00:50.810
into your SAN,
the next step is to configure them.

17
00:00:50.810 --> 00:00:54.620
And before we start configuring them,
we have to make some decisions on

18
00:00:54.620 --> 00:00:56.840
how we're going to be
arranging that storage and

19
00:00:56.840 --> 00:00:58.600
the file systems that we're
going to place on them.

20
00:00:58.600 --> 00:01:00.958
So, that's what we're going to
talk about here in this episode.

21
00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:04.800
We're going to take a look at RAID,
which is how we build in redundancy and

22
00:01:04.800 --> 00:01:07.860
efficiency into the storage, and we're
going to get a chance to take a look at

23
00:01:07.860 --> 00:01:10.930
the file systems that you may
be using on top of those drives.

24
00:01:10.930 --> 00:01:15.630
>> Well, Don I will spare our viewers
the ubiquitous joke of it kills bugs dead.

25
00:01:15.630 --> 00:01:18.380
And you know,
I kind of did just make the joke.

26
00:01:18.380 --> 00:01:20.480
>> Good job.
>> I know I slid it in and

27
00:01:20.480 --> 00:01:23.070
yet I didn't do it, that's how I roll.

28
00:01:23.070 --> 00:01:25.990
But it is something that
we do need to understand.

29
00:01:25.990 --> 00:01:28.860
And if you're at this level, you've
probably encountered RAID before, but

30
00:01:28.860 --> 00:01:32.770
we're going to go over it again, make sure
you understand some of the particulars

31
00:01:32.770 --> 00:01:36.710
about the common types of RAID that
you will use in a SAN environment, or

32
00:01:36.710 --> 00:01:38.660
a storage-attached environment.

33
00:01:38.660 --> 00:01:39.830
So Don, let's start there.

34
00:01:39.830 --> 00:01:41.060
Let's start with RAID.

35
00:01:41.060 --> 00:01:44.156
>> All right, so the key thing to think
about with a SAN is that you're going to

36
00:01:44.156 --> 00:01:46.210
have a lot of drives, a lot.

37
00:01:46.210 --> 00:01:47.100
When you buy a SAN,

38
00:01:47.100 --> 00:01:51.180
usually the smallest one you can buy
has about a 15 bay drive enclosure.

39
00:01:51.180 --> 00:01:54.130
You can have the 15 drives
just right out of the box.

40
00:01:54.130 --> 00:01:57.300
Then you start adding more enclosures
to it and more, and more, and more.

41
00:01:57.300 --> 00:01:59.330
And you can have a SAN And
with 250, 750 drives.

42
00:01:59.330 --> 00:02:04.750
I'm not talking about 750 gigs,
I'm talking about 750 actual hard dives,

43
00:02:04.750 --> 00:02:06.935
and it could take more then
one rack in your server room.

44
00:02:06.935 --> 00:02:09.640
SANs could get really really large, and

45
00:02:09.640 --> 00:02:13.630
the main reason the do that is
because in a lot of configurations,

46
00:02:13.630 --> 00:02:17.780
the more physical disks you have,
the better performance you get.

47
00:02:17.780 --> 00:02:20.840
Instead of having one drive doing
the read and write operation,

48
00:02:20.840 --> 00:02:22.970
we can have more than one drive doing it.

49
00:02:22.970 --> 00:02:25.980
We can spread our reads and
writes out across many drives, and

50
00:02:25.980 --> 00:02:28.910
you get data at a much faster rate.

51
00:02:28.910 --> 00:02:30.645
You can also build a lot
more redundancy in there,

52
00:02:30.645 --> 00:02:32.840
because we all know that drives fail,
right?

53
00:02:32.840 --> 00:02:37.200
And so if I have one hard drive, I might
have a second hard drive as a spare.

54
00:02:37.200 --> 00:02:40.770
But if I have 1,000 hard drives,
how many spares do I need?

55
00:02:40.770 --> 00:02:41.660
Quite a few.

56
00:02:41.660 --> 00:02:44.730
And with a SAN, we can pool those all
together and have them available.

57
00:02:44.730 --> 00:02:47.580
So there's some really neat
technologies that are there.

58
00:02:47.580 --> 00:02:50.920
But when you've got more than one drive,
and we need a technology to link them all

59
00:02:50.920 --> 00:02:54.110
together, typically
that's going to be RAID.

60
00:02:54.110 --> 00:02:57.390
And RAID, it's one of those terms that,
it stands for many things.

61
00:02:57.390 --> 00:03:00.280
It used to be redundant
array of inexpensive disks.

62
00:03:00.280 --> 00:03:03.850
Now people like to call it redundant
array of independent disks.

63
00:03:03.850 --> 00:03:06.380
They're not necessarily independent
if they're in an array are they?

64
00:03:06.380 --> 00:03:08.060
But that's what they've chosen to make it.

65
00:03:08.060 --> 00:03:12.166
So, we have RAID which allows us
to combine more than one disk,

66
00:03:12.166 --> 00:03:15.581
to create a single virtual
disk that we can then use.

67
00:03:15.581 --> 00:03:19.448
Our operating systems, our virtual
machines, they just need one disk, but

68
00:03:19.448 --> 00:03:22.880
on the back end, this is spread
across more than one physical disk.

69
00:03:22.880 --> 00:03:25.970
One of the earliest forms of this
was something called RAID 0, and

70
00:03:25.970 --> 00:03:29.330
I've got a little diagram here that
kind of shows how RAID 0 works.

71
00:03:29.330 --> 00:03:33.550
RAID 0 is also called striping,
and the way that it works is,

72
00:03:33.550 --> 00:03:36.540
instead of writing your
data just to one disk,

73
00:03:36.540 --> 00:03:41.300
it spreads your data across multiple
disks, and it does those in stripes.

74
00:03:41.300 --> 00:03:45.720
And so when you create a striped array,
you tell it how many disks you have.

75
00:03:45.720 --> 00:03:47.450
In my case, I've got three.

76
00:03:47.450 --> 00:03:51.850
And then when it starts writing data,
it will write some data to the first disk,

77
00:03:51.850 --> 00:03:55.530
and then it'll move over and
write data to the next disk.

78
00:03:55.530 --> 00:03:58.360
And it's doing this according
to a stripe size that we define.

79
00:03:58.360 --> 00:04:01.160
When you build your array you can say,
I want my stripes to be 64k in size, or

80
00:04:01.160 --> 00:04:06.010
128k, or 2 MBs, or
whatever it is you want, okay?

81
00:04:06.010 --> 00:04:09.220
