528
00:25:40.330 --> 00:25:42.380
But your operating system might not be.

529
00:25:42.380 --> 00:25:45.620
So we need to be aware of, in real
life we need to be aware of this but

530
00:25:45.620 --> 00:25:47.160
also on the exam we need to be aware,

531
00:25:47.160 --> 00:25:51.260
that different file systems have
different maximum volume sizes.

532
00:25:51.260 --> 00:25:54.190
And they may not be able to recognize
the size drives that we create,

533
00:25:54.190 --> 00:25:55.800
so we've gotta be careful.

534
00:25:55.800 --> 00:25:59.170
So I've got a little slide here that I
worked up that has all the different ones

535
00:25:59.170 --> 00:26:02.280
that might show up on the exam, and some
of the limits that we've got out there.

536
00:26:02.280 --> 00:26:06.790
And you'll see some of them are really,
really big, like UFS.

537
00:26:06.790 --> 00:26:08.720
UFS is the Unix file system.

538
00:26:08.720 --> 00:26:12.540
It was originally developed for
BSD and made it into Unix, Linux,

539
00:26:12.540 --> 00:26:14.910
and OSX, or Mac OS.

540
00:26:14.910 --> 00:26:17.660
But it was primarily developed in BSD.

541
00:26:17.660 --> 00:26:22.443
And it has a maximum file size of 8ZB,
which is massive,

542
00:26:22.443 --> 00:26:25.344
and a maximum volume size of 8ZB.

543
00:26:25.344 --> 00:26:26.700
It's big.

544
00:26:26.700 --> 00:26:29.611
It can handle really, really big stuff,
and it does it just fine.

545
00:26:29.611 --> 00:26:33.520
The only problem is nobody
runs UFS these days.

546
00:26:33.520 --> 00:26:35.520
It exists, a lot of systems support it,

547
00:26:35.520 --> 00:26:39.290
Mac OS supports it if you wanna use it,
but most people aren't using it.

548
00:26:39.290 --> 00:26:43.285
So instead we find that we're using these
other file systems that are a little more

549
00:26:43.285 --> 00:26:45.210
vendor-specific.

550
00:26:45.210 --> 00:26:48.220
So in the Linux world,
you see the extended file system,

551
00:26:48.220 --> 00:26:52.170
EXT, and there's EXT2, EXT3, EXT4.

552
00:26:52.170 --> 00:26:56.230
Most Linux distros, when you install them,
do EXT3 by default,

553
00:26:56.230 --> 00:26:58.750
and then you can enable
the EXT4 if you want.

554
00:26:58.750 --> 00:27:02.988
Well, there's some big differences
when you look at EXT2, 3, and 4.

555
00:27:02.988 --> 00:27:10.610
With 2 and 3 they have a 2TB maximum file
size and a 32TB maximum volume size.

556
00:27:10.610 --> 00:27:15.150
So if I create an array that's
bigger than 32TB, when I go into

557
00:27:15.150 --> 00:27:19.940
Linux I'm gonna have to break it up
into 32TB chunks if I want to use it.

558
00:27:19.940 --> 00:27:22.900
And even then, when I start to throw
files on it I've got a maximum of 2TB.

559
00:27:22.900 --> 00:27:24.580
Now why is that important to me?

560
00:27:24.580 --> 00:27:29.260
Well, when I create a virtual machine, the
virtual machine has a virtual hard drive.

561
00:27:29.260 --> 00:27:33.130
And the virtual hard drive is a file,

562
00:27:33.130 --> 00:27:37.320
which means it's gonna have
a maximum of 2TB in size.

563
00:27:37.320 --> 00:27:40.210
If I'm running KBM as
my type 1 Hypervisor,

564
00:27:40.210 --> 00:27:46.150
I'm running it on top of CentOS or Ubuntu
or whatever, and my file system is EXT3,

565
00:27:46.150 --> 00:27:49.620
I can't have a virtual machine
with a hard drive bigger than 2TB,

566
00:27:49.620 --> 00:27:53.230
because that's the maximum file size
supported on those file systems.

567
00:27:53.230 --> 00:27:55.510
I'll have to break up the drives
to get something bigger, and

568
00:27:55.510 --> 00:27:56.600
there's ways to do that.

569
00:27:56.600 --> 00:27:58.451
Different operating systems
have different technologies.

570
00:27:58.451 --> 00:28:02.544
If I go EXT4,
I can have up to a 16TB file size and

571
00:28:02.544 --> 00:28:06.850
up to 1EX for a volume size,
so you get much larger.

572
00:28:06.850 --> 00:28:09.740
So if you're gonna be dealing
with large virtual hard drives,

573
00:28:09.740 --> 00:28:13.130
you'll want to make sure you
get over to EXT4 if you can.

574
00:28:13.130 --> 00:28:14.320
That's in the Linux world.

575
00:28:14.320 --> 00:28:15.700
Windows has the same thing.

576
00:28:15.700 --> 00:28:19.274
In Windows you have NTFS,
FAT32, and ExFAT.

577
00:28:19.274 --> 00:28:21.980
Those are the three systems
that are really supported now.

578
00:28:21.980 --> 00:28:25.445
FAT32 is the oldest and
you'll see it's the smallest.

579
00:28:25.445 --> 00:28:29.610
4GB is the max file size and
8TB is the maximum partition size.

580
00:28:29.610 --> 00:28:31.810
Actually in Windows,
they cripple it in software so

581
00:28:31.810 --> 00:28:35.750
it's even smaller, but technically
it can go up to 8TB if you want.

582
00:28:35.750 --> 00:28:38.990
If you want something bigger, which
I can have one hard drive that's 8TB.

583
00:28:38.990 --> 00:28:42.330
If I wanna go bigger,
FAT32's not gonna work for me.

584
00:28:42.330 --> 00:28:47.640
I can go ExFAT, which gives me 16EB and
64ZB for that storage.

585
00:28:47.640 --> 00:28:52.055
Again, massive sizes, but ExFAT is
missing a lot of features that we want,

586
00:28:52.055 --> 00:28:52.865
like journaling.

587
00:28:52.865 --> 00:28:57.379
It's really easy to get data corruption in
ExFAT, so it's normally not recommended to

588
00:28:57.379 --> 00:29:01.675
use ExFAT if you're running Hyper-V,
Microsoft's Type 1 hypervisor.

589
00:29:01.675 --> 00:29:04.606
So instead,
you're gonna end up at NTFS, and

590
00:29:04.606 --> 00:29:09.282
NTFS has a maximum file size of 16EB and
a maximum volume size of 16EB.

591
00:29:09.282 --> 00:29:12.250
That's bigger than what most
people are working with today.

592
00:29:12.250 --> 00:29:14.130
Ten years from now,
that might be different, but for

593
00:29:14.130 --> 00:29:16.580
the next couple of years this
is plenty of head room, and

594
00:29:16.580 --> 00:29:19.380
Microsoft will probably improve
NTFS between now and then.

595
00:29:19.380 --> 00:29:20.880
We'll see.

596
00:29:20.880 --> 00:29:22.910
So definitely be aware of that one.

597
00:29:22.910 --> 00:29:26.760
If you're running VMware, VMware is
technically running Linux under the hood.

598
00:29:26.760 --> 00:29:31.610
If you have VMware ESX, it is a special
version of Linux running under the hood.

599
00:29:31.610 --> 00:29:36.360
But they created their own
file system called VMFS.

600
00:29:36.360 --> 00:29:39.180
So the VMware Virtual Machine File System.

601
00:29:39.180 --> 00:29:44.730
And on their file system,
they've got a 4TB maximum file size and

602
00:29:44.730 --> 00:29:47.500
a 64TB maximum volume size.

603
00:29:47.500 --> 00:29:51.170
So if you wanna go bigger than that,
well, you're gonna have to break it up.

604
00:29:51.170 --> 00:29:52.890
And it actually supports
breaking it up for you.

605
00:29:52.890 --> 00:29:54.650
It does it in the background and
you don't have to worry about it.

606
00:29:54.650 --> 00:29:57.580
But under the hood it's
capping things out.

607
00:29:57.580 --> 00:30:02.326
Maximum file size of 4TB,
maximum volume size of 64TB.

608
00:30:02.326 --> 00:30:04.800
And the last one that's
on the slide here is ZFS.

609
00:30:04.800 --> 00:30:08.591
Now ZFS, most of you guys
aren't gonna see in production.

610
00:30:08.591 --> 00:30:13.755
It was developed for Solaris originally,
which was Sun Microsystems version of BSD.

611
00:30:13.755 --> 00:30:17.745
Today it's owned by Oracle, and
development for it has been really spotty.

612
00:30:17.745 --> 00:30:22.025
So most operating systems don't
have official ZFS support yet, but

613
00:30:22.025 --> 00:30:26.449
everybody looks to it as the future,
that Linux is gonna move over to ZFS

614
00:30:26.449 --> 00:30:29.989
eventually, and
Mac OS may move over to ZFS eventually,

615
00:30:29.989 --> 00:30:33.356
and all these Unix based
systems may move over to ZFS.

616
00:30:33.356 --> 00:30:35.072
But it's all may move over.

617
00:30:35.072 --> 00:30:38.022
None of them are doing it by default
because there are certain data loss

618
00:30:38.022 --> 00:30:40.482
scenarios that can happen,
and that's always bad.

619
00:30:40.482 --> 00:30:45.160
But when it does make it into production,
16EB maximum file size,

620
00:30:45.160 --> 00:30:50.578
just like Windows, but
256ZB maximum volume size.

621
00:30:50.578 --> 00:30:52.520
And just kinda looking
at all of these guys,

622
00:30:52.520 --> 00:30:56.300
that's the largest maximum volume
size of any of these file systems.

623
00:30:56.300 --> 00:30:59.430
And that's why people are looking at this
as the future, that it can get really,

624
00:30:59.430 --> 00:31:02.460
really big, and
you can really get some value out of that.

625
00:31:02.460 --> 00:31:04.660
So these are the different file systems.

626
00:31:04.660 --> 00:31:09.200
When you create an array, it's a good
idea to remember these file systems and

627
00:31:09.200 --> 00:31:10.410
their limitations.

628
00:31:10.410 --> 00:31:13.210
And usually you just don't wanna
make an array that's bigger than

629
00:31:13.210 --> 00:31:15.820
the maximum volume size of
the file system you're gonna use.

630
00:31:15.820 --> 00:31:18.140
If you do, you may start to have problems.

631
00:31:18.140 --> 00:31:18.940
And I usually try and

632
00:31:18.940 --> 00:31:22.860
go well beneath the thresholds just to
make sure everything runs smooth, because

633
00:31:22.860 --> 00:31:27.790
the bigger that volume is, the more
addressing space it requires on a system.

634
00:31:27.790 --> 00:31:29.320
And while it usually takes account for

635
00:31:29.320 --> 00:31:32.230
that anyway, you can start ending
up with weird scenarios where

636
00:31:32.230 --> 00:31:35.680
you cross these little thresholds and
the file systems don't work properly.

637
00:31:35.680 --> 00:31:40.720
You create a 15TB array, and
the the operating system sees it as 2TB,

638
00:31:40.720 --> 00:31:42.530
because it screwed up some
kind of memory addressing.

639
00:31:42.530 --> 00:31:43.410
And that does happen,

640
00:31:43.410 --> 00:31:46.780
so we've always got to remember those
file systems and what we're using.

641
00:31:46.780 --> 00:31:49.650
>> That is definitely some news
we can use, ladies and gentlemen.

642
00:31:49.650 --> 00:31:52.960
So go through that chart, look at it, kind
of that's one of those things you just

643
00:31:52.960 --> 00:31:55.190
have to brute-force memorize,
unfortunately.

644
00:31:55.190 --> 00:31:58.800
That's just life sometimes,
and this is that part.

645
00:31:58.800 --> 00:32:00.830
So go through that,
make sure you get good and

646
00:32:00.830 --> 00:32:05.420
familiar with those different sizes,
the file sizes and the volume sizes and

647
00:32:05.420 --> 00:32:08.920
their maximum capacities, so
that you're ready for the exam.

648
00:32:08.920 --> 00:32:11.690
And when you get out there in real
life you know exactly what you'll want

649
00:32:11.690 --> 00:32:13.610
to use in the environment that you're in.

650
00:32:13.610 --> 00:32:15.340
Don, you've given us a lot
of great information today.

651
00:32:15.340 --> 00:32:18.340
Is there anything else you want to throw
on the pile before we close the show?

652
00:32:18.340 --> 00:32:19.320
>> That's pretty much it.

653
00:32:19.320 --> 00:32:21.590
At this point we've talked
a lot about storage.

654
00:32:21.590 --> 00:32:22.830
We haven't actually configured any.

655
00:32:22.830 --> 00:32:26.100
So stay tuned, cuz in the next episode
we're gonna actually see configuring this

656
00:32:26.100 --> 00:32:28.100
stuff on a SAN and kinda how that works.

657
00:32:28.100 --> 00:32:30.980
But we have to have all this base
knowledge to make the right decisions when

658
00:32:30.980 --> 00:32:32.410
it comes to configuration time.

659
00:32:32.410 --> 00:32:33.860
>> All right, well,
thank you so much, Don, for

660
00:32:33.860 --> 00:32:36.040
showing us this, and
thank you guys for watching.

661
00:32:36.040 --> 00:32:37.570
We hope to see you in the next episode.

662
00:32:37.570 --> 00:32:41.110
Until then, signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

663
00:32:41.110 --> 00:32:41.858
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

664
00:32:41.858 --> 00:32:43.715
>> And we'll see you next time.

665
00:32:43.715 --> 00:32:51.770

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don take you through configuring a Storage Area Network(SAN) appliance. They explain the best practices and procedures for implementing a SAN and then jump into actually working with a SAN's interface. They show you how to create LUNs as well as security features like zoning and LUN masking.

Buying hard drives, how to pick them, how

They usually have CLI also, but
you typically don't have to have it.

23
00:01:06.370 --> 00:01:09.710
And for the most part, SANs are one of
the things where you configure it, and

00:01:09.710 --> 00:01:12.090

25

Then you have to add more disks.

26
00:01:13.100 --> 00:01:17.290
So they're pretty low maintenance devices,
and you just get in and set the things up.

27
00:01:17.290 --> 00:01:19.930
So that's what we're going to take
a look at here in this episode.

28
00:01:19.930 --> 00:01:23.040
>> Yeah, if you've been waiting with
bated breath to actually see some SAN

29
00:01:23.040 --> 00:01:25.190
configuration, this is the episode for
you.

30

It's a lot of fun.

For me, this is the kind of
thing that gets me into IT.

34

It gets my IT beanie twirling.

So, we'll just dispense
with the pleasantries, Don.

I'll let you go ahead and jump behind Mr.

Command over here and
show us how to make this happen.

38

>> All right, well I know I brought this
up in another episode at one point, but

39
00:01:47.020 --> 00:01:49.480
I've got a little EMC SAN

40
00:01:49.480 --> 00:01:53.740
And basically it a fairly typical device,
and

41
00:01:53.740 --> 00:01:56.785
if you've never worked with one of these,

42
00:01:56.785 --> 00:01:59.460
because you can see
a little picture of it.

00:01:59.460 --> 00:02:04.715
and what the SAn actually
looks like Is this right here.

00:02:04.715 --> 00:02:05.305
Okay?

00:02:05.305 --> 00:02:10.135
So, this is the SAN itself, and notice up
here, its saying Disk Processor Enclosure.

46
00:02:10.135 --> 00:02:13.345
So, this right here has
a processor in the back of it and

47
00:02:13.345 --> 00:02:15.602
its actually running the show.

48
00:02:15.602 --> 00:02:17.922
Built into it you'll see
it's got these drives, and

00:02:17.922 --> 00:02:20.752
what do we have here,
it looks like 12 drives.

50
00:02:20.752 --> 00:02:23.732
So we've got 12 drives of capacity for it.

51
00:02:23.732 --> 00:02:26.282
Now, whichever one is your
disk processor enclosure,

52
00:02:26.282 --> 00:02:30.552
whichever one is the main brain for
your unit, it's going to have disks, but

53
00:02:30.552 --> 00:02:33.280
they're not all available for you to use.

54
00:02:33.280 --> 00:02:36.960
Usually a couple of them will be pooled

55
00:02:36.960 --> 00:02:40.540
Your SAN has an operating system, and
it needs drives to store that, and so

56
00:02:40.540 --> 00:02:43.800
it'll normally pull three or
four drives aside for itself.

57
00:02:43.800 --> 00:02:46.890
Four is pretty common, where it'll have
three in array and five array, and

58
00:02:46.890 --> 00:02:48.980
one as a spare that's available.

59
00:02:48.980 --> 00:02:52.250
And you can normally spot spares, because
it'll show grayed out like this, or

60
00:02:52.250 --> 00:02:54.930
on some SANs grayed out might
indicate that it's an empty bay.

61
00:02:54.930 --> 00:02:57.390
But normally,
the graphic updates to show an empty bay.

62
00:02:57.390 --> 00:02:59.990

00:02:59.990 --> 00:03:03.490

or somewhere like that
spread in this array.

76
00:03:34.370 --> 00:03:36.490
You can have a lot of disks, and

77
00:03:36.490 --> 00:03:39.400
as your SAN grows,
you just add more of these enclosures.

78

So you might have a 42U rack that's packed
full of these enclosures right here,

79
00:03:44.600 --> 00:03:47.350
and that's how you can get to 250 drives,
or even 1,000 drives.

80
00:03:47.350 --> 00:03:49.400
On some SANs you can have really,

00:03:49.400 --> 00:03:52.130
really massive enclosures just
by popping those disks in.

00:03:53.220 --> 00:03:55.860
Now I'm looking at the front

00:07:51.340 --> 00:07:52.731

the switch is.

534
00:25:03.270 --> 00:25:05.730
And a lot of times the switch
can be aware of the SAN and so

535
00:25:05.730 --> 00:25:07.440
it can take action with that.

536
00:25:07.440 --> 00:25:10.280
But a VSAN, a virtual SAN,
is very similar,

537
00:25:10.280 --> 00:25:14.270
let's us divide up our connections to
limit which drives are visible to our

538
00:25:14.270 --> 00:25:18.140
hosts based on usually what
port they're plugged into.

539
00:25:18.140 --> 00:25:21.840
And zoning can do the same thing
by dividing up those ports, but

540
00:25:21.840 --> 00:25:25.610
a VSAN can hide more than one SAN
behind it, very similar technologies.

541
00:25:25.610 --> 00:25:29.280
There is one more method we can use,
which is called LUN masking.

542
00:25:29.280 --> 00:25:31.970
LUN masking can usually
be done on the SAN, or

543
00:25:31.970 --> 00:25:33.100
it can be done on the Fiber Switch.

544
00:25:33.100 --> 00:25:34.970
And, I just did it on
the SAN a minute ago.

545
00:25:34.970 --> 00:25:39.300
When I created the LUN, I was able
to pick who was allowed to see it.

546
00:25:39.300 --> 00:25:43.020
If you're not in that list,
it'll hide that LUN from you, all right?

547
00:25:43.020 --> 00:25:44.420
So really easy to do.

548
00:25:44.420 --> 00:25:45.560
And you can do it on a switch too.

549
00:25:45.560 --> 00:25:48.450
You can come in, and you can say these
LUNs are only visible to these hosts,

550
00:25:48.450 --> 00:25:50.290
you create access control lists.

551
00:25:50.290 --> 00:25:54.060
The problem with LUN masking
is it's tied to an ID number.

552
00:25:54.060 --> 00:25:56.770
And it used to be tied to
the ID number of the HBA, so

553
00:25:56.770 --> 00:26:00.310
when you have a host bus adapter in
something like this WEB01 server.

554
00:26:00.310 --> 00:26:03.180
If I have a host bus adapter in it,
it would have an identifier.

555
00:26:03.180 --> 00:26:05.480
And the problem was people
could spoof the identifier.

556
00:26:05.480 --> 00:26:07.160
You could have more than one identifier.

557
00:26:07.160 --> 00:26:09.060
I think I talked about that
in another episode too.

558
00:26:09.060 --> 00:26:10.670
But people could spoof it.

559
00:26:10.670 --> 00:26:14.280
And, so if an attacker broke into WEB01,
they could just start trying

560
00:26:14.280 --> 00:26:17.490
random numbers until maybe they hit on
one, and started seeing other drives.

561
00:26:17.490 --> 00:26:19.450
And, now they could access drives for
another system.

562
00:26:19.450 --> 00:26:20.790
And, that's really bad.

563
00:26:20.790 --> 00:26:24.890
And, so LUN masking has kind of gone away,
we don't see LUN masking as much any more.

564
00:26:24.890 --> 00:26:27.250
But, it's supported everywhere,
cuz it's so easy.

565
00:26:27.250 --> 00:26:32.100
Normally, we're gonna see VSANs,
or zoning and

566
00:26:32.100 --> 00:26:34.210
zoning is the most common,
that's what you'll see.

567
00:26:34.210 --> 00:26:37.050
And it's normally one or
the other, either zoning or VSANS.

568
00:26:37.050 --> 00:26:40.110
You don't normally see both because
they kind of do the same thing, right?

569
00:26:40.110 --> 00:26:42.750
If you have VSANS that's
the one you want to use.

570
00:26:42.750 --> 00:26:44.230
VSANS are more powerful.

571
00:26:44.230 --> 00:26:49.270
But if all you have is zoning, don't worry
it's fine because the way zoning works

572
00:26:49.270 --> 00:26:51.690
is it's not actually paying
attention to who the host is.

573
00:26:51.690 --> 00:26:52.500
It doesn't care you're WEB01.

574
00:26:53.680 --> 00:26:56.130
It cares about the port
you're plugged into.

575
00:26:56.130 --> 00:26:58.590
It says,
whoever is plugged into this physical port

576
00:26:58.590 --> 00:27:00.900
can only see these LUNs, right?

577
00:27:00.900 --> 00:27:02.900
Can only see these LUNs
that are in the same zone.

578
00:27:02.900 --> 00:27:04.890
And that way,
if a hacker were to break into WEB01,

579
00:27:04.890 --> 00:27:06.930
it doesn't matter what they spoof.

580
00:27:06.930 --> 00:27:09.550
They would have to physically
unplug this cable and

581
00:27:09.550 --> 00:27:12.150
move it to another port in
order to see other drives.

582
00:27:12.150 --> 00:27:13.710
They'd have to have physical access.

583
00:27:13.710 --> 00:27:15.170
And believe me if they
have physical access,

584
00:27:15.170 --> 00:27:17.570
you've got bigger problems
than LUN masking.

585
00:27:17.570 --> 00:27:19.920
They've got full access at that point.

586
00:27:19.920 --> 00:27:23.420
So when you VSANs or
Zoning it's tied to the physical port.

587
00:27:23.420 --> 00:27:27.300
And there's an important concept you need
to know here, what's called a world wide

588
00:27:27.300 --> 00:27:31.780
name, because we don't care about the host
that's plugged in we need some way to

589
00:27:31.780 --> 00:27:36.700
identify the port the switch the node and
the lines, right?

590
00:27:36.700 --> 00:27:39.450
And so the switch will assign what
are called word wide names to these

591
00:27:39.450 --> 00:27:43.220
identifiers and the world wide part is
that they're supposed to be unique.

592
00:27:43.220 --> 00:27:46.400
They aren't necessarily but
if you have more than one switch,

593
00:27:46.400 --> 00:27:49.010
there's supposed to be unique
across those switches and they are.

594
00:27:49.010 --> 00:27:53.112
I've never seen a duplicate and that
allows us to have more than one switch

595
00:27:53.112 --> 00:27:55.730
daisy chained and
still apply these names to it.

596
00:27:55.730 --> 00:28:00.850
Let me show you an example, I've got
a fake fiber switch around here somewhere,

597
00:28:00.850 --> 00:28:06.600
here, all right so here's a san topology,
that I've got and it's a san switch

598
00:28:06.600 --> 00:28:11.100
that if I take a look at it, it's got
two line cards in it with 24 ports each.

599
00:28:11.100 --> 00:28:15.010
So I've got two 24 port
fiber channel cards in it.

600
00:28:15.010 --> 00:28:18.520
And when I set this up,
I kinda left it in the default.

601
00:28:18.520 --> 00:28:24.440
So all 24 ports on each line card, or all
48 ports, are in the same logical network.

602
00:28:24.440 --> 00:28:26.550
If you plug into one you'll see
everything that's on the others.

603
00:28:26.550 --> 00:28:29.550
If I plug in a san I'll see everything
that's on that san, all the lines.

604
00:28:31.130 --> 00:28:34.930
But we can go into,
it's in here I'll show you my zoning.

605
00:28:34.930 --> 00:28:39.060
So in my zoning I've got just one default
zone, everybody's in the default zone.

606
00:28:39.060 --> 00:28:41.100
And over here you'll see
how it's tracking it.

607
00:28:41.100 --> 00:28:45.530
See how I've got host,
adapter, port, right?

608
00:28:45.530 --> 00:28:49.350
I've got a host machine and
in the host, is an HPA, an adapter.

609
00:28:49.350 --> 00:28:51.770
And in that adapter it's got a port.

610
00:28:51.770 --> 00:28:54.760
And that's plugging in to my switch.

611
00:28:54.760 --> 00:28:59.329
My switch has a worldwide node name and
then in in the switch,

612
00:28:59.329 --> 00:29:04.356
I've got ports, which are worldwide
port names, wwnn and wwpn.

613
00:29:04.356 --> 00:29:11.050
Wwnn, that's the switch itself,
cuz I might have more than one switch.

614
00:29:11.050 --> 00:29:16.480
And WWPN, that's the port on that switch,
and here's how we get our uniqueness.

615
00:29:16.480 --> 00:29:20.020
As long as I don't have two switches
with the same node name, I won't have

616
00:29:20.020 --> 00:29:23.380
duplicates, cuz these two combine to
form the identifier for that port, and

617
00:29:23.380 --> 00:29:29.480
we can create VSANs over here that
indicate what is gonna be on that.

618
00:29:29.480 --> 00:29:34.350
So I can put one of my SANs on VSAN 1 and
a different SAN on VSAN 5.

619
00:29:34.350 --> 00:29:37.340
And then, if you're not on VSAN5,
you don't see that other sand, or

620
00:29:37.340 --> 00:29:39.210
you can even divide the LUN level.

621
00:29:39.210 --> 00:29:41.110
And really get granular on that stuff.

622
00:29:41.110 --> 00:29:43.370
>> Seems like the same
basic concept of VLANs,

623
00:29:43.370 --> 00:29:47.970
I'm segregating out the data
using ports or whatever.

624
00:29:47.970 --> 00:29:49.960
>> It absolutely is,
it really is the same.

625
00:29:49.960 --> 00:29:52.010
And the configuration is pretty easy.

626
00:29:52.010 --> 00:29:54.870
Different switches have different
user interfaces, right.

627
00:29:54.870 --> 00:29:58.790
But on this particular one you'll see
where I've got a couple of VSANs to

628
00:29:58.790 --> 00:29:59.380
find here.

629
00:29:59.380 --> 00:30:01.640
VSANs zero, one, two, three, and four.

630
00:30:01.640 --> 00:30:04.270
And I can come over here and
I can pick a VSAN.

631
00:30:04.270 --> 00:30:06.710
Like if I take my default VSAN here,
this guy,

632
00:30:06.710 --> 00:30:08.750
actually it's VSAN one,
ten, 20, 30, and 40.

633
00:30:08.750 --> 00:30:12.910
If I take VSAN 1 that's my default, right?

634
00:30:12.910 --> 00:30:15.360
And if I look at my legend down here,

635
00:30:15.360 --> 00:30:17.900
I'll see my ports aren't
really configured for this.

636
00:30:17.900 --> 00:30:19.480
If I jump into the switch, there we go,

637
00:30:19.480 --> 00:30:22.930
now I see it, all 24 ports
currently belong to this VSAN.

638
00:30:22.930 --> 00:30:27.930
So all of my ports on both line cards,
so all 48 ports are on VSAN 1.

639
00:30:27.930 --> 00:30:32.020
But I can start to take ports and redesign
them and move them to other ones, so

640
00:30:32.020 --> 00:30:36.390
let's say that VSAN 20 here,
this is gonna be my DMZ and

641
00:30:36.390 --> 00:30:38.850
I wanna flag a couple of ports for it.

642
00:30:38.850 --> 00:30:43.080
So I can take some ports and
start to manipulate that configuration, so

643
00:30:43.080 --> 00:30:47.710
what we do is we pick the port we
want to reassign, I'll take this one.

644
00:30:47.710 --> 00:30:50.100
And then we can choose
to add it to the VSAN.

645
00:30:50.100 --> 00:30:53.350
And I'm gonna do that for
each port that I want to add to VSAN 20,

646
00:30:53.350 --> 00:30:57.980
and I'm moving them over to that VSAN.

647
00:30:57.980 --> 00:31:01.440
And so then I can plug in one of
my physical SAN connectors, and

648
00:31:01.440 --> 00:31:02.270
set some LUNs on it.

649
00:31:02.270 --> 00:31:05.670
And then I can plug in my
hosts into these ports.

650
00:31:05.670 --> 00:31:10.840
And they will only see the LUNS that
are attached to that set of links.

651
00:31:10.840 --> 00:31:14.490
And so once I've got that in place,
which come in those changes real quick.

652
00:31:14.490 --> 00:31:20.460
There we go, now notice when I look
at VSAN 1, those four ports are gone.

653
00:31:20.460 --> 00:31:21.230
And when I go up and

654
00:31:21.230 --> 00:31:25.260
look at VSAN 20 Those four ports
are the only thing that's present.

655
00:31:25.260 --> 00:31:30.350
I'm dividing up the ports on the switch,
I don't care what you HBAI identifier is,

656
00:31:30.350 --> 00:31:33.620
I care about the port,
It's a very physical thing.

657
00:31:33.620 --> 00:31:34.480
We take the security and

658
00:31:34.480 --> 00:31:38.120
move it to a physical area and
that's the best way to do it.

659
00:31:38.120 --> 00:31:41.705
Zoning and VSANs, they work the same way.

660
00:31:41.705 --> 00:31:45.590
VSANS can just encompass more
than what a zone typically can.

661
00:31:45.590 --> 00:31:48.090
And I just have that one zone
because we're not using it.

662
00:31:48.090 --> 00:31:49.770
I'm using the VSAN instead.

663
00:31:49.770 --> 00:31:50.930
You can jump in and configure that.

664
00:31:50.930 --> 00:31:53.640
A great way to secure your systems and
ensure that it's very difficult for

665
00:31:53.640 --> 00:31:55.760
a hacker to spoof resources like that.

666
00:31:55.760 --> 00:31:58.790
>> Yeah, this is definitely some of
the best information in this series yet

667
00:31:58.790 --> 00:32:00.800
because this is the practical part, right?

668
00:32:00.800 --> 00:32:02.630
This is, I have to go in.

669
00:32:02.630 --> 00:32:03.640
I have to work with a SAND.

670
00:32:03.640 --> 00:32:05.320
I have to create a storage pool.

671
00:32:05.320 --> 00:32:06.407
I have to create a LUN.

672
00:32:06.407 --> 00:32:07.760
I have to secure those things so

673
00:32:07.760 --> 00:32:12.930
that only certain resources can access
certain ones for their purposes.

674
00:32:12.930 --> 00:32:16.450
This is the good stuff Don,
you're doing a great job of showing us.

675
00:32:16.450 --> 00:32:20.340
I know that our viewers out
there are probably going, wow,

676
00:32:20.340 --> 00:32:21.860
I can actually work with a SAN, I think.

677
00:32:21.860 --> 00:32:23.790
It's not that complicated.

678
00:32:23.790 --> 00:32:25.800
>> It's not but, think about it,

679
00:32:25.800 --> 00:32:29.100
if you make a mistake on the SAN,
it's really hard to fix afterwards.

680
00:32:29.100 --> 00:32:30.990
>> Yeah.
>> If you got a bunch of virtual machines

681
00:32:30.990 --> 00:32:34.080
running on there and a ton of data,
you gotta move that data off to fix it.

682
00:32:34.080 --> 00:32:37.830
If you decide, I'm gonna change
my RAID model, that's not fun.

683
00:32:37.830 --> 00:32:39.500
That's not something you wanna do, right.

684
00:32:39.500 --> 00:32:42.170
So you gotta make
the right decisions first.

685
00:32:42.170 --> 00:32:44.750
And that's why it took me three
episodes before we even got to where we

686
00:32:44.750 --> 00:32:45.560
configured something, right?

687
00:32:45.560 --> 00:32:47.880
We were covering all the concepts so

688
00:32:47.880 --> 00:32:50.640
you could make the right
decisions when the time came.

689
00:32:50.640 --> 00:32:53.650
Different SANS support different features,
so you might not see all the things that I

690
00:32:53.650 --> 00:32:55.950
see, and you might even have
more options than I see,

691
00:32:55.950 --> 00:32:58.690
because you might have
a better SAN than I do.

692
00:32:58.690 --> 00:33:00.750
Probably a given in most scenarios but

693
00:33:00.750 --> 00:33:03.730
just be aware that it is a big
decision that you have to make.

694
00:33:03.730 --> 00:33:04.720
>> What do they say?

695
00:33:04.720 --> 00:33:07.670
Proper preparation prevents
poor performance right?

696
00:33:07.670 --> 00:33:08.360
Very good stuff, Don.

697
00:33:08.360 --> 00:33:11.375
Is there anything else that we
need to cover in this episode?

698
00:33:11.375 --> 00:33:12.715
These SAN devices.

699
00:33:12.715 --> 00:33:13.435
>> That's about it.

700
00:33:13.435 --> 00:33:16.595
I think we've covered storage in
pretty big depth at this point.

701
00:33:16.595 --> 00:33:17.995
We're gonna move to networking next.

702
00:33:17.995 --> 00:33:20.595
So we'll probably wrap this one up and
then head to the networking world.

703
00:33:20.595 --> 00:33:22.765
>> All right, well thanks again for
joining us and

704
00:33:22.765 --> 00:33:24.405
explaining these concepts to us.

705
00:33:24.405 --> 00:33:25.395
Thank you guys for watching.

706
00:33:25.395 --> 00:33:27.355
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for IT Pro TV.

707
00:33:27.355 --> 00:33:29.135
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

708
00:33:29.135 --> 00:33:29.785
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

709
00:33:29.785 --> 00:33:31.031
>> And we'll see you next time.

710
00:33:31.031 --> 00:33:39.690
[MUSIC].

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don review basic networking concepts.  They briefly describe the use of IP addresses and its breakdown.  Don takes time to describe the basics of classful and classless IP address spaces and the use of subnet masks.  The guys take a look at 2 examples:  1 of subnetting and 1 of supernetting.  They emphasize the need to understand why and when it use them.
episodes.title: Network Concepts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.663 --> 00:00:16.110
Welcome to another another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.110 --> 00:00:17.230
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong,

4
00:00:17.230 --> 00:00:20.970
and today we're gonna be taking
a look at the CompTIA Cloud Plus.

5
00:00:20.970 --> 00:00:24.510
Specifically we're gonna be
addressing network concepts, and

6
00:00:24.510 --> 00:00:27.110
who better to help us than Mr.
Don Pezet himself.

7
00:00:27.110 --> 00:00:28.740
Don, what are we taking a look at today?

8
00:00:28.740 --> 00:00:31.390
>> All right, well, we're gonna jump
into some general network concepts.

9
00:00:31.390 --> 00:00:32.340
And like that name implies,

10
00:00:32.340 --> 00:00:36.330
we're not really focusing on
things that are only in the cloud.

11
00:00:36.330 --> 00:00:39.380
This is just standard networking
topics we need to be familiar with.

12
00:00:39.380 --> 00:00:42.547
Now, some of you may have already
done the Network+ certification, and

13
00:00:42.547 --> 00:00:45.322
if you have, then you probably
already know a lot of this stuff.

14
00:00:45.322 --> 00:00:48.630
And you won't hurt my feelings if you
skip the episode, that's just how it is.

15
00:00:48.630 --> 00:00:51.141
But, if you're just jumping
straight into Cloud Plus,

16
00:00:51.141 --> 00:00:54.488
we do need to have some basic fundamental
experience in just simple things,

17
00:00:54.488 --> 00:00:56.266
like IP addressing, and port numbers,

18
00:00:56.266 --> 00:00:59.809
so that we know how to handle these
protocols in a virtual environment, right.

19
00:00:59.809 --> 00:01:03.350
Now, if you're saying to yourself,
Don, I don't need to know this stuff.

20
00:01:03.350 --> 00:01:04.920
Let me just show you a quick example,
right?

21
00:01:04.920 --> 00:01:07.365
So here on my desktop
I've got VMware Fusion.

22
00:01:07.365 --> 00:01:10.288
And so
this is my virtual machine library and

23
00:01:10.288 --> 00:01:13.372
each virtual machine is
on a virtual network.

24
00:01:13.372 --> 00:01:15.610
We talked about virtual
networks in another episode.

25
00:01:15.610 --> 00:01:19.100
And if I go into my VMware Fusion
settings, when I jump into here and

26
00:01:19.100 --> 00:01:22.190
into the networking, here's where I
can start to set the configuration.

27
00:01:22.190 --> 00:01:25.750
And you can see where I can
share system access with my MAC.

28
00:01:25.750 --> 00:01:29.504
I can bridge a virtual machine to
be directly plugged into one of my

29
00:01:29.504 --> 00:01:33.020
networks like Thunderbolt,
or WiFi, or whatever.

30
00:01:33.020 --> 00:01:37.170
But then right down here, I can start
creating these virtual machine networks.

31
00:01:37.170 --> 00:01:41.840
And when you do that, you have to
specify Subnet IPs and Subnet Masks.

32
00:01:41.840 --> 00:01:44.580
And If you don't know
what a subnet mask does,

33
00:01:44.580 --> 00:01:48.370
there's a lot of mistakes that can be
made here that can cause some problems.

34
00:01:48.370 --> 00:01:50.390
And some of the new shorthand notation or

35
00:01:50.390 --> 00:01:54.450
side or subnet notation for
writing subnets is important to know, too.

36
00:01:54.450 --> 00:01:55.675
And this is VMware Fusion, but

37
00:01:55.675 --> 00:01:58.200
all the various virtualization
products are this way.

38
00:01:58.200 --> 00:02:02.350
They have different ways of setting it,
but the concept underneath is the same.

39
00:02:02.350 --> 00:02:06.076
So in this episode, we're gonna talk about
those subnet masks, and what they mean,

40
00:02:06.076 --> 00:02:09.490
how they work, how we can use them to
create the virtual networks that we need,

41
00:02:09.490 --> 00:02:11.596
so we make sure that's
implemented properly.

42
00:02:11.596 --> 00:02:13.753
And then we put our virtual
machines on top of them.

43
00:02:13.753 --> 00:02:17.567
>> All right, so Don, when we start taking

00:26:28.510 --> 00:26:31.760
Those would be the usable
IP's in that range.

502
00:26:31.760 --> 00:26:35.290
Let's say I wanted to divide it in half

503
00:26:35.290 --> 00:26:39.940
I wanna break that in half to
get two different networks.

504
00:26:39.940 --> 00:26:43.890
And those two different networks are just
dividing this current one into two pieces.

505
00:26:43.890 --> 00:26:47.640
So it's basically the first half and
the second half of this one network.

506
00:26:47.640 --> 00:26:54.810
Well the subnet I would normally use
is 255.255.255.0 for my one network and

507
00:26:54.810 --> 00:27:00.730
if I were to write that in binary
it would look something like this.

508
00:27:00.730 --> 00:27:04.070
I think I might have gotten
an extra 1 in there somewhere.

509
00:27:06.030 --> 00:27:07.130
No, actually I did it right.

510
00:27:07.130 --> 00:27:09.630
Okay, so
that's what that subnet would look like.

511
00:27:09.630 --> 00:27:14.680
Well, if I take one extra zero and
add it to the network ID,

512
00:27:14.680 --> 00:27:18.190
that can have two placeholder
values: zero, or a value of one.

513
00:27:18.190 --> 00:27:20.520
Effectively creating
two different networks.

514
00:27:20.520 --> 00:27:22.620
One that has a zero there,
and one that has a one there.

515
00:27:22.620 --> 00:27:26.300
And that starts to create that
division within my network.

516
00:27:26.300 --> 00:27:29.559
And that's what is going to allow
me to divide this into two pieces.

517
00:27:30.630 --> 00:27:36.510
So I'm just gonna basically borrow, or
steal, or however you wanna call it,

518
00:27:36.510 --> 00:27:40.140
this extra bit from the host ID and
give it to the network ID.

519
00:27:40.140 --> 00:27:44.090
Now, the first one that I wrote,
this guy, is a /24.

520
00:27:44.090 --> 00:27:47.990
There's 24 ones and zeros.

521
00:27:47.990 --> 00:27:52.210
Or I'm sorry, 24 1's before the zero
starts, but this next one that I'm making

522
00:27:52.210 --> 00:27:58.320
is a slash 25, I'm giving one more bit to
the network ID to create a second network.

523
00:27:59.410 --> 00:28:05.200
And what I end up with and
I'll save us the time of doing the whole

524
00:28:05.200 --> 00:28:09.350
binary conversion is two networks,
192.168.0.0,

525
00:28:09.350 --> 00:28:12.790
all the way through 127 and
192.168.0.128 through 255, right?

526
00:28:12.790 --> 00:28:20.430
Those are the two networks
that I just made.

527
00:28:20.430 --> 00:28:23.260
I divided it in half.

528
00:28:23.260 --> 00:28:28.500
By stealing this one bit and attaching it
to network ID, so I've now sub netted,

529
00:28:28.500 --> 00:28:33.120
I've divided a network up into multiple
smaller pieces and that's useful.

530
00:28:33.120 --> 00:28:36.210
Not so much on private networks like
these, we don't normally bother on private

531
00:28:36.210 --> 00:28:40.920
but on a public network if we have public
IP's that have been assigned to us,

532
00:28:40.920 --> 00:28:45.460
we can do this to divide what we've
got and use them more efficiently.

533
00:28:45.460 --> 00:28:46.160
Right?

534
00:28:46.160 --> 00:28:49.690
Same thing goes for
supernetting where I combine networks.

535
00:28:49.690 --> 00:28:53.160
Let's say I've got 300 computers.

536
00:28:53.160 --> 00:29:00.330
Well, if I use 192.168.0.0 like we did
up here, well, that's gonna give me 254.

537
00:29:00.330 --> 00:29:03.170
But I need, I need more, right?

538
00:29:03.170 --> 00:29:04.360
I need 300.

539
00:29:04.360 --> 00:29:10.640
So if I need 300, Well what I can
do is go the opposite direction.

540
00:29:10.640 --> 00:29:16.830
Instead of stealing a host bit
I could steal a network bit.

541
00:29:16.830 --> 00:29:21.910
And what that's gonna do is it's
gonna combine two networks.

542
00:29:21.910 --> 00:29:27.080
It will take the 192.168.0.0 network and
combine it with the next one in line.

543
00:29:27.080 --> 00:29:27.710
Which is the 192.

544
00:29:27.710 --> 00:29:28.380
168. 1. 0 network.

545
00:29:28.380 --> 00:29:33.070
And we can combine those two
together to create a network that

546
00:29:33.070 --> 00:29:35.190
has over 500 usable IPs.

547
00:29:35.190 --> 00:29:39.060
And again I'll save us
the binary conversion but

548
00:29:39.060 --> 00:29:42.063
it basically works out to 192.

549
00:29:42.063 --> 00:29:44.860
168. 0. 0 All the way
through 192.168.1.255, right.

550
00:29:44.860 --> 00:29:49.970
That gives you 512 usable
IPs in that network.

551
00:29:49.970 --> 00:29:53.600
That's supernetting,
that's combining, right.

552
00:29:54.640 --> 00:29:57.560
And like I said, on private networks,
we don't necessarily worry about that.

553
00:29:57.560 --> 00:29:58.240
Although you might have

554
00:29:58.240 --> 00:30:01.450
a virtual machine network that you want to
make a little bigger, and you can do this.

555
00:30:01.450 --> 00:30:04.610
But on public networks,
that's when this becomes really handy.

556
00:30:04.610 --> 00:30:06.770
I've said private and public a few times,

557
00:30:06.770 --> 00:30:09.380
let's talk about that just real briefly
cuz it might turn up on the exam.

558
00:30:09.380 --> 00:30:13.960
I mentioned how there were Class As,
Class Bs and Class Cs way up here.

559
00:30:15.030 --> 00:30:18.930
And I mentioned how those first OCTEps
kinda mattered back in the day, right.

560
00:30:18.930 --> 00:30:21.730
We'll when it comes to public IPs.

561
00:30:21.730 --> 00:30:24.730
These numbers are the numbers
that we see out there, right.

562
00:30:24.730 --> 00:30:27.770
So basically 1 through
223 in that first octet.

563
00:30:27.770 --> 00:30:31.640
But there's certain exceptions and
gaps that occur, so you may or

564
00:30:31.640 --> 00:30:34.160
may not actually see all these IPs in use.

565
00:30:34.160 --> 00:30:38.939
For example, on the Class A,
you have 10.0.0.0,

566
00:30:38.939 --> 00:30:42.140
right, 10 Is a special one.

567
00:30:42.140 --> 00:30:43.230
That one's private.

568
00:30:44.530 --> 00:30:45.450
Everything else.

569
00:30:45.450 --> 00:30:52.550
So one through nine and 11 through 126,
those are all public Class A addresses.

570
00:30:52.550 --> 00:30:54.020
You can't just use those.

571
00:30:54.020 --> 00:30:56.050
You have to go to the IANA and
register them.

572
00:30:56.050 --> 00:31:00.360
You've got to basically lease them
from the IANA to be able to use them.

573
00:31:00.360 --> 00:31:01.650
You really lease them from your ISP but

574
00:31:01.650 --> 00:31:04.740
either way, you gotta get those
addresses and have them registered.

575
00:31:04.740 --> 00:31:07.190
You will be the only person
on the planet that has those.

576
00:31:07.190 --> 00:31:10.760
But the private addresses anybody can
use those, right, and most people do.

577
00:31:10.760 --> 00:31:13.500
So 10., that's the private for
your class A.

578
00:31:13.500 --> 00:31:16.880
And on the class B it's very similar.

579
00:31:16.880 --> 00:31:24.880
You get 128 through 191 but
172.16 Through 172.31 are reserved,

580
00:31:24.880 --> 00:31:29.920
those are the private ones, right?

581
00:31:29.920 --> 00:31:34.680
So those are the private addresses.

582
00:31:34.680 --> 00:31:39.596
Keep in mind that 172.16.0,
that's a public, right?

583
00:31:39.596 --> 00:31:43.052
172.16.32, I'm sorry, 172.32,
there we go, I can't get it straight.

584
00:31:43.052 --> 00:31:43.645
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

585
00:31:43.645 --> 00:31:47.140
>> 172.0 there we go, that's a public.

586
00:31:47.140 --> 00:31:49.740
172.32, that's a public.

587
00:31:49.740 --> 00:31:51.784
172.15, that's a public.

588
00:31:51.784 --> 00:31:53.827
172.16.

589
00:31:53.827 --> 00:31:55.415
That's a private, right?

590
00:31:55.415 --> 00:31:57.609
Just that little range inside of there.

591
00:31:57.609 --> 00:32:00.240
I wrote it right, but I said it wrong.

592
00:32:00.240 --> 00:32:02.280
So anyhow, that's the correct site.

593
00:32:02.280 --> 00:32:04.835
And then on the Class C, it's easy here,

594
00:32:04.835 --> 00:32:08.432
just anything that starts with 192.168,
right.

595
00:32:08.432 --> 00:32:13.265
Now 192.167, that's a public.

596
00:32:13.265 --> 00:32:14.700
192.169 is a public, all right.

597
00:32:14.700 --> 00:32:16.473
Those are public IPs
that are really usable.

598
00:32:16.473 --> 00:32:20.124
192.168 that's the private, right.

599
00:32:20.124 --> 00:32:25.020
So 192.168 Is the private range.

600
00:32:25.020 --> 00:32:28.870
Okay, so each one is a private range set
aside and those are defined in an RFC.

601
00:32:28.870 --> 00:32:31.440
If you wanna learn more about it,
RFC 1918, you can look it up.

602
00:32:31.440 --> 00:32:35.410
It's a terribly boring read but it'll
tell you how these were set aside for

603
00:32:35.410 --> 00:32:36.220
private use.

604
00:32:36.220 --> 00:32:38.260
And when we're creating
virtual machine networks,

605
00:32:38.260 --> 00:32:40.450
we're normally using
these private addresses.

606
00:32:40.450 --> 00:32:42.568
But you don't have to.

607
00:32:42.568 --> 00:32:47.192
If you look back at my virtual
machine configuration.

608
00:32:47.192 --> 00:32:50.132
Let me just unlock this again so
it'll actually be legible.

609
00:32:50.132 --> 00:32:50.852
Whoops.

610
00:32:50.852 --> 00:32:54.392
If I figure out my password.

611
00:32:54.392 --> 00:32:58.393
Notice how here in vmnet 3,
I'm using 192.168.0.0.

612
00:32:58.393 --> 00:32:59.193
It's a private address range.

613
00:32:59.193 --> 00:33:00.872
I can use that to my heart's content.

614
00:33:00.872 --> 00:33:04.613
Or vmnet4, 192.168.1.0.

615
00:33:04.613 --> 00:33:06.280
172.16.0.0.

616
00:33:06.280 --> 00:33:08.680
So I'm using all these private ranges.

617
00:33:08.680 --> 00:33:11.886
But if you look at my vmnet2,
what is that?

618
00:33:11.886 --> 00:33:18.198
209.251.159.176 and
it's a 255.255.255.240.

619
00:33:18.198 --> 00:33:20.078
That's a public range, right.

620
00:33:20.078 --> 00:33:23.260
It's not just a public range,
it's the range for our studio here.

621
00:33:23.260 --> 00:33:25.040
Why do I have that?

622
00:33:25.040 --> 00:33:26.410
Well, I use it for testing.

623
00:33:26.410 --> 00:33:29.390
If I wanna test something and I don't
wanna impact my production environment,

624
00:33:29.390 --> 00:33:32.060
I might wanna bring up
some VMs right here and

625
00:33:32.060 --> 00:33:36.230
I do it in that IP range, the same IP
range that I use in the public network.

626
00:33:36.230 --> 00:33:39.320
Now they overlap, so these hosts
can't get out to the Internet right.

627
00:33:39.320 --> 00:33:41.600
They're stuck here and
nobody will know how to get back to them.

628
00:33:41.600 --> 00:33:45.130
But for testing a restore of a server or
testing some kind of dev change,

629
00:33:45.130 --> 00:33:46.730
you can do it right here and
it works out pretty well.

630
00:33:46.730 --> 00:33:51.970
So you can use public IPs in your network
configuration, you just have to be careful

631
00:33:51.970 --> 00:33:55.940
with it because you are overlapping
real networks that are out there and,

632
00:33:55.940 --> 00:33:58.270
if it's your own network,
it's fine, it's great for testing.

633
00:33:58.270 --> 00:33:59.810
But if it's somebody else's network,

634
00:33:59.810 --> 00:34:01.630
then you won't be able to
access their services anymore.

635
00:34:03.240 --> 00:34:04.110
All right.

636
00:34:04.110 --> 00:34:06.740

00:34:10.120 --> 00:34:11.460
I did it pretty quick, right?

00:34:11.460 --> 00:34:14.080
I ran through just some

This should be stuff you guys

00:34:30.040 --> 00:34:31.800
Ronnie, you were there too.

00:34:33.720 --> 00:34:36.030

On the exam, they really,

they want you to know the difference

00:34:41.695 --> 00:34:45.720
cuz that's important and they want you

00:34:45.720 --> 00:34:49.136
So know whether an IP is on the same
network as another IP based on

00:34:49.136 --> 00:34:50.360
the subnet mask.

00:34:50.360 --> 00:34:52.140
You need to understand what those are,
right.

654
00:34:52.140 --> 00:34:54.560
So don't expect to have
to do anything too crazy.

655
00:34:54.560 --> 00:34:56.370
I doubt you'll see any subnetting or

00:34:56.370 --> 00:35:00.230
supernetting beyond just the basic concept
of what it is, but it can turn up,

657
00:35:00.230 --> 00:35:02.710
it is an exam objective, so
we wanted to make sure that we covered it.

658
00:35:02.710 --> 00:35:04.100
>> All right, Don.
Well thank you again for

00:35:04.100 --> 00:35:06.170
showing us those demonstrations.

660
00:35:06.170 --> 00:35:07.480
Any last words here?

661
00:35:07.480 --> 00:35:09.860
>> All right,
well we covered a lot on subnetting and

662
00:35:09.860 --> 00:35:10.920
some different concepts there.

00:35:10.920 --> 00:35:13.190
I already mentioned the Network+
show definitely check it out.

00:35:13.190 --> 00:35:15.810
We are gonna do one more episode

00:35:15.810 --> 00:35:19.470
cuz I wanna talk about network address

The NAT option is is always present

00:35:24.350 --> 00:35:27.580

00:35:27.580 --> 00:35:28.700
So we'll get a chance to see that,

00:35:40.290 --> 00:35:42.530

506
00:26:47.220 --> 00:26:50.160
it's also doing port address translation.

507
00:26:50.160 --> 00:26:52.450
And that's a pretty common process.

508
00:26:52.450 --> 00:26:54.800
And so make sure you're
familiar with those two terms.

509
00:26:54.800 --> 00:26:57.650
So let me write them here on this slide.

510
00:26:57.650 --> 00:27:03.166
So we had NAT, which was network
address translation, right?

511
00:27:03.166 --> 00:27:06.149
And, hold on,
am I not allowed to increase my font size?

512
00:27:06.149 --> 00:27:08.090
There we go.

513
00:27:08.090 --> 00:27:10.480
Try to make it a little bigger so
we can all read it.

514
00:27:10.480 --> 00:27:15.470
So NAT,
which was Network Address Translation, and

515
00:27:15.470 --> 00:27:20.380
then we've got PAT,
which is Port Address Translation.

516
00:27:20.380 --> 00:27:25.100
And usually, you don't do PAT without NAT,
so they're typically used together.

517
00:27:25.100 --> 00:27:26.490
PAT is a complement.

518
00:27:26.490 --> 00:27:29.170
It adds on to Network Address Translation

519
00:27:29.170 --> 00:27:31.980
to achieve our goal of being
able to share these IPs.

520
00:27:31.980 --> 00:27:35.630
But those two technologies right there,
your software is performing them.

521
00:27:35.630 --> 00:27:41.410
If I go back into my VMware Fusion,
wherever I parked that, here.

522
00:27:41.410 --> 00:27:44.360
It just says allow virtual machines
on this network to connect

523
00:27:44.360 --> 00:27:45.710
to external networks using NAT.

524
00:27:46.780 --> 00:27:48.690
It doesn't mention PAT,
but it is doing it.

525
00:27:48.690 --> 00:27:50.000
Poor address translation is apart of that.

526
00:27:51.460 --> 00:27:53.810
All right, the last thing that I
want to mention before we wrap up,

527
00:27:53.810 --> 00:27:56.640
because I know I'm running low on time,
are those port numbers.

528
00:27:56.640 --> 00:27:59.750
I mentioned how, somewhere in here,
I mentioned that.

529
00:27:59.750 --> 00:28:01.660
Where did I mention that?

530
00:28:01.660 --> 00:28:03.170
Somewhere, here.

531
00:28:03.170 --> 00:28:06.760
That we had 1 through 1,024
are well-known port numbers.

532
00:28:06.760 --> 00:28:08.090
And most of our stuff is gonna be there.

533
00:28:08.090 --> 00:28:10.640
There's just a handful of port
numbers that CompTIA wants

534
00:28:10.640 --> 00:28:12.550
you to memorize for the exam.

535
00:28:12.550 --> 00:28:13.880
They're really common ones.

536
00:28:13.880 --> 00:28:16.530
So I've got those kinda
whipped up in a diagram here.

537
00:28:16.530 --> 00:28:18.400
Let's take a look at this.

538
00:28:18.400 --> 00:28:20.520
So these are some common protocols.

539
00:28:20.520 --> 00:28:23.060
And these are the ones that
CompTIA wants you to know

540
00:28:23.060 --> 00:28:25.670
prior to going into that
exam booth to take the exam.

541
00:28:26.970 --> 00:28:28.270
File Transfer Protocol, FTP.

542
00:28:28.270 --> 00:28:31.870
That's what we used to use to
transfer files back in the day.

543
00:28:31.870 --> 00:28:32.980
It's a UNIX protocol.

544
00:28:32.980 --> 00:28:33.790
It's still in use today.

545
00:28:33.790 --> 00:28:36.390
We use it here for
moving video files all the time.

546
00:28:36.390 --> 00:28:38.990
File Transfer Protocol uses ports 20 and
21.

547
00:28:38.990 --> 00:28:41.070
21 is the primary port.

548
00:28:41.070 --> 00:28:43.240
That's what it connects on,
but it uses 20 also.

549
00:28:44.750 --> 00:28:48.590
SSH, secure shell, that's a encrypted
shell connection between you and

550
00:28:48.590 --> 00:28:50.568
another system, it uses port 22.

551
00:28:50.568 --> 00:28:53.600
That's important,
cuz if you're bringing up Linux boxes,

552
00:28:53.600 --> 00:28:56.740
you might need to SSH into your
virtual machine to control it, and so

553
00:28:56.740 --> 00:29:00.100
you'll need to make sure that's allowed
through firewalls or other services.

554
00:29:00.100 --> 00:29:02.570
Now, SSH isn't the only
thing that uses port 22.

555
00:29:02.570 --> 00:29:07.930
You can actually take a lot of other
protocols and then embed them in SSH.

556
00:29:07.930 --> 00:29:10.370
So like secure file transfer protocol,

557
00:29:10.370 --> 00:29:12.850
SFTP, if you want to do
that goes over port 22.

558
00:29:12.850 --> 00:29:16.910
All that is is FTP over an SSH tunnel.

559
00:29:18.320 --> 00:29:21.620
Simple Mail Transport Protocol,
SMTP, uses port 25.

560
00:29:21.620 --> 00:29:26.360
So anytime you send an email and
moves from server to server it's port 25.

561
00:29:26.360 --> 00:29:28.590
DNS, DNS uses port 53.

562
00:29:28.590 --> 00:29:33.280
And it's a little bit different than the
other protocols, cuz it uses TCP and UDP.

563
00:29:33.280 --> 00:29:37.440
If you're not familiar with the transport
protocols, you can jump over and

564
00:29:37.440 --> 00:29:39.850
check out our Network Plus show,
we go in depth on it there.

565
00:29:39.850 --> 00:29:44.220
But what it just means is that
DNS can run as a stateful,

566
00:29:44.220 --> 00:29:47.070
reliable connection, or
a best effort connection,

567
00:29:47.070 --> 00:29:50.850
which is designed for networks
where latency is usually a concern.

568
00:29:50.850 --> 00:29:53.320
So it runs on port 53.

569
00:29:53.320 --> 00:29:57.100
You got DHCP, Dynamic Host Configuration
Protocol, it runs on port 68.

570
00:29:57.100 --> 00:30:00.280
When you're exchanging those
requests to get an address,

571
00:30:00.280 --> 00:30:03.290
we've gotta make sure those
are allowed trough our network.

572
00:30:03.290 --> 00:30:07.670
HTTP, which is web access, runs on
port 80, Hyper Text Transfer Protocol.

573
00:30:07.670 --> 00:30:08.850
That's how we browse the web,

574
00:30:08.850 --> 00:30:13.500
a web server's gonna use port 80, and
port 443 is the name thing but secure.

575
00:30:13.500 --> 00:30:17.330
HTTP over SSL,
we use secure communications.

576
00:30:17.330 --> 00:30:21.010
And when I pulled up my
terminal connection earlier and

577
00:30:21.010 --> 00:30:25.050
was looking at all my various
connections to ITProTV,

578
00:30:25.050 --> 00:30:29.250
you'll see where all those went out,
on port 443.

579
00:30:29.250 --> 00:30:32.419
That was me doing a secure web
connection to our website.

580
00:30:33.520 --> 00:30:36.030
Right there you see the connection and
you're in business.

581
00:30:36.030 --> 00:30:39.870
So by knowing those port numbers I
was able to identify that web traffic

582
00:30:39.870 --> 00:30:42.230
very quickly, and
that's why it's important to know these.

583
00:30:42.230 --> 00:30:45.295
It's really helpful for
troubleshooting and other things too.

584
00:30:45.295 --> 00:30:46.345
It's not such a bad list.

585
00:30:46.345 --> 00:30:49.115
I know in the Network Plus show I
have like two screens of this stuff.

586
00:30:49.115 --> 00:30:51.175
In the Linux Plus show I have
two screens of this stuff.

587
00:30:51.175 --> 00:30:53.475
But here we just have to know these seven.

588
00:30:53.475 --> 00:30:54.725
It's not so bad.

589
00:30:54.725 --> 00:30:57.325
But definitely have these memorized before
going into the exam cuz you'll need to

590
00:30:57.325 --> 00:30:58.805
know them.

591
00:30:58.805 --> 00:30:59.365
>> All right, Don.
Well,

592
00:30:59.365 --> 00:31:02.375
that's a good review of network
address translation as well as some of

593
00:31:02.375 --> 00:31:06.190
the port numbers that are very common for
all of to have to get used to.

594
00:31:06.190 --> 00:31:10.280
And remember that going over these network
concepts are actually key if you want

595
00:31:10.280 --> 00:31:15.550
to make sure that you get where
you need to get on your Cloud Plus

596
00:31:15.550 --> 00:31:16.920
certification as well.

597
00:31:16.920 --> 00:31:20.920
Don, any other last minute hints
as they get ready for the exam?

598
00:31:20.920 --> 00:31:21.900
>> That's really it.

599
00:31:21.900 --> 00:31:25.100
Remember, it's not a networking exam, but
these are basic concepts they expect you

600
00:31:25.100 --> 00:31:27.440
to already know, so
that's why it's important to cover them.

601
00:31:27.440 --> 00:31:28.830
If this went way over your head,

602
00:31:28.830 --> 00:31:31.290
if it didn't make sense,
definitely jump over to Network Plus.

603
00:31:31.290 --> 00:31:33.490
Great content over there,
we go in-depth on it.

604
00:31:33.490 --> 00:31:36.820
But if none of this was new to you,
then you're well-prepared.

605
00:31:36.820 --> 00:31:38.630
You got everything you need to know for
networking.

606
00:31:38.630 --> 00:31:41.560
Let's move on to the other technologies
and get to see it working.

607
00:31:41.560 --> 00:31:44.400
But those are just some basic concepts
that we need to make sure we've got

608
00:31:44.400 --> 00:31:45.660
under our belt.

609
00:31:45.660 --> 00:31:46.280
>> All right, Don.

610
00:31:46.280 --> 00:31:48.310
Thank you again for that great review.

611
00:31:48.310 --> 00:31:50.550
Thank you for also joining us too.

612
00:31:50.550 --> 00:31:52.160
Signing off for IT ProTV.

613
00:31:52.160 --> 00:31:53.748
I'm Ronnie Wong.

614
00:31:53.748 --> 00:31:55.436
>> And I'm Don Pizet.

615
00:31:55.436 --> 00:31:57.955
>> And we'll see you next time.

616
00:31:57.955 --> 00:32:04.380
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don discuss advanced networking concepts. They will introduce virtual local area networks(VLAN) and IEEE 802.1Q VLAN trunks. They look at bonding two or more switch ports through a technique call link aggregation. They explain some of the aspects of the network adapters needed in virtualization.
episodes.title: Advanced Networking
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.093 --> 00:00:10.093
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.109 --> 00:00:15.410
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.410 --> 00:00:16.380
I'm your host, Wes Bryan and

4
00:00:16.380 --> 00:00:19.900
in today's episode we're gonna
be moving along in Cloud+.

5
00:00:19.900 --> 00:00:21.230
And who do we have with us today?

6
00:00:21.230 --> 00:00:24.650
None other than Mr. Don Pezet to help
us get our head out of the clouds, or

7
00:00:24.650 --> 00:00:26.290
in this case, maybe in the clouds.

8
00:00:26.290 --> 00:00:27.320
How we doing today, Don?

9
00:00:27.320 --> 00:00:28.260
I am doing great, Wes.

10
00:00:28.260 --> 00:00:32.120
Thanks for having me on the show and
ready to dive into the world of advanced

11
00:00:32.120 --> 00:00:35.200
networking inside of
a virtualization cloud.

12
00:00:35.200 --> 00:00:37.830
And remember when we talk about
that cloud we're talking about

13
00:00:37.830 --> 00:00:40.710
hosted solutions out there on
the Internet as well as private,

14
00:00:40.710 --> 00:00:43.450
internal clouds that we've built
up with our own infrastructure.

15
00:00:43.450 --> 00:00:47.118
And all of them have certain things that
we can tweak with networking to improve

16
00:00:47.118 --> 00:00:49.741
performance, get things
running as best as possible.

17
00:00:49.741 --> 00:00:53.520
We're gonna take a look at some of those
bells and whistles right in this episode.

18
00:00:53.520 --> 00:00:55.310
All right well, what we're gonna do is,

19
00:00:55.310 --> 00:00:58.888
we're gonna kick off talking about
virtual local area networks, or VLANs.

20
00:00:58.888 --> 00:01:01.170
I know I've mentioned them
briefly in a few other episodes,

21
00:01:01.170 --> 00:01:03.650
I think three different episodes
we've mentioned them briefly.

22
00:01:03.650 --> 00:01:07.180
In this episode we're gonna actually see
how they work and how we can use them.

23
00:01:07.180 --> 00:01:11.142
And one of the big challenges that we have
when we're doing virtualization is you

24
00:01:11.142 --> 00:01:12.957
have to have a virtualization host.

25
00:01:12.957 --> 00:01:17.120
And that host might be VMware ESX,
it might be Citrix Xenserver or whatever.

26
00:01:17.120 --> 00:01:20.976
And that host, it's a piece of
hardware and it can only have so

27
00:01:20.976 --> 00:01:23.220
many network adapters in it.

28
00:01:23.220 --> 00:01:27.675
So if I have, let's say I've got 15
virtual machines running on that host.

29
00:01:27.675 --> 00:01:31.000
I got tons of memory, tons of CPU,
I've got 15 VM's running.

30
00:01:31.000 --> 00:01:34.010
Am I gonna have 15 network cards for
those VM's?

31
00:01:34.010 --> 00:01:35.590
Pretty doubtful, right?

32
00:01:35.590 --> 00:01:38.730
Almost every server today comes
with two network adapters.

33
00:01:38.730 --> 00:01:41.534
And the intention of those two network
adapters is that you use one for

34
00:01:41.534 --> 00:01:44.210
management and you use the other for
actual data flow.

35
00:01:44.210 --> 00:01:48.380
But if I have 15 VMs, I don't want
them all on one network adapter, do I?

36
00:01:48.380 --> 00:01:51.670
Well, maybe, if it's only a 10 gig
adapter, if you got tons of bandwidth, or

37
00:01:51.670 --> 00:01:53.960
maybe it's a low bandwidth application,

38
00:01:53.960 --> 00:01:56.380
like an Active Directory
domain controller.

39
00:01:56.380 --> 00:01:59.080
Domain controllers don't need a ton of
bandwidth, they just need to be up and

40
00:01:59.080 --> 00:02:00.200
available, right?

41
00:02:00.200 --> 00:02:03.544
So we can have 15 machines sharing
a single adapter if we want.

42
00:02:03.544 --> 00:02:08.069
But the odds are we're gonna want
some kind of isolation between those

43
00:02:08.069 --> 00:02:09.750
virtual machines.

44
00:02:09.750 --> 00:02:15.155
That one VM might not be something we
want sitting right next to another VM.

45
00:02:15.155 --> 00:02:18.340
A great example would be,
let's say that we had a DMZ, right.

46
00:02:18.340 --> 00:02:21.000
I've got a web server that I want
to be publicly internet facing.

47
00:02:21.000 --> 00:02:23.630
I want everybody else in
the Internet to see this web server.

48
00:02:23.630 --> 00:02:26.270
But then I've got an Active Directory
domain controller

49
00:02:26.270 --> 00:02:28.170
that I don't want everybody to see.

50
00:02:28.170 --> 00:02:30.550
I want that to be internal only, right.

51
00:02:30.550 --> 00:02:35.420
So I have my LAN resources and my DMZ
resources and I wanna isolate those out.

52
00:02:35.420 --> 00:02:38.985
Well in the past, you had to get
separate physical network adapters.

53
00:02:38.985 --> 00:02:39.505
And you'd say, all right,

54
00:02:39.505 --> 00:02:42.525
well this physical adapter is
gonna be tied to the LAN, and

55
00:02:42.525 --> 00:02:46.335
this other physical adapter is gonna
be type to the WAN, or DMZ or whatever.

56
00:02:46.335 --> 00:02:48.865
And so you'd have to have
multiple network adapters.

57
00:02:48.865 --> 00:02:50.305
But eventually you run out of slots,

58
00:02:50.305 --> 00:02:52.755
you can only get fit many
adapters in that server.

59
00:02:52.755 --> 00:02:53.605
And so what we can do is,

60
00:02:53.605 --> 00:02:58.030
instead of doing physical adapters,
we can do virtual local area networks.

61
00:02:58.030 --> 00:03:01.550
We can divide that one connector
up into several smaller networks.

62
00:03:01.550 --> 00:03:04.410
And there's a number of big benefits for
doing that, but

63
00:03:04.410 --> 00:03:08.920
basically it's gonna divide that up and
allow us to share that resource.

64
00:03:08.920 --> 00:03:12.514
>> Don, one of the questions I have,
they call out on Cloud+,

65
00:03:12.514 --> 00:03:17.440
they talk about things like multitenancy
and network segregation, right?

66
00:03:17.440 --> 00:03:21.585
And if I do have multiple tenants
from a cloud provider's perspective,

67
00:03:21.585 --> 00:03:24.380
and we need to enforce things
like data security standards,

68
00:03:24.380 --> 00:03:25.810
is this the way that they can do that?

69
00:03:25.810 --> 00:03:29.575
How they can segregate those networks
from one another inside of the cloud?

70
00:03:29.575 --> 00:03:32.420
>> It certainly is, I mean, with VLANs
what you're doing is you're taking

71
00:03:32.420 --> 00:03:36.600
a physical switch, and you're dividing
the physical switch up into multiple

72
00:03:36.600 --> 00:03:38.480
virtual switches, logical switches.

73
00:03:38.480 --> 00:03:40.990
And if somebody's plugged into one
of those virtual switches they

74
00:03:40.990 --> 00:03:44.200
only see the other devices
on that virtual switch.

75
00:03:44.200 --> 00:03:47.723
So if we were hosting VMs for more than
one company, you could do this and

76
00:03:47.723 --> 00:03:50.550
isolate them out and
they wouldn't see each other.

77
00:03:50.550 --> 00:03:54.870
Right, now if you're ultra super
top secret security, you might opt

78
00:03:54.870 --> 00:03:58.050
to do separate physical switches,
completely separate infrastructures.

79
00:03:58.050 --> 00:04:00.950
Because there are certain
attacks that people can wage

80
00:04:00.950 --> 00:04:04.410
to do what's called VLAN hopping, right,
to try and jump from one VLAN to another.

81
00:04:04.410 --> 00:04:07.984
Same thing with virtual machines, in
theory every virtual machine is isolated,

82
00:04:07.984 --> 00:04:09.609
they're separate from each other.

83
00:04:09.609 --> 00:04:11.944
But there's certain memory
attacks that they can try and

84
00:04:11.944 --> 00:04:14.627
perform against the host OS to try and
read memory from other VMs.

85
00:04:14.627 --> 00:04:18.851
Most of those don't, they're patched,
they don't happen anymore, but

86
00:04:18.851 --> 00:04:20.180
it is a potential risk.

87
00:04:20.180 --> 00:04:22.293
And so
some people don't like to use VLANs.

88
00:04:22.293 --> 00:04:26.380
But for most people, and by most I
mean 99% of the people out there,

89
00:04:26.380 --> 00:04:28.200
VLANs are a perfect solution.

90
00:04:28.200 --> 00:04:31.700
They give you a very high degree of
security and let you dice up that network,

91
00:04:31.700 --> 00:04:33.940
get a chance kinda see what that does.

92
00:04:33.940 --> 00:04:39.410
Now understand that when we create VLANs,
these are separate, isolated networks.

93
00:04:39.410 --> 00:04:42.350
And by default,
the VLANs cannot see each other,

94
00:04:42.350 --> 00:04:45.490
they are completely partitioned off,
they're completely separate.

95
00:04:45.490 --> 00:04:48.677
So if I create virtual machines and place
them in one VLAN and I take other virtual

96
00:04:48.677 --> 00:04:51.735
machines and place them with a different
VLAN, they cannot see each other.

97
00:04:51.735 --> 00:04:55.830
So I'm still going to need some sort
of routing infrastructure to be able to

98
00:04:55.830 --> 00:04:58.108
communicate traffic between the VLANs.

99
00:04:58.108 --> 00:05:01.220
And on the exam objectives they call
out routing and routing tables.

100
00:05:01.220 --> 00:05:05.210
Right, because each VLAN is
gonna have its own IP subnet.

101
00:05:05.210 --> 00:05:08.775
And so when you have a router, its routing
table has got to be updated to contain all

102
00:05:08.775 --> 00:05:12.760
the networks that you've created for
these VLANs, right, that's important.

103
00:05:12.760 --> 00:05:14.390
And so we've gotta designate that,

104
00:05:14.390 --> 00:05:17.760
we've gotta create those resources and
flag them and have it available.

105
00:05:17.760 --> 00:05:19.380
Now you're router,
it might be a physical router.

106
00:05:19.380 --> 00:05:23.728
You might have a Cisco router, or Juniper,
or somebody like that that's plugged into

107
00:05:23.728 --> 00:05:26.067
these VLANs and
is able to route between them.

108
00:05:26.067 --> 00:05:28.555
Or you might have a software router.

109
00:05:28.555 --> 00:05:29.965
Plenty of virtualization
platforms have it,

110
00:05:29.965 --> 00:05:31.575
I know I've shown that in other episodes.

111
00:05:31.575 --> 00:05:35.955
But there's also things like the pfSense
firewall that you can run in a virtual

112
00:05:35.955 --> 00:05:38.045
machine and it can route between
all the different VLANs.

113
00:05:38.045 --> 00:05:41.337
You can really get kinda powerful with
this stuff, it's pretty neat, so.

114
00:05:41.337 --> 00:05:43.217
All right well,
I've kinda been talking about it here, but

115
00:05:43.217 --> 00:05:44.877
let me show how this works.
