all that stuff, it's just a lot of work.

554
00:28:20.600 --> 00:28:25.220
And so, in servers a lot of times you'll
find where the network adapters support

555
00:28:25.220 --> 00:28:27.600
what's called a TCP offload engine,
or TOE.

556
00:28:27.600 --> 00:28:30.920
Here they're calling it
TCP Checksum Offload, but

557
00:28:30.920 --> 00:28:32.690
on the adapters is normally TOE, right?

558
00:28:33.960 --> 00:28:37.140
On a dedicated server, we don't
really care all that much about it,

559
00:28:37.140 --> 00:28:41.050
maybe on a file server, but on your normal
like DNS or domain controller, whatever,

560
00:28:41.050 --> 00:28:42.250
you don't really care about it.

561
00:28:42.250 --> 00:28:45.600
But on a virtualization host,
it really makes a difference.

562
00:28:45.600 --> 00:28:48.680
It takes that layer four transport
protocol and the work that it does,

563
00:28:48.680 --> 00:28:52.400
the sequence numbers and all that,
and it does it in hardware, so

564
00:28:52.400 --> 00:28:55.040
instead of relying on your software,
your general purpose CPU,

565
00:28:55.040 --> 00:28:57.670
to do it, it can do it right
here in dedicated hardware.

566
00:28:57.670 --> 00:29:01.600
Notice on mine, not only does it
support it, but it's turned on, right?

567
00:29:01.600 --> 00:29:05.160
You can tweak that and turn it off, or
set it to receive or transmit only.

568
00:29:05.160 --> 00:29:06.490
You want it on, right?

569
00:29:06.490 --> 00:29:09.740
Not only do you want it on, you want to
make sure when you buy your adapters that

570
00:29:09.740 --> 00:29:10.740
this is something you think about.

571
00:29:10.740 --> 00:29:14.930
When I go shopping for an adapter,
I want it to have a TCP offload engine.

572
00:29:14.930 --> 00:29:17.030
It's pretty common these days,
it used to be pretty rare, and

573
00:29:17.030 --> 00:29:19.450
you had to pay a lot more to get it.

574
00:29:19.450 --> 00:29:22.820
These days it's built into most server
NICs, but if you're using desktop grade

575
00:29:22.820 --> 00:29:26.660
NICs, they're not gonna have this and your
performance is gonna suffer as a result.

576
00:29:26.660 --> 00:29:27.970
>> Your virtualization host,

577
00:29:27.970 --> 00:29:31.710
it is important just like we talked about
in other virtualization episodes that that

578
00:29:31.710 --> 00:29:35.030
physical network adapter is
obviously going to be important.

579
00:29:35.030 --> 00:29:38.650
Without the physical network adapter, the
virtual network adapters don't work, and

580
00:29:38.650 --> 00:29:42.150
as you start adding more VMs,
you start adding more trunks,

581
00:29:42.150 --> 00:29:45.520
you're definitely going to have to pay
attention to this as far as speed and

582
00:29:45.520 --> 00:29:47.520
the type of network adapters you buy.

583
00:29:47.520 --> 00:29:48.990
>> Absolutely, absolutely.

584
00:29:48.990 --> 00:29:53.060
You mentioned speed, when you buy network
adapters, you can get 100 megabit

585
00:29:53.060 --> 00:29:57.650
adapters, you can get gigabit adapters,
you can get 10 gig adapters, right?

586
00:29:57.650 --> 00:30:00.510
You need to make sure that you buy
the adapters that are right for

587
00:30:00.510 --> 00:30:02.650
the amount of traffic you're
going to be handling, right?

588
00:30:02.650 --> 00:30:04.350
You've got to look at
the bandwidth utilization of

589
00:30:04.350 --> 00:30:07.630
each of your virtual machines and
add it all up and say, hey, at peak time,

590
00:30:07.630 --> 00:30:10.970
what is the maximum amount of bandwidth
I might be pushing out of these VMs?

591
00:30:10.970 --> 00:30:13.330
Do I have the physical
infrastructure to handle that?

592
00:30:13.330 --> 00:30:16.330
Because if you don't,
your network performance is gonna suffer.

593
00:30:16.330 --> 00:30:20.550
You might have a file server that normally
runs just fine on a gig connection, but

594
00:30:20.550 --> 00:30:23.420
when you virtualize it and
it's sitting next to a Web server and

595
00:30:23.420 --> 00:30:26.990
a database server and a few other things,
you might find the network gets saturated.

596
00:30:26.990 --> 00:30:28.920
Now the server is slower
when it's virtualized, and

597
00:30:28.920 --> 00:30:30.640
you start blaming
the virtualization platform, but

598
00:30:30.640 --> 00:30:32.190
it's not the platform's fault.

599
00:30:32.190 --> 00:30:35.197
It's that you've got more than one
resource all sharing that single gig

600
00:30:35.197 --> 00:30:37.772
connection, so
in those scenarios you've got two choices.

601
00:30:37.772 --> 00:30:41.732
Choice number one,
is to add more network adapters, right?

602
00:30:41.732 --> 00:30:43.927
You could add more network adapters,
bond them together and

603
00:30:43.927 --> 00:30:45.490
you will get more bandwidth.

604
00:30:45.490 --> 00:30:48.070
Or choice number two,
I guess it's three choices, right?

605
00:30:48.070 --> 00:30:51.860
Because you could buy a faster adapter, if
you've got gig, you guys buy ten gig, but

606
00:30:51.860 --> 00:30:56.020
if you've got ten gig, there's not really
anything above that to buy, right?

607
00:30:56.020 --> 00:31:00.690
At that point, what you may need to do
is go to dedicated network adapters.

608
00:31:00.690 --> 00:31:01.610
Just because these machines

609
00:31:01.610 --> 00:31:04.120
are virtualized doesn't mean they
can't have a dedicated adapter.

610
00:31:04.120 --> 00:31:07.995
I might buy an extra network adapter card
to stick in my host and say this one

611
00:31:07.995 --> 00:31:11.886
virtual machine is the only thing
attached to that one physical adapter.

612
00:31:11.886 --> 00:31:14.311
Now it's got a dedicated adapter and
it gets all the bandwidth it needs.

613
00:31:14.311 --> 00:31:17.290
That may be necessary especially
on a file server, right?

614
00:31:17.290 --> 00:31:19.980
Or a database server that's
doing live replication.

615
00:31:19.980 --> 00:31:22.440
You want to ensure that replication
is as low latency as possible.

616
00:31:22.440 --> 00:31:25.451
You want a dedicated link to do that,
so you get those extra network adapters,

617
00:31:25.451 --> 00:31:28.080
you get them put in there,
and now you get it going, so

618
00:31:28.080 --> 00:31:30.940
thinking about the quantity of your
network adapters is important.

619
00:31:30.940 --> 00:31:32.510
When I deploy virtual machine hosts,

620
00:31:32.510 --> 00:31:35.450
I pretty much always deploy four adapters,
right?

621
00:31:35.450 --> 00:31:36.840
Mostly cuz you can't buy three,

622
00:31:36.840 --> 00:31:41.420
you go from one to two to four usually,
but I like to have one adapter for

623
00:31:41.420 --> 00:31:46.190
management and then two adapters
bonded for my virtual machines.

624
00:31:46.190 --> 00:31:47.800
That's kind of what I like to have.

625
00:31:47.800 --> 00:31:50.830
If I need any other dedicated NICs,
then I'll bring those in for VMs.

626
00:31:50.830 --> 00:31:53.680
I might have more, or
if I wanna do more than two bonded NICs,

627
00:31:53.680 --> 00:31:56.310
then we may do that too and
bring those in, but

628
00:31:56.310 --> 00:31:59.720
usually I do a minimum of three
adapters for virtual machine host.

629
00:31:59.720 --> 00:32:03.250
If you're doing iSCSI or
any kind of network attached storage,

630
00:32:03.250 --> 00:32:04.710
you may want to have
dedicated adapters for

631
00:32:04.710 --> 00:32:07.860
that, and so in those scenarios,
I'll usually go up to like five adapters.

632
00:32:07.860 --> 00:32:11.910
One adapter dedicated for management,
two bonded for virtual machine data, and

633
00:32:11.910 --> 00:32:16.480
two bonded for storage data, so I've got
dedicated storage network performance.

634
00:32:16.480 --> 00:32:18.650
It's up to you how many adapters you need.

635
00:32:18.650 --> 00:32:21.070
Just remember, if you're trying
to set up some kind of a cluster,

636
00:32:21.070 --> 00:32:23.752
where VMs can fail over from
one host to another to another.

637
00:32:23.752 --> 00:32:28.820
VMware's VMotion, where you can live
migrate a VM from one host to another,

638
00:32:28.820 --> 00:32:31.930
you gotta have a similar
configuration in each.

639
00:32:31.930 --> 00:32:34.340
Otherwise, the VM is going to
jump over to another host and

640
00:32:34.340 --> 00:32:36.650
not have a network connection, and then
it might as well be turned off, right?

641
00:32:36.650 --> 00:32:38.370
And so that's something to think about.

642
00:32:38.370 --> 00:32:39.990
>> All right,
great information there, Don.

643
00:32:39.990 --> 00:32:42.420
We've gone through a lot today,
we've talked about VLANs,

644
00:32:42.420 --> 00:32:43.980
the virtual local area networks.

645
00:32:43.980 --> 00:32:47.700
We've also showed you some examples of how
to set them up, we've talked about how

646
00:32:47.700 --> 00:32:50.830
if you need increased performance,
because maybe you have a lot of machines

647
00:32:50.830 --> 00:32:53.550
connecting to a single point,
you can bond them together, right?

648
00:32:53.550 --> 00:32:57.670
Take multiple ports, aggregate them,
and you have a super port, if you will.

649
00:32:57.670 --> 00:33:01.330
We've also talked about the network
adapters themselves and

650
00:33:01.330 --> 00:33:04.470
some of the criteria,
some of the characteristics or

651
00:33:04.470 --> 00:33:07.780
specifications you need to keep in mind
when you are going to support this.

652
00:33:07.780 --> 00:33:09.550
Don, do you have anything else for us?

653
00:33:09.550 --> 00:33:10.290
>> I think that's about it.

654
00:33:10.290 --> 00:33:13.650
We are going to do a little bit more
networking in the next episode so

655
00:33:13.650 --> 00:33:18.250
check that out, but as far VLANs and
the quantities reports,

656
00:33:18.250 --> 00:33:21.720
the port aggregation and stuff,
that's a pretty good rundown of it.

657
00:33:21.720 --> 00:33:24.660
Just remember that, depending on
the solution you guys go with,

658
00:33:24.660 --> 00:33:27.430
depending on the vendors of hardware you
use, you may have to apply this a little

659
00:33:27.430 --> 00:33:29.720
bit differently, but
the concept is always the same.

660
00:33:29.720 --> 00:33:33.630
>> All right, well, then, bringing this
episode to a close, I've been your host,

661
00:33:33.630 --> 00:33:34.610
Wes Bryan.

662
00:33:34.610 --> 00:33:35.470
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

663
00:33:35.470 --> 00:33:39.405
>> And we'll see you next time.

664
00:33:39.405 --> 00:33:45.850
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take a look at different network optimization techniques. They will explore different network types such as wide area networks, local area networks and metropolitan area networks. They discuss different techniques to keep these network connection running efficiently and effectively like clustering, load balancing, compression and caching. They demonstrate tools like ping, nslookup, traceroute and ifconfig to troubleshooting network connections as well.
episodes.title: Networking Optimization
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.169 --> 00:00:14.630
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.630 --> 00:00:17.010
I'm your host Wes Brian,
and in today's episode,

4
00:00:17.010 --> 00:00:19.060
we're going to be continuing
along with cloud plus.

5
00:00:19.060 --> 00:00:23.290
And we're going to be looking more
specifically at network optimizations day.

6
00:00:23.290 --> 00:00:26.560
And we have on hand to help us out with
everything that is known as the Cloud,

7
00:00:26.560 --> 00:00:27.420
Mr Don Pezet.

8
00:00:27.420 --> 00:00:28.670
Don, how are you doing today, sir?

9
00:00:28.670 --> 00:00:29.740
>> I am doing great Wes.

10
00:00:29.740 --> 00:00:33.300
Ready to jump right back into the world of
networking on a virtualization platform.

11
00:00:33.300 --> 00:00:34.030
In the last episode,

12
00:00:34.030 --> 00:00:36.970
we talked about some of the advanced
networking features that are out there.

13
00:00:36.970 --> 00:00:37.790
And in this episode,

14
00:00:37.790 --> 00:00:40.840
we're going to be just taking a look
at ways that we can optimize.

15
00:00:40.840 --> 00:00:42.800
And troubleshoot
the networks that we've got.

16
00:00:42.800 --> 00:00:45.210
And there's definitely some
considerations we have to have,

17
00:00:45.210 --> 00:00:46.920
when we deploy this
type of infrastructure.

18
00:00:46.920 --> 00:00:49.480
And that pretty much anybody is
going to to have to deal with.

19
00:00:49.480 --> 00:00:53.040
The first thing I want to address is,
that in the last episode we talked about

20
00:00:53.040 --> 00:00:55.350
three network divisions,
that Comptia makes.

21
00:00:55.350 --> 00:00:58.910
Internet, intranet, and extranet.

22
00:00:58.910 --> 00:01:01.750
And those are as they
pertain to our servers and

23
00:01:01.750 --> 00:01:03.090
who those servers are available to.

24
00:01:03.090 --> 00:01:05.630
So I said at the time,
that an intranet system,

25
00:01:05.630 --> 00:01:09.175
that was the server that was
available to our internal employees.

26
00:01:09.175 --> 00:01:12.880
An extranet system, was the one that
was available to our customers.

27
00:01:12.880 --> 00:01:15.456
Or third party vendors that
we were partnered with.

28
00:01:15.456 --> 00:01:18.390
An internet system's were one's
connected to the internet.

29
00:01:18.390 --> 00:01:21.820
That were public to the whole world,
anybody connected to the internet.

30
00:01:21.820 --> 00:01:26.500
Well those terms, are really describing
the networks and the virtual machines and

31
00:01:26.500 --> 00:01:28.110
what their exposure is.

32
00:01:28.110 --> 00:01:31.510
But there's another set of terms that
CompTIA wants you to be aware of

33
00:01:31.510 --> 00:01:32.370
for the exam.

34
00:01:32.370 --> 00:01:36.270
That really describe
the connection itself, right.

35
00:01:36.270 --> 00:01:40.900
And those are WAN, LAN,
and MAN, all right.

36
00:01:40.900 --> 00:01:44.240
Lets start with WAN,
WAN is wide area network.

37
00:01:44.240 --> 00:01:47.860
And a wide area network, that's usually
your connection to the internet.

38
00:01:47.860 --> 00:01:50.240
But it can also be private
connections between you and

39
00:01:50.240 --> 00:01:51.370
your branch offices, right.

40
00:01:51.370 --> 00:01:54.240
And WANs don't have to
be internet connections.

41
00:01:54.240 --> 00:01:56.690
They don't have to be public,
but they oftentimes are.

42
00:01:56.690 --> 00:01:59.610
So, with a wide area network,
these are not lines that you own.

43
00:01:59.610 --> 00:02:01.200
This is not something that you control.

44
00:02:01.200 --> 00:02:05.500
It's a link that runs,
typically from your home office to an ISP.

45
00:02:05.500 --> 00:02:09.170
That gives you Internet access, or
from your home office to a branch office.

46
00:02:09.170 --> 00:02:12.230
But the lines themselves
are owned by who knows who?

47
00:02:12.230 --> 00:02:18.010
A level three AT&T cogent, whoever it
is that you're buying your lines from.

48
00:02:18.010 --> 00:02:21.230
They're the ones that are providing that
and you basically lease them, right.

49
00:02:21.230 --> 00:02:24.080
A lot of people call them leased lines,
because you're paying every month for

50
00:02:24.080 --> 00:02:24.994
access to that line.

51
00:02:24.994 --> 00:02:27.950
T-ones would be an example of this.

52
00:02:27.950 --> 00:02:32.700
There's other technologies like
frame relay and MPLS circuits and

53
00:02:32.700 --> 00:02:34.220
all sorts of technologies like that.

54
00:02:34.220 --> 00:02:36.310
Those are a part of wide area networks.

55
00:02:36.310 --> 00:02:39.920
But also we've got cable modems and
DSL, right.

56
00:02:39.920 --> 00:02:44.750
the high speed broadband connections,
those fall under wide area networks also.

57
00:02:44.750 --> 00:02:45.940
Now, why do I bring that up here?

58
00:02:45.940 --> 00:02:47.445
Because we're talking
about virtualization,

59
00:02:47.445 --> 00:02:48.650
what do we care about that?

60
00:02:48.650 --> 00:02:51.050
Well, the big thing we need
to be concerned with is,

61
00:02:51.050 --> 00:02:53.320
that a wide area network.

62
00:02:53.320 --> 00:02:56.980
Is normally the lowest amount of
bandwidth you have in your communication.

63
00:02:56.980 --> 00:02:59.490
When a customer connects to you or
your end users connect.

64
00:02:59.490 --> 00:03:01.920
It's usually the wide area network
that serves as a bottleneck.

65
00:03:01.920 --> 00:03:05.830
So, anytime you have virtual machines
that are exposed to a wide area network.

66
00:03:05.830 --> 00:03:07.520
They need to be efficient.

67
00:03:07.520 --> 00:03:10.900
They need to be as efficient as
possible to make use of the bandwidth

68
00:03:10.900 --> 00:03:12.090
that they have.

69
00:03:12.090 --> 00:03:15.420
If we're doing things like live
migrating virtual machines.

70
00:03:15.420 --> 00:03:17.100
I have a virtual machine
that's running on host one and

71
00:03:17.100 --> 00:03:18.700
I want to fail it over to host two.

72
00:03:18.700 --> 00:03:22.400
Well, if those two hosts are right next
to each other on the same network.

73
00:03:22.400 --> 00:03:24.090
You're going to get the best
performance possible.

74
00:03:24.090 --> 00:03:27.840
You can fail over, your end users won't
even notice the system goes offline.

75
00:03:27.840 --> 00:03:30.260
It's a smooth and fluid motion, right.

76
00:03:30.260 --> 00:03:33.030
But a VM host 01 is in your headquarters.

77
00:03:33.030 --> 00:03:37.380
And VM host 02 is in your disaster
recovery center, halfway across the state,

78
00:03:37.380 --> 00:03:39.290
or even in another country.

79
00:03:39.290 --> 00:03:42.830
Well, your replication between those two
systems is going to have some latency

80
00:03:42.830 --> 00:03:43.680
to it, right.

81
00:03:43.680 --> 00:03:46.660
Your wide area network doesn't
have enough bandwidth to be doing

82
00:03:46.660 --> 00:03:48.690
real time replication.

83
00:03:48.690 --> 00:03:52.580
And so, you end up with delays, and
if you want to do a fail over like that,

84
00:03:52.580 --> 00:03:53.720
your end users do see it.

85
00:03:53.720 --> 00:03:56.540
They see that it takes time to make
it over to the other side, and

86
00:03:56.540 --> 00:03:58.350
then that is a bit of a problem, right.

87
00:03:58.350 --> 00:04:00.870
So, that's something that we
need to keep an eye out for

88
00:04:00.870 --> 00:04:03.320
when we're building up our topologies.

89
00:04:03.320 --> 00:04:04.960
That you want to have
a disaster recovery center.

90
00:04:04.960 --> 00:04:07.465
You want to have these other locations,
that might be out there on a WAN.

91
00:04:07.465 --> 00:04:11.970
But, you don't want to do things like
virtual machine replication over them.

92
00:04:11.970 --> 00:04:15.420
If you're trying to minimize the latency,
right.

93
00:04:15.420 --> 00:04:20.170
So, I might need to maintain multiple
replicas of the server in my headquarters.

94
00:04:20.170 --> 00:04:21.790
I don't want to have just one VM Host.

95
00:04:21.790 --> 00:04:25.330
I might want to have five or ten or
even 100 VM hosts, to host all my guests,

96
00:04:25.330 --> 00:04:27.170
all my virtual machines.

97
00:04:27.170 --> 00:04:29.710
But at my disaster recovery center,
I might only have 10 or 15 of them.

98
00:04:29.710 --> 00:04:33.500
And just my mission critical servers
are getting replicated to the other side.

99
00:04:33.500 --> 00:04:36.035
I'm trying to optimize that link.

100
00:04:36.035 --> 00:04:37.405
On the local area network,
on the LAN side,

101
00:04:37.405 --> 00:04:39.835
usually that's where we
have the most bandwidth.

102
00:04:39.835 --> 00:04:41.365
You have tons of bandwidth internally.

103
00:04:41.365 --> 00:04:43.995
And so, you can do things
like replicating clusters and

104
00:04:43.995 --> 00:04:45.205
take all the bandwidth you want.

105
00:04:45.205 --> 00:04:46.505
You'll have a little latency.

106
00:04:46.505 --> 00:04:48.695
Things work great in
your local area network.

107
00:04:48.695 --> 00:04:50.345
The problem is,
if your building is destroyed,

108
00:04:50.345 --> 00:04:52.055
your whole local area
network is destroyed.

109
00:04:52.055 --> 00:04:53.865
You just lost all that access.

110
00:04:53.865 --> 00:04:54.695
That's why it's so

111
00:04:54.695 --> 00:04:58.660
important to have a WAN somewhere
that you can replicate to, right.

112
00:04:58.660 --> 00:05:00.030
Now, the third one that
I mentioned is a MAN.

113

00:27:13.570 --> 00:27:16.820
If I've got management ports on
my virtualization host or even

557
00:27:16.820 --> 00:27:22.100
the configuration of my virtual machines,
right, we might have to set ip addresses.

558
00:27:22.100 --> 00:27:24.860
In the Windows world you
have the ip config command,

559
00:27:24.860 --> 00:27:26.840
which is not present in the Unix world.

560
00:27:26.840 --> 00:27:28.600
I say it, but then it worked, didn't it?

561
00:27:28.600 --> 00:27:30.910
Well, anyhow,
let me jump over to a Windows box and

562
00:27:30.910 --> 00:27:33.690
I'll show you here on a Windows machine.

563
00:27:33.690 --> 00:27:36.930
If I run ipconfig,
it's gonna show me my network adapters and

564
00:27:36.930 --> 00:27:38.470
their default gateway and
their subnet mask.

565
00:27:38.470 --> 00:27:41.190
We talked about that back in
the network concepts episode.

566
00:27:41.190 --> 00:27:43.762
But if you're on a Unix machine,
you may not have that.

567
00:27:43.762 --> 00:27:48.367
On a Unix machine, the command that
we normally run here is ifconfig, or

568
00:27:48.367 --> 00:27:52.217
interface config,
kind of like ipconfig but ifconfig, and

569
00:27:52.217 --> 00:27:55.935
it'll show you all your adapters and
their IP addresses.

570
00:27:55.935 --> 00:27:57.793
You don't get as much data, though,

571
00:27:57.793 --> 00:28:00.240
I don't get the subnet
masks that are being used.

572
00:28:00.240 --> 00:28:02.570
So I might have to dig through
my configs to find those, but

573
00:28:02.570 --> 00:28:05.340
it's kind of an alternative
to that command, all right.

574
00:28:05.340 --> 00:28:08.470
On some newer Linux systems,
you might not have IF config.

575
00:28:08.470 --> 00:28:11.880
You do on VMWare ESX and
Citrix Zen server, they've got it.

576
00:28:11.880 --> 00:28:15.230
But if you're building up
your own KVM host, and

577
00:28:15.230 --> 00:28:18.720
you run on the newer versions of CentOS,
they don't have ifconfig anymore.

578
00:28:18.720 --> 00:28:22.040
So you might need to use
the ip addr command.

579
00:28:22.040 --> 00:28:25.084
And you'll see,
I don't have it on this system, but

580
00:28:25.084 --> 00:28:29.501
that'll show your IP addressing also,
it's kind of another way to view it.

581
00:28:29.501 --> 00:28:30.290
Let's see, route.

582
00:28:30.290 --> 00:28:33.207
I mentioned routing tables in the last
episode, if we have VLANs and

583
00:28:33.207 --> 00:28:36.398
different networks that are out there,
we need to know how to get to them.

584
00:28:36.398 --> 00:28:38.525
Well, if you've got a router
that takes care of it, but

585
00:28:38.525 --> 00:28:41.424
if you don't have a router you can
actually use your own machine as a router,

586
00:28:41.424 --> 00:28:44.480
or you can even put static routes and
you do it with the route command.

587
00:28:44.480 --> 00:28:46.920
The route command is present in Windows,
as well as Linux and

588
00:28:46.920 --> 00:28:48.580
Unix, so you've got it.

589
00:28:48.580 --> 00:28:53.690
And basically you can just come in and
specify different routes that

590
00:28:53.690 --> 00:28:58.760
you want to put in and, they don't
give me any examples here, do they?

591
00:28:58.760 --> 00:29:01.600
>> Kind of like in Windows if you
want to see the routing table,

592
00:29:01.600 --> 00:29:05.580
you can just do a route print command,
and it just outputs the route command.

593
00:29:05.580 --> 00:29:08.220
>> Yeah.
>> Or you could do a route print dash

594
00:29:08.220 --> 00:29:11.550
four, I think, and
it just shows you the IPv4 information so

595
00:29:11.550 --> 00:29:12.620
you can filter it even more there.

596
00:29:12.620 --> 00:29:16.230
>> Yeah, absolutely, so you he's talking
about the route print command So

597
00:29:16.230 --> 00:29:19.050
you can see that routing table and
the different things that are listed.

598
00:29:19.050 --> 00:29:21.750
And so there's all the IPs that we know
about and the links that we get to them.

599
00:29:21.750 --> 00:29:22.745
Unix is the same way.

600
00:29:22.745 --> 00:29:25.728
In fact, I think it is what is a route- a.

601
00:29:25.728 --> 00:29:28.445
It's something.

602
00:29:28.445 --> 00:29:30.861
You run route something.

603
00:29:30.861 --> 00:29:33.760
[LAUGH] It'll display the routing table,
so you can add routes and

604
00:29:33.760 --> 00:29:36.010
stuff to it too if you
need to manipulate that.

605
00:29:36.010 --> 00:29:37.960
>> Typically, we don't need to
though because you actually have

606
00:29:37.960 --> 00:29:42.330
routers that are doing that job and not
necessarily your virtualization platform.

607
00:29:42.330 --> 00:29:43.900
Another one that I use a lot is arp.

608
00:29:43.900 --> 00:29:47.290
Arp is incredibly useful,
especially when you have bonded NICs.

609
00:29:47.290 --> 00:29:50.730
If we've got multiple network adapters
bonded together like we saw in the last

610
00:29:50.730 --> 00:29:54.190
episode, well, we need to make sure
that they're actually functioning.

611
00:29:54.190 --> 00:29:57.250
And a quick arp -a is
a great way to see that.

612
00:29:57.250 --> 00:30:01.230
Arp -a shows all the IP
addresses you've learned and

613
00:30:01.230 --> 00:30:03.930
their corresponding Mac addresses.

614
00:30:03.930 --> 00:30:06.810
So what Mac address has
been tied to what IP, and

615
00:30:06.810 --> 00:30:09.560
more importantly,
what adapter they were learned on.

616
00:30:09.560 --> 00:30:13.890
See how I've got some learned on en0,
and some on en4, right?

617
00:30:13.890 --> 00:30:17.230
So some were learned on my Ethernet
adapter 0, some on Ethernet adapter 4,

618
00:30:17.230 --> 00:30:19.870
that's how I know both
adapters are working.

619
00:30:19.870 --> 00:30:23.130
If I think that I'm load balancing
across NICs and I check my ARP table and

620
00:30:23.130 --> 00:30:27.120
I only see entries on one adapter,
then I'm not load balancing.

621
00:30:27.120 --> 00:30:31.090
Now I might be in a active/passive
failover type configuration, or

622
00:30:31.090 --> 00:30:33.000
the other one might just
not be working at all and

623
00:30:33.000 --> 00:30:34.710
everything's having to
default to one adapter.

624
00:30:34.710 --> 00:30:39.060
Just be careful that you check this
from the host, because in a VM,

625
00:30:39.060 --> 00:30:42.110
it's only gonna see its one adapter, the
virtual machine sees its virtual adapter,

626
00:30:42.110 --> 00:30:45.370
it only sees that and
the ARP data isn't as useful there.

627
00:30:45.370 --> 00:30:50.580
But if your virtual machine is put on a
VLAN and it's not able to talk to anybody,

628
00:30:50.580 --> 00:30:56.200
you can use ARP just to see if you're even
getting Mac addresses back and so forth.

629
00:30:56.200 --> 00:30:57.540
If you have a firewall in place,

630
00:30:57.540 --> 00:31:00.110
even a firewall's going to allow
the ARP broadcast to happen,

631
00:31:00.110 --> 00:31:03.380
that way you can find the host to talk to,
and then it'll filter you based on that.

632
00:31:03.380 --> 00:31:06.198
So I might have a ping to
somebody that's failing, right?

633
00:31:06.198 --> 00:31:10.230
So I might try and ping 10.1.230.209.

634
00:31:10.230 --> 00:31:11.517
Shoot.
I had to pick one that was

635
00:31:11.517 --> 00:31:12.710
actually present.

636
00:31:12.710 --> 00:31:14.940
I was trying to pick an IP that
wasn't in use on our network.

637
00:31:17.100 --> 00:31:20.035
There we go.
So I'm trying to ping 10.1.230.244.

638
00:31:20.035 --> 00:31:22.463
Now, I'm not getting a response back, so

639
00:31:22.463 --> 00:31:26.000
that machine obviously doesn't exist,
right?

640
00:31:26.000 --> 00:31:27.350
Well, not necessarily.

641
00:31:27.350 --> 00:31:31.750
If it's a modern machine,
a lot of them block pings by default.

642
00:31:31.750 --> 00:31:33.237
I might be getting blocked.

643
00:31:33.237 --> 00:31:38.939
But if I do an arp -a, and
I look for 10.1.230.244,

644
00:31:38.939 --> 00:31:42.787
I might find a Mac address for
that machine.

645
00:31:42.787 --> 00:31:46.733
And if I do, that means there is a machine
there, but a firewall blocked me and

646
00:31:46.733 --> 00:31:48.696
that's why I wasn't able to ping it.

647
00:31:48.696 --> 00:31:51.531
So ARP is a great way to find out
whether there's a firewall in place, and

648
00:31:51.531 --> 00:31:53.077
whether that's what your problem is.

649
00:31:53.077 --> 00:31:56.982
But in this scenario, I can see I didn't,
I've got an incomplete here.

650
00:31:56.982 --> 00:32:00.413
Which tells me that I didn't
get a MAC address and

651
00:32:00.413 --> 00:32:03.520
this machine effectively doesn't exist.

652
00:32:03.520 --> 00:32:04.231
All right.

653
00:32:04.231 --> 00:32:05.960
Last two things that I wanna mention.

654
00:32:05.960 --> 00:32:09.290
These are ones that CompTIA calls
out that are pretty important.

655
00:32:10.340 --> 00:32:12.350
If you're not finding what
you want with your commands,

656
00:32:12.350 --> 00:32:16.640
if the network just isn't working,
always remember to check your system logs.

657
00:32:16.640 --> 00:32:19.010
In Windows,
you have the event viewer, right?

658
00:32:19.010 --> 00:32:21.940
So in Windows,
if you go into your server manager and

659
00:32:21.940 --> 00:32:25.440
go under Tools,
you've got a tool called the event viewer.

660
00:32:25.440 --> 00:32:30.490
And Hyper-V has its own logs that it
keeps, so that you can jump in there and

661
00:32:30.490 --> 00:32:34.070
find out whether everything's working
properly or if things are acting up, or

662
00:32:34.070 --> 00:32:37.750
whatever, so you can jump in and
check your system logs and so on.

663
00:32:37.750 --> 00:32:42.510
And you can even drill down and find your
Hyper-V logs buried in here somewhere.

664
00:32:42.510 --> 00:32:43.470
Let me find them.

665
00:32:43.470 --> 00:32:43.970
Here we go.

666
00:32:43.970 --> 00:32:46.767
So you'll see all these different
Hyper-V logs right here.

667
00:32:46.767 --> 00:32:51.990
Hyper-V -Config, EmulatedNic, Hypervisor,
Integration, and you can look

668
00:32:51.990 --> 00:32:55.360
at the log files to see if there's any
errors or other things entered in there.

669
00:32:55.360 --> 00:32:58.090
Definitely something that you want to
check out to make sure that all this

670
00:32:58.090 --> 00:33:00.680
stuff is working properly, right?

671
00:33:00.680 --> 00:33:05.640
In the UNIX world, so if you're running
VMWare ESX or Citrix XenServer KVM,

672
00:33:05.640 --> 00:33:08.420
what you're gonna want to
look at are your syslogs.

673
00:33:08.420 --> 00:33:14.430
And those are stored in, well,
normally they're in /var/logs.

674
00:33:14.430 --> 00:33:18.940
First, sorry, no s, /var/log and you'll
see a file in there called messages and

675
00:33:18.940 --> 00:33:20.390
that's normally where it is.

676
00:33:20.390 --> 00:33:26.230
I'm on a Mac here so it's not exactly
the same, I don't have a messages file but

677
00:33:26.230 --> 00:33:29.330
you see my system logs right there
that are kind of popping by and

678
00:33:29.330 --> 00:33:32.300
that's cause Mac's have their
own little log monitor.

679
00:33:32.300 --> 00:33:38.080
But on a UNIX machine,
you'll normally have /var/log/messages.

680
00:33:38.080 --> 00:33:39.260
And you can look in that file and

681
00:33:39.260 --> 00:33:43.450
if there's any errors or things going on,
that's a great place to find it.

682
00:33:43.450 --> 00:33:47.660
But probably the best troubleshooting tool
you'll have is the vendor documentation.

683
00:33:47.660 --> 00:33:49.830
Remember that there's great
documentation available for

684
00:33:49.830 --> 00:33:51.230
all the various products
that are out there.

685
00:33:51.230 --> 00:33:52.470
But maybe not so much KVM.

686
00:33:52.470 --> 00:33:55.290
But the other ones,
there's great documentation for.

687
00:33:55.290 --> 00:33:57.720
Definitely read up on it cuz a lot
of the stuff that's going wrong,

688
00:33:57.720 --> 00:34:00.520
problems that you might be having,
that may already be answered for

689
00:34:00.520 --> 00:34:03.800
you in a document and all you had to do
was look at it and find that information.

690
00:34:03.800 --> 00:34:06.260
>> A lot of good information on that one,

691
00:34:06.260 --> 00:34:09.500
speaking of which, and
we've talked about a lot of different

692
00:34:09.500 --> 00:34:12.430
concepts here in this episode
>> We've talked about the different types

693
00:34:12.430 --> 00:34:15.820
of networks and you know,
talked about how they, you know,

694
00:34:15.820 --> 00:34:20.340
a WAN, what WAN means for you,
the CAN, not the CAN, the LAN,

695
00:34:20.340 --> 00:34:22.540
the man,
CAN will be in another episode, right?

696
00:34:22.540 --> 00:34:25.050
We've talked about bandwidth,
things like clustering and

697
00:34:25.050 --> 00:34:28.690
some of the things you can do
to help you with compression and

698
00:34:28.690 --> 00:34:31.710
caching
>> We've also looked at a bunch of tools,

00:34:31.710 --> 00:34:34.790
a whole bunch of tools that
CompTIA calls out on the exam, so

00:34:34.790 --> 00:34:35.800
definitely check them out.

00:34:35.800 --> 00:34:37.910
Don, you have anything else for
us in this episode?

00:34:37.910 --> 00:34:39.480
>> That's really about it.

703
00:34:39.480 --> 00:34:40.310
Just be aware,

00:34:40.310 --> 00:34:42.400
different platforms have different

We're gonna see more more troubleshooting
down the road as we continue on with

00:34:45.040 --> 00:34:45.715
Cloud+.

But for right now, these are the tools

00:34:47.765 --> 00:34:49.195

>> All right, well, that sounds like

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don will dive into monitoring resource utilization. They will look at the common resources that can effect performance such as CPU, RAM, disk I/O and network bandwidth. They talk about the methods that can be used to monitor these resources such as SNMP, WMI, IPMI and Syslog. They explore what administrators can use to set up alerting like setting up SMS messages, email messages and HTTP posts.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.087 --> 00:00:10.087
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.964 --> 00:00:14.422
Welcome back to another
episode here at ITPro TV.

3
00:00:14.422 --> 00:00:15.743
I'm your host Wes Brian and

4
00:00:15.743 --> 00:00:18.851
in today's episode we're gonna
be moving along in Cloud Plus.

5
00:00:18.851 --> 00:00:22.956
And more specifically what we're gonna be
talking about Is monitoring resources in

6
00:00:22.956 --> 00:00:23.544
the Cloud.

7
00:00:23.544 --> 00:00:26.340
And we have on tap for
you today Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:26.340 --> 00:00:27.700
Don, how are you doing today, sir?

9
00:00:27.700 --> 00:00:31.220
>> I'm doing great Wes, ready to jump
right back into the world of Cloud plus.

10
00:00:31.220 --> 00:00:34.260
And in this episode we're gonna to
talk about monitoring resources,

11
00:00:34.260 --> 00:00:36.260
which is really important.

12
00:00:36.260 --> 00:00:38.190
When you've got dedicated servers,

13
00:00:38.190 --> 00:00:41.010
you have one role being
performed on one server.

14
00:00:41.010 --> 00:00:43.080
They have full access to resources.

15
00:00:43.080 --> 00:00:45.506
But when we start going into
virtualized environments,

16
00:00:45.506 --> 00:00:48.901
you might have many virtual machines
running from the same physical hardware.

17
00:00:48.901 --> 00:00:51.522
And they all start to compete for
resources.

18
00:00:51.522 --> 00:00:55.586
You have a lot of contention for access.

19
00:00:55.586 --> 00:00:58.085
So we need a way to monitor that,
to keep an eye on it.

20
00:00:58.085 --> 00:01:00.074
And make sure our network's running happy,
healthy, and

21
00:01:00.074 --> 00:01:02.310
everything's running the way
that it needs to be.

22
00:01:02.310 --> 00:01:04.770
Or, at a minimum,
we know when it's time to upgrade.

23
00:01:04.770 --> 00:01:06.570
We know when there's a resource
that we're running out of and

24
00:01:06.570 --> 00:01:09.070
we need to add more to
kind of compensate for it.

25
00:01:09.070 --> 00:01:11.698
Monitoring is really important
in a virtualized environment.

26
00:01:11.698 --> 00:01:14.156
So that's what we're gonna be taking
a look at right here in this episode.

27
00:01:14.156 --> 00:01:16.290
>> Now, when it comes to monitoring,

28
00:01:16.290 --> 00:01:19.930
there's different criteria
that we need to monitor, Don.

29
00:01:19.930 --> 00:01:21.971
And this is wrapped up
into a concept of metrics.

30
00:01:21.971 --> 00:01:26.220
So, I believe you have a ton of different
types of metrics and those parameters and

31
00:01:26.220 --> 00:01:28.879
characteristics that
we're looking to monitor.

32
00:01:28.879 --> 00:01:30.950
So, you tell us a little bit about those?

33
00:01:30.950 --> 00:01:34.720
>> All right, so let's say that you're
hosting up on Amazon's Web Services,

34
00:01:34.720 --> 00:01:39.380
AWS, or you're hosting on Microsoft Azure
or Rack Space, or Google Computer,

35
00:01:39.380 --> 00:01:40.640
whoever it is that you're using.

36
00:01:40.640 --> 00:01:44.880
With those guys, we don't normally worry
so much about CPU and memory and so on.

37
00:01:44.880 --> 00:01:47.990
When you spin up a VN, you pick how
much memory you want it to have.

38
00:01:47.990 --> 00:01:51.990
But the underlying virtualization host,
you never see it, so you don't care.

39
00:01:51.990 --> 00:01:54.550
Because Google, or Microsoft, or whoever,

40
00:01:54.550 --> 00:01:56.430
is managing that server under the hood,
right?

41
00:01:57.570 --> 00:02:01.814
The only metric we really care about when
we're hosting up in the cloud like that,

42
00:02:01.814 --> 00:02:02.871
is up time, right?

43
00:02:02.871 --> 00:02:04.009
What is our up time?

44
00:02:04.009 --> 00:02:09.790
And almost all these vendors will have
a service level agreement an SLA,

45
00:02:09.790 --> 00:02:15.691
that says like Microsoft's is 99.98%,
actually 99.49%.

46
00:02:15.691 --> 00:02:16.664
>> Four nine's, yes.

47
00:02:16.664 --> 00:02:21.214
>> It's not five 9s it's a little
bit lower and what it amounts to is

48
00:02:21.214 --> 00:02:26.120
I believe it's something like 40
minutes of downtime per month.

49
00:02:26.120 --> 00:02:28.280
Or I think it's 20 minutes
of downtime per month.

50
00:02:28.280 --> 00:02:33.620
So they're guaranteeing you an uptime of
a certain level and are you getting it?

51
00:02:33.620 --> 00:02:36.030
Well you need to monitor it,
you need a way to watch and see.

52
00:02:36.030 --> 00:02:37.220
Are my systems actually up?

53
00:02:37.220 --> 00:02:40.010
Have they gone down and
Microsoft just didn't alert me.

54
00:02:40.010 --> 00:02:40.820
I need to know.

55
00:02:40.820 --> 00:02:44.350
I'm relying on these other people to
host my systems and keep them online and

56
00:02:44.350 --> 00:02:45.240
keep them healthy.

57
00:02:45.240 --> 00:02:48.120
So, uptime is a really important metric.

58
00:02:48.120 --> 00:02:50.430
It's important for
your own local network servers, too.

59
00:02:50.430 --> 00:02:53.273
But when they're out in the Cloud like
that it's really the only metric that we

60
00:02:53.273 --> 00:02:53.973
truly care about.

61
00:02:53.973 --> 00:02:56.994
You'll probably monitor performance

00:15:20.320 --> 00:15:21.680

00:15:28.810 --> 00:15:31.700

00:15:33.290 --> 00:15:35.690

00:15:35.690 --> 00:15:37.140

00:15:37.140 --> 00:15:39.060

00:15:39.060 --> 00:15:40.720

00:15:40.720 --> 00:15:42.690

00:15:42.690 --> 00:15:45.130

00:15:45.130 --> 00:15:48.900

00:15:48.900 --> 00:15:52.633

00:15:52.633 --> 00:15:53.665

So, for example,

a way that we can ask

00:18:13.461 --> 00:18:17.389

00:18:48.746 --> 00:18:50.650

00:18:50.650 --> 00:18:52.910

00:18:52.910 --> 00:18:54.610

00:19:01.760 --> 00:19:03.630

00:19:03.630 --> 00:19:06.590

00:19:06.590 --> 00:19:10.640
IPMI stands for

00:19:10.640 --> 00:19:13.130

What is my trend, what is my load?

513
00:24:09.350 --> 00:24:12.330
And as I start to look at it here, well,

514
00:24:12.330 --> 00:24:15.400
maybe my time is not
right here on this one.

515
00:24:15.400 --> 00:24:18.950
But it looks like it's kinda flat lined,
it's actually not busy at all right now.

516
00:24:18.950 --> 00:24:20.230
So what the heck's that all about?

517
00:24:20.230 --> 00:24:22.546
Well, I can come down here and
I can tell it what to monitor.

518
00:24:22.546 --> 00:24:24.450
Do I want to watch the last 24 hours?

519
00:24:24.450 --> 00:24:26.280
Or do I want to watch today, or whatever.

520
00:24:26.280 --> 00:24:27.979
So maybe I'll go to the last 24 hours.

521
00:24:29.090 --> 00:24:32.900
And we'll refresh that, and
see what it's been like,

522
00:24:32.900 --> 00:24:37.650
and I do see some, you know, a little
extra traffic way back here at midnight.

523
00:24:37.650 --> 00:24:39.790
But for the most part,
this server is not busy.

524
00:24:39.790 --> 00:24:43.170
So, whatever alert that I triggered
that it was showing high CPU,

525
00:24:43.170 --> 00:24:45.520
it's apparently resolved itself and
it's gone away, right?

526
00:24:45.520 --> 00:24:49.140
So now, I need to start thinking about,
what about longer periods of time,

527
00:24:49.140 --> 00:24:54.700
what if I want like the last month of
data, and so we go in and refresh that.

528
00:24:54.700 --> 00:24:57.050
It could also be that my sample
intervals not close enough.

529
00:24:57.050 --> 00:25:01.450
But looking at my month of data,
this server is really not very busy.

530
00:25:01.450 --> 00:25:03.140
So I'm more than likely
looking at a fluke.

531
00:25:03.140 --> 00:25:04.580
It just happened to spike and

532
00:25:04.580 --> 00:25:07.610
hit those high numbers, I don't
necessarily need to take an action.

533
00:25:07.610 --> 00:25:10.810
And that's what monitoring
software like this can do for us.

534
00:25:10.810 --> 00:25:15.120
It's very powerful in letting you see what
all's going on inside of your environment.

535
00:25:15.120 --> 00:25:18.446
And it's even cooler when you're able
to monitor multiple types of systems.

536
00:25:18.446 --> 00:25:22.200
I can monitor my VMware servers,
my Hyper-V servers, my Storage, right?

537
00:25:22.200 --> 00:25:23.786
So if I've got a SAN in place, and

538
00:25:23.786 --> 00:25:26.300
you can even view additional
data on these systems.

539
00:25:26.300 --> 00:25:28.620
So, for example,
if I'm doing syslogging, right?

540
00:25:28.620 --> 00:25:31.583
So, maybe I drive into
one of these systems,

541
00:25:31.583 --> 00:25:33.870
and I'll pull up this VCenter server here.

542
00:25:33.870 --> 00:25:37.140
When I go into the VCenter server and
start looking at its data,

543
00:25:37.140 --> 00:25:40.900
you can collect the syslog data and
have it posted right here inside of it.

544
00:25:40.900 --> 00:25:43.570
And let's see, have they done that for us?

545
00:25:43.570 --> 00:25:45.830
And, it doesn't look like it.

546
00:25:45.830 --> 00:25:48.785
We've got other statistics and
performance metrics.

547
00:25:48.785 --> 00:25:51.597
You got a lot in here,
based on storage, network, and so on.

548
00:25:51.597 --> 00:25:54.916
It's all being collected
in easy to read format,

549
00:25:54.916 --> 00:25:59.668
one that we can kinda take a look at and
explore, but they also support.

550
00:25:59.668 --> 00:26:01.737
Apparently, they haven't set it up, but

551
00:26:01.737 --> 00:26:05.469
they do also support where you can bring
in the syslogs for these systems and,

552
00:26:05.469 --> 00:26:08.190
let me jump over and
see if I can find the syslog server.

553
00:26:08.190 --> 00:26:09.200
Here it is.

554
00:26:09.200 --> 00:26:11.840
And I'll show you an example
of the syslogs that come in.

555
00:26:11.840 --> 00:26:12.590
Here we go.

556
00:26:12.590 --> 00:26:15.160
So here's syslog messages that
are coming in from different systems.

557
00:26:15.160 --> 00:26:16.520
And you'll see where
it's just reporting in.

558
00:26:16.520 --> 00:26:19.840
A lot of these are just informational
messages that we ignore.

559
00:26:19.840 --> 00:26:20.940
Some are really critical though,

560
00:26:20.940 --> 00:26:22.790
and there are actions that
we need to take if it's red.

561
00:26:22.790 --> 00:26:24.500
And you can filter by time.

562
00:26:24.500 --> 00:26:28.786
So if somebody calls and says, hey, the
system was really slow yesterday at 2 PM,

563
00:26:28.786 --> 00:26:31.433
okay, well,
what was going on yesterday at 2 PM?

564
00:26:31.433 --> 00:26:35.581
You can come up here and set a time
period, and we can customize that.

565
00:26:35.581 --> 00:26:40.856
And we can come in and
specify that I wanna begin yesterday at,

566
00:26:40.856 --> 00:26:48.175
you know, maybe I look at 1 PM, and I'll
end it yesterday at 2 PM, or 3 PM, right?

567
00:26:48.175 --> 00:26:52.763
So I'm gonna get the time around
that failure, that issue, right?

568
00:26:52.763 --> 00:26:55.744
So I'm specifying that time interval
to get basically before and

569
00:26:55.744 --> 00:26:57.500
after that failure issue.

570
00:26:57.500 --> 00:27:01.196
And so then I can refresh it, and now I'm
gonna see my syslog messages that were

571
00:27:01.196 --> 00:27:04.846
occurring during that time and, well,
here's something big red, right?

572
00:27:04.846 --> 00:27:05.926
I've got some kind of problem.

573
00:27:05.926 --> 00:27:06.681
I kind of lucked out on that one.

574
00:27:06.681 --> 00:27:10.079
[LAUGH] So I can look in here and well,
it's just not very exciting here.

575
00:27:10.079 --> 00:27:11.797
Unknown user name or bad password.

576
00:27:11.797 --> 00:27:13.434
Somebody tried to login and
it didn't work.

577
00:27:13.434 --> 00:27:14.640
All right, well, that's not exciting.

578
00:27:14.640 --> 00:27:16.750
But, if I have performance
thresholds that are being broken or

579
00:27:16.750 --> 00:27:20.530
whatever I can see those here, and
you can set up automated responses and

580
00:27:20.530 --> 00:27:24.070
actions to take when a failure occurs,
it can notify you and so on.

581
00:27:24.070 --> 00:27:27.740
This is what management software does, and
having a centralized management platform

582
00:27:27.740 --> 00:27:31.010
like this, be it SolarWinds or
be it any of the other ones, right?

583
00:27:31.010 --> 00:27:36.664
System Center Operations Manager,
IBM's Tivoli, VM, what's the other one?

584
00:27:36.664 --> 00:27:40.970
Cloud, Cloudtastic, something crazy,
Cloudify, Cloudify, those platforms,

585
00:27:40.970 --> 00:27:44.377
they can monitor your private and
public clouds and give you great,

586
00:27:44.377 --> 00:27:48.443
easy to read metric data and information
that helps you make decisions on whether

587
00:27:48.443 --> 00:27:52.720
you've got the right hardware or enough
hardware, to support your environments.

588
00:27:52.720 --> 00:27:54.070
It's very powerful stuff.

589
00:27:54.070 --> 00:27:54.990
>> Very good, very good.

590
00:27:54.990 --> 00:27:55.520
All right.

591
00:27:55.520 --> 00:27:58.460
So, we've looked at a lot of good
information within this episode.

592
00:27:58.460 --> 00:28:01.470
We talked about some of
the metrics that you can see.

593
00:28:01.470 --> 00:28:03.190
What is it that we're gonna be monitoring.

594
00:28:03.190 --> 00:28:05.430
We talked about, for instance,
some of the resources.

595
00:28:05.430 --> 00:28:06.550
Remember the four horsemen.

596
00:28:06.550 --> 00:28:08.580
We've got RAM, CPU, hard drive, and

597
00:28:08.580 --> 00:28:12.640
network utilization, anyone of these
fails, it brings everything to a halt.

598
00:28:12.640 --> 00:28:17.659
We've also looked at things like, for
instance, alerts, being able to send out

599
00:28:17.659 --> 00:28:23.057
alerts through things like SMS messages,
email, syslog, HTP, or HTTP, excuse me.

600
00:28:23.057 --> 00:28:26.534
We've also talked about the Windows
Management Interface, IPMI, and

601
00:28:26.534 --> 00:28:29.850
a bunch of other methods that you
can use to monitor these resources.

602
00:28:29.850 --> 00:28:31.890
A lot of good information in this episode.

603
00:28:31.890 --> 00:28:33.510
Don, do you have anything else for us?

604
00:28:33.510 --> 00:28:34.350
>> I think that's about it.

605
00:28:34.350 --> 00:28:36.350
Just remember, there's plenty
of products out there, right?

606
00:28:36.350 --> 00:28:37.770
So pick the one that works for you.

607
00:28:37.770 --> 00:28:40.540
But the key thing is,
you've got to monitor for performance.

608
00:28:40.540 --> 00:28:42.600
You've got to know when
your system is suffering.

609
00:28:42.600 --> 00:28:44.940
Because if you don't know about it,
your end users certainly do, right?

610
00:28:44.940 --> 00:28:47.231
So that's definitely part of the problem,
you've gotta keep your,

611
00:28:47.231 --> 00:28:49.760
kind of,
your thumb on the pulse of your network.

612
00:28:49.760 --> 00:28:51.210
And monitoring solutions
is how we do that.

613
00:28:51.210 --> 00:28:53.840
>> Very good, Don, and as always,
it's a pleasure having you here, and

614
00:28:53.840 --> 00:28:56.050
thank you for that information,
but we're gonna go ahead and

615
00:28:56.050 --> 00:28:59.580
sign off here at ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

616
00:28:59.580 --> 00:29:00.338
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

617
00:29:00.338 --> 00:29:01.929
>> And we'll see you next time.

618
00:29:01.929 --> 00:29:09.230
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don dive into resource allocation and discuss the primary resources needed in virtualization such as memory, processing power, storage and network bandwidth. They look at best practices when assigning memory like dynamic versus static memory allocation and CPU allocation.
episodes.title: Allocating Resources
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.169 --> 00:00:10.169
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.468 --> 00:00:15.080
Welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:15.080 --> 00:00:16.470
I'm your host Wes Bryan,

4
00:00:16.470 --> 00:00:20.270
and in today's episode, we're gonna be
moving along in our cloud plus series.

5
00:00:20.270 --> 00:00:22.620
Now in some of the past episodes,
we've been talking about,

6
00:00:22.620 --> 00:00:25.950
well the resources that we have for
our systems, right.

7
00:00:25.950 --> 00:00:30.810
We've talked about what type of resources,
how to optimize those resources.

8
00:00:30.810 --> 00:00:35.100
Now, today we're going to talk about how
you actually allocate those resources.

9
00:00:35.100 --> 00:00:37.960
And that's what this episode's going
to be all about, allocating resources.

10
00:00:37.960 --> 00:00:40.760
We have none other than Mr.
Don Pezet here to help us out.

11
00:00:40.760 --> 00:00:41.950
Don, how are you doing today, sir?

12
00:00:41.950 --> 00:00:42.720
>> I'm doing great Wes.

13
00:00:42.720 --> 00:00:44.020
Glad to be back on the show and

14
00:00:44.020 --> 00:00:45.690
ready to jump back into
the world of cloud computing.

15
00:00:45.690 --> 00:00:48.480
And just like Wes sad, we're going to be
talking about allocating resources and

16
00:00:48.480 --> 00:00:50.140
I I know what you're thinking.

17
00:00:50.140 --> 00:00:53.070
In a previous episode, I showed you
guys how to spin out virtual machines,

18
00:00:53.070 --> 00:00:57.150
and we saw how to assign resources to VMs,
so we kind of already understand

19
00:00:57.150 --> 00:00:59.800
how to do it,
what the heck's this episode all about?

20
00:00:59.800 --> 00:01:04.415
Well what we wanna do here is take
a look at not how to attach a network

21
00:01:04.415 --> 00:01:08.190
adapter to a VM or how to assign four
gigs of RAM versus six gigs of RAM.

22
00:01:08.190 --> 00:01:12.990
But the best practices behind assigning
those resources, the things we always need

23
00:01:12.990 --> 00:01:16.070
to keep in the back of our mind
whenever we assign that RAM.

24
00:01:16.070 --> 00:01:19.460
And Wes and I were having a bit of
a conversation about this before the show.

25
00:01:19.460 --> 00:01:24.750
It's so easy to add resources to
a VM that it puts you at risk.

26
00:01:24.750 --> 00:01:26.450
There's a lot of mistakes that can happen,

27
00:01:26.450 --> 00:01:29.150
a lot of different kind
of pitfalls that happen.

28
00:01:29.150 --> 00:01:31.560
And these didn't happen in
the physical server days.

29
00:01:31.560 --> 00:01:35.620
When you had physical servers that you
deployed, if I had eight gigs of RAM in

30
00:01:35.620 --> 00:01:39.520
there and I decided I wanted to go to 16,
it wasn't a matter of flipping a switch.

31
00:01:39.520 --> 00:01:41.230
I had to get a purchase order and quotes.

32
00:01:41.230 --> 00:01:42.710
I had to buy the memory,
get it shipped in.

33
00:01:42.710 --> 00:01:44.700
There was a lot that had to happen.

34
00:01:44.700 --> 00:01:46.570
And so we had to really, really want that.

35
00:01:46.570 --> 00:01:49.860
And there was a dollar sign attached
to it that was an immediate thing.

36
00:01:49.860 --> 00:01:51.700
We had to pay to get it.

37
00:01:51.700 --> 00:01:52.850
And that acted as a gateway.

38
00:01:52.850 --> 00:01:56.000
It acted as a safety net for
assigning resources.

39
00:01:56.000 --> 00:01:58.210
In a virtual world, it's not like that.

40
00:01:58.210 --> 00:02:01.770
In a virtual world, you likely have a pool
of resources already available just

41
00:02:01.770 --> 00:02:02.850
sitting there waiting to be grabbed.

42
00:02:02.850 --> 00:02:08.080
And the temptation to just reach out and
grab that memory is really easy.

43
00:02:08.080 --> 00:02:10.150
And it's challenging.

44
00:02:10.150 --> 00:02:11.230
So we gotta be careful with that.

45
00:02:11.230 --> 00:02:12.990
It doesn't mean you can't,

46
00:02:12.990 --> 00:02:16.020
the stuff is there you might as well
use it, but we've gotta be careful.

47
00:02:16.020 --> 00:02:19.690
And we have to be careful not just
within the virtual machines, but

48
00:02:19.690 --> 00:02:22.150
on our physical hosts also.

49
00:02:22.150 --> 00:02:24.740
So we're gonna talk about those
resources from both perspectives today,

50
00:02:24.740 --> 00:02:27.560
the physical host as well as the logical,
the VMs.

51
00:02:27.560 --> 00:02:30.190
And just see the things
we need to be aware of

52
00:02:30.190 --> 00:02:34.000
as we start assigning out these
resources and the various pitfalls.

53
00:02:34.000 --> 00:02:36.940
We're just gonna take a look at
that from kind of a higher level.

54
00:02:36.940 --> 00:02:40.260
>> So you mentioned 64 gigs of RAM,
Don, and you're gonna allocate to one

55
00:02:40.260 --> 00:02:42.340
of these virtual machines,
you're gonna allocate eight gigs.

56
00:02:42.340 --> 00:02:45.210
That means, in theory, right,
I should be able to have what?

57
00:02:45.210 --> 00:02:47.550
Eight virtual machines with
eight gigs of ram of piece.

58
00:02:47.550 --> 00:02:50.470
>> You'd think that, it is nice
if you slice out the eight gigs,

59
00:02:50.470 --> 00:02:54.380
we give it to the VM and it's got it, and
if we have eight VMs with eight gigs each,

60
00:02:54.380 --> 00:02:54.920
that's 64 gigs.

61
00:02:54.920 --> 00:02:59.270
But you've always gotta remember,
you've got your underlying host.

62
00:02:59.270 --> 00:03:02.910
And the underlying host, they need
memory too, or they don't function.

63
00:03:02.910 --> 00:03:05.680
And I know We showed that
diagram in another episode of

64
00:03:05.680 --> 00:03:09.380
a type one hypervisor and
how the host is technically a VM itself,

65
00:03:09.380 --> 00:03:12.100
running on top of the hypervisor, but we
don't really see that when we look at it.

66
00:03:12.100 --> 00:03:15.730
And when you run VMware ESX,
it's actually a little Linux box

67
00:03:15.730 --> 00:03:18.280
that's running on there, and it's running
directly on top of the hypervisor.

68
00:03:18.280 --> 00:03:21.780
If you're running Citrix XenServer, it's
a Linux box running on the hypervisor.

69
00:03:21.780 --> 00:03:23.430
If you're running Windows, but

70
00:03:23.430 --> 00:03:27.360
like Hyper-V, it's actually a Microsoft
Windows operating system that's running.

71
00:03:27.360 --> 00:03:31.400
And each of those OS's have
different requirements, right.

72
00:03:31.400 --> 00:03:32.450
So for example, Windows,

73
00:03:32.450 --> 00:03:35.320
the minimum amount of memory
it can have is one gig of RAM.

74
00:03:35.320 --> 00:03:38.952
And ideally, they want you to have
two gigs or more on 64-bit system.

75
00:03:38.952 --> 00:03:41.450
So I need to set that memory aside too.

76
00:03:41.450 --> 00:03:45.560
You don't allocate that in Hyper-V because
it's not technically a part of Hyper-V.

77
00:03:45.560 --> 00:03:47.700
It's a part of the host OS.

78
00:03:47.700 --> 00:03:50.640
So you need to check your vendor
documentation before you start doling out

79
00:03:50.640 --> 00:03:54.895
your memory, because there is some memory
that needs to be set aside for that host.

80
00:03:54.895 --> 00:03:56.875
That's really important.

81
00:03:56.875 --> 00:04:02.095
And on ESX and on ZenServer, it's actually
not a whole heck of a lot of memory.

82
00:04:02.095 --> 00:04:05.415
If I remember, on ZenServer, it's
something weird like 684 megs of memory,

83
00:04:05.415 --> 00:04:07.280
something bizarre like that.

84
00:04:07.280 --> 00:04:10.570
On VMware ESX, I'm pretty sure it's a gig.

85
00:04:10.570 --> 00:04:12.540
I'll have to check
the documentation on that.

86
00:04:12.540 --> 00:04:15.070
On Windows, I know a gig is
the minimum you can get away with, but

87
00:04:15.070 --> 00:04:17.810
they recommend two gigs for that host OS.

88
00:04:17.810 --> 00:04:19.930
So I start to lose some of that memory.

89
00:04:19.930 --> 00:04:21.280
The other thing is,

90
00:04:21.280 --> 00:04:25.820
when you deploy your virtual machines,
It's expecting you to do servers.

91
00:04:25.820 --> 00:04:29.560
But some people do work stations like VDI,
virtual desktop infrastructure.

92
00:04:29.560 --> 00:04:33.430
And if you're doing desktop OSs when
you deploy them inside of a VM,

93
00:04:33.430 --> 00:04:35.390
you might choose to turn
on 3D acceleration.

94
00:04:35.390 --> 00:04:38.210
This is an option inside of a lot
of virtualization software.

95
00:04:38.210 --> 00:04:42.210
And when you do that it asks for
a video card memory and

96
00:04:42.210 --> 00:04:46.160
that video card memory is
important because it adds up fast.

97
00:04:46.160 --> 00:04:47.770
If I'm doing virtual desktops and

98
00:04:47.770 --> 00:04:50.690
I decide that each desktop is gonna
have two gigs of RAM, all right?

99
00:04:50.690 --> 00:04:52.520
Well, I've got 64 gigs of RAM on my host.

100
00:04:52.520 --> 00:04:53.350
I've got plenty of room.

101
00:04:53.350 --> 00:04:56.620
I can create 30 desktops pretty easy,
right?

102
00:04:56.620 --> 00:05:01.760
Well, if each one of them gets 256 mgs of
video memory And I've got 30 other things.

103
00:05:01.760 --> 00:05:04.600
I just picked something
with hard math didn't I?

104
00:05:04.600 --> 00:05:05.350
Anyhow it's like seven and

105
00:05:05.350 --> 00:05:09.800
a half gigs of memory that's tied up
in this virtual video cards right?

106
00:05:09.800 --> 00:05:12.440
And that's another thing I
have to take into account.

107
00:05:12.440 --> 00:05:15.590
So remember when you
allocate memory like that

108
00:05:15.590 --> 00:05:18.430
your physical host needs
enough memory to support this.

109
00:05:18.430 --> 00:05:23.280
And then your VMs,
they each are slicing out that memory and

110
00:05:23.280 --> 00:05:25.050
they're having to slice
away video card memory too,

111
00:05:25.050 --> 00:05:27.510
definitely things that
you kinda factored in.

112
00:05:27.510 --> 00:05:29.720
Now, static assignments work great,

113
00:05:29.720 --> 00:05:32.360
because you know when you
assign the memory, it's got it.

114
00:05:32.360 --> 00:05:34.370
If I give a virtual
machine eight gigs of RAM.

00:20:39.190 --> 00:20:42.930

00:20:47.080 --> 00:20:51.530

00:21:09.090 --> 00:21:13.870
All right, so if I want ITPROTV-WEB01

00:21:50.940 --> 00:21:51.900

00:22:19.070 --> 00:22:20.735
If I bump it up to three or even four,

No other VM is gonna be able to function.

00:22:28.810 --> 00:22:32.060
Just this one VM, so

00:23:33.360 --> 00:23:35.600

00:23:39.680 --> 00:23:41.940

00:23:41.940 --> 00:23:45.790

00:23:45.790 --> 00:23:50.030

00:23:50.030 --> 00:23:53.275

00:23:58.246 --> 00:24:01.669

00:24:01.669 --> 00:24:03.275

00:24:03.275 --> 00:24:07.175

00:24:11.344 --> 00:24:13.886

00:24:13.886 --> 00:24:14.564

00:24:14.564 --> 00:24:15.504
And they can take advantage of that.

00:24:15.504 --> 00:24:20.493
So user reservation, when you want to hard

00:24:20.493 --> 00:24:25.294

00:24:25.294 --> 00:24:27.904

00:24:27.904 --> 00:24:29.997

00:24:41.054 --> 00:24:44.922

00:24:48.084 --> 00:24:50.718

Static assignments of memory, static
assignments of your virtual CPU resources

565
00:27:14.424 --> 00:27:17.933
to make sure you can count on
those resources being there.

566
00:27:17.933 --> 00:27:21.181
And then in lab environments, you can take
advantage of all the bells and whistles,

567
00:27:21.181 --> 00:27:23.213
the dynamic memory, TPS,
all those other things.

568
00:27:23.213 --> 00:27:24.942
They are great when they
work in production, but

569
00:27:24.942 --> 00:27:26.343
it is not something you wanna count on.

570
00:27:26.343 --> 00:27:27.183
You don't wanna rely on it.

571
00:27:27.183 --> 00:27:30.538
You wanna make sure that your host has
the resources to match the VMs, and

572
00:27:30.538 --> 00:27:32.083
it's able to support your load.

573
00:27:32.083 --> 00:27:33.363
>> Very good, and thank you for that, Don.

574
00:27:33.363 --> 00:27:36.595
And pay attention now out there cuz when
it comes down to is with the elasticity

575
00:27:36.595 --> 00:27:38.584
and the on-demand nature
of cloud computing,

576
00:27:38.584 --> 00:27:40.572
very easy to spin up some
virtual machines, but

577
00:27:40.572 --> 00:27:43.523
it's also easy to break the bank too,
and do some misconfiguration.

578
00:27:43.523 --> 00:27:44.903
Don, got anything else for us on this one?

579
00:27:44.903 --> 00:27:45.883
>> I think that's it.

580
00:27:45.883 --> 00:27:49.235
David did actually mention something
in the chatroom that's worthwhile,

581
00:27:49.235 --> 00:27:51.340
not that all his comments
aren't worthwhile.

582
00:27:51.340 --> 00:27:55.226
But that when you get your CPUs, it's not
just about core count that we also have

583
00:27:55.226 --> 00:27:58.310
cache inside, the L1, L2,
L3 cache that are part of CPUs.

584
00:27:58.310 --> 00:27:59.690
And the more of that cache you have,

585
00:27:59.690 --> 00:28:01.670
the better performance you
get out of those cores.

586
00:28:01.670 --> 00:28:05.487
So not all cores are created equal,
not all CPUs are created equal, and as you

587
00:28:05.487 --> 00:28:09.453
bounce from host to host, you can get
various performance profiles there too.

588
00:28:09.453 --> 00:28:11.933
So it's just more stuff that we
need to monitor in those systems.

589
00:28:11.933 --> 00:28:12.813
>> All right, very good.

590
00:28:12.813 --> 00:28:16.143
And it looks like we've come to the end of
another exciting episode here at ITProTV.

591
00:28:16.143 --> 00:28:18.003
So we're gonna go ahead and sign out here.

592
00:28:18.003 --> 00:28:19.263
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

593
00:28:19.263 --> 00:28:20.163
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

594
00:28:20.163 --> 00:28:24.428
>> And we'll see you next time.

595
00:28:24.428 --> 00:28:30.850

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don continue their discussion on resource allocation and the primary resources needed in virtualization such as memory, processing power, storage and network bandwidth. They explore best practices when provisioning storage for virtual machine as well as network communication best practices. They will talk about reservations, quotas and licensing in this episode.
episodes.title: Allocating Resources Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.469 --> 00:00:10.469
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.245 --> 00:00:14.970
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.970 --> 00:00:17.360
I'm your host, Wes Bryan,
and in today's episode,

4
00:00:17.360 --> 00:00:20.050
we're gonna be moving along
in our Cloud Plus series,

5
00:00:20.050 --> 00:00:24.110
and we're actually coming back with
a part two of allocating resources.

6
00:00:24.110 --> 00:00:27.150
That's right, in the first part,
we talked way too much, or

7
00:00:27.150 --> 00:00:30.490
at least enough to fill up
the part two of this side.

8
00:00:30.490 --> 00:00:32.460
And, we got Don Pezet to help us out.

9
00:00:32.460 --> 00:00:33.760
Don, how are you doing today, sir?

10
00:00:33.760 --> 00:00:36.040
>> I'm doing great, Wes,
ready to wrap this turkey up, right?

11
00:00:36.040 --> 00:00:38.660
So, we've talked about allocating
resources in the first episode.

12
00:00:38.660 --> 00:00:41.730
We tackled CPU, we tackled RAM.

13
00:00:41.730 --> 00:00:43.620
We still have a storage network
to talk about, right, so

14
00:00:43.620 --> 00:00:45.070
additional resources there.

15
00:00:45.070 --> 00:00:47.400
And we'll find that there's a common
theme that runs through this,

16
00:00:47.400 --> 00:00:50.310
that we have a dynamic type of allocation
and a static type of allocation.

17
00:00:50.310 --> 00:00:53.960
And we just have to remember all
the different pieces that add up that then

18
00:00:53.960 --> 00:00:55.500
consume our full set of resources.

19
00:00:55.500 --> 00:00:57.930
So we're just gonna continue on with that,
