20
00:00:57.930 --> 00:01:01.030
And then at the end of the episode,
hopefully I won't ramble on too long cuz I

21
00:01:01.030 --> 00:01:05.840
wanna talk a little about self
service portals, and some of the other

22
00:01:05.840 --> 00:01:10.070
little issues that we can bump into when
we let non-admins into our accounts.

23
00:01:10.070 --> 00:01:12.220
I know it sounds crazy,
but it does happen.

24
00:01:12.220 --> 00:01:15.400
So we'll talk about that
a little later in the episode.

25
00:01:15.400 --> 00:01:17.615
Well, Well,
let's kick things off with storage.

26
00:01:17.615 --> 00:01:18.155
Right?

27
00:01:18.155 --> 00:01:22.165
Storage at first glance storage seems
like a really easy thing to meter out.

28
00:01:22.165 --> 00:01:24.525
You're like,
well I've got a bunch of VM's.

29
00:01:24.525 --> 00:01:27.095
Here's the hard drive sizes they've got I
just need to make sure I have that much

30
00:01:27.095 --> 00:01:28.135
storage and I'm done.

31
00:01:28.135 --> 00:01:30.185
And a lot of people think that way and

32
00:01:30.185 --> 00:01:34.505
you kind of end up being in an area
where Disk IO becomes your bottleneck.

33
00:01:34.505 --> 00:01:36.395
Disk IO is always your bottleneck anyway,
right?

34
00:01:36.395 --> 00:01:39.400
Because it's the slowest
component in your computer.

35
00:01:39.400 --> 00:01:42.840
If you've got spinning disks, there is
nothing else slower in your computer.

36
00:01:42.840 --> 00:01:47.780
If you have SSD, it's a heck of a lot
better, but it's still slower than RAM and

37
00:01:47.780 --> 00:01:48.670
CPU.

38
00:01:48.670 --> 00:01:51.790
It may well be faster than your network,
depending on the type of

39
00:01:51.790 --> 00:01:54.220
network that you have, some network
becomes you bottleneck, right?

40
00:01:54.220 --> 00:01:57.920
But storage almost always is an area
where we have bottlenecks, and

41
00:01:57.920 --> 00:02:00.750
just because I have a one terabyte drive

42
00:02:00.750 --> 00:02:05.790
doesn't mean that I can fire up ten
VM's with 100 GB of storage each, right?

43
00:02:05.790 --> 00:02:07.310
Because if all ten VM's,

44
00:02:07.310 --> 00:02:10.420
yeah they'll be able to store their
data there's enough room for it, but

45
00:02:10.420 --> 00:02:14.080
if all ten VM's try and access their
data at the same time what happens?

46
00:02:14.080 --> 00:02:16.800
That one disk can only
do one thing at a time.

47
00:02:16.800 --> 00:02:19.650
Even in SSD well it might be
a multi-channel SSD I guess,

48
00:02:19.650 --> 00:02:23.270
some of them can do as many as four
things at a time, but that's your limit.

49
00:02:23.270 --> 00:02:25.250
If I got ten VMs all trying
to do something at once.

50
00:02:25.250 --> 00:02:28.340
I hit that limit and
my queue starts to build up.

51
00:02:28.340 --> 00:02:31.360
And in the performance monitoring episodes
I'll show you guys how to monitor that

52
00:02:31.360 --> 00:02:33.120
queue and see when that's happening.

53
00:02:33.120 --> 00:02:35.820
And the simplest solution
is to add more storage.

54
00:02:35.820 --> 00:02:37.550
Right, add more drives.

55
00:02:37.550 --> 00:02:43.326
If I need 10 TB of storage I could do,
no wait, that's a bad one.

56
00:02:43.326 --> 00:02:44.870
[LAUGH] Let's pick works better.

57
00:02:44.870 --> 00:02:49.180
If I need 8 TB of storage,
I can get two 4 TB drives and

58
00:02:49.180 --> 00:02:50.160
stripe them, and there we go.

59
00:02:50.160 --> 00:02:51.700
4 TB drives, they're on the market,

60
00:02:51.700 --> 00:02:55.280
you can buy them pretty easy,
there's my 8 TB of storage.

61
00:02:55.280 --> 00:02:57.370
But I've only got two
drives doing the work.

62
00:02:57.370 --> 00:03:00.730
I could get eight, one TB drives,

63
00:03:00.730 --> 00:03:05.220
and now I've got eight drives doing
the work, I can do eight things at once,

64
00:03:05.220 --> 00:03:08.320
versus two four terrabyte drives
I can only do two things at once.

65
00:03:08.320 --> 00:03:10.700
So those are the things that we
need to take into consideration.

66
00:03:10.700 --> 00:03:15.520
It's not just about the storage size,
it's also about redundancy,

67
00:03:15.520 --> 00:03:17.970
resiliency and throughput.

68
00:03:17.970 --> 00:03:19.600
How much can we do at any given time?

69
00:03:19.600 --> 00:03:22.670
Those really key principles that
we need to be familiar with.

70
00:03:22.670 --> 00:03:27.610
We start to allocate storage to our VM's
and we attach that storage to our hosts.

71
00:03:27.610 --> 00:03:30.800
>> I was sitting here thinking this was
starting to become, in this episode,

72
00:03:30.800 --> 00:03:33.990
what's Don's mathematical challenge for
today?

73
00:03:33.990 --> 00:03:37.620
You know, and I know that when we're
talking about production side we're all,

74
00:03:37.620 --> 00:03:40.190
let me tell you a little
bit about what happened on

75
00:03:40.190 --> 00:03:43.030
the client's side virtualization and
labs for me, Don.

76
00:03:43.030 --> 00:03:46.960
You know I have a machine at the house and
I did exactly what you said.

77
00:03:46.960 --> 00:03:50.690
I took all of my virtual machines and,
again, remember it's a type 2 hypervisor,

78
00:03:50.690 --> 00:03:53.020
so little bit different than
a production environment, but

79
00:03:53.020 --> 00:03:55.700
you could see how the production
environment would be even worse.

80
00:03:55.700 --> 00:03:59.300
Took all of my virtual machines, put them
on a one TB drive and I tell you what,

81
00:03:59.300 --> 00:04:02.500
go to launch I don't know five or
six of these virtual machines up.

82
00:04:02.500 --> 00:04:04.780
I've got plenty of memory, so
I'm not worried about memory.

83
00:04:04.780 --> 00:04:07.190
And man, every one of those machines
would just come to a crawl.

84
00:04:07.190 --> 00:04:10.210
So what I ended up having to do, and I
thought it was better, I could go out and

85
00:04:10.210 --> 00:04:12.625
get two cheaper solid state drives.

86
00:04:12.625 --> 00:04:15.530
Not a lot of space on them,
only eight giggers or so.

87
00:04:15.530 --> 00:04:18.080
But then I would allocate
the hard drives for

88
00:04:18.080 --> 00:04:21.000
one virtual machine to one
80 GB solid state drive.

89
00:04:21.000 --> 00:04:24.100
And then I'd allocate to another
80 GB solid state drive.

90
00:04:24.100 --> 00:04:27.060
And now, every time the virtual machines
spin up, I've got two different disks

91
00:04:27.060 --> 00:04:29.570
that are running, so, I started to
see a little bit better performance.

92
00:04:29.570 --> 00:04:32.840
Now, I can only imagine, Don,
in a production environment, where you're

93
00:04:32.840 --> 00:04:36.180
really working these machines,
you're gonna need something like that.

94
00:04:36.180 --> 00:04:38.320
>> Absolutely, and so
we've gotta think about it.

95
00:04:38.320 --> 00:04:39.520
We've gotta think about disk group.

96
00:04:39.520 --> 00:04:42.990
When you buy a new disk, written
right on the front, it will say like,

97
00:04:42.990 --> 00:04:48.400
this is a SATA 3 disk that
has 6 GB of throughput.

98
00:04:48.400 --> 00:04:51.810
Great, I can move 6 GB of
data through that thing.

99
00:04:51.810 --> 00:04:55.000
That starts to set the bar of what I can
measure to see how I can move, right?

100
00:04:55.000 --> 00:04:56.610
Same thing with SAS drives.

101
00:04:56.610 --> 00:04:58.410
SAS drives you can get
up to 12 GB right now.

102
00:04:58.410 --> 00:05:01.330
You get those fiber channel SAS
drives that are they're pretty sweet.

103
00:05:01.330 --> 00:05:04.450
But, the drives aren't
the only consideration.

104
00:05:04.450 --> 00:05:07.630
Let me show you a little diagram
that I used in another episode.

105
00:05:07.630 --> 00:05:09.840
This is a very simplistic view of a SAN,

106
00:05:09.840 --> 00:05:14.480
but it gets my point across that
we might have physical hosts.

107
00:05:14.480 --> 00:05:19.440
Let's say that this is VMHOST1 and
then I've got VMHOST2 and

108
00:05:19.440 --> 00:05:23.350
who knows, maybe I've got some
physical servers attached to this SAN.

109
00:05:24.470 --> 00:05:27.980
So each one has a connection to the SAN,
and not necessarily directly to the SAN.

110
00:05:27.980 --> 00:05:30.650
We normally go through
a fiber switch like this one.

111
00:05:30.650 --> 00:05:34.870
Let's think about all the components
that are involved in this communication.

112
00:05:34.870 --> 00:05:37.930
I'm talking about disks and disk speed.

113
00:05:37.930 --> 00:05:41.090
So down here, when I get these disks,
I've gotta think about their speed.

114
00:05:41.090 --> 00:05:44.870
If I've got 12 GB SAS drives in here.

115
00:05:44.870 --> 00:05:46.930
They're nice and fast.

116
00:05:46.930 --> 00:05:51.430
But at the end of the day, this virtual
machine host, they might have ten VMs on

117
00:05:51.430 --> 00:05:55.480
it, that all need to access that storage,
and it's not directly accessing the drive.

118
00:05:55.480 --> 00:05:59.260
So, it's great that drive is 12 GB,
that's wonderful.

119
00:05:59.260 --> 00:06:03.510
But, what about the switch
that's in between it?

120
00:06:03.510 --> 00:06:07.610
What about the HBA that's on the SAN
that this network cable is plugged into?

121
00:06:07.610 --> 00:06:12.130
What about the HBA that's in my virtual
machine host that it's plugged into?

122
00:06:12.130 --> 00:06:19.020
This HBA right here plugged into VMHOST1,
that thing might only be 12 GB.

123
00:06:19.020 --> 00:06:20.310
If it's set up for

124
00:06:20.310 --> 00:06:25.360
a 12 GB SAN, then it's gonna have 12
GB of throughput on that one HBA.

125
00:06:25.360 --> 00:06:30.870
That means that any one VM
could hit 12 GB of speed.

126
00:06:30.870 --> 00:06:34.560
But if I've got five VMs,
they're all sharing that link.

127
00:06:34.560 --> 00:06:39.645
And so, if there's even two hosts
talking or two VMs talking at once.

128
00:06:39.645 --> 00:06:42.735
They're gonna divide that up, and
they're not gonna get 12 GB, right?

129
00:06:42.735 --> 00:06:47.755
So all of my virtual machines are having
to share that HBA, or if it's an iSCSI

130
00:06:47.755 --> 00:06:52.620
SAN, they're having to share that iSCSI
connection to get to the storage, right?

131
00:06:52.620 --> 00:06:54.930
And so that becomes a bottleneck for

132
00:06:54.930 --> 00:06:59.260
this one host, not even considering
all the other hosts, right, Wes?

133
00:06:59.260 --> 00:07:01.840
>> Yeah, this reminds me coming
out of A+ and NET+, Donn.

134
00:07:01.840 --> 00:07:02.900
And help me out with this one.

135
00:07:02.900 --> 00:07:07.030
This looks like the same thing when we
say contention-based media access, right?

136
00:07:07.030 --> 00:07:08.940
We've got a struggle going on here.

137
00:07:08.940 --> 00:07:11.470
Maybe not a struggle, but
we're definitely dividing that.

138
00:07:11.470 --> 00:07:15.090
Or when you talk about, for instance, an
ISP and shared bandwidth with your cable

139
00:07:15.090 --> 00:07:18.050
providers, you only get your
little piece of the pie.

140
00:07:18.050 --> 00:07:19.920
And now it could cause
performance degradation?

141
00:07:19.920 --> 00:07:24.220
>> Yeah, and it's not quite the same
as media access contingent.

142
00:07:24.220 --> 00:07:26.120
>> Right.
>> Where, like in an ethernet network,

143
00:07:26.120 --> 00:07:28.940
where only one person can talk a link
at a time or you get collisions.

144
00:07:28.940 --> 00:07:30.870
It's not like that here
cuz we have the LUNs and

145
00:07:30.870 --> 00:07:32.890
you get parallel type communications.

146
00:07:32.890 --> 00:07:34.880
But you do have that competition for
bandwidth.

147
00:07:34.880 --> 00:07:38.070
There's only so much bandwidth that
can go on one of these links, and

148
00:07:38.070 --> 00:07:39.700
you can exceed it.

149
00:07:39.700 --> 00:07:42.370
And it's easy to plan for
that on the hosts.

150
00:07:42.370 --> 00:07:43.720
It's harder on the SAN.

151
00:07:43.720 --> 00:07:45.410
This SAN has two connections.

152
00:07:45.410 --> 00:07:47.420
Let's say they're 12 GB each.

153
00:07:47.420 --> 00:07:51.480
So there's 24 GB of bandwidth on the SAN.

154
00:07:51.480 --> 00:07:56.463
Well, if I have each of these hosts
with a 12 GB adapter, that's a lot more,

155
00:07:56.463 --> 00:07:57.228
isn't it?

156
00:07:57.228 --> 00:08:00.083
That's 24 GB, no, it's 48 GB.

157
00:08:00.083 --> 00:08:00.606
There it is.

158
00:08:00.606 --> 00:08:01.663
Don's math is challenged today.

159
00:08:01.663 --> 00:08:04.959
>> I told you.
>> So, I got 48 GB potential.

160
00:08:04.959 --> 00:08:07.613
Of traffic that's gonna
be crossing those lines,

161
00:08:07.613 --> 00:08:11.370
verses the 24 that I've got down here,
because of these links.

162
00:08:11.370 --> 00:08:14.370
And when you buy a SAN,
the two gig stuff is pretty old,

163
00:08:14.370 --> 00:08:15.650
you don't see that anymore so much.

164
00:08:15.650 --> 00:08:18.180
But the four gig is still
on sale quite a bit.

165
00:08:18.180 --> 00:08:20.670
The eight gig is out there,
that's usually the best price point.

166
00:08:20.670 --> 00:08:22.260
And the 12 gig, is the fast stuff.

167
00:08:22.260 --> 00:08:25.610
So you can get that, but
you may need more than one connection or

168
00:08:25.610 --> 00:08:29.570
you may need more than one SAN if you know
you're going to be exceeding those values.

169
00:08:29.570 --> 00:08:31.670
Now what are your values gonna be?

170
00:08:31.670 --> 00:08:32.880
Unfortunately, I don't know.

171
00:08:32.880 --> 00:08:35.410
If you have a database server,
these values could be really high.

172
00:08:35.410 --> 00:08:38.140
Databases can push a lot of reads and
writes.

173
00:08:38.140 --> 00:08:40.870
But you might have a web server
that caches the web page and

174
00:08:40.870 --> 00:08:43.320
it rarely ever touches these
disks on the back end.

175
00:08:43.320 --> 00:08:45.210
In fact then,
the disks only really get used for

176
00:08:45.210 --> 00:08:47.070
cluster fail over which you
might not even be doing.

177
00:08:47.070 --> 00:08:51.030
You might be load balancing across VMs and
your disk IO is negligible.

178
00:08:51.030 --> 00:08:53.160
In those cases,
you may have plenty of bandwidth here.

179
00:08:53.160 --> 00:08:55.460
You've got to measure
the bandwidth of your host.

180
00:08:55.460 --> 00:08:58.198
How much storage bandwidth that they need?

181
00:08:58.198 --> 00:09:01.090
How many reads and
writes per second are they performing?

182
00:09:01.090 --> 00:09:04.500
And you've gotta add that up for
each of the VMs and

183
00:09:04.500 --> 00:09:09.410
each of the hosts to see if you exceed
it anywhere along the lines, right?

184
00:09:09.410 --> 00:09:14.320
There's the physical drives,
there's the storage controller in the SAN,

185
00:09:14.320 --> 00:09:18.150
There's the HBAs in the SAN that
connect to the fiber switch.

186
00:09:18.150 --> 00:09:19.880
There's the fiber switch itself,

187
00:09:19.880 --> 00:09:23.130
which has a back plane that has
a certain performance point.

188
00:09:23.130 --> 00:09:27.660
Then you've got the links to the hosts and
the HBAs in the hosts.

189
00:09:27.660 --> 00:09:30.820
All of those points could be
potential bottle necks and

190

641
00:30:33.430 --> 00:30:37.190
and this is where that scale up
versus scale out decision comes in.

642
00:30:37.190 --> 00:30:41.710
Cuz if I have one VM with eight
GB of RAM that's one VM license.

643
00:30:41.710 --> 00:30:46.160
But if I have two VMs with 4 GB of RAM, I
might get better performance if I pay for

644
00:30:46.160 --> 00:30:47.110
two host licenses.

645
00:30:47.110 --> 00:30:50.200
So always remember your licensing
as part of metering this out.

646
00:30:50.200 --> 00:30:54.790
And if you've only bought 20 licenses,
you can't spin up more than 20 VMs,

647
00:30:54.790 --> 00:30:56.070
you've got that limit.

648
00:30:56.070 --> 00:30:59.960
And that's another resource we've
got to monitor, meter, and allocate.

649
00:31:01.480 --> 00:31:03.850
All right so
we've talked about a lot of stuff.

650
00:31:03.850 --> 00:31:07.370
The only other thing I have on my notes
to cover here is resource pooling.

651
00:31:07.370 --> 00:31:12.150
And I covered resource pooling in another
episode when we were talking about

652
00:31:12.150 --> 00:31:14.220
how we can share resources
between systems.

653
00:31:14.220 --> 00:31:17.180
And I specifically did it in
storage talking about IOPs.

654
00:31:17.180 --> 00:31:19.430
When you have resources
that are available,

655
00:31:19.430 --> 00:31:23.550
sometimes you can pool them together to
get the most effective use out of it.

656
00:31:23.550 --> 00:31:29.180
And that's called the resource pool, and
it maybe shared storage, it maybe disk IO,

657
00:31:29.180 --> 00:31:33.220
it might be CPU cycles where you share
them amongst the pool of machines.

658
00:31:33.220 --> 00:31:35.100
It's really just dynamic allocation,
right?

659
00:31:35.100 --> 00:31:38.210
It's like what we talked
about with dynamic CPU's and

660
00:31:38.210 --> 00:31:39.820
thin provisioning of storage and so on.

661
00:31:39.820 --> 00:31:40.990
It's the same concept.

662
00:31:40.990 --> 00:31:43.490
So resource pooling is just one big name

663
00:31:43.490 --> 00:31:47.130
that encompasses all those smaller
elements that we talked about earlier.

664
00:31:47.130 --> 00:31:49.830
So just be aware that you might
see that term on the exam.

665
00:31:49.830 --> 00:31:53.580
If you're not familiar with it, check out
our storage episode cuz I show a great

666
00:31:53.580 --> 00:31:58.600
example of setting up an IOPs pool inside
of Microsoft Azure for some SQL servers.

667
00:31:58.600 --> 00:32:01.950
And it's just pretty easy to do and
it creates that shared resource.

668
00:32:01.950 --> 00:32:05.610
But as with any dynamic technology,
you've gotta monitor it.

669
00:32:05.610 --> 00:32:07.980
You've gotta keep track of it
to know if you're going over,

670
00:32:07.980 --> 00:32:09.640
to know if you're getting contention.

671
00:32:09.640 --> 00:32:12.180
Because then you need to either
increase the size of your pool or

672
00:32:12.180 --> 00:32:14.440
start adding some dedicated resources.

673
00:32:14.440 --> 00:32:17.940
>> In this episode, we have looked at,
well, networking right, and

674
00:32:17.940 --> 00:32:22.040
what we do and the best practices for
allocating network resources.

675
00:32:22.040 --> 00:32:24.700
We've also looked at some
of the best practices for

676
00:32:24.700 --> 00:32:27.640
allocating storage resources and
then finished it up with quotas.

677
00:32:27.640 --> 00:32:29.860
Now, in the first part of the episode,
go back and watch that.

678
00:32:29.860 --> 00:32:33.750
Remember we looked at CPU and
we looked at some other concepts as well,

679
00:32:33.750 --> 00:32:35.560
if we're catching you off guard.

680
00:32:35.560 --> 00:32:37.910
But looks like we've come to
the end of another episode.

681
00:32:37.910 --> 00:32:39.950
Don do you have anything else for
us on this one?

682
00:32:39.950 --> 00:32:41.380
>> I think I've rambled on long enough.

683
00:32:41.380 --> 00:32:43.500
I do have a little more I wanna
talk about with some other topics,

684
00:32:43.500 --> 00:32:45.000
which we'll get into in other episodes.

685
00:32:45.000 --> 00:32:48.360
But as far as resource allocation,
we've covered a lot of things.

686
00:32:48.360 --> 00:32:50.810
That's a pretty good point for
us to stop right there.

687
00:32:50.810 --> 00:32:52.360
>> A lot of good information on this one,
Don.

688
00:32:52.360 --> 00:32:53.350
Thank you for that.

689
00:32:53.350 --> 00:32:54.780
Got anything else for us in this episode?

690
00:32:54.780 --> 00:32:56.070
>> I think that's probably about it.

691
00:32:56.070 --> 00:32:57.950
I've rambled on enough, so
we'll go ahead and wrap this one up.

692
00:32:57.950 --> 00:32:58.500
Stay tuned,

693
00:32:58.500 --> 00:33:01.370
we've got a lot more Cloud+ coverage
that's gonna be coming down the pipe.

694
00:33:01.370 --> 00:33:02.770
>> All right,
I look forward to seeing that, and

695
00:33:02.770 --> 00:33:04.390
we look forward to seeing you guys there,
but

696
00:33:04.390 --> 00:33:07.230
we're gonna go ahead and
sign off here at ITProTV.

697
00:33:07.230 --> 00:33:11.990
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

698
00:33:11.990 --> 00:33:12.990
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

699
00:33:12.990 --> 00:33:16.232
>> And we'll see you next time.

700
00:33:16.232 --> 00:33:18.313
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don explore remote access technologies used to connect to cloud based virtual environments. They look at the difference between remotely connecting to a virtual machine host as well as a virtual machine guest. They will discuss topics like using Microsoft's Remote Desktop Protocol, SSH and VNC to manage the virtual environment.
episodes.title: Remote Access
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.114 --> 00:00:10.114
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.215 --> 00:00:15.364
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.364 --> 00:00:16.664
I'm your host, Wes Bryan, and

4
00:00:16.664 --> 00:00:19.820
in today's episode we're going to be
moving along in our Cloud+ training.

5
00:00:19.820 --> 00:00:23.250
And today we're gonna be looking at
more specifically, remote access, and

6
00:00:23.250 --> 00:00:27.130
how do we gain access to the cloud-based
services when we need to.

7
00:00:27.130 --> 00:00:28.794
And we got Don Pezet here to help us out.

8
00:00:28.794 --> 00:00:29.800
Don, how you doing today, sir?

9
00:00:29.800 --> 00:00:30.949
And welcome back.

10
00:00:30.949 --> 00:00:33.380
>> [LAUGH] Well thanks for
having me back on the show, Wes.

11
00:00:33.380 --> 00:00:36.250
It's kinda a neat topic to jump into,
the remote access side of things.

12
00:00:36.250 --> 00:00:40.310
Cuz we spend a lot of time talking
about creating the virtual machines,

13
00:00:40.310 --> 00:00:42.350
and creating this, creating that,
putting it in place.

14
00:00:42.350 --> 00:00:45.725
And we don't really see getting in and
using the resources that we make, and so

15
00:00:45.725 --> 00:00:47.810
that's what we're gonna look at here.

16
00:00:47.810 --> 00:00:51.067
I wanna talk about remote access
to connect to the hosts, right,

17
00:00:51.067 --> 00:00:52.728
the virtualization platforms,

18
00:00:52.728 --> 00:00:55.944
as well as remote access to connect
to the guests that we create.

19
00:00:55.944 --> 00:00:59.228
And it's actually very similar between the
two, the different ways that we use it,

20
00:00:59.228 --> 00:01:01.414
but we're just gonna kind of
run through some of those.

21
00:01:01.414 --> 00:01:03.991
We won't spend a ton of time on it,
because for most platforms,

22
00:01:03.991 --> 00:01:06.838
when you deploy it, you can kinda
rely on your vendor documentation.

23
00:01:06.838 --> 00:01:10.430
But I wanna show you the most common
ones and just give you a few scenarios.

24
00:01:10.430 --> 00:01:11.650
All right, so let's kick it off, and

25
00:01:11.650 --> 00:01:14.230
I wanna start by talking
about the platform, right.

26
00:01:14.230 --> 00:01:18.850
When you deploy a cloud, if it's a public
cloud, it might be Amazon Web Services or

27
00:01:18.850 --> 00:01:22.348
Microsoft Azure, for those guys,
they've got a nice web UI.

28
00:01:22.348 --> 00:01:24.368
You just go to the webpage, you log in and

29
00:01:24.368 --> 00:01:26.514
you can spin up all
the instances you want.

30
00:01:26.514 --> 00:01:30.712
I know I've brought it up in a few of our
shows, so we've kinda seen it before,

31
00:01:30.712 --> 00:01:33.595
but that web interface is
how we manage the platform.

32
00:01:33.595 --> 00:01:36.821
And a lot of them have APIs for
command line type access also,

33
00:01:36.821 --> 00:01:40.270
Microsoft lets you send with
the Azure PowerShell commandlet.

34
00:01:40.270 --> 00:01:43.420
So you can send PowerShell commands up
to create virtual machines and stuff.

35
00:01:43.420 --> 00:01:46.430
With Amazon, they have their own API,
you can do the same thing and

36
00:01:46.430 --> 00:01:51.730
the AWS CLI, so those are different
ways we can access those public clouds.

37
00:01:51.730 --> 00:01:54.840
But for a private cloud, when you
deploy it, when you create the whole

38
00:01:54.840 --> 00:01:59.220
infrastructure yourself, you are the one
who has to create that environment, right?

39
00:01:59.220 --> 00:02:01.380
And how do you manage that system?

40
00:02:01.380 --> 00:02:03.235
Well, it's somewhat up to you, right?

41
00:02:03.235 --> 00:02:05.771
Let's start with the one that
you're always gonna have, and

42
00:02:05.771 --> 00:02:07.380
that's console access.

43
00:02:07.380 --> 00:02:12.120
When you bring up a hypervisor, at a
minimum, you can hook a keyboard, a mouse,

44
00:02:12.120 --> 00:02:15.920
and a monitor up to that physical
server and you will see something.

45
00:02:15.920 --> 00:02:18.620
It might not be the most useful thing on
the planet, but you will see something.

46
00:02:18.620 --> 00:02:20.650
Let me just show you some examples here.

47
00:02:20.650 --> 00:02:25.640
So, if I had installed ESX on
a physical box, and I hook a monitor,

48
00:02:25.640 --> 00:02:27.980
and a keyboard, and a mouse,
I'm gonna see this screen right here.

49
00:02:27.980 --> 00:02:30.990
And this is actually its little sleep
mode, so it's kind of dimmed out a little

50
00:02:30.990 --> 00:02:34.410
bit, but if I hit a button,
there we go, it wakes up.

51
00:02:34.410 --> 00:02:39.290
And, all we're seeing is a really simple
splash page which, at first glance,

52
00:02:39.290 --> 00:02:41.120
looks like we can't do anything, right?

53
00:02:41.120 --> 00:02:44.470
If you kind of look at some of
the stuff that it's giving me,

54
00:02:44.470 --> 00:02:47.540
it tells me information about my system.

55
00:02:47.540 --> 00:02:54.188
So this one's running ESXi version 6.0,
I've got two processors, or two cores.

56
00:02:54.188 --> 00:02:56.710
I've got four gigs of memory
attached to this system,

57
00:02:56.710 --> 00:02:58.260
which is not a whole heck of a lot.

58
00:02:58.260 --> 00:03:02.465
And then right down here it says,
download tools to manage this host from,

59
00:03:02.465 --> 00:03:07.800
10.1.230.20, that's the IP address that
was assigned to this host when it came up.

60
00:03:07.800 --> 00:03:10.580
And what they're basically trying to tell
me here is hey, buddy you're in the wrong

61
00:03:10.580 --> 00:03:15.790
place, you don't manage the server from
here, you need to go and use our software

62
00:03:15.790 --> 00:03:20.720
and connect up, use this IP, get connected
and you can manage the system, right.

63
00:03:20.720 --> 00:03:24.610
But I can see this, and there is actually
a little bit that I can do from here.

64
00:03:24.610 --> 00:03:27.760
What you'll see is way down
at the bottom of the screen,

65
00:03:27.760 --> 00:03:30.980
and let me see if I can zoom in on that,
there we go,

66
00:03:30.980 --> 00:03:36.300
we've got this press F12 to Shut Down or
Restart, right?

67
00:03:36.300 --> 00:03:39.558
Well, that's not very exciting [LAUGH]
I can shut it down and restart it.

68
00:03:39.558 --> 00:03:42.969
So we do have that, and
then on the other side,

69
00:03:42.969 --> 00:03:47.000
I've got press F2 to Customize System and
View Logs.

70
00:03:47.000 --> 00:03:49.450
Now that's a little more exciting for
me right there, right?

71
00:03:49.450 --> 00:03:53.630
If I want to start to actually work
with this system, I could press F2,

72
00:03:53.630 --> 00:03:56.360
and it's gonna make me log
in with whatever password

73
00:03:56.360 --> 00:03:58.490
we assigned when we created the system.

74
00:03:58.490 --> 00:04:02.070
But then it's gonna give me
a limited management interface to

75
00:04:02.070 --> 00:04:03.970
begin working with this system.

76
00:04:03.970 --> 00:04:05.925
And so
here I am in that limited interface.

77
00:04:05.925 --> 00:04:08.020
And you'll see the choices it gives me.

78
00:04:08.020 --> 00:04:10.983
I can configure my password, I can
configure lockdown mode, that only works

79
00:04:10.983 --> 00:04:13.825
when you're connected to vCenter so
that's why it's grayed out for me.

80
00:04:13.825 --> 00:04:16.020
I can configure the management network.

81
00:04:16.020 --> 00:04:19.150
If you ever screw up and lock yourself
out of the management network interface,

82
00:04:19.150 --> 00:04:20.860
I can recover that right here.

83
00:04:20.860 --> 00:04:22.710
I can do a network restore and

84
00:04:22.710 --> 00:04:25.180
put my entire network
configuration back in place.

85
00:04:25.180 --> 00:04:28.690
I can configure my keyboard,
I can view the system logs, and

86
00:04:28.690 --> 00:04:30.730
I can reset the configuration.

87
00:04:30.730 --> 00:04:32.820
Can I create virtual machines?

88
00:04:32.820 --> 00:04:33.600
No.

89
00:04:33.600 --> 00:04:35.870
Can I start and stop virtual machines?

90
00:04:35.870 --> 00:04:36.650
No.

91
00:04:36.650 --> 00:04:39.030
Can I create virtual networks?

92
00:04:39.030 --> 00:04:39.870
No.

93
00:04:39.870 --> 00:04:42.210
It's a very, very limited interface.

94
00:04:42.210 --> 00:04:45.330
The console is really
just an emergency level,

95
00:04:45.330 --> 00:04:49.102
like you've gotten yourself locked out,
here's how we get back in, right?

96
00:04:49.102 --> 00:04:52.730
Really base-level stuff, not intended
to be used for any regular management.

97
00:04:52.730 --> 00:04:57.050
So most people just pretend this
console doesn't even exist.

98
00:04:57.050 --> 00:04:59.950
Now that's VMware,
not everybody's like that.

99
00:04:59.950 --> 00:05:03.130
Citrix XenServer, for example, I've got
one of those in the background here.

100
00:05:04.250 --> 00:05:07.800
When you plug a monitor, a keyboard, or
a mouse into a Citrix XenServer you'll see

101
00:05:07.800 --> 00:05:12.000
a screen like this, which is black,
right, it's just gone to sleep, right?

102
00:05:12.000 --> 00:05:12.890
And if we wake that up,

103
00:05:12.890 --> 00:05:16.830
you actually see a screen that's a bit
more useful than what we saw with VMware.

104
00:05:16.830 --> 00:05:19.500
What they give us is the ability
to do all sorts of things.

105
00:05:19.500 --> 00:05:23.240
We've got the network and management
interface like we saw with VMware.

106
00:05:23.240 --> 00:05:25.940
But we can actually view
the virtual machines we have.

107
00:05:25.940 --> 00:05:29.585
And you can't create virtual machines,
but you can start and stop them.

108
00:05:29.585 --> 00:05:32.990
And you can even migrate them from one
host to another if we're in a cluster.

109
00:05:32.990 --> 00:05:35.360
We can see our disk and
storage repositories, and

110
00:05:35.360 --> 00:05:37.580
actually do some basic
configuration there.

111
00:05:37.580 --> 00:05:38.600
So with XenServer,

112
00:05:38.600 --> 00:05:44.250
we can actually do a little bit from
the console, not a ton, but a little bit.

113
00:05:44.250 --> 00:05:48.520
And what it really wants us to do,
is not to work from here, but

114
00:05:48.520 --> 00:05:54.430
just like with ESX, to install a software
to remotely manage the system.

115
00:05:54.430 --> 00:05:56.930
And in fact, if I were to get out of this,

116
00:05:56.930 --> 00:06:00.760
which, let's see if I can
remember how to even do that.

117
00:06:00.760 --> 00:06:02.880
But anyway, after a while,
the machine will time out, and

118
00:06:02.880 --> 00:06:05.980
it'll display a little pop up saying
browse to this page to manage the server,

119
00:06:05.980 --> 00:06:09.440
and it'll give the IP just like
we saw with the VMWare box.

120
00:06:09.440 --> 00:06:14.227
The only real exception to this is
Microsoft's Hyper-V because on Hyper-V

121
00:06:14.227 --> 00:06:15.480
when you log in to it,

122
00:06:15.480 --> 00:06:18.750
it's a full Windows desktop, right,
unless you do a core services install.

123
00:06:18.750 --> 00:06:21.350
On a regular install you have
a graphical user interface.

124
00:06:21.350 --> 00:06:23.880
And you can launch your Hyper-V
manager and you can work with it and

125
00:06:23.880 --> 00:06:27.320
you can do everything
right from the console.

126
00:06:27.320 --> 00:06:31.420
But the trade off there is, that means
we need a lot more resources tied to

127
00:06:31.420 --> 00:06:36.340
our host machine to keep it running than
VMWare and Citrix do, cuz on those guys,

128
00:06:36.340 --> 00:06:41.240
you just need a small amount of memory and
CPU available to power that host.

129
00:06:41.240 --> 00:06:43.580
>> You know, Don, those first two screens,

130
00:06:43.580 --> 00:06:47.362
they bear a striking resemblance to
the basic screens we see in BIOS.

131
00:06:47.362 --> 00:06:51.315
And I wanna be careful with that, because
we did see in XenCenter there that, or

132
00:06:51.315 --> 00:06:54.690
the XenServer, that you do have
a location that says view the BIOS.

133
00:06:54.690 --> 00:06:57.710
So it's not BIOS, but boy,
it really looks like BIOS.

134
00:06:57.710 --> 00:07:00.440
>> Yeah, it's supposed to be super
simple and it's supposed to work on

135
00:07:00.440 --> 00:07:03.050
every monitor, that's why it's
like super low resolution and all,

136
00:07:03.050 --> 00:07:06.110
it's just not designed to be fancy and
flashy.

137
00:07:06.110 --> 00:07:10.120
Instead, what they're expecting you to do
is to run full-blown management clients.

138
00:07:10.120 --> 00:07:13.680
So Hyper-V here that I'm showing you
guys is a full-blown management client.

139
00:07:13.680 --> 00:07:17.080
And if I have more than one Hyper-V
host I can just come up here and

140
00:07:17.080 --> 00:07:21.230
add them to my Hyper-V manager by
choosing this Connect to Server.

141
00:07:21.230 --> 00:07:25.890
And I can connect to as many other servers
as I've got, so I might have other ones,

142
00:07:25.890 --> 00:07:27.980
I can punch in their data here and
get connected.

143
00:07:27.980 --> 00:07:30.550
And then I can start to manage
them from this panel, and

144
00:07:30.550 --> 00:07:32.640
I can create VMs,
turn them on, turn them off.

145
00:07:32.640 --> 00:07:34.810
Do all that other great stuff.

146
00:07:34.810 --> 00:07:41.120
Well, for Citrix and for VMWare,
we have those clients too, right?

147
00:07:41.120 --> 00:07:43.500
It's just,
they don't make an operating system for

148
00:07:43.500 --> 00:07:45.490
you to run on your desktop
like Microsoft does.

149
00:07:45.490 --> 00:07:48.130
So Microsoft gives it to us right
here as part of the operating system.

150
00:07:48.130 --> 00:07:51.556
But with Xen and
with ESX we've gotta install it ourselves.

151
00:07:51.556 --> 00:07:54.431
And the way you normally do that
is by firing up a web browser and

152
00:07:54.431 --> 00:07:56.712
just pointing it to the IP
address of the server.

153
00:07:56.712 --> 00:08:01.356
So, for example, if I browse to
the IP address of my ESX server,

154
00:08:01.356 --> 00:08:06.946
I get this web page right here, and
it's telling me I'm on a VMware ESXi box,

155
00:08:06.946 --> 00:08:10.930
and I can download the vSphere client for
Windows.

156
00:08:10.930 --> 00:08:14.400
That's the management client for
managing ESX, right?

157
00:08:14.400 --> 00:08:18.460
vSphere client,
we use to manage individual ESX boxes, and

158
00:08:18.460 --> 00:08:21.580
then there's vCenter,
which is a full blown server install that

159

we can use to manage

Especially distributed denial

26

CompTIA calls it out on the objectives

00:01:13.950 --> 00:01:18.490
news world without hearing about

32

But it's extremely easy to perform

33
00:01:33.300 --> 00:01:34.460

34

Now what is denial of service?

35
00:01:36.920 --> 00:01:37.890
You have a service.

36
00:01:37.890 --> 00:01:40.720
Let's say Our website, ITProTV.

37

We got a website, and
you can come to our website and

38

39

40

We have bandwidth that we pay for every
month, and we have a certain amount of it.

41
00:01:49.080 --> 00:01:53.700
And if we ever hit the limit of that
bandwidth, our site stops responding.

42
00:01:53.700 --> 00:01:54.860
People can't get to our site.

43
00:01:54.860 --> 00:01:56.630
Our service is no longer available.

44
00:01:56.630 --> 00:02:00.540
Now, we monitor how much bandwidth we use
every month and we pay the right amount to

45
00:02:00.540 --> 00:02:03.420
pay for that, and so we've always

46
00:02:03.420 --> 00:02:07.100
But if an attacker wanted,
they could start flooding our lines,

47
00:02:07.100 --> 00:02:11.530
flooding our bandwidth, saturating all
that bandwidth, and then we run out,

48
00:02:11.530 --> 00:02:15.810
and then our legitimate customers are no
longer able to get to the website.

49
00:02:15.810 --> 00:02:19.150
That's a very real thing, it happens,
and it's incredibly easy to do.

50
00:02:19.150 --> 00:02:21.720
It used to be super
easy back in the 1990s,

51
00:02:21.720 --> 00:02:23.640
cuz people didn't have a lot of bandwidth.

52
00:02:23.640 --> 00:02:26.570
It's actually a little bit harder
now because people have large

53
00:02:26.570 --> 00:02:27.790
quantities of bandwidth.

54
00:02:27.790 --> 00:02:30.340
Here at the studio we got
80 megabits of bandwidth.

55
00:02:30.340 --> 00:02:33.500
So if somebody wants to perform
a denial service against our system

56
00:02:33.500 --> 00:02:36.680
they have to send 80 megabits of traffic.

57
00:02:36.680 --> 00:02:39.560
Well let's say I'm sitting at home and
I'm on my computer.

58
00:02:39.560 --> 00:02:42.300
I'm like I hate those ITProTV guys,
that Dons voice really

59
00:02:42.300 --> 00:02:45.580
annoys the heck out of me I'm gonna flood
their line, and shut them down, okay?

60
00:02:46.580 --> 00:02:51.170
Sitting from my computer at home, I have
a cable modem, high speed, broadband,

61
00:02:51.170 --> 00:02:53.250
whatever, it's all bs.

62
00:02:53.250 --> 00:02:56.290
So, I have 20 megabytes, is,
maybe, what I get on a good day.

63
00:02:56.290 --> 00:03:00.410
So, I can generate 20 megabits of traffic,
and throw it at ITProTV, but,

64
00:03:00.410 --> 00:03:03.880
we've got 80 megabits of bandwidth here,
I can't saturate the line, right?

65
00:03:03.880 --> 00:03:07.330
Doing a straight up denial of service
stack is not really possible.

66
00:03:07.330 --> 00:03:09.460
There's some protocols
that can be exploited,

67
00:03:09.460 --> 00:03:11.370
and it's not always about bandwidth.

68
00:03:11.370 --> 00:03:14.580
It might be about throughput,
that if I send enough packets,

69
00:03:14.580 --> 00:03:18.260
like TCP buffer saturation.

70
00:03:18.260 --> 00:03:22.610
If I open up enough TCP sessions
I might not be flowing in a true

71
00:03:22.610 --> 00:03:23.750
payload across it.

72
00:03:23.750 --> 00:03:26.855
So very small packages
opening up TCP sessions.

73
00:03:26.855 --> 00:03:31.000
Well, a server can only have so many TCP
ports open before it runs out of RAM and

74
00:03:31.000 --> 00:03:35.320
so we can flood that opening up by just
doing a bunch of TCP send requests and

75
00:03:35.320 --> 00:03:38.550
the server will open up all these
ports waiting for acknowledgements and

76
00:03:38.550 --> 00:03:41.400
they'll just sit there open and we can
run the server out of resources, right?

77
00:03:41.400 --> 00:03:44.930
So we can do that even with low bandwidth,
but it's easy to spot that.

78
00:03:44.930 --> 00:03:49.810
It's easy to see why does this one person
have 10 million TCP SYNs open right now?

79
00:03:49.810 --> 00:03:51.850
What the heck's going on there, right?

80
00:03:51.850 --> 00:03:54.590
And you can spot it and
stop it and modern firewalls do,

81
00:03:54.590 --> 00:03:56.370
they see that traffic and stop it.

82
00:03:56.370 --> 00:03:57.630
It's not a big deal.

83
00:03:57.630 --> 00:04:01.020
Same thing with a giant flood of
traffic coming from one system.

84
00:04:01.020 --> 00:04:04.340
So what attackers have to do is they have
to get a little more sophisticated, and

85
00:04:04.340 --> 00:04:07.400
that's where the old denial of
service that no longer works

86
00:04:07.400 --> 00:04:10.590
gets replaced by the distributed
denial of service.

87
00:04:10.590 --> 00:04:13.835
So let's talk a little bit about how
distributed denial service works.

88
00:04:13.835 --> 00:04:17.335
And understand why it's so difficult for
us to protect from that, all right?

89
00:04:17.335 --> 00:04:19.575
Well I've got a diagram
kinda whipped up here but

90
00:04:19.575 --> 00:04:20.945
with typical corporate network, right?

91
00:04:20.945 --> 00:04:23.945
You've got the Internet and you might
have the DMZ with some servers and

92
00:04:23.945 --> 00:04:25.205
that what's normally gonna get attacked.

93
00:04:25.205 --> 00:04:26.935
That's your public facing side.

94
00:04:26.935 --> 00:04:27.675
You got a website.

95
00:04:27.675 --> 00:04:30.805
If somebody wants to bring it down,
they're gonna start sending a flood of

96
00:04:30.805 --> 00:04:34.070
traffic in to hit that web server or
whatever, right?

97
00:04:34.070 --> 00:04:37.750
When they do that, if they can exceed your
bandwidth that's one way to shut you down,

98
00:04:37.750 --> 00:04:41.310
or if they can exceed the amount of
connections allow that can shut you down,

99
00:04:41.310 --> 00:04:43.230
there's several different
ways they can go about it.

100
00:04:43.230 --> 00:04:45.240
That's what they're attacking, all right?

101
00:04:45.240 --> 00:04:49.020
But I just said like one host is
not enough, and it really isn't.

102
00:04:49.020 --> 00:04:53.830
So today if you wanna do a denial
of service attack on somebody,

103
00:04:53.830 --> 00:04:54.910
you don't need one host.

104
00:04:54.910 --> 00:04:55.560
You don't need ten.

105
00:04:55.560 --> 00:04:56.520
You don't need a hundred.

106
00:04:56.520 --> 00:04:58.690
You need thousands, tens of thousands or

107
00:04:58.690 --> 00:05:02.540
even hundreds of thousands of
hosts to perform that attack.

108
00:05:02.540 --> 00:05:03.850
Well, who has that?

109
00:05:03.850 --> 00:05:07.570
Who has a hundred thousand machines
sitting there ready to do an attack?

110
00:05:07.570 --> 00:05:08.380
The answer is nobody.

111
00:05:08.380 --> 00:05:11.320
Nobody's got that many machines
sitting around just for an attack.

112
00:05:11.320 --> 00:05:16.600
So, what an attacker has to do
is compromise other systems.

113
00:05:16.600 --> 00:05:20.410
A distributed denial of service
attack involves multiple pieces.

114
00:05:20.410 --> 00:05:23.490
There's you, you and your servers,
right, that's what's being targeted,

115
00:05:23.490 --> 00:05:25.300
that's what they're after.

116
00:05:25.300 --> 00:05:28.330
Then there's the attacker, and
the attacker might be just one

117
00:05:28.330 --> 00:05:32.340
little laptop sitting in
a coffee shop in Czechoslovakia.

118
00:05:32.340 --> 00:05:35.960
He could be anywhere, right,
he could be right in the same city as you.

119
00:05:35.960 --> 00:05:37.780
They're just sitting there
in a coffee shop, right.

120
00:05:37.780 --> 00:05:38.750
And they want to attack you.

121
00:05:38.750 --> 00:05:40.010
So what do they do?

122
00:05:40.010 --> 00:05:41.990
Well first they write some kind of virus,

123
00:05:41.990 --> 00:05:46.660
some kind of malware, a worm,
that spreads across the Internet.

124
00:05:46.660 --> 00:05:49.730
And as it's spread across the Internet
it's infecting machines, right.

125
00:05:49.730 --> 00:05:50.510
These machines,

126
00:05:50.510 --> 00:05:54.560
which are gonna be our infected systems,
they're sometimes called bots, or zombies.

127
00:05:54.560 --> 00:05:58.870
These are machines that are just regular
old people that are out there that don't

128
00:05:58.870 --> 00:06:01.020
know how to run decent antivirus, right?

129
00:06:01.020 --> 00:06:05.530
And it's your mom and dad,
it's your aunt and uncle,

130
00:06:05.530 --> 00:06:09.560
it's your coworkers at the office,
it's people who are not IT people that

131
00:06:09.560 --> 00:06:13.010
are just browsing the Internet and
they get their system infected.

132
00:06:13.010 --> 00:06:17.740
And when that happens, they start
phoning home, not to the attacker.

133
00:06:17.740 --> 00:06:19.400
Because, if they were
phoning home to the attacker,

134
00:06:19.400 --> 00:06:21.930
the authorities could find that and
shut them off real fast.

135
00:06:21.930 --> 00:06:25.320
But instead, they're reporting back
to what are called Command and

136
00:06:25.320 --> 00:06:27.850
Control Servers, C&C Servers, right?

137
00:06:27.850 --> 00:06:30.585
These servers are normally running
something like in net relay chat, so

138
00:06:30.585 --> 00:06:32.010
running little chat rooms.

139
00:06:32.010 --> 00:06:36.010
And the server, these infected
systems reach back to the servers, and

140
00:06:36.010 --> 00:06:37.510
they listen for commands.

141
00:06:38.620 --> 00:06:42.920
And all the attacker has to do is send
a command to one of those C&C servers.

142
00:06:42.920 --> 00:06:44.010
It'll be a chat room.

143
00:06:44.010 --> 00:06:48.860
So they send a message in the chat room
that says, target this IP address.

144
00:06:48.860 --> 00:06:51.340
And then all of the infected systems.

145
00:06:51.340 --> 00:06:53.850
And there might be hundreds
of thousands of these things.

146
00:06:53.850 --> 00:06:56.430
These infected systems
all around the world,

147
00:06:56.430 --> 00:06:59.470
they all start sending very small
amounts of traffic at your server.

148
00:07:00.490 --> 00:07:03.938
They're checking in with the C&C boxes,
they get their instructions, and

149
00:07:03.938 --> 00:07:05.167
then they start to attack.

150
00:07:05.167 --> 00:07:08.620
And the way the attack works
is it looks like this.

151
00:07:08.620 --> 00:07:11.760
The attacker sends
instructions to the C&C.

152
00:07:11.760 --> 00:07:15.720
The infected systems all get
the instructions from the C&C servers.

153
00:07:15.720 --> 00:07:18.990
And there might be more than one
C&C server or it might only be one.

154
00:07:18.990 --> 00:07:21.760
But they start to get their
instructions and then they all,

155
00:07:21.760 --> 00:07:27.380
at a predetermined time, simultaneously
start sending traffic at your system.

156
00:07:28.420 --> 00:07:31.090
And now you're getting what
looks like legitimate traffic.

157
00:07:31.090 --> 00:07:34.520
These guys, they might not be malformed
TCP SYNs or anything like that.

158
00:07:34.520 --> 00:07:36.950
It might just be they asked for
a copy of your home page,

159
00:07:36.950 --> 00:07:39.970
just like anybody on the Internet
browsing your home page would do.

160
00:07:39.970 --> 00:07:43.090
So, can we recognize that
as malicious traffic?

161
00:07:43.090 --> 00:07:45.130
No, it's really hard to identify this,

162
00:07:45.130 --> 00:07:48.180
cuz what we're getting is
hundreds of thousands of

163
00:07:48.180 --> 00:07:52.030
connections every single second from
people just asking to get our homepage.

164
00:07:52.030 --> 00:07:55.758
And it exceeds the resources of our
servers and our servers go offline.

165
00:07:55.758 --> 00:07:59.086
Servers are up and running, they just
don't have the bandwidth or the CPU or

166
00:07:59.086 --> 00:08:00.751
the RAM to be able to handle that load.

167
00:08:00.751 --> 00:08:01.447
Right?

168
00:08:01.447 --> 00:08:03.049
That's a distributed
denial of service attack.

169
00:08:03.049 --> 00:08:06.610
It's very difficult to
prevent this type of attack.

170
00:08:06.610 --> 00:08:08.230
>> Now Don one of the things
that this looks like, and

171
00:08:08.230 --> 00:08:09.980
correct me if I'm wrong here.

172
00:08:09.980 --> 00:08:14.620
This looks like,
what would be known as a reflected attack.

173
00:08:14.620 --> 00:08:17.320
Where it's being bounced
off a third party.

174
00:08:17.320 --> 00:08:18.840
It's not actually coming
from the attacker,

175
00:08:18.840 --> 00:08:20.660
like you said, you mentioned yourself.

176
00:08:20.660 --> 00:08:22.960
So, is this kind of like
a reflected attack,

177
00:08:22.960 --> 00:08:26.080
the fact that it's being reflected
off of that Internet relay chatroom?

178
00:08:26.080 --> 00:08:27.490
>> Well, it's not a true reflection.

179
00:08:27.490 --> 00:08:28.440
>> It's not a true reflection.

180
00:08:28.440 --> 00:08:32.290
>> Right, so a true reflection is where
I send the attack traffic, right.

181
00:08:32.290 --> 00:08:34.980
So, malformed sim requests.

182
00:08:34.980 --> 00:08:37.070
And I bounce those through a proxy, so

183
00:08:37.070 --> 00:08:39.150
it looks like the attack's
coming from that proxy.

184
00:08:39.150 --> 00:08:41.820
Well here, whoever the attacker is,

185
00:08:41.820 --> 00:08:44.120
isn't necessarily sending
an attack at all, right.

186
00:08:44.120 --> 00:08:45.620
They're just sending
a command to the CNC and

187
00:08:45.620 --> 00:08:48.600
that command is normally saying
target this IP and that's it.

188
00:08:48.600 --> 00:08:49.950
It's not an attack.

189
00:08:49.950 --> 00:08:53.070
And the cnc servers aren't
giving an attack either.

00:08:53.070 --> 00:08:56.080

00:11:50.640 --> 00:11:54.500

00:12:01.390 --> 00:12:06.010

263
00:12:06.010 --> 00:12:08.770
Ping is a really easy protocol to exploit.

264
00:12:08.770 --> 00:12:13.000
Because when these attacks come in, these
infected systems need to send traffic.

265
00:12:13.000 --> 00:12:15.780
And ping traffic is sessionless.

266
00:12:15.780 --> 00:12:16.960
You can just throw it on the network and

267
00:12:16.960 --> 00:12:18.250
you can throw another
one right afterwards.

268
00:12:18.250 --> 00:12:20.560
Systems expect to see
a lot of ping traffic.

269
00:12:20.560 --> 00:12:22.800
And so, you can get a ton of it coming in.

270
00:12:22.800 --> 00:12:25.810
Just a raw ping flood can
eat up your bandwidth or

271
00:12:25.810 --> 00:12:27.570
consume your server resources.

272
00:12:27.570 --> 00:12:29.160
But ping floods are pretty easy to detect.

273
00:12:29.160 --> 00:12:31.320
You just see a ton of pings,
so you filter them out.

274
00:12:31.320 --> 00:12:33.630
But a ping of death,
is a little bit different.

275
00:12:33.630 --> 00:12:38.120
A ping normally contains about,
let's say, 58 bytes of traffic.

276
00:12:38.120 --> 00:12:39.290
It can be less, it can be more.

277
00:12:39.290 --> 00:12:42.630
But it's usually around 58 bytes of
traffic, when it goes across the network.

278
00:12:42.630 --> 00:12:47.990
A ping of death, is where you put
a lot more data into that ping.

279
00:12:47.990 --> 00:12:51.070
If you run a protocol sniffer and
you intercept a ping.

280
00:12:51.070 --> 00:12:53.860
The traffic that's inside of it,
is normally just the alphabet repeated.

281
00:12:53.860 --> 00:12:54.540
Right, so A, B, C,

282
00:12:54.540 --> 00:12:57.390
D all the way through Z and
then A through Z again and A through Z.

283
00:12:57.390 --> 00:12:59.690
That's what's normally inside a ping,
it's not much.

284
00:12:59.690 --> 00:13:02.970
And, if we increase the size of that ping,
it's just the alphabet repeating more,

285
00:13:02.970 --> 00:13:04.040
and more, and more.

286
00:13:04.040 --> 00:13:08.860
Well, a packet when it crosses
the network, can only be so big.

287
00:13:08.860 --> 00:13:11.591
Most systems limit it to 1,500 bytes.

288
00:13:11.591 --> 00:13:15.920
And if we build a ping and
we push it above that 1,500 bytes,

289
00:13:15.920 --> 00:13:18.908
then it's going to get segmented, right.

290
00:13:18.908 --> 00:13:22.140
It's going to get broken into fragments,
to be able to be sent on the network.

291
00:13:22.140 --> 00:13:24.230
And on the other end,
they've got to reassemble that.

292
00:13:24.230 --> 00:13:27.610
And if we go even bigger, like if
we cross the 65,535 byte threshold.

293
00:13:27.610 --> 00:13:33.900
If we get over that, the side of
the other end is receiving these frames.

294
00:13:33.900 --> 00:13:36.360
And they're holding them in a buffer
on the network card, a memory buffer.

295
00:13:36.360 --> 00:13:38.502
And they're reassembling them.

296
00:13:38.502 --> 00:13:42.519
And so,
if I'm sending over 65 bytes of data.

297
00:13:42.519 --> 00:13:46.310
And it's having to build,
actually it would be 65 kilobytes of data.

298
00:13:46.310 --> 00:13:48.060
It's going to hold that
while it reassembles it and

299
00:13:48.060 --> 00:13:49.750
if I can keep sending more of these pings.

300
00:13:49.750 --> 00:13:53.430
It's holding those and re-assembling them,
I can run the network heart out of memory.

301
00:13:53.430 --> 00:13:55.520
And that's a really easy
attack to pull off.

302
00:13:55.520 --> 00:13:59.910
Now, if you've got a firewall, every
modern firewall checks this and stops it.

303
00:13:59.910 --> 00:14:02.810
They stop it from getting to your
server and the payloads not that big,

304
00:14:02.810 --> 00:14:04.140
that you're not gonna
run a lot of bandwidth.

305
00:14:04.140 --> 00:14:06.030
And so, you're fine and you're insulated.

306
00:14:06.030 --> 00:14:08.540
Having a good firewall is essential.

307
00:14:08.540 --> 00:14:11.490
Blocking pings is even better.

308
00:14:11.490 --> 00:14:14.675
When you configure Amazon Web Services or
Microsoft Azure or whatever.

309
00:14:14.675 --> 00:14:15.270
In their firewalls,

310
00:14:15.270 --> 00:14:18.490
you can block pings and
then you don't have to worry about that.

311
00:14:18.490 --> 00:14:20.450
But there's other protocols
that can be exploited.

312
00:14:20.450 --> 00:14:22.449
There's a lot of other things
that can be attacked, so

313
00:14:22.449 --> 00:14:24.390
don't assume that just
blocking pings is enough.

314
00:14:24.390 --> 00:14:26.164
You want to have a good
firewall in place and

315
00:14:26.164 --> 00:14:28.710
you want to only allow
traffic that's legitimate.

316
00:14:28.710 --> 00:14:31.570
And you really need somebody
monitoring that connection.

317
00:14:31.570 --> 00:14:33.730
It can be a cloud provider or
a third party service.

318
00:14:33.730 --> 00:14:37.350
>> So if somebody does have information
inside of that storage region and

00:14:37.350 --> 00:14:39.290
it could be executable code, right.

00:14:39.290 --> 00:14:44.090
And it fills up that memory and it spills

00:14:44.090 --> 00:14:47.170
They could potentially execute that and

00:14:47.170 --> 00:14:47.940

00:14:47.940 --> 00:14:50.130
>> Yeah and that's kind of the key

00:14:50.130 --> 00:14:51.670

00:14:51.670 --> 00:14:53.410

00:14:55.800 --> 00:14:58.352

00:14:59.856 --> 00:15:02.028

00:15:04.100 --> 00:15:07.980

00:15:07.980 --> 00:15:10.390

00:15:10.390 --> 00:15:11.357

00:15:42.660 --> 00:15:47.178

00:15:47.178 --> 00:15:47.744

00:15:55.711 --> 00:15:58.384

00:15:58.384 --> 00:16:00.518

00:16:00.518 --> 00:16:03.226

00:16:03.226 --> 00:16:06.090

00:16:06.090 --> 00:16:08.020

00:16:08.020 --> 00:16:09.940

00:16:09.940 --> 00:16:11.390

00:16:11.390 --> 00:16:14.510
Because I'm using a role instead of

00:16:14.510 --> 00:16:18.610
The other advantage is that we have

358
00:16:18.610 --> 00:16:20.215

00:16:20.215 --> 00:16:25.740
Role-based access control lets us fall

00:16:28.610 --> 00:16:32.490

00:27:34.520 --> 00:27:37.158

00:27:37.158 --> 00:27:41.433
which effectively takes what was a,

00:27:41.433 --> 00:27:42.222
>> Yes, I believe that's right.

00:27:42.222 --> 00:27:46.490

00:27:46.490 --> 00:27:48.640
And you end up something,

00:27:48.640 --> 00:27:49.760
I can never remember this one.

00:27:49.760 --> 00:27:53.165
You end up with 168 bit key size on
it by running it three times, and

00:27:53.165 --> 00:27:56.893

00:27:56.893 --> 00:28:01.950
And we're starting to see with modern CPU

00:28:01.950 --> 00:28:04.955

00:31:16.010 --> 00:31:17.430

00:31:18.733 --> 00:31:22.840
So when I have data crossing the Internet,

00:31:22.840 --> 00:31:24.752

a lot of these encryption algorithms,

00:31:24.752 --> 00:31:27.390

00:31:27.390 --> 00:31:30.660

00:32:03.170 --> 00:32:04.780

72
00:03:45.978 --> 00:03:49.678
And then we tell it, you're the web server
so you just connect to this one drive, so

73
00:03:49.678 --> 00:03:53.278
my web server's green, it's gonna connect
to this green hard drive and that's it,

74
00:03:53.278 --> 00:03:55.690
we tell it to do that
when we configure it.

75
00:03:55.690 --> 00:03:57.960
But if a hacker gets in there,
they can say, all right, well, yeah,

76
00:03:57.960 --> 00:04:00.610
you can connect to the green drive, that's
great, but let's connect to the purple

77
00:04:00.610 --> 00:04:04.650
drive also, and these red drives and these
blue drives, let's connect to all of them.

78
00:04:04.650 --> 00:04:09.230
And now, from this one compromised
web server, they can access data for

79
00:04:09.230 --> 00:04:11.900
the database server and
data for the mail server

80
00:04:11.900 --> 00:04:14.640
without logging in cuz they're not
going to your software anymore.

81
00:04:14.640 --> 00:04:15.900
This is hardware access.

82
00:04:15.900 --> 00:04:21.010
They're physically accessing those drives,
and bypassing all of your security.

83
00:04:21.010 --> 00:04:22.520
So, we have a challenge.

84
00:04:22.520 --> 00:04:23.420
And how do we fix that?

85
00:04:23.420 --> 00:04:24.950
How do we prevent that?

86
00:04:24.950 --> 00:04:28.470
Well, I talked about three technologies
in another episode that addressed this,

87
00:04:28.470 --> 00:04:31.990
one of which was what's
called LUN masking.

88
00:04:31.990 --> 00:04:36.118
LUN masking is where we say, all right,
when I create this hard drive on the SAN,

89
00:04:36.118 --> 00:04:37.781
so I create my green hard drive.

90
00:04:37.781 --> 00:04:41.670
When we make that green drive, it has to
get a logical unit number, a LUN number.

91
00:04:41.670 --> 00:04:44.160
So, maybe this one's LUN number five.

92
00:04:44.160 --> 00:04:49.500
And I can create an access control list,
an ACL that says,

93
00:04:49.500 --> 00:04:56.040
only this host, only WEB01 is allowed
to access this LUN and that's it.

94
00:04:56.040 --> 00:04:59.080
I don't want anyone else to access it,
just this one.

95
00:05:00.530 --> 00:05:05.364
And then on this purple drive, maybe it's
LUN number seven, and so I tell it, hey,

96
00:05:05.364 --> 00:05:08.510
the only person who can
access this is web server 02.

97
00:05:08.510 --> 00:05:13.284
And so now if I go to web server 01, and
I fire up my disk management utility or

98
00:05:13.284 --> 00:05:17.020
whatever, LVM,
whatever is that I'm running.

99
00:05:17.020 --> 00:05:21.750
It can scan the SAN, and
it'll only see one LUN and

100
00:05:21.750 --> 00:05:24.840
that's it,
it'll just see the LUN attached to it.

101
00:05:24.840 --> 00:05:26.360
That's called LUN masking, and

102
00:05:26.360 --> 00:05:30.580
it works by mapping the LUN numbers to
the hosts that are allowed to connect.

103
00:05:30.580 --> 00:05:33.670
This database server here,
it has two hard drives.

104
00:05:33.670 --> 00:05:35.690
So there'd be two LUNs, and

105
00:05:35.690 --> 00:05:38.210
both of them would be allowed to
be seen by that database server.

106
00:05:38.210 --> 00:05:41.288
So that it would see two LUNs, but
it wouldn't see anybody else's stuff.

107
00:05:41.288 --> 00:05:44.500
Now, it's easy thing to apply.

108
00:05:44.500 --> 00:05:46.010
When you create a LUN
you just set that list,

109
00:05:46.010 --> 00:05:49.470
it's no big deal, but
it's also an easy thing to defeat.

110
00:05:49.470 --> 00:05:52.419
If a hacker breaks into
one of your systems,

111
00:05:52.419 --> 00:05:56.257
all they have to do is start
spoofing the HPA identifier.

112
00:05:56.257 --> 00:06:00.677
And as they do that, they can hope to
eventually hit the right identifier to be

113
00:06:00.677 --> 00:06:03.300
able to see other discs on the network.

114
00:06:03.300 --> 00:06:07.040
And your HPA identifiers
are normally 48-bit or 64-bit.

115
00:06:07.040 --> 00:06:10.357
And so when you've got a 64-bit number,

116
00:06:10.357 --> 00:06:14.220
how many possible combinations
of that are there?

117
00:06:14.220 --> 00:06:15.660
Well, there's billions.

118
00:06:15.660 --> 00:06:19.970
Actually, there's quadrillions of numbers,
but for a computer to sit there and

119
00:06:19.970 --> 00:06:23.010
rifle through them, it can be doing
this in the background running for

120
00:06:23.010 --> 00:06:25.690
days before it starts to hit
some of the other numbers.

121
00:06:25.690 --> 00:06:26.703
And they'll get it eventually.

122
00:06:26.703 --> 00:06:30.890
You've got better odds than the lottery,
I think on some of these things.

123
00:06:30.890 --> 00:06:33.190
So, they can hit it eventually,
and that's a problem.

124
00:06:33.190 --> 00:06:36.840
So LUN masking is one option,
but there's better options, and

125
00:06:36.840 --> 00:06:43.790
some of the better options I talked about
were VSANs and Zoning, there we go.

126
00:06:43.790 --> 00:06:45.253
[LAUGH] Had a little brain freeze there.

127
00:06:45.253 --> 00:06:46.230
VSANs and Zoning.

128
00:06:46.230 --> 00:06:48.990
I always have a hard time remembering
Zoning cuz I don't really use Zoning

129
00:06:48.990 --> 00:06:53.490
anymore, VSAN is kind of replaced it, and
so VSANs are what we'll typically go with.

130
00:06:53.490 --> 00:06:55.060
And they work on the same principle.

131
00:06:55.060 --> 00:06:58.717
What they do is they say, look when we
do the security through LUN masking,

132
00:06:58.717 --> 00:07:00.823
it can be spoofed, and that's a problem.

133
00:07:00.823 --> 00:07:03.112
I don't want somebody spoofing
the data and defeating my security,

134
00:07:03.112 --> 00:07:05.020
I need something that's a little tighter.

135
00:07:05.020 --> 00:07:08.725
And so what a VSAN does is it says is,
instead of applying security on the SAN,

136
00:07:08.725 --> 00:07:10.723
let's apply the security on the switch.

137
00:07:10.723 --> 00:07:15.038
And on the switch,
what you can do is you can say,

138
00:07:15.038 --> 00:07:22.003
this physical port right here, this port
is allowed to see this LUN down here.

139
00:07:22.003 --> 00:07:25.105
And the way it does it,
is it sees these LUNs come in, and

140
00:07:25.105 --> 00:07:28.385
it sees these hosts come in,
and it uses worldwide names.

141
00:07:28.385 --> 00:07:31.110
Worldwide names that are associated
with the physical ports, and

142
00:07:31.110 --> 00:07:35.130
it says,
this port is allowed to access this LUN.

143
00:07:35.130 --> 00:07:37.460
Now, it doesn't care who's
plugged into that port.

144
00:07:37.460 --> 00:07:40.490
Whoever does plug in to the portal
will only be able to see that one LUN.

145
00:07:40.490 --> 00:07:44.035
So if a hacker breaks in, and
they break into this web server, and

146
00:07:44.035 --> 00:07:48.225
they start spoofing the ID, it doesn't
matter cuz that ID is not being used,

147
00:07:48.225 --> 00:07:50.628
it's the identifier of the physical port.

148
00:07:50.628 --> 00:07:54.867
Now, the only way they'd be able to see
those LUNs would be if they were to

149
00:07:54.867 --> 00:07:59.732
come in, and say, they unplugged to the
database server, I'll just yank that And

150
00:07:59.732 --> 00:08:03.235
then took the web server and
plugged it in over here, okay?

151
00:08:03.235 --> 00:08:06.010
Now, are you gonna notice
that that happened?

152
00:08:06.010 --> 00:08:09.670
I sure hope so, right, because first off,
your database server went offline.

153
00:08:09.670 --> 00:08:15.070
And secondly, they had to physically be in
your building to move that cable, right?

154
00:08:15.070 --> 00:08:19.820
So now we've stopped somebody from being
able to get into our data at rest,

155
00:08:19.820 --> 00:08:22.340
the data that's on the SAN remotely.

156
00:08:22.340 --> 00:08:26.070
They would have to physically be in
the building and able to move that.

157
00:08:26.070 --> 00:08:27.700
And you now how you defeat that?

158
00:08:27.700 --> 00:08:28.680
A locked door.

159
00:08:28.680 --> 00:08:29.960
It's not hard, right?

160
00:08:29.960 --> 00:08:32.360
You have a locked door
into your server room,

161
00:08:32.360 --> 00:08:35.500
you don't allow unauthorized personnel
in there, and you've defeated this.

162
00:08:36.800 --> 00:08:39.260
Except, if it's one of the administrators,
or even you.

163
00:08:39.260 --> 00:08:41.270
Maybe you're that disgruntled employee,
and you're like, screw it,

164
00:08:41.270 --> 00:08:42.090
I'm getting at this data.

165
00:08:42.090 --> 00:08:44.460
I wanna find out how much money
the CEO makes, and you go and

166
00:08:44.460 --> 00:08:46.360
you move that cable and
you start looking at it, right.

167
00:08:46.360 --> 00:08:47.950
That attack is still very real.

168
00:08:47.950 --> 00:08:51.690
It's difficult to prevent from
every possibility, right.

169
00:08:51.690 --> 00:08:56.140
So there's a lot of different things
that could creep up, but doing VSANs or

170
00:08:56.140 --> 00:08:58.460
doing zoning will take care of that.

171
00:08:58.460 --> 00:09:01.980
Now with the zoning,
I divide up my ports and my LUNs and

172
00:09:01.980 --> 00:09:03.740
I just kinda slice it up and that's that.

173
00:09:03.740 --> 00:09:07.940
Zoning is very much like setting up
a VLAN, VSANs are basically the same way,

174
00:09:07.940 --> 00:09:11.820
except VSANs can span multiple switches.

175
00:09:11.820 --> 00:09:15.249
And so when you implement a VSAN, you
could actually have more than one physical

176
00:09:15.249 --> 00:09:17.466
SAN behind it and
you can have more than one switch.

177
00:09:17.466 --> 00:09:22.860
And so I could say, like maybe Node 1 and
Node 2 here, these guys are in a cluster.

178
00:09:22.860 --> 00:09:24.061
They're clustered together.

179
00:09:24.061 --> 00:09:28.546
And so I want them both to see these two
hard drives and so I can create a VSAN.

180
00:09:28.546 --> 00:09:31.725
And when they connect it up, they would
think they were looking at one SAN, but

181
00:09:31.725 --> 00:09:34.560
they're actually seeing LUNs from
two different physical SAN's.

182
00:09:34.560 --> 00:09:37.350
You can have a lot of really cool
stuff masked behind a VSAN, so

183
00:09:37.350 --> 00:09:39.380
it's a more powerful form of zoning.

184
00:09:39.380 --> 00:09:43.420
Zoning is just done on the switch and
we start to break that up, creating

185
00:09:43.420 --> 00:09:47.090
these zones of ports, and we would say
node 1 and node 2 are in the same zone.

186
00:09:47.090 --> 00:09:50.520
And these two LUNs are in that zone,
and as a result, those nodes and

187
00:09:50.520 --> 00:09:52.300
those LUNs are all visible to each other.

188
00:09:52.300 --> 00:09:54.190
But with a VSAN,
we can really start to get bigger.

189
00:09:54.190 --> 00:09:57.760
It's some cool stuff you can do with that,
but the technologies work the same.

190
00:09:57.760 --> 00:09:59.480
And so we talked about all
of these in another episode.

191
00:09:59.480 --> 00:10:04.450
We talked about LUN masking, VSANs,
and zoning, and I kinda showed how to

192
00:10:04.450 --> 00:10:09.960
configure that on a VLAN switch and
on a SAN, so we got a chance to see those.

193
00:10:09.960 --> 00:10:12.650
But just to recap,
those were some principles right there.

194
00:10:12.650 --> 00:10:16.210
They've all got their benefits,
they've all got their weaknesses, right?

195
00:10:16.210 --> 00:10:18.500
There's nothing that's a perfect solution,
so

196
00:10:18.500 --> 00:10:21.100
oftentimes we'll use
combinations of these.

197
00:10:21.100 --> 00:10:25.960
You might use LUN masking in combination
with VSANs to achieve your goal and

198
00:10:25.960 --> 00:10:27.220
you certainly can do that.

199
00:10:27.220 --> 00:10:27.950
>> And at that,

200
00:10:27.950 --> 00:10:31.620
they talk about the ten immutable
laws of security at Microsoft, right?

201
00:10:31.620 --> 00:10:35.640
If I can touch your computer,
well it's really no longer your computer.

00:10:35.640 --> 00:10:37.660
I'm sure that'd be that
same thing with a SAN.

00:10:37.660 --> 00:10:40.480
If you got a malicious insider,
we do all we want.

204
00:10:40.480 --> 00:10:42.706
We can do zoning, we can do LUN masking.

00:10:42.706 --> 00:10:44.710
But if somebody's got physical
access to that device,

206
00:10:44.710 --> 00:10:46.710
well you've got bigger
problems to worry about.

207
00:10:46.710 --> 00:10:48.030
>> Absolutely, yup.

00:10:48.030 --> 00:10:51.040
And even on top of that, we probably

00:10:51.040 --> 00:10:53.876
So you set up your LUN masking, you set up

210
00:10:53.876 --> 00:10:56.990
and you get it all put in place,
you probably don't wanna stop there.

211
00:10:56.990 --> 00:10:58.730
Because if somebody can
gain physical access,

00:10:58.730 --> 00:11:00.950
they can just rip the hard drives out and

00:11:00.950 --> 00:11:04.130
And at that point,

214
00:11:04.130 --> 00:11:06.654
Do the VSANs even matter, does the ID?

00:11:06.654 --> 00:11:07.910
None of that matters anymore.

00:11:07.910 --> 00:11:10.170
They rip the hard drives out,
they got your data.

00:11:10.170 --> 00:11:14.440
And so we're normally gonna combine

00:11:14.440 --> 00:11:17.310
We're gonna encrypt the data at rest.

00:11:17.310 --> 00:11:21.156
Now, if your storage area network is in
a secure facility, locked in a server room

00:11:21.156 --> 00:11:24.859
that you have full control over, you
may choose not to do encryption, right.

221
00:11:24.859 --> 00:11:27.900
And there's plenty of good reasons,
I know some of you out there are like,

222
00:11:27.900 --> 00:11:29.941
that's crazy talk,
why wouldn't I encrypt it?

223
00:11:29.941 --> 00:11:33.760
Well, encryption hurts performance,

224
00:11:33.760 --> 00:11:37.280
If I write unencrypted data to a hard
drive, it happens very quickly,

225
00:11:37.280 --> 00:11:40.190
if I need to encrypt it first,
I gonna slow down for a second.

226
00:11:40.190 --> 00:11:43.420
Even if I have hardware accelerators,
there's still a little bit of a slow down.

227
00:11:43.420 --> 00:11:46.120
So we take a performance
hit when we encrypt data.

228
00:11:46.120 --> 00:11:51.311
If your SAN is secured and no unauthorized
personnel has physical access to it,

229
00:11:51.311 --> 00:11:55.040
then you're not really needed
to do encryption on that.

230
00:11:55.040 --> 00:11:56.030
Your data's safe, right.

231
00:11:56.030 --> 00:11:59.590
You've got it, but a lot of times, we're

00:11:59.590 --> 00:12:01.400

00:12:01.400 --> 00:12:04.700
Like, maybe you work for

00:12:13.310 --> 00:12:15.010

00:12:24.080 --> 00:12:25.260
So now I can't trust it.

00:12:25.260 --> 00:12:28.610
And so it's worth it to take

00:12:28.610 --> 00:12:31.900
When we encrypt that data now it's safe,

00:12:31.900 --> 00:12:34.490

00:12:34.490 --> 00:12:37.310
Where it's even more

00:12:37.310 --> 00:12:39.820

00:12:39.820 --> 00:12:41.550

00:13:03.650 --> 00:13:05.045

If I deploy a virtual

00:13:21.430 --> 00:13:24.330

00:13:24.330 --> 00:13:27.647
Right, so the virtual hard drive

Right, I go crazy, lose my mind,

00:13:58.030 --> 00:14:01.060

What's to stop that customer from
