00:25:38.777 --> 00:25:41.990
you can certainly do that by
pulling up the properties, and

518
00:25:41.990 --> 00:25:45.863
going into the security, and
granting your physical servers access.

519
00:25:45.863 --> 00:25:52.320
So I can come in here and add server
01 and server 02, adding a system.

520
00:25:52.320 --> 00:25:54.820
Now by default,
it's not going to like that,

521
00:25:54.820 --> 00:25:56.630
because by default it's looking for users,

522
00:25:56.630 --> 00:26:01.160
groups, or built-in security principles,
so I need to add computers to that list.

523
00:26:01.160 --> 00:26:04.960
And so now,
it's going to accept computer names also.

524
00:26:04.960 --> 00:26:10.070
And so I can grant SERVER01 and
SERVER02 full control of that file.

525
00:26:10.070 --> 00:26:11.640
They need to boot that virtual machine.

526
00:26:11.640 --> 00:26:13.310
They need access to that VHD.

527
00:26:13.310 --> 00:26:14.740
But I can take users out.

528
00:26:14.740 --> 00:26:16.490
Like, hey,
I don't want users to have access.

529
00:26:16.490 --> 00:26:19.780
I can deny them, or whatever, and
take them out and start to restrict it.

530
00:26:19.780 --> 00:26:22.220
So ACLs are one way to do that.

531
00:26:22.220 --> 00:26:23.800
And then there's other ways.

532
00:26:23.800 --> 00:26:25.800
If you're setting up shared storage.

533
00:26:25.800 --> 00:26:29.801
So I've got an iSCSI SAN set up,
let's see, here.

534
00:26:29.801 --> 00:26:31.101
I think it's on this server.

535
00:26:31.101 --> 00:26:34.693
>> You know while you're logging in, one
of the things I was thinking Don is that

536
00:26:34.693 --> 00:26:37.250
the authorization,
that's after the fact, right?

537
00:26:37.250 --> 00:26:41.500
We know that it's an authorized user,
but we do need some kind of mechanism or

538
00:26:41.500 --> 00:26:44.280
way to even figure out,
are they authorized?

539
00:26:44.280 --> 00:26:47.770
>> Yeah, yeah, and for that we can use all
sorts of authentication, usernames and

540
00:26:47.770 --> 00:26:49.000
passwords and so on.

541
00:26:49.000 --> 00:26:52.420
That access control list I showed you,
we have to validate this user somehow.

542
00:26:52.420 --> 00:26:55.930
And so Windows uses like MTML,
the old MT LAN manager,

543
00:26:55.930 --> 00:26:58.430
or they use Kerberos to
do the authentication.

544
00:26:58.430 --> 00:27:00.270
There's different systems like that.

545
00:27:00.270 --> 00:27:05.060
Here on this iSCSI SAN, and
even on a traditional SAN, you can set

546
00:27:05.060 --> 00:27:09.400
things like validating their identifier,
their ID, like we said with LUN masking.

547
00:27:09.400 --> 00:27:12.410
You can require a CHAP username and
password.

548
00:27:12.410 --> 00:27:17.315
So here's those virtual hard drives
that are mounted on my iSCSI server,

549
00:27:17.315 --> 00:27:19.291
and when you work with those,

550
00:27:19.291 --> 00:27:23.588
you don't have a whole lot of
options here on the device itself.

551
00:27:23.588 --> 00:27:28.220
But in iSCSI, you create what
are called iSCSI targets, and

552
00:27:28.220 --> 00:27:32.570
my targets are down here, and that's
what your clients actually connect to.

553
00:27:32.570 --> 00:27:37.830
And when you define the target,
you can specify what LUNs,

554
00:27:37.830 --> 00:27:40.940
what hard drives, are available on it and
who is allowed to connect.

555
00:27:40.940 --> 00:27:45.300
And so you'll notice here,
I can go under security, and

556
00:27:45.300 --> 00:27:48.020
I can turn on CHAP, challenge handshake.

557
00:27:48.020 --> 00:27:51.750
If somebody wants to connect and access
this storage, they are going to have to

558
00:27:51.750 --> 00:27:54.816
provide a user name and password just
to even connect and see the storage.

559
00:27:54.816 --> 00:27:57.430
Because iSCSI is available on
their regular TCICP network,

560
00:27:57.430 --> 00:28:00.390
I might not want just any old person
to try and connect to these drives.

561
00:28:00.390 --> 00:28:01.830
I can authenticate them.

562
00:28:01.830 --> 00:28:04.860
But on top of that,
I can go to Initiators, and

563
00:28:04.860 --> 00:28:09.660
here I can specify the iSCSI
identifiers or the IP addresses of

564
00:28:09.660 --> 00:28:13.980
the systems that are allowed to connect,
and now only those people will connect.

565
00:28:13.980 --> 00:28:16.170
But somebody could spoof an IP,
couldn't they?

566
00:28:16.170 --> 00:28:21.030
So if I combine these, if I do the IP
filter and I do a CHAP user name and

567
00:28:21.030 --> 00:28:23.766
password, now I get
the best of both worlds.

568
00:28:23.766 --> 00:28:25.760
Now they've got to have an IP,
or identifier,

569
00:28:25.760 --> 00:28:27.950
that's the right name, and
they have to have a user name and

570
00:28:27.950 --> 00:28:29.968
password, and
now they're allowed to access it.

571
00:28:29.968 --> 00:28:32.740
It's basically multi-factor
authentication at that point, and

572
00:28:32.740 --> 00:28:35.070
they're able to get in and
access those disks.

573
00:28:35.070 --> 00:28:39.140
On a traditional SAN, these might be your
HBA identifiers, but you also might have

574
00:28:39.140 --> 00:28:42.120
CHAP to be able to do that challenge
handshake and authenticate the systems.

575
00:28:42.120 --> 00:28:44.040
>> I noticed that you're in Hyper-V here,

576
00:28:44.040 --> 00:28:46.280
and I'm going to throw
you a curve ball here.

577
00:28:46.280 --> 00:28:47.330
You talk about CHAP.

578
00:28:47.330 --> 00:28:48.930
Is it limited to just CHAP?

579
00:28:48.930 --> 00:28:52.100
Because in the cloud today,
like you've shown us with Amazon,

580
00:28:52.100 --> 00:28:56.520
you can spin up a Linux server,
you can spin up a Windows-based server.

581
00:28:56.520 --> 00:28:58.440
And I've really just been in
the Windows environment, and

582
00:28:58.440 --> 00:29:00.948
I know you're not really stuck or
married to any operating system.

583
00:29:00.948 --> 00:29:03.248
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

584
00:29:03.248 --> 00:29:06.750
would MS Chat versus the non-Windows
CHAP come into play here?

585
00:29:06.750 --> 00:29:08.590
Are they pretty supportive across?

586
00:29:08.590 --> 00:29:11.520
>> This is the official standard CHAP,
not the MS CHAP.

587
00:29:11.520 --> 00:29:14.710
Even Microsoft's doing the official one,
because this is not Hyper-V doing it.

588
00:29:14.710 --> 00:29:15.900
This is the iSCSI target.

589
00:29:15.900 --> 00:29:16.699
>> Gotcha.
>> Because it's got to

590
00:29:16.699 --> 00:29:18.820
be iSCSI compatible, and
that's where that comes from.

591
00:29:18.820 --> 00:29:21.940
So if this were a Linux, or
Windows, or even Mac OS for

592
00:29:21.940 --> 00:29:24.410
that matter,
they all handle iSCSI the same way.

593
00:29:24.410 --> 00:29:26.680
And CHAP's not the strongest
thing in the world.

594
00:29:26.680 --> 00:29:30.660
There are certain attacks that
seem to be waged against CHAP, but

595
00:29:30.660 --> 00:29:34.030
you should have a dedicated
storage network anyway.

596
00:29:34.030 --> 00:29:36.650
So somebody would have to have physical
access to your network to be able to

597
00:29:36.650 --> 00:29:38.840
intercept this stuff and
try and break it, right?

598
00:29:38.840 --> 00:29:41.490
And if they've already got physical
access to your network, believe me,

599
00:29:41.490 --> 00:29:42.370
they can get past the CHAP.

600
00:29:42.370 --> 00:29:44.320
All they've got to do is just
rip your hard drives out and go.

601
00:29:44.320 --> 00:29:48.090
So physical security is always
something we need to be concerned with.

602
00:29:48.090 --> 00:29:52.140
CHAP here is just the standard Challenge
Handshake Authentication Protocol.

603
00:29:52.140 --> 00:29:56.340
>> Now if we want to do something like
maybe confirm that this is set up,

604
00:29:56.340 --> 00:30:00.730
we want to find out who is gaining access,
what they're gaining access to,

605
00:30:00.730 --> 00:30:03.240
we basically want to track
these system wide activities.

606
00:30:03.240 --> 00:30:05.590
We want to know what's
happening in our systems.

607
00:30:05.590 --> 00:30:07.110
Do we have a way we can do that as well?

608
00:30:07.110 --> 00:30:07.800
>> Yeah, absolutely.

609
00:30:07.800 --> 00:30:09.410
Hold on, I'm on the wrong server.

610
00:30:09.410 --> 00:30:10.391
That's why I'm not seeing it.

611
00:30:10.391 --> 00:30:13.666
[LAUGH] So I showed you earlier here
on this server, there's the virtual

612
00:30:13.666 --> 00:30:17.010
hard drive for one of my VMs, or
the configuration files are right here.

613
00:30:17.010 --> 00:30:19.420
So here's the configuration file for
that VM.

614
00:30:19.420 --> 00:30:22.440
If I want to know when somebody
changes it, and get notifications and

615
00:30:22.440 --> 00:30:25.010
stuff, we can turn on file auditing.

616
00:30:25.010 --> 00:30:28.990
We talked about auditing and
CISLogs during the monitoring episode.

617
00:30:28.990 --> 00:30:31.700
We talked about that already from
the standpoint of watching when a server

618
00:30:31.700 --> 00:30:35.140
failure happens, but
you might want to audit things just for

619
00:30:35.140 --> 00:30:36.480
a security prospective.

620
00:30:36.480 --> 00:30:39.600
It's not that the server went down,
but that somebody modified it, and

621
00:30:39.600 --> 00:30:40.730
I want to know about it.

622
00:30:40.730 --> 00:30:44.580
And so at the file level,
we can turn on auditing.

623
00:30:44.580 --> 00:30:46.840
If you take a file and go into security,

624
00:30:46.840 --> 00:30:50.920
normally we're talking about permissions
here, but if I go into advanced,

625
00:30:50.920 --> 00:30:54.280
under the advanced side you'll see where
we can start to configure auditing.

626
00:30:54.280 --> 00:30:58.210
And here I can specify hey, I want to
audit this, and I'm going to add in

627
00:30:58.210 --> 00:31:03.880
everyone because I want to know
when anybody touches this file.

628
00:31:03.880 --> 00:31:04.830
I'm not messing around.

629
00:31:04.830 --> 00:31:06.140
I want to know.

630
00:31:06.140 --> 00:31:10.680
I'm going to add in everyone, and
I'm going to add for modifies and writes.

631
00:31:10.680 --> 00:31:12.810
I might not care about reads.

632
00:31:12.810 --> 00:31:14.000
I might just want to
know about the writes.

633
00:31:14.000 --> 00:31:16.790
I want to know when somebody
changes this document, or whatever.

634
00:31:16.790 --> 00:31:19.970
And when you do modify, they have
to do the read to do the modify so

635
00:31:19.970 --> 00:31:21.460
it gets factored in.

636
00:31:21.460 --> 00:31:23.130
And I might just want
to monitor successes.

637
00:31:23.130 --> 00:31:23.910
Be careful with this.

638
00:31:23.910 --> 00:31:26.020
This can be a trick question
on the exam sometimes.

639
00:31:26.020 --> 00:31:28.110
A lot of people just audit for failures.

640
00:31:28.110 --> 00:31:28.750
Right?

641
00:31:28.750 --> 00:31:31.850
And I'll tell you, auditing for failures,
for the most part, is a waste of time.

642
00:31:31.850 --> 00:31:33.580
Auditing for successes is what you want.

643
00:31:33.580 --> 00:31:34.700
And I know it's counter-intuitive.

644
00:31:34.700 --> 00:31:37.610
A lot of people say, well,
if somebody tries to get at that data that

645
00:31:37.610 --> 00:31:40.050
they're not supposed to get there,
I want to know about that.

646
00:31:40.050 --> 00:31:43.720
But when a failure happens,
that means your system is working right.

647
00:31:43.720 --> 00:31:46.550
Somebody tried to modify that file,
and they weren't allowed to, and

648
00:31:46.550 --> 00:31:47.660
they were stopped.

649
00:31:47.660 --> 00:31:49.380
That's what a failure means,
and that's good.

650
00:31:49.380 --> 00:31:50.850
They were stopped.

651
00:31:50.850 --> 00:31:54.480
Where you need to be worried is if
somebody tries to modify data they are not

652
00:31:54.480 --> 00:31:56.750
supposed to, and they succeed.

653
00:31:56.750 --> 00:31:57.940
That's a problem.

654
00:31:57.940 --> 00:31:59.370
That's what we need to know about.

655
00:31:59.370 --> 00:32:00.789
So you always want to monitor successes.

656
00:32:02.090 --> 00:32:04.310
Or you might choose to do both,
successes and failures.

657
00:32:04.310 --> 00:32:05.750
But you never just want
to monitor failure.

658
00:32:05.750 --> 00:32:08.600
The only thing you'll learn there is if
somebody's trying to brute force you.

659
00:32:08.600 --> 00:32:11.390
So if you have a massive brute force
attack, but you don't need to monitor

660
00:32:11.390 --> 00:32:13.370
failures for that, you can just
see the extra network activity.

661
00:32:13.370 --> 00:32:15.560
So really monitoring failure
is kind of a waste of time.

662
00:32:15.560 --> 00:32:16.650
So all or successes.

663
00:32:16.650 --> 00:32:18.010
I normally just do successes.

664
00:32:18.010 --> 00:32:21.400
I just want to see when somebody
tries to modify and it works.

665
00:32:21.400 --> 00:32:24.660
And now, when I go to my system logs,
I'm going to see

666
00:32:24.660 --> 00:32:27.900
anytime somebody successfully modifies,
or reads, or writes.

667
00:32:27.900 --> 00:32:30.600
Now, reads on a VHD can
be pretty excessive, so

668
00:32:30.600 --> 00:32:33.790
I'm going to have to start using filters
and pay attention to my log sizes.

669
00:32:33.790 --> 00:32:35.840
But the modifies are what's
really important.

670
00:32:35.840 --> 00:32:39.590
And if I'm using a monitoring system like
SolarWinds Network Performance Monitor, or

671
00:32:39.590 --> 00:32:43.040
something like that,
then I can have it set to alert me.

672
00:32:43.040 --> 00:32:45.120
Any time a modify happens
send me an alert.

673
00:32:45.120 --> 00:32:48.480
If it's a read don't bother, but
if it's a modify, send me an alert,

674
00:32:48.480 --> 00:32:51.740
send me an email, let me know, and
I can go and find out what happened.

675
00:32:51.740 --> 00:32:52.970
I want to know who did it.
>> Definitely and

676
00:32:52.970 --> 00:32:55.250
you said successes and failures.

677
00:32:55.250 --> 00:32:57.860
I can think of,for instance,
the brute force right?

678
00:32:57.860 --> 00:32:59.635
Fail, fail, fail, success.

679
00:32:59.635 --> 00:33:03.470
I definitely want to monitor that time,
get some kind of trending analysis,

680
00:33:03.470 --> 00:33:04.850
or when it's happening.

681
00:33:04.850 --> 00:33:07.200
It might help you out find out
what's going on in your systems.

682
00:33:07.200 --> 00:33:09.000
All right Don, great information.

683
00:33:09.000 --> 00:33:11.410
A lot on storage security.

684
00:33:11.410 --> 00:33:12.940
We touched a little bit,

685
00:33:12.940 --> 00:33:16.220
touched base on some of the stuff that we
had talked about in the previous episodes,

686
00:33:16.220 --> 00:33:19.770
so if any of that's confusing to you,
go back and watch those episodes.

687
00:33:19.770 --> 00:33:22.770
But as for this, Don,
you have anything else for us on this one?

688
00:33:22.770 --> 00:33:24.210
>> That's about it on storage security.

689
00:33:24.210 --> 00:33:26.610
Do remember, we have covered pieces
of this in other episodes, so

690
00:33:26.610 --> 00:33:27.960
we kind of tried to sum it up here.

691
00:33:27.960 --> 00:33:29.170
Obviously, it's a big topic.

692
00:33:29.170 --> 00:33:31.040
There's a lot of stuff you need to know.

693
00:33:31.040 --> 00:33:35.630
Just remember, don't overlook that data
at rest, and just because a vendor says

694
00:33:35.630 --> 00:33:37.970
they'll encrypt the data for you,
doesn't mean you should trust it, right?

695
00:33:37.970 --> 00:33:40.500
That's the two lessons from this
episodes that are really important.

696
00:33:40.500 --> 00:33:42.690
>> All right, great information here, and

697
00:33:42.690 --> 00:33:45.330
it looks like we've come to
the end of another great episode.

698
00:33:45.330 --> 00:33:47.400
So we're going to go ahead and
wrap it up here at ITProTV.

699
00:33:47.400 --> 00:33:48.980
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

700
00:33:48.980 --> 00:33:50.090
>> And I'm Don Pizet.

701
00:33:50.090 --> 00:33:52.200
>> And we'll see you next time.

702
00:33:52.200 --> 00:34:00.310
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don focus on the systems we use to access cloud based data. They introduce the viewers to the concept of system hardening like disabling administrative accounts, changing default usernames and passwords, installing antivirus, patches and implementing host-based firewalls.
episodes.title: System Hardening
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.084 --> 00:00:14.791
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.791 --> 00:00:16.720
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and

4
00:00:16.720 --> 00:00:19.710
in today's episode,
we're gonna be moving along in Cloud+.

5
00:00:19.710 --> 00:00:23.290
And so far, we've been talking
a lot about securing your data.

6
00:00:23.290 --> 00:00:26.930
When it's on the move, and
when it is stationary, right?

7
00:00:26.930 --> 00:00:28.760
When it's been parked on our harddrives.

8
00:00:28.760 --> 00:00:32.440
But now we've got to talk a little bit
more about the devices themselves, and

9
00:00:32.440 --> 00:00:33.770
how we keep them secure.

10
00:00:33.770 --> 00:00:36.290
So in this episode, we're gonna be
taking a look at system hardening.

11
00:00:36.290 --> 00:00:40.220
And we've got out resident professional,
none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

12
00:00:40.220 --> 00:00:41.070
How you doing, Don?

13
00:00:41.070 --> 00:00:42.112
>> I am doing great, Wes.

14
00:00:42.112 --> 00:00:43.320
Thank you for having me back on the show.

15
00:00:43.320 --> 00:00:46.410
And yeah, in this episode we're gonna
really get to that topic that a lot of you

16
00:00:46.410 --> 00:00:47.670
have been wanting to see.

17
00:00:47.670 --> 00:00:53.660
When we deploy a hypervisor as a host and
virtual machines as our guests,

18
00:00:53.660 --> 00:00:57.030
they're rarely deployed in a very
secure fashion by default.

19
00:00:57.030 --> 00:01:00.120
We've got to take steps to make
sure that we follow proper security

20
00:01:00.120 --> 00:01:00.820
practices on them.

21
00:01:00.820 --> 00:01:02.710
And some vendors are better than others,
but

22
00:01:02.710 --> 00:01:05.440
they all have their faults and weaknesses.

23
00:01:05.440 --> 00:01:08.260
And we've got to make sure we take the
steps to make sure those systems run as

24
00:01:08.260 --> 00:01:09.410
securely as possible.

25
00:01:09.410 --> 00:01:12.220
And they call that
process system hardening.

26
00:01:12.220 --> 00:01:13.850
You do a default install.

27
00:01:13.850 --> 00:01:17.640
And then you perform certain actions to
increase the security of those devices.

28
00:01:17.640 --> 00:01:20.940
And once that's done, you've got a nice
secure system that's up and running.

29
00:01:20.940 --> 00:01:22.080
You're still at risk, right?

30
00:01:22.080 --> 00:01:24.780
There's always that attacker on
the outside trying to come in, but

31
00:01:24.780 --> 00:01:27.630
you've taken the steps to
eliminate all the common threats.

32
00:01:27.630 --> 00:01:30.440
And so, now it would take a very
sophisticated attacker to break

33
00:01:30.440 --> 00:01:31.930
into your system.

34
00:01:31.930 --> 00:01:34.460
All right, well, let's just start with
some kind of general things that apply to

35
00:01:34.460 --> 00:01:35.480
every system.

36
00:01:35.480 --> 00:01:38.620
Understand that when I talk about
system hardening I'm talking about our

37
00:01:38.620 --> 00:01:40.690
virtual machine hosts.

38
00:01:40.690 --> 00:01:42.270
And our guests.

39
00:01:42.270 --> 00:01:45.980
So on the host side,
we might be talking about VMware ESX or

40
00:01:45.980 --> 00:01:48.360
Microsoft's Hyper-V
running on top of Windows.

41

you need to be doing this on
your systems to keep them safe.

728
00:32:52.853 --> 00:32:53.990
All great information.

729
00:32:53.990 --> 00:32:55.569
Don, got anything else for us on this one?

730
00:32:55.569 --> 00:32:59.290
>> You know James in the chat room
mentioned he was mentioning something else

but it kind of reminded me how
he changes his SSH port number.

732
00:33:02.361 --> 00:33:04.404
Everybody knows SSH uses port 22.

733
00:33:04.404 --> 00:33:07.560
You could actually go and change your
port number and be something different.

734
00:33:07.560 --> 00:33:09.059
Now that's not the truest.

735
00:33:09.059 --> 00:33:11.533
It’s more like security obfuscation,
right.

736
00:33:11.533 --> 00:33:12.798
It's security through obscurity.

737
00:33:12.798 --> 00:33:15.551
You're kind of hiding SSH by moving
it to a different port number, but

738
00:33:15.551 --> 00:33:17.150
it does help to increase that security.

739
00:33:17.150 --> 00:33:18.301
So those are all different things.

740
00:33:18.301 --> 00:33:20.576
Just remember, there's a ton of
different options out there.

741
00:33:20.576 --> 00:33:23.350
Just come up with something consistent and
make sure you follow it all the time.

742
00:33:23.350 --> 00:33:24.232
>> Very good.

743
00:33:24.232 --> 00:33:26.733
Well it looks like we've
come to another or

744
00:33:26.733 --> 00:33:30.559
the end I should say of another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

745
00:33:30.559 --> 00:33:32.358
So we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for this one.

746
00:33:32.358 --> 00:33:33.798
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

747
00:33:33.798 --> 00:33:34.738
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

748
00:33:34.738 --> 00:33:35.876
>> And we'll see you next time.

749

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take a look at the policies and procedure concepts to manage information technology based businesses. They discuss common concepts such as asset management, asset accountability and IP address management. They will dive into the realm of capacity management and help to differentiate asset management from capacity management.
episodes.title: Policies and Procedures
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.098 --> 00:00:10.098
[MUSIC]

2

Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITPtoTV.

00:00:14.630 --> 00:00:16.260
I'm your host, Wes Bryant, and

in today's episode we're going to be

00:00:20.430 --> 00:00:22.970
we're going to be taking a look at,
well a little bit of the paperwork and

stuff you need to know from the business

00:00:25.880 --> 00:00:29.200

8
00:00:29.200 --> 00:00:30.310

9
00:00:30.310 --> 00:00:33.410
>> I'm doing great Wes,
ready to jump back into Cloud world and

00:00:33.410 --> 00:00:37.250

00:00:37.250 --> 00:00:41.510

There is a lot of infrastructure

And so what Comptea recommends is that you

00:01:12.760 --> 00:01:14.960
And that's what we're gonna be taking

00:01:16.880 --> 00:01:19.280
If you're not familiar with ITIL,

00:01:19.280 --> 00:01:21.380

Something we can apply to make sure that

efficiently, and most importantly,

It's done the same way every time.

Nice and consistent.

30

That we ensure that we
are doing things the right way.

31

That's really what this bureaucracy
kind of piece is all about.

32
00:01:38.120 --> 00:01:42.000
>> Now, Don when we look at things
like enterprise level environments,

33
00:01:42.000 --> 00:01:42.980
we can have.

34
00:01:42.980 --> 00:01:45.790

thousands of computers.

35
00:01:45.790 --> 00:01:48.350
We can have different software,
we can have servers.

36
00:01:48.350 --> 00:01:50.220
We looked at storage networks, right.

37
00:01:50.220 --> 00:01:52.470
So there's a lot of components that well,

38
00:01:52.470 --> 00:01:56.120
are under the hood of a major
enterprise environment.

39
00:01:56.120 --> 00:01:59.772
Don, how is it that we track
this type of complexity.

40
00:01:59.772 --> 00:02:03.157
>> All right, so in the olden days

41
00:02:03.157 --> 00:02:08.596
You had Excel spreadsheets or just paper

42

And in the olden days even today
when you have a private cloud,

43
00:02:11.182 --> 00:02:14.517
when you manage your own infrastructure,
there's kind of this nice piece that

44
00:02:14.517 --> 00:02:18.300
forces us to keep track of things and
that's the accounting department.

45
00:02:18.300 --> 00:02:22.880
If I want to add a new server, I can't
just call HP and say hey send me a server.

46
00:02:22.880 --> 00:02:24.650
Because what's HP gonna say?

47
00:02:24.650 --> 00:02:25.320
Show me the money.

48
00:02:25.320 --> 00:02:28.030
We need some money or we're not gonna
give you the server, so we've gotta go to

49
00:02:28.030 --> 00:02:30.990
the accounting department,
we've gotta get them to cut a PO,

50
00:02:30.990 --> 00:02:35.810
send that to HP, they send us the server,
HP sends a bill, accounting pays the bill.

51
00:02:35.810 --> 00:02:38.650
We kind of have a good handle
on how many servers we have and

52
00:02:38.650 --> 00:02:41.720
how much other hardware and
how much our software licensing is,

53
00:02:41.720 --> 00:02:43.920
because the accounting department
is staying on top of it.

54
00:02:43.920 --> 00:02:44.710
All right?

55
00:02:44.710 --> 00:02:46.780
But when you deploy a public cloud.

56
00:02:46.780 --> 00:02:49.570
If I go into Amazon AWS or
Microsoft Azure and

57
00:02:49.570 --> 00:02:54.180
I start whipping up VMs, all that
stuff doesn't happen anymore, right?

58
00:02:54.180 --> 00:02:55.720
It's all just done.

59
00:02:55.720 --> 00:02:59.876
And in a matter of a couple of clicks,
I can have new servers deployed and

60
00:02:59.876 --> 00:03:00.856
my bill goes up.

61
00:03:00.856 --> 00:03:04.477
But I don't notice right away because it's
all just being billed to a credit card.

62
00:03:04.477 --> 00:03:06.591
We have a credit card on file.

63
00:03:06.591 --> 00:03:08.942
And as I spit out more
servers the credit card bill,

64
00:03:08.942 --> 00:03:10.701
maybe 30 days later will be higher.

65
00:03:10.701 --> 00:03:12.884
And the accounting department
will find out eventually.

66
00:03:12.884 --> 00:03:15.870
And they'll look at it and they'll say,
why is the bill higher this month?

67
00:03:15.870 --> 00:03:18.460
And when they look at that bill
they won't necessarily know.

68
00:03:18.460 --> 00:03:20.700
Is it higher because
we added more servers?

69
00:03:20.700 --> 00:03:22.850
Is it higher because we
used more bandwidth?

70
00:03:22.850 --> 00:03:24.800
Is it higher because
we're using more storage?

71
00:03:24.800 --> 00:03:28.630
All of those things are stuff that impacts
our bill, and it makes the bill go higher.

72
00:03:28.630 --> 00:03:31.410
So the accounting department no
longer has visibility into that.

73
00:03:31.410 --> 00:03:34.600
And if we're not tracking it,
then nobody has visibility.

74
00:03:34.600 --> 00:03:37.640
And for all you know, somebody
could have hacked your account and

75
00:03:37.640 --> 00:03:40.030
started spinning up
instances as Bitcoin miners.

76
00:03:40.030 --> 00:03:43.170
This is what happens, if somebody
compromises one of your cloud accounts,

77
00:03:43.170 --> 00:03:45.650
they'll usually spin up VMs
to create Bitcoin miners.

78
00:03:45.650 --> 00:03:49.080
That way they can turn
it into easily laundered

79
00:03:49.080 --> 00:03:52.320
untraceable money that's
kinda the goal there.

80
00:03:52.320 --> 00:03:53.550
Or they go after your database right?

81
00:03:53.550 --> 00:03:54.603
That's kinda the other side, but

82
00:03:54.603 --> 00:03:56.808
the Bitcoin mining is a little
more lucrative for these guys.

83
00:03:56.808 --> 00:03:58.627
So they'll start generating
that revenue and

84
00:03:58.627 --> 00:04:01.528
you won't notice until you're bill
comes in and you see it higher right?

85
00:04:01.528 --> 00:04:05.556
So we've got to keep a good handle on
the resources we have deployed and

86
00:04:05.556 --> 00:04:10.060
not just from a what's my bill gonna be
kinda standpoint, but because you more

87
00:04:10.060 --> 00:04:14.590
than likely have regulatory compliance and
other things you've got to meet.

88
00:04:14.590 --> 00:04:17.222
At a minimum you pay taxes on
a lot of this stuff and so

89
00:04:17.222 --> 00:04:20.834
at the end of the year you might be
able to depreciate the value of some of

90
00:04:20.834 --> 00:04:23.730
this equipment to defray your tax burden.

91
00:04:23.730 --> 00:04:24.410
Right?
I know

92
00:04:24.410 --> 00:04:27.540
I'm starting to use accounting terms I
need to stop that, this is an IT show.

93
00:04:27.540 --> 00:04:29.280
But it's a real issue.

94
00:04:29.280 --> 00:04:32.080
It's something that your accounting
department has to deal with.

95
00:04:32.080 --> 00:04:37.200
And so, it's really blending what the IT
people do, getting servers up and

96
00:04:37.200 --> 00:04:40.030
running, and what the accountants
do to keep your company up and

97
00:04:40.030 --> 00:04:41.240
running and financially viable.

98
00:04:41.240 --> 00:04:43.760
Every company needs to make money or
they're not gonna be around very long.

99
00:04:43.760 --> 00:04:48.652
So we gotta combine these two worlds, and
that's where stuff gets really tricky.

100
00:04:48.652 --> 00:04:50.567
And that's where ITIL comes in.

101
00:04:50.567 --> 00:04:53.676
So, the British government or
the UK government recognized,

102
00:04:53.676 --> 00:04:57.835
this is many years ago, probably 15,
20 years ago, they recognized that IT was

103
00:04:57.835 --> 00:05:01.527
becoming a growing thing and there
were a lot of companies, contractors,

104
00:05:01.527 --> 00:05:05.660
that were coming to deploy IT related
technologies for the government.

105
00:05:05.660 --> 00:05:07.940
And some of them went great and
it was wonderful and

106
00:05:07.940 --> 00:05:11.000
the technology was deployed and
it was a beautiful thing.

107
00:05:11.000 --> 00:05:14.980
But many of them would come in and
mismanage their budget,

108
00:05:14.980 --> 00:05:19.150
mismanage their schedule, mismanage
the documentation of their product.

109
00:05:19.150 --> 00:05:21.430
And by the time it rolled out,
they'd be way over budget, or

110
00:05:21.430 --> 00:05:24.413
their product wouldn't work as it was
originally pitched to the government.

111
00:05:24.413 --> 00:05:26.247
And they were having these projects fail.

112
00:05:26.247 --> 00:05:30.646
And so the British government recognized
that early on that this was gonna be

113
00:05:30.646 --> 00:05:34.216
a problem, and so they set out
to create a governance system,

114
00:05:34.216 --> 00:05:37.100
a way to be able to better
monitor these projects,

115
00:05:37.100 --> 00:05:41.841
to better monitor these IT companies to
make sure they were running properly, and

116
00:05:41.841 --> 00:05:46.512
that governance then started to evolve
into a framework of, hey, if you wanna do

117
00:05:46.512 --> 00:05:51.370
business with the UK government, here's
how you need to structure your company.

118
00:05:51.370 --> 00:05:52.470
It's like a set of instructions,

119
00:05:52.470 --> 00:05:56.150
a framework of how you should
manage your department.

120
00:05:56.150 --> 00:06:00.830
And what started out as just a way to
protect the government over there from

121
00:06:00.830 --> 00:06:03.580
failed projects,
became a really great thing.

122
00:06:03.580 --> 00:06:06.580
And now across the world,
even here in the US,

123
00:06:06.580 --> 00:06:10.360
companies are willingly adopting
ITIL to structure their environment.

124
00:06:10.360 --> 00:06:14.400
And it's because they know this can help
to guarantee the success of our projects,

125
00:06:14.400 --> 00:06:18.070
to make our company more stable,
more dependable.

126
00:06:18.070 --> 00:06:22.595
And when we start to advertise as
a product to a customer, the customer can

127
00:06:22.595 --> 00:06:26.145
count on us doing a better job, cuz they
know we're following these practices.

128
00:06:26.145 --> 00:06:27.415
And that's what ITIL does.

129
00:06:27.415 --> 00:06:32.345
And if you want to learn a bunch about
ITIL, we actually had a whole show

130
00:06:32.345 --> 00:06:34.905
called ITIL foundations, where,
I think it was Ronnie and I.

131
00:06:34.905 --> 00:06:38.868
We went through and covered all
the different topics and what ITIL is and

132
00:06:38.868 --> 00:06:40.395
all the different pieces.

133
00:06:40.395 --> 00:06:41.857
CompTIA doesn't want you to know all that.

134
00:06:41.857 --> 00:06:46.440
CompTIA wants you to know the stuff
that impacts a regular worker.

135
00:06:46.440 --> 00:06:48.340
So if you're an IT administrator,

136
00:06:48.340 --> 00:06:51.320
if you're the person running this cloud,
what do you need to know.

137
00:06:51.320 --> 00:06:52.760
And there's a couple of pieces.

138
00:06:52.760 --> 00:06:55.210
You don't need to know how to
cut a check to pay for a bill.

139
00:06:55.210 --> 00:06:57.090
Because the accounting department's
gonna take care of that.

140
00:06:57.090 --> 00:06:59.620
But there's operations that
you are responsible for and so

141
00:06:59.620 --> 00:07:00.690
I wanna run through those.

142
00:07:00.690 --> 00:07:05.510
>> So in the CompTIA world, we always talk
about that kinda setting the stage and

143
00:07:05.510 --> 00:07:08.180
you learn a lot of introductory terms.

144
00:07:08.180 --> 00:07:09.930
We hit you with a bunch of acronyms.

145
00:07:09.930 --> 00:07:10.460
Right?

146
00:07:10.460 --> 00:07:13.550
We commonly talk about things like
standardization and some of you guys have

147
00:07:13.550 --> 00:07:16.860
probably seen, we've talked about
standardization of cables, protocols.

148
00:07:16.860 --> 00:07:17.550
And what does that do?

149
00:07:17.550 --> 00:07:19.060
it gives you a consistency and

150
00:07:19.060 --> 00:07:23.900
an interoperability between many different
moving components inside of networking.

151
00:07:23.900 --> 00:07:27.670
Well Don is the ITILl pretty much the same
thing, but for a lot of the stuff then can

152
00:07:27.670 --> 00:07:31.710
get lost in the wash proverbially,
like in paperwork and stuff like that?

153
00:07:31.710 --> 00:07:37.210
>> Absolutely, yeah it's a bureaucracy,
don't get me wrong, it is extra work that

154
00:07:37.210 --> 00:07:41.230
you're gonna have to do, but it's going to
ensure that all the moving pieces in your

155
00:07:41.230 --> 00:07:44.430
department are properly being tracked,
and so let's kind of break that down.

156
00:07:44.430 --> 00:07:47.557
First off, I've said ITIL a few times,
I don't think I've said what it stood for.

157
00:07:47.557 --> 00:07:51.708
It's the information technology,
IT, industry, not industry,

158
00:07:51.708 --> 00:07:53.861
infrastructure library, right?

159
00:07:53.861 --> 00:07:55.668
And what it is is a library,

160
00:07:55.668 --> 00:08:00.631
a collection of recommended processes
that you can take or leave, right?

161
00:08:00.631 --> 00:08:02.630
If you take them, you use them.

162
00:08:02.630 --> 00:08:05.410
You integrate them into your system and
it explains how to do stuff.

163
00:08:05.410 --> 00:08:09.390
And so some of the things in there center
around really important concepts like

164
00:08:09.390 --> 00:08:10.040
change management.

165
00:08:10.040 --> 00:08:11.010
We'll talk about that later.

166
00:08:11.010 --> 00:08:12.230
Really critical key.

167
00:08:12.230 --> 00:08:14.210
If you use nothing else from ITIL,

168
00:08:14.210 --> 00:08:16.440
change management is definitely
a piece you'll want to use.

169
00:08:16.440 --> 00:08:19.350
But asset management is another big piece.

170
00:08:19.350 --> 00:08:22.100
When we're deploying physical servers
in our environment, we've already got

171
00:08:22.100 --> 00:08:25.340
asset management cuz the accounting
department acts as a gatekeeper.

172
00:08:25.340 --> 00:08:26.455
But in the virtual world,

173
00:08:26.455 --> 00:08:30.300
you've gotta track you assets, your
assets are not physical assets anymore.

174
00:08:30.300 --> 00:08:34.080
So I might have one virtual server or
20 virtual servers.

175
00:08:34.080 --> 00:08:35.960
But when I walk up to my
office in the morning,

176
00:08:35.960 --> 00:08:37.360
it doesn't look any different, right?

177
00:08:37.360 --> 00:08:39.160
Because these servers are virtual,
they're out there on the cloud,

178
00:08:39.160 --> 00:08:40.170
I don't actually see it.

179
00:08:40.170 --> 00:08:43.050
But I'm paying that bill and
I've gotta keep track of that.

180
00:08:43.050 --> 00:08:45.080
And every server has characteristics.

181
00:08:45.080 --> 00:08:48.550
It has a name, it has an IP address,
it has an amount of RAM,

182
00:08:48.550 --> 00:08:50.690
it has certain applications running on it.

183
00:08:50.690 --> 00:08:53.950
I need to keep track of that,
too, so I can say, hm,

184
00:08:53.950 --> 00:08:59.600
I just noticed there's an exploit out for
Windows 2012, all right?

185
00:08:59.600 --> 00:09:01.176
How many servers do I have
that are running Windows 2012?

186
00:09:01.176 --> 00:09:03.208
I don't know, right?

187
00:09:03.208 --> 00:09:07.180
How do I know I've patched them all,
if I don't know how many I have?

188
00:09:07.180 --> 00:09:08.240
Or it's a Linux exploit.

189
00:09:08.240 --> 00:09:09.400
How many do I have that are running Linux?

190
00:09:09.400 --> 00:09:10.970
Or a particular version,
a particular distro?

191
00:09:10.970 --> 00:09:13.640
We need to have inventories
that tell us that.

192
00:09:13.640 --> 00:09:16.190
So that we can go in and
rapidly find out, how vulnerable am I?

193
00:09:16.190 --> 00:09:18.920
There's been several OpenSSL
exploits recently, and

194
00:09:18.920 --> 00:09:21.100
they always hit the news
because it is a big deal.

195
00:09:21.100 --> 00:09:25.420
So if I know that a particular
version of OpenSSL has an exploit,

196
00:09:25.420 --> 00:09:27.780
do I have a way to quickly
look at all of my servers and

197
00:09:27.780 --> 00:09:31.250
find out how many of them
are running that version of OpenSSL?

198
00:09:31.250 --> 00:09:33.960
Well you'd be surprised at how many
companies don't have a way to do that,

199
00:09:33.960 --> 00:09:37.860
and there's plenty of ways
that they could do it, right?

200
00:09:37.860 --> 00:09:40.870
Good asset management is really important.

201
00:09:40.870 --> 00:09:43.300
Physical assets we need to track for
tax purposes, right?

202
00:09:43.300 --> 00:09:45.090
But also for warranty purposes.

203
00:09:45.090 --> 00:09:47.350

00:31:30.420 --> 00:31:34.210
We want to make sure that our systems are
configured and properly adhering to our

654
00:31:34.210 --> 00:31:38.550
policies, and so that's called
configuration standardization.

655
00:31:38.550 --> 00:31:41.590
We want to make sure that all our systems
have a standard configuration and

656
00:31:41.590 --> 00:31:43.320
that they meet our policies.

657
00:31:43.320 --> 00:31:46.040
And you can do it by hand you can
have a checklist if you want.

658
00:31:46.040 --> 00:31:48.170
I've worked in that kind of environment
where hey I'm deploying a new

659
00:31:48.170 --> 00:31:49.170
server here's my checklist.

660
00:31:49.170 --> 00:31:50.470
Let me just run down the list.

661
00:31:50.470 --> 00:31:52.244
I did this, I did this, I did this.

662
00:31:52.244 --> 00:31:55.873
By having a checklist it makes sure
you don't miss any steps, right.

663
00:31:55.873 --> 00:31:57.382
There might be 100 steps to do.

664
00:31:57.382 --> 00:31:59.957
And if you're an expert,
if you've done it 1000 times,

665
00:31:59.957 --> 00:32:01.748
you could still forget one of those steps.

666
00:32:01.748 --> 00:32:04.800
And just forgetting one thing could
lead to a security breech, and

667
00:32:04.800 --> 00:32:07.290
you definitely don't want that.

668
00:32:07.290 --> 00:32:09.830
But if you're like me,
you just don't trust that,

669
00:32:09.830 --> 00:32:12.330
you just don't trust that people
are gonna do what they say they do.

670
00:32:12.330 --> 00:32:15.190
And you know for sure that once it's
deployed, the system gets out of your

671
00:32:15.190 --> 00:32:18.300
hands and other people get in it, and
then who knows what happen, right?

672
00:32:18.300 --> 00:32:20.120
It could be unauthorized
people that hack into the box.

673
00:32:20.120 --> 00:32:22.230
It could be internal employees
supporting the server and

674
00:32:22.230 --> 00:32:24.880
they just do something dumb and
now the server is vulnerable.

675
00:32:24.880 --> 00:32:27.790
So, we usually leverage some
third party software to monitor

676
00:32:27.790 --> 00:32:29.330
these dynamically, too.

677
00:32:29.330 --> 00:32:33.730
I always call it,
it's like have a security officer,

678
00:32:33.730 --> 00:32:37.270
an IT security officer
that's working 24/7.

679
00:32:37.270 --> 00:32:41.670
If I were to hire somebody, so
put yourself in this position.

680
00:32:41.670 --> 00:32:44.872
If I were to hire you as a security
officer for my company and

681
00:32:44.872 --> 00:32:46.430
I said I want you to
monitor the servers and

682
00:32:46.430 --> 00:32:51.070
make sure they're compliant, okay, and
I want you to do it 24 hours a day.

683
00:32:51.070 --> 00:32:52.610
How long could you keep that up?

684
00:32:52.610 --> 00:32:54.160
Two, three days,
you've gotta sleep sooner or later.

685
00:32:54.160 --> 00:32:55.770
You can only drink so much coffee.

686
00:32:55.770 --> 00:32:57.150
It's hard for somebody to do that.

687
00:32:57.150 --> 00:32:59.625
So if I were to hire you,
I could get, let's say,

688
00:32:59.625 --> 00:33:02.790
eight to ten hours of work out of
you any given day, and only so

689
00:33:02.790 --> 00:33:05.670
much in a given week, and
you monitor those systems.

690
00:33:05.670 --> 00:33:08.020
One by one you go to each server,
running through your checklist, and

691
00:33:08.020 --> 00:33:10.600
then when you're done you just
go back to the first one again.

692
00:33:10.600 --> 00:33:12.460
If you had 1000 servers,

693
00:33:12.460 --> 00:33:15.500
you could probably only get to
each server every couple of days.

694
00:33:15.500 --> 00:33:18.600
And so,
it would be a few days in-between checks.

695
00:33:18.600 --> 00:33:24.196
And I'd probably have to pay you a lot of
money, let's say $100,000 a year, right?

696
00:33:24.196 --> 00:33:29.137
Or, for $100,000 I could buy some of
the best compliance software that was out

697
00:33:29.137 --> 00:33:32.653
there and it could run 24 hours a day,
seven days a week, and

698
00:33:32.653 --> 00:33:37.185
it could be scanning every single server
on my network every couple of minutes,

699
00:33:37.185 --> 00:33:39.050
and ensuring that compliance.

700
00:33:39.050 --> 00:33:41.229
And if somebody went and
disabled the software firewall,

701
00:33:41.229 --> 00:33:43.511
I would immediately get a warning and
know about it, right?

702
00:33:43.511 --> 00:33:46.750
Now I can be ensure that people
are adhering to my policy.

703
00:33:46.750 --> 00:33:49.880
And one example of that software is,
I'll pull it up here,

704
00:33:49.880 --> 00:33:51.520
the McAfee Policy Auditor.

705
00:33:51.520 --> 00:33:56.460
Now I'm not a big fan of McAfee products,
this one is technically not McAfee.

706
00:33:56.460 --> 00:33:57.950
Remember that Intel bought McAfee.

707
00:33:57.950 --> 00:34:00.610
And so now they just brand all
the security stuff that way.

708
00:34:00.610 --> 00:34:03.310
So it's really the Intel policy auditor.

709
00:34:03.310 --> 00:34:07.480
And it's built on top of another product,
which is the e-policy orchestrator.

710
00:34:07.480 --> 00:34:09.320
And it's great technology.

711
00:34:09.320 --> 00:34:10.250
You can run it.

712
00:34:10.250 --> 00:34:12.110
You can tell it what
your security policy is.

713
00:34:12.110 --> 00:34:13.120
You tell it the things.

714
00:34:13.120 --> 00:34:17.500
Like, the administrator's group
should only contain these people.

715
00:34:17.500 --> 00:34:20.070
If the administrator's group
ever contains somebody else?

716
00:34:20.070 --> 00:34:20.570
Red flag.

717
00:34:21.820 --> 00:34:24.353
Root users should not
be allowed to SSH in.

718
00:34:24.353 --> 00:34:25.560
And if that ever happens?

719
00:34:25.560 --> 00:34:26.920
Red flag.

720
00:34:26.920 --> 00:34:30.802
These IP addresses are the only ones that
should be approved to connect in via SSH.

721
00:34:30.802 --> 00:34:31.941
If that ever changes?

722
00:34:31.941 --> 00:34:32.810
Red flag.

723
00:34:32.810 --> 00:34:35.540
You get a notification right away.

724
00:34:35.540 --> 00:34:37.670
And now when somebody deploys a server,

725
00:34:37.670 --> 00:34:39.250
they might still have
a checklist they follow.

726
00:34:39.250 --> 00:34:42.290
But if they miss anything,
you'll know right away.

727
00:34:42.290 --> 00:34:46.580
So software like this, it scans your
system, it monitors what's going on,

728
00:34:46.580 --> 00:34:48.880
it checks out what's happening.

729
00:34:48.880 --> 00:34:52.040
And that there's ever a deviation,
it tells you.

730
00:34:52.040 --> 00:34:56.400
And it can monitor, also,
this one does Windows, Linux, Mac OS, AIX,

731
00:34:56.400 --> 00:34:59.990
it'll monitor all your different systems,
you just tell it what your policy is and

732
00:34:59.990 --> 00:35:03.080
it monitors it 24 hours a day,
7 days a week.

733
00:35:03.080 --> 00:35:05.478
I've used this product,
I've also used Bind View CC,

734
00:35:05.478 --> 00:35:08.337
which has changed ownership a few times,
owned by Semantic now and

735
00:35:08.337 --> 00:35:11.110
I always make the joke,
Symantec is where software goes to die.

736
00:35:11.110 --> 00:35:13.780
And so in a way,
that's what Bind View CC has done.

737
00:35:13.780 --> 00:35:16.770
But there's plenty of other
products that are out there.

738
00:35:16.770 --> 00:35:19.640
There used to be one that I used called
ScriptLogic that I really liked and

739
00:35:19.640 --> 00:35:20.770
it changed hands a few times.

740
00:35:20.770 --> 00:35:25.000
Dell owns it now and I think they call
it the Dell System Administrator or

741
00:35:25.000 --> 00:35:26.704
something crazy like that.

742
00:35:26.704 --> 00:35:27.850
It's got a different name.

743
00:35:27.850 --> 00:35:29.710
I'll look it up and
put it in the show notes for you guys.

744
00:35:29.710 --> 00:35:33.400
But it's a good product too and
I don't think Dell makes it free.

745
00:35:33.400 --> 00:35:34.820
I think they do make you pay for it.

746
00:35:34.820 --> 00:35:37.910
But just a way to check compliance.

747
00:35:37.910 --> 00:35:40.190
Are all these systems
following my security policy?

748
00:35:40.190 --> 00:35:44.110
So, we gotta have that in place, because
you just can't count on your system

749
00:35:44.110 --> 00:35:46.740
staying compliant and
you need to know when that changes.

750
00:35:46.740 --> 00:35:48.780
>> Great information,
keep in mind, policies and

751
00:35:48.780 --> 00:35:51.580
procedures, something that you're
gonna see in the real world as well

752
00:35:51.580 --> 00:35:54.290
as the Cloud Plus exam so
you need to know this stuff.

753
00:35:54.290 --> 00:35:56.810
Remember, asset management,
capacity management, and

754
00:35:56.810 --> 00:35:58.980
a standardization in your configurations.

755
00:35:58.980 --> 00:36:01.220
Great information Don,
do you have anything else for us?

756
00:36:01.220 --> 00:36:01.930
>> That's about it.

757
00:36:01.930 --> 00:36:04.680
We do have more to talk about,
some more ITIL related concepts.

758
00:36:04.680 --> 00:36:07.050
Change configuration management,
which are really important.

759
00:36:07.050 --> 00:36:08.320
We'll do those in part two.

760
00:36:08.320 --> 00:36:10.050
So there is a little more to this.

761
00:36:10.050 --> 00:36:12.390
But these are kind of the key
concepts that we've covered today.

762
00:36:12.390 --> 00:36:13.790
>> Very good.
Well stick around,

763
00:36:13.790 --> 00:36:14.800
because we've got more to come.

764
00:36:14.800 --> 00:36:16.600
But that's gonna be saved for a part two.

765
00:36:16.600 --> 00:36:18.936
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off here at ITProTV.

766
00:36:18.936 --> 00:36:20.142
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

767
00:36:20.142 --> 00:36:20.921
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

768
00:36:20.921 --> 00:36:22.314
>> And we'll see you next time.

769
00:36:22.314 --> 00:36:30.488
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don continue their discussion on policies and procedures. They move into configuration management and change management. The introduce concepts such as change requests, cange advisory boards. They will look at life cycle managment and the five step process defined by the information lifecycle management and practical lifecycle management.
episodes.title: Policies and Procedures Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.962 --> 00:00:14.681
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:14.681 --> 00:00:18.665
I'm your host Wes Bryan and in today's
episode we're gonna be moving along in our

4
00:00:18.665 --> 00:00:23.060
Cloud+ training and we're coming back
at you with a part two of policies and

5
00:00:23.060 --> 00:00:25.890
procedures and we have Mr.
Don Pezet here to help us out with that.

6
00:00:25.890 --> 00:00:27.100
Don, how ya doing today sir?

7
00:00:27.100 --> 00:00:28.430
>> I'm doing just swell Wes.

8
00:00:28.430 --> 00:00:30.480
And I'm glad to be back on the show.

9
00:00:30.480 --> 00:00:31.560
For those of you that
watched the last one,

10
00:00:31.560 --> 00:00:33.380
you know that I do have a tendency
to ramble on a little bit.

11
00:00:33.380 --> 00:00:37.460
So we talked a quite a bit about asset
management and a few other things.

12
00:00:37.460 --> 00:00:40.690
And one of the concepts that I brought up,
I had just mentioned it really briefly,

13
00:00:40.690 --> 00:00:42.360
was change management.

14
00:00:42.360 --> 00:00:45.300
In this episode we're gonna talk
a little about change management and

15
00:00:45.300 --> 00:00:48.620
configuration management and why they're
so important and how we need to keep

16
00:00:48.620 --> 00:00:52.540
track of all the stuff that's going on in
our network after things are deployed,

17
00:00:52.540 --> 00:00:54.510
it is a critical thing to track.

18
00:00:54.510 --> 00:00:57.290
>> Now, Don, I'm looking at some of
the topics that we have to cover here and

19
00:00:57.290 --> 00:00:59.970
the first thing that comes to mind is,
well change management,

20
00:00:59.970 --> 00:01:02.600
configuration management,
they look like they're the same thing.

21
00:01:02.600 --> 00:01:03.370
Can you help us out?

22
00:01:03.370 --> 00:01:04.980
Is there a difference between them?

23
00:01:04.980 --> 00:01:07.846
All right, I'll tell you guys,
if you're a network administrator or

24
00:01:07.846 --> 00:01:11.145
if you're a systems administrator or
even if you're a security administrator,

25
00:01:11.145 --> 00:01:13.421
a lot of times people use
these terms interchangeably.

26
00:01:13.421 --> 00:01:14.796
Change management,
configuration management.

27
00:01:14.796 --> 00:01:15.940
Who cares?
They both start with a C.

28
00:01:15.940 --> 00:01:18.340
We'll just call them the same thing,
right?

29
00:01:18.340 --> 00:01:22.280
But they actually are two different things
and when they're used the way they were

30
00:01:22.280 --> 00:01:26.180
originally intended to be used, it's very
obvious that they're different, right?

31
00:01:26.180 --> 00:01:28.270
But the thing is that a lot of
us use them in ways that they're

32
00:01:28.270 --> 00:01:28.870
not intended to be used.

33
00:01:28.870 --> 00:01:29.740
That's not a bad thing.

34
00:01:29.740 --> 00:01:31.900
It's because they're so flexible and
they're a good concept, but

35
00:01:31.900 --> 00:01:33.460
there is a difference.

36
00:01:33.460 --> 00:01:34.900
Configuration management.

37
00:01:34.900 --> 00:01:37.430
Both of these actually kind of
stem from project management so

38
00:01:37.430 --> 00:01:40.290
in a project environment they
have very well-defined meanings.

39
00:01:40.290 --> 00:01:46.480
When you kick off a project, a project
has this triad of requirements, something

40
00:01:46.480 --> 00:01:51.170
that determines how, they call them your
constraints, your project constraints.

41
00:01:51.170 --> 00:01:53.290
And so
your triple constraints are your budget,

42
00:01:53.290 --> 00:01:58.090
which is just how much money you have,
your schedule, how much time you have, and

43
00:01:58.090 --> 00:02:01.210
then your requirements,
which is what you're trying to achieve.

44
00:02:01.210 --> 00:02:04.180
So anytime you set out on a project,
those are three things you have to know.

45
00:02:04.180 --> 00:02:09.340
How much money can I spend, how much time
do I have, and what do I have to get done.

46
00:02:09.340 --> 00:02:15.000
Well configuration management applies
to the what I have to get done part.

47
00:02:15.000 --> 00:02:16.390
So if somebody gives you a project and

48
00:02:16.390 --> 00:02:20.980
they say we need you to deploy
a online billing system.

49
00:02:20.980 --> 00:02:24.520
We need our customers to be able to browse
the website, view their account details,

50
00:02:24.520 --> 00:02:26.190
and pay their bill, right?

51
00:02:26.190 --> 00:02:27.550
We have to start thinking what we need for
that.

52
00:02:27.550 --> 00:02:28.560
You need servers.

53
00:02:28.560 --> 00:02:31.140
You got security,
certificates, encryption.

54
00:02:31.140 --> 00:02:32.580
We need infrastructure for

55
00:02:32.580 --> 00:02:35.430
that, redundancy,
all of this stuff that we need.

56
00:02:35.430 --> 00:02:38.950
And it's all gotta fit together
to create this overall solution.

57
00:02:38.950 --> 00:02:42.290
That meets the requirements
of the project, right?

58
00:02:42.290 --> 00:02:44.680
That is our requirements.

59
00:02:44.680 --> 00:02:47.750
And anytime we deviate
from those requirements,

60
00:02:47.750 --> 00:02:49.850
it's called configuration management.

61
00:02:49.850 --> 00:02:52.300
The configuration of our solution,

62
00:02:52.300 --> 00:02:55.390
of our product is meeting
the requirements of the project.

63
00:02:55.390 --> 00:03:00.720
And if we change that configuration,
if I say hm, we were gonna deploy SSL and

64
00:03:00.720 --> 00:03:06.080
then we realized that it's horribly broken
and instead we needed to use TLS instead.

65
00:03:06.080 --> 00:03:08.240
And not just TLS 1.1, we wanna do TLS 1.2.

66
00:03:08.240 --> 00:03:12.620
Well now I'm changing my configuration,
right, my cost and

67
00:03:12.620 --> 00:03:16.630
my schedule still stay the same,
but my configuration changes.

68
00:03:16.630 --> 00:03:18.790
And that's where configuration
management comes in.

69
00:03:18.790 --> 00:03:23.020
Because if we just start arbitrarily
changing our configuration,

70
00:03:23.020 --> 00:03:26.190
we might not be able to meet our
schedule and our budget any more.

71
00:03:26.190 --> 00:03:28.370
We might not even be able
to complete our project or

72
00:03:28.370 --> 00:03:34.180
project might no longer be in line with
what the original customer's asking for.

73
00:03:34.180 --> 00:03:38.150
So maybe we say, you know they called for
five servers, but four will do,

74
00:03:38.150 --> 00:03:40.640
let's just cut off one of those
servers and save some money.

75
00:03:40.640 --> 00:03:45.030
Well you can do that if you have
the customer's approval to do it, right?

76
00:03:45.030 --> 00:03:46.490
And that's how it works
in a project world.

77
00:03:47.730 --> 00:03:51.750
Change management on the other hand
doesn't apply to the configuration.

78
00:03:51.750 --> 00:03:55.660
Change management, we're still trying to
complete the configuration as requested

79
00:03:55.660 --> 00:03:58.530
but we recognize that we're
not gonna meet our budget.

80
00:03:58.530 --> 00:04:00.462
Or, we recognize that we're
not gonna meet our schedule.

81
00:04:00.462 --> 00:04:03.370
And so we put in a change request to say,
can I change that schedule?

82
00:04:03.370 --> 00:04:06.730
Can I change that budget?

83
00:04:06.730 --> 00:04:07.920
Can I have a little more money?

84
00:04:07.920 --> 00:04:09.300
Can I have a little more time?

85
00:04:09.300 --> 00:04:11.510
Or, maybe we're ahead of schedule so
we say, can we have less time?

86
00:04:11.510 --> 00:04:13.020
We're gonna get done early, right?

87
00:04:13.020 --> 00:04:14.990
That's where change management comes in.

88
00:04:14.990 --> 00:04:18.740
And so in a project world
that's very important, right.

89
00:04:18.740 --> 00:04:21.640
Two very distinct separate ideas.

90
00:04:21.640 --> 00:04:25.790
The thing is if you're following ITIL
practices, you'll use change and

91
00:04:25.790 --> 00:04:28.430
configuration management
outside of projects.

92
00:04:28.430 --> 00:04:32.860
A project has a well defined start and
an end.

93
00:04:32.860 --> 00:04:36.850
A project starts,
it achieves a goal and it ends.

94
00:04:36.850 --> 00:04:39.965
But in the IT world, we have a lot
of stuff that isn't a project,

95
00:04:39.965 --> 00:04:42.030
that is what's called operations.

96
00:04:42.030 --> 00:04:44.587
And with operations that's stuff
that goes on every single day.

97
00:04:44.587 --> 00:04:48.569
So I might have a project to bring up a
web server but once the web server is up,

98
00:04:48.569 --> 00:04:52.741
that project is over but the web server
doesn't disappear, it stays running,

99
00:04:52.741 --> 00:04:56.630
day after day, after day, for
years throughout its life cycle, right.

100
00:04:56.630 --> 00:05:00.500
A life cycle is,
how we deploy stuff, right.

101
00:05:00.500 --> 00:05:03.210
And with a life cycle,
you start with kind of a design phase.

102
00:05:03.210 --> 00:05:04.505
You come up with what you're gonna do.

103
00:05:04.505 --> 00:05:05.047
In fact here,

104
00:05:05.047 --> 00:05:08.088
let me, I'm gonna jump ahead in the notes,
Wes, I'll throw you out of order.

105
00:05:08.088 --> 00:05:08.846
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So,

106
00:05:08.846 --> 00:05:10.750
in ITIL we have this life cycle.

107
00:05:10.750 --> 00:05:13.040
And the life cycle really has
five kind of pieces to it.

108
00:05:13.040 --> 00:05:17.110
So, you basically start out
with designing a service.

109
00:05:17.110 --> 00:05:19.520
What it is that you're gonna do,
this design.

110
00:05:19.520 --> 00:05:22.690
And then you transition the service.

111
00:05:22.690 --> 00:05:24.740
You've designed it,
