And things are just not working.

342
00:16:06.162 --> 00:16:07.972
And you're kind of undoing the work or

343
00:16:07.972 --> 00:16:10.696
they're undoing the work that
you're trying to put in.

344
00:16:10.696 --> 00:16:13.235
And that's why we've gotta
have good communications, and

345
00:16:13.235 --> 00:16:15.034
Change Management does that, all right?

346
00:16:15.034 --> 00:16:19.606
The first key concept with Change
Management is that we introduced a CAB,

347
00:16:19.606 --> 00:16:21.500
a Change Advisory Board.

348
00:16:21.500 --> 00:16:22.700
There's different names.

349
00:16:22.700 --> 00:16:25.889
You'll have, some people call it
a configuration board or whatever.

350
00:16:25.889 --> 00:16:30.495
But a Change Advisory Board or
a CAB is one of the more common names.

351
00:16:30.495 --> 00:16:34.284
>> Now with the Change Advisory Board
is that commonly made up of people

352
00:16:34.284 --> 00:16:36.943
like stakeholders, shareholders and stuff,

353
00:16:36.943 --> 00:16:40.920
that have an invested interest in
the company or not always or at all?

354
00:16:40.920 --> 00:16:42.220
>> In a project, it would be.

355
00:16:42.220 --> 00:16:44.420
>> Okay.
>> But the outside of a project,

356
00:16:44.420 --> 00:16:47.460
you don't have stakeholders when
you're outside of a project, right?

357
00:16:47.460 --> 00:16:50.383
So what you would do is you would make
it up out of usually at least one

358
00:16:50.383 --> 00:16:52.212
representative from the IT Department,

359
00:16:52.212 --> 00:16:55.156
because you need somebody with
technical knowledge on the board.

360
00:16:55.156 --> 00:16:57.829
You'd usually have one representative
from your security team,

361
00:16:57.829 --> 00:17:00.226
because you've gotta have
someone with security in mind.

362
00:17:00.226 --> 00:17:04.483
And the rest of the representatives would
be made up of people from accounting and

363
00:17:04.483 --> 00:17:06.424
the departments that are affected,

364
00:17:06.424 --> 00:17:09.330
the people who would be
impacted by this change.

365
00:17:09.330 --> 00:17:14.880
So if I worked for a bank and I have
a web based mortgage lending system,

366
00:17:14.880 --> 00:17:18.020
I need to have somebody from the mortgage
department and from the underwriting

367
00:17:18.020 --> 00:17:20.910
department, because these are the people
that use that system every single day.

368
00:17:20.910 --> 00:17:25.200
And if I'm about to make a change, to
an IT guy like me, I might not care, and

369
00:17:25.200 --> 00:17:28.870
say, we're gonna update to the latest
version of software it's more secure.

370
00:17:28.870 --> 00:17:31.384
And by the way,
it requires Internet Explorer 11.

371
00:17:32.680 --> 00:17:34.850
And that's it,
we don't support Firefox or Chrome or

372
00:17:34.850 --> 00:17:37.670
lower versions of Internet Explorer, and
so that's what we're gonna roll out, and

373
00:17:37.670 --> 00:17:38.890
I'm fine with that.

374
00:17:38.890 --> 00:17:42.140
But then we go to the change board and
we say what we're gonna do, and

375
00:17:42.140 --> 00:17:47.130
the underwriting team says, whoa, wait
a minute we just bought 1000 laptops and

376
00:17:47.130 --> 00:17:49.660
they've all got
Internet Explorer 10 on it.

377
00:17:49.660 --> 00:17:52.510
Or boy we hate Internet Explorer,
we just use Firefox, and

378
00:17:52.510 --> 00:17:53.980
you're about to take
away our Firefox support.

379
00:17:55.340 --> 00:17:57.050
And now, as the IT guy,

380
00:17:57.050 --> 00:18:00.050
well it didn't bother me but
I see it's a problem for you.

381
00:18:00.050 --> 00:18:04.280
>> So the committee is more just
a completely inter-departmental, and

382
00:18:04.280 --> 00:18:05.390
it has to be it seems like,

383
00:18:05.390 --> 00:18:09.480
cuz that makes sense that all those
brand new laptops now are out of date.

384
00:18:09.480 --> 00:18:12.823
They're not really out of date, but
they're not configured correctly anymore.

385
00:18:12.823 --> 00:18:14.070
>> Let me give you a real world example.

386
00:18:14.070 --> 00:18:15.930
This is one that happened
to me a few years ago is,

387
00:18:15.930 --> 00:18:20.200
I had some servers that I needed to do
maintenance on, just routine maintenance.

388
00:18:20.200 --> 00:18:23.030
I knew that I could save a little memory
on them, get them running a little faster,

389
00:18:23.030 --> 00:18:25.910
so it was optional maintenance,
it was something I was chosing to do.

390
00:18:25.910 --> 00:18:30.700
So I filled out my change ticket, and
I said I wanna come in on a Saturday,

391
00:18:30.700 --> 00:18:34.140
and I'll just come in at 6AM and
I'll put in this change,

392
00:18:34.140 --> 00:18:37.740
knowing that the company was closed at
6AM, and so I could get in there and

393
00:18:37.740 --> 00:18:40.380
make that change that really
wouldn't impact anybody, right?

394
00:18:40.380 --> 00:18:43.035
So I put in that ticket, and
then my ticket got rejected, and

395
00:18:43.035 --> 00:18:46.107
I was like well that sucks, I was
kinda like volunteering to come in and

396
00:18:46.107 --> 00:18:48.160
do this stuff on the weekend,
what happened?

397
00:18:48.160 --> 00:18:51.895
And the reason it was rejected was that
somebody in the underwriting department

398
00:18:51.895 --> 00:18:54.568
was at that meeting, and
they said whoa, wait a minute,

399
00:18:54.568 --> 00:18:56.368
we're actually backed up right now.

400
00:18:56.368 --> 00:19:00.351
And so we're bringing in our
team on Saturday to get ahead,

401
00:19:00.351 --> 00:19:02.262
to catch up on our backlog and

402
00:19:02.262 --> 00:19:07.570
process some of the adjustments that
have been coming into the company.

403
00:19:07.570 --> 00:19:10.310
And I didn't know that because
I'm not an underwriter.

404
00:19:10.310 --> 00:19:13.600
I don't care when they work,
I'm the IT guy, I run the servers, right?

405
00:19:13.600 --> 00:19:16.100
So I know the company's
closed on Saturday but

406
00:19:16.100 --> 00:19:18.560
they had scheduled weekend
work that I didn't know about.

407
00:19:18.560 --> 00:19:19.970
And so they told me.

408
00:19:19.970 --> 00:19:22.930
So it wasn't that my change was
rejected like, you can't do that.

409
00:19:22.930 --> 00:19:24.970
It was, you just can't do it on that day.

410
00:19:24.970 --> 00:19:26.870
So if you wanna do it,
can you come in on Sunday and

411
00:19:26.870 --> 00:19:30.070
do it, or maybe the next Saturday,
and that's exactly what I did.

412
00:19:30.070 --> 00:19:31.900
I just moved it to the next Saturday,
I didn't care.

413
00:19:31.900 --> 00:19:34.640
So you move it, but it avoided a disaster.

414
00:19:34.640 --> 00:19:37.420
I could have come in that Saturday
knowing the company was closed and

415
00:19:37.420 --> 00:19:41.400
started making that change, and they could
have had 20 underwriters show up to work,

416
00:19:41.400 --> 00:19:43.620
and the system would have been offline.

417
00:19:43.620 --> 00:19:46.490
And they're like great, we came in on the
weekend, and we can't even do our work?

418
00:19:46.490 --> 00:19:49.520
And it was just cuz there's not that
level of communication normally.

419
00:19:49.520 --> 00:19:51.790
But the Change Advisory Board
served it's purpose there.

420
00:19:51.790 --> 00:19:54.610
And it let me know about that and
it let us avoid an outage.

421
00:19:54.610 --> 00:19:55.622
That's what this is all about, right?

422
00:19:55.622 --> 00:19:58.115
That's why Change Advisory Boards are so
important, all right?

423
00:19:58.115 --> 00:20:01.180
Now when you fill out a change ticket,
I've got a sample here.

424
00:20:01.180 --> 00:20:02.310
Just a change request template.

425
00:20:02.310 --> 00:20:03.770
I use this in our project
management shows.

426
00:20:03.770 --> 00:20:06.700
If you ever watch our PMP series,
I use this a lot.

427
00:20:06.700 --> 00:20:09.040
But basically a change
request boils down to this,

428
00:20:09.040 --> 00:20:14.000
you have to provide some basic information
about what it is you're doing.

429
00:20:14.000 --> 00:20:18.460
And so normally you're gonna give a
detailed description of the change, okay?

430
00:20:18.460 --> 00:20:20.920
So this is what I wanna do, right?

431
00:20:20.920 --> 00:20:25.610
And for that example I gave a minute
ago with the insurance company,

432
00:20:25.610 --> 00:20:30.510
what I was wanting to do was move some
software from one server to another.

433
00:20:30.510 --> 00:20:33.820
So I had one physical server that only
had, I think it had four processors, and

434
00:20:33.820 --> 00:20:35.790
I wanted to move it to a system
that had eight processors.

435
00:20:35.790 --> 00:20:38.200
And that way it would have
some more CPU available to it.

436
00:20:38.200 --> 00:20:39.500
And it would perform better.

437
00:20:39.500 --> 00:20:40.570
So that's why I put in my change.

438
00:20:40.570 --> 00:20:44.570
So I put you know I wanna move the image
right front end from this server over to

439
00:20:44.570 --> 00:20:46.100
another server, okay?

440
00:20:46.100 --> 00:20:48.760
And then justification for
proposed change.

441
00:20:48.760 --> 00:20:53.300
Here's where I put in the existing
servers been logging about 80% CPU

442
00:20:53.300 --> 00:20:56.610
utilization on average every single day.

443
00:20:56.610 --> 00:20:58.065
If I move it over to the new system,

444
00:20:58.065 --> 00:21:01.200
that'll drop us down to less than
40% CPU utilization everyday,

445
00:21:01.200 --> 00:21:04.370
which will give us plenty of room to
grow and plenty of room to spike.

446
00:21:04.370 --> 00:21:06.120
And so that's what I put in there.

447
00:21:06.120 --> 00:21:07.010
Impact of change.

448
00:21:07.010 --> 00:21:09.400
For the impact of change I put,

449
00:21:09.400 --> 00:21:12.900
while I'm making the change
the entire system will be offline.

450
00:21:12.900 --> 00:21:15.460
The change will take approximately two
hours, so for two hours we're gonna have

451
00:21:15.460 --> 00:21:19.650
an outage, that's the impact and
it's gonna impact anybody in

452
00:21:19.650 --> 00:21:23.780
the adjusting department, the underwriting
department and, it was years ago now so

453
00:21:23.780 --> 00:21:26.140
I can't remember, there was one
other department that was affected.

454
00:21:26.140 --> 00:21:27.970
If you were in accounting you didn't care,

455
00:21:27.970 --> 00:21:29.940
if you were in the mail room you
didn't care, but if you were in

456
00:21:29.940 --> 00:21:33.510
these other departments these are the
people that would be impacted, right?

457
00:21:33.510 --> 00:21:34.850
And then I just put in any other comments,

458
00:21:34.850 --> 00:21:37.560
I don't remember if I had any comments,
I usually do.

459
00:21:37.560 --> 00:21:39.980
So then, this can go before the board.

460
00:21:39.980 --> 00:21:43.090
Now there's usually a few other
steps that we might include in here.

461
00:21:43.090 --> 00:21:44.750
Things like a rollback plan.

462
00:21:44.750 --> 00:21:46.000
What if i screw it up?

463
00:21:46.000 --> 00:21:49.440
What if I'm moving this software over and
a problem happens?

464
00:21:49.440 --> 00:21:51.440
You put a roll back plan in, right?

465
00:21:51.440 --> 00:21:53.230
Roll back plans are really important.

466
00:21:53.230 --> 00:21:56.540
I know one of the gentlemen that I worked
with is a brilliant guy, just really,

467
00:21:56.540 --> 00:21:59.300
really smart, and he did a lot of work.

468
00:21:59.300 --> 00:22:01.840
He really just got a lot
done in any given week, but

469
00:22:01.840 --> 00:22:05.310
you always knew when he was about
to go on vacation, because for

470
00:22:05.310 --> 00:22:08.880
one week he would just do
an amazing amount of work.

471
00:22:08.880 --> 00:22:12.170
He would double his effort
the week before going on vacation,

472
00:22:12.170 --> 00:22:14.090
and then he'd go on vacation.

473
00:22:14.090 --> 00:22:18.130
And so he's a company guy,
really dedicated to the company.

474
00:22:18.130 --> 00:22:22.460
The problem was he'd put in a ton of
changes, and then he'd go on vacation.

475
00:22:22.460 --> 00:22:25.720
And I'd come in on Monday, and
there'd be red lights all over the place.

476
00:22:25.720 --> 00:22:26.640
People are going crazy.

477
00:22:26.640 --> 00:22:29.430
This software's not working,
this isn't right, my icons are missing,

478
00:22:29.430 --> 00:22:33.770
the color of the webpage is wrong,
it was just crazy stuff.

479
00:22:33.770 --> 00:22:37.080
And I would have to sit there and
reverse engineer the changes he did.

480
00:22:37.080 --> 00:22:40.890
What the heck happened on Friday
that's making Monday so bad?

481
00:22:40.890 --> 00:22:42.700
And I would just have to start undoing it.

482
00:22:42.700 --> 00:22:45.570
And in the early days before we had
change management, it was a nightmare.

483
00:22:45.570 --> 00:22:47.440
I hated it when he went on vacation.

484
00:22:47.440 --> 00:22:49.970
And so once we had change
management it was a lot easier.

485
00:22:49.970 --> 00:22:51.320
Cuz on that Monday I can just come in and

486
00:22:51.320 --> 00:22:52.990
say all right let me pull
the change tickets for Friday.

487
00:22:52.990 --> 00:22:54.370
What was approved?

488
00:22:54.370 --> 00:22:57.540
And then go through and here's the one
that's effecting this, let me just roll it

489
00:22:57.540 --> 00:23:00.320
back, and then he can sort it out when
he gets back from vacation, right?

490
00:23:00.320 --> 00:23:01.490
And now I've got the steps to roll back.

491
00:23:01.490 --> 00:23:05.350
So a roll back plan or
a back out plan is really nice to have.

492
00:23:05.350 --> 00:23:07.210
It also shows that you've
done your research.

493
00:23:07.210 --> 00:23:10.630
This isn't some change that
I'm willy nilly throwing in.

494
00:23:10.630 --> 00:23:12.270
It's something that I've
really thought out.

495
00:23:12.270 --> 00:23:13.500
I've tested it.

496
00:23:13.500 --> 00:23:15.470
I've shown that it works, and

497
00:23:15.470 --> 00:23:17.760
here's how you can undo it
if there's a problem, right?

498
00:23:17.760 --> 00:23:20.990
Or if it doesn't work, right, cuz another
part of this is change validation.

499
00:23:20.990 --> 00:23:22.720
How do we verify the change worked?

500
00:23:22.720 --> 00:23:25.650
So if I go through the trouble of
moving this server to new hardware,

501
00:23:25.650 --> 00:23:27.710
how do I show that I'm actually
getting the benefit of it?

502
00:23:27.710 --> 00:23:29.750
We need to track that, because if
we don't get the benefit out of it,

503
00:23:29.750 --> 00:23:30.970
I need to move it back.

504
00:23:30.970 --> 00:23:33.580
I need to move it back to where it
was because I've wasted my time, and

505
00:23:33.580 --> 00:23:35.980
I might need that other hardware for
something else, right?

506
00:23:35.980 --> 00:23:37.960
So you need to undo changes
that don't work, and

507
00:23:37.960 --> 00:23:40.310
that might be a part of
your change ticket also.

508
00:23:40.310 --> 00:23:44.280
But then, at the end of the day, the last
page is what's important, right here.

509
00:23:44.280 --> 00:23:47.824
This is where they can approve,
defer, or decline the change.

510
00:23:47.824 --> 00:23:52.344
If they approve it, now it's an authorized
change, and we've got it on paper here.

511
00:23:52.344 --> 00:23:54.538
We know exactly whats happening and
we keep track of it.

512
00:23:54.538 --> 00:23:56.953
If we decline it,
we're not gonna make the change.

513
00:23:56.953 --> 00:24:01.333
If we defer it, we're normally gonna
defer it to either schedule it for

514
00:24:01.333 --> 00:24:04.700
a better time or
to request more information.

515
00:24:04.700 --> 00:24:08.090
Maybe we need some more data about this
change than what you've given us and so

516
00:24:08.090 --> 00:24:10.120
we put in here, in the Justification for

517
00:24:10.120 --> 00:24:14.500
Disposition, here's what I need you to
give me before we can approve this change.

518
00:24:14.500 --> 00:24:18.130
And then you get your signatures,
your change control board signatures.

519
00:24:18.130 --> 00:24:20.970
Now here it's a change control
board instead of a change

520
00:24:20.970 --> 00:24:22.230
advisory board, or whatever.

521
00:24:22.230 --> 00:24:23.410
There's different names
that are out there.

522
00:24:23.410 --> 00:24:25.110
This one's a CCB.

523
00:24:25.110 --> 00:24:28.620
Now I mention we need to have
members of the CCB that are from

524
00:24:28.620 --> 00:24:29.980
multiple departments.

525
00:24:29.980 --> 00:24:32.840
It can be really hard to
get those people together.

526
00:24:32.840 --> 00:24:33.760
Right?
Especially if it's

527
00:24:33.760 --> 00:24:36.270
several different departments for
a large company.

528
00:24:36.270 --> 00:24:39.340
So you might only have a CAB meeting,
Change Advisory Board,

529
00:24:39.340 --> 00:24:41.650
a CAB meeting once a week.

530
00:24:41.650 --> 00:24:44.530
If you just have a CAB meeting one a week,
you build up your changes

531
00:24:44.530 --> 00:24:47.820
through the week, you submit them all at
once, and you try and get them approved.

532
00:24:47.820 --> 00:24:49.960
And if the CAB meeting is on Wednesday and

533
00:24:49.960 --> 00:24:53.710
you come up with a change on Thursday,
you gotta wait six days for

534
00:24:53.710 --> 00:24:56.170
the next Wednesday to roll around for
that change to get approved.

535
00:24:56.170 --> 00:25:02.520
So a cab can really be an obstacle for
reactivity, right?

536
00:25:02.520 --> 00:25:05.725
For change, for improving your systems,
it can be bureaucracy and so

537
00:25:05.725 --> 00:25:07.285
people hate it, right.

538
00:25:07.285 --> 00:25:10.705
But what you need to do is you need to
recognize that some changes are critical

539
00:25:10.705 --> 00:25:13.975
and urgent and most aren't,
and most can wait a week.

540
00:25:13.975 --> 00:25:14.815
It's not a big deal.

541
00:25:14.815 --> 00:25:16.975
You might wanna do it right now,
but you can wait a week.

542
00:25:16.975 --> 00:25:18.915
But there's other ones that are critical.

543
00:25:18.915 --> 00:25:23.215
Hey, a firewall is about to run out
of memory at this branch office.

544
00:25:23.215 --> 00:25:24.595
I see it, I wanna reboot it.

545
00:25:24.595 --> 00:25:27.450
I'm gonna do a change ticket and
say I'm gonna reboot it, but

546
00:25:27.450 --> 00:25:28.740
I gotta wait six days.

547
00:25:28.740 --> 00:25:30.820
It's gonna run out of memory in two days.

548
00:25:30.820 --> 00:25:33.080
I'm out of luck.
I just gotta let that branch go down.

549
00:25:33.080 --> 00:25:35.620
Well no, you can do an emergency ticket.

550
00:25:35.620 --> 00:25:38.890
You need to have an emergency plan
that says, if I've got an emergency,

551
00:25:38.890 --> 00:25:41.460
I don't necessarily have to
convene the whole board, but

552
00:25:41.460 --> 00:25:42.990
I can reach out to
the members individually.

553
00:25:42.990 --> 00:25:46.200
And as long as I get three out
of five signatures, or whatever,

554
00:25:46.200 --> 00:25:49.150
a certain portion, I can go ahead and
push the emergency change through.

555
00:25:49.150 --> 00:25:52.100
But it's gotta be an emergency change, so
you've gotta come up with a policy that

556
00:25:52.100 --> 00:25:56.050
defines what's an emergency,
and what's not, right?

557
00:25:56.050 --> 00:25:59.290
If I know that branch is gonna
be down before the next cab,

558
00:25:59.290 --> 00:26:02.320
that's an emergency, that needs
to be able to be pushed through.

559
00:26:02.320 --> 00:26:06.610
And maybe my policy is really small, and
I just say the CIO can approve it, and

560
00:26:06.610 --> 00:26:07.339
that's it.

561
00:26:07.339 --> 00:26:08.476
But normally it does a little bit more,

562
00:26:08.476 --> 00:26:09.784
cuz you do wanna check
with the other people,

563
00:26:09.784 --> 00:26:11.450
make sure that you're not
gonna impact anything crazy.

564
00:26:11.450 --> 00:26:14.080
So change management, really critical.

565
00:26:14.080 --> 00:26:17.400
Just because you need that
document that says what change, so

566
00:26:17.400 --> 00:26:19.370
you know what's going
on in your environment.

567
00:26:19.370 --> 00:26:21.850
And your configuration management,
also important.

568
00:26:21.850 --> 00:26:25.233
So when you deploy new systems, you've
got a consistent way to deploy them.

569
00:26:25.233 --> 00:26:28.660
And if anybody deviates from that, you'll
know about it, you've got it right there.

570
00:26:28.660 --> 00:26:31.750
So these two go hand in hand and
they're really important.

571
00:26:31.750 --> 00:26:35.440
If you're a small company with one IT guy,
you can get away with not doing them.

572
00:26:35.440 --> 00:26:39.720
But if you're a large company, if you've
got 30, 40 IT people that are all managing

573
00:26:39.720 --> 00:26:41.980
the systems,
you're stepping on each other's toes,

574
00:26:41.980 --> 00:26:47.010
you're gonna get inconsistency and you're
gonna get compromised, because different

575
00:26:47.010 --> 00:26:50.130
admins are configuring systems different
ways and all of a sudden you've got one

576
00:26:50.130 --> 00:26:53.910
system that's weaker than another and
you get broken into, and that's terrible.

577
00:26:53.910 --> 00:26:57.770
So you wanna avoid that,
dis-bureaucracy solves that problem.

578
00:26:57.770 --> 00:26:59.890
>> Configuration management and
change management,

579
00:26:59.890 --> 00:27:02.870
if you're first getting into this it can
be confusing, and you know what I've been

580
00:27:02.870 --> 00:27:05.460
studying a little bit myself and
it's sometimes still confusing.

581
00:27:05.460 --> 00:27:08.060
So Don thank you for
alleviating some of that confusion.

582
00:27:08.060 --> 00:27:11.340
Keep in mind that you need to know this
stuff for the clown plus exam, but

583
00:27:11.340 --> 00:27:15.840
it's very good information to know,
if you're not in a certification endeavor.

584
00:27:15.840 --> 00:27:17.920
So again Don thank you for that.

585
00:27:17.920 --> 00:27:20.320
Do you have anything else for
us in this episode?

586
00:27:20.320 --> 00:27:20.960
>> That's about it.

587
00:27:20.960 --> 00:27:23.670
I mean, you usually are gonna
leverage third parties software for

588
00:27:23.670 --> 00:27:24.270
a lot of this stuff.

589
00:27:24.270 --> 00:27:27.087
There's plenty of companies out there
that make change management systems and

590
00:27:27.087 --> 00:27:29.199
usually you just use like their
support ticketing system.

591
00:27:29.199 --> 00:27:33.650
But honestly, Word templates or
text files or whatever, they work.

592
00:27:33.650 --> 00:27:35.620
Even simple emails can serve as that.

593
00:27:35.620 --> 00:27:37.590
But you'll need to set up
a change database somewhere, or

594
00:27:37.590 --> 00:27:39.950
a configuration management database,
so you can keep track of it all.

595
00:27:39.950 --> 00:27:43.190
So definitely look for
third-party software that can do that.

596
00:27:43.190 --> 00:27:43.970
>> Thank you very much.

597
00:27:43.970 --> 00:27:45.660
Remember, this has been
a two-part episode,

598
00:27:45.660 --> 00:27:49.090
so if you missed any of the first part,
go back and watch it.

599
00:27:49.090 --> 00:27:52.310
But looks like we've come to the end
of another episode here at ITProTV.

600
00:27:52.310 --> 00:27:54.090
So we're gonna go ahead and
sign off today.

601
00:27:54.090 --> 00:27:55.360
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

602
00:27:55.360 --> 00:27:56.280
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

603
00:27:56.280 --> 00:27:58.888
>> And we'll see you next time.

604
00:27:58.888 --> 00:28:05.860
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don talk about the concepts that drive performance. They look at disk performance and disk-related concepts such as IOPS, reads vs. writes, metadata performance and caching. They demonstrate networking concepts like bandwidth, throughput, latency, jumbo frames, multipathing and load balancing. They will also explain scaling topics such as scaling vertically, horizontally and diagonally.
episodes.title: Performance Concepts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.021 --> 00:00:14.741
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITPro TV.

3
00:00:14.741 --> 00:00:16.530
I'm your host Wes Brian and

4
00:00:16.530 --> 00:00:20.400
in today's episode we're gonna be
moving along our Cloud Plus series.

5
00:00:20.400 --> 00:00:23.580
And we're gonna be looking at some
components today that can either

6
00:00:23.580 --> 00:00:27.270
drastically improve the quality of
the service that you provide or

7
00:00:27.270 --> 00:00:28.540
the opposite way, right?

8
00:00:28.540 --> 00:00:31.000
Can really degrade
the quality of the service.

9
00:00:31.000 --> 00:00:33.770
So, we're gonna be looking at
some performance concepts and

10
00:00:33.770 --> 00:00:36.130
here to show us these concepts is Mr.
Don Pezet.

11
00:00:36.130 --> 00:00:36.980
How you doing, Don?

12
00:00:36.980 --> 00:00:38.420
>> I'm doing great, Wes, and

13
00:00:38.420 --> 00:00:41.890
you know just ready to jump back right be
into the world of Cloud Plus environment.

14
00:00:41.890 --> 00:00:44.720
And if you're looking at the Cloud Plus
exam objectives, you'll notice that when

15
00:00:44.720 --> 00:00:47.780
we get to performance,
that they really only call out.

16
00:00:47.780 --> 00:00:49.050
Wes and
I were talking about it before the show,

17
00:00:49.050 --> 00:00:51.580
they call out network performance and
disk performance.

18
00:00:51.580 --> 00:00:54.140
But we're gonna talk about
kind of the big four.

19
00:00:54.140 --> 00:00:58.680
Or as Wes call them, the four horsemen,
right, CPU, RAM, network, disk.

20
00:00:58.680 --> 00:01:02.350
As we start to deploy our servers,
especially in a virtual environment,

21
00:01:02.350 --> 00:01:05.940
we've gotta keep an eye on this and
it's performance in the VMs

22
00:01:05.940 --> 00:01:10.930
as well as performance in the hosts,
because degradation at the host level

23
00:01:10.930 --> 00:01:15.940
is going to affect the VM, and a VM that's
going crazy might affect other VMs.

24
00:01:15.940 --> 00:01:18.260
So we've gotta be able to watch this
stuff, keep a handle on it, and

25
00:01:18.260 --> 00:01:20.010
understand what these numbers mean.

26
00:01:20.010 --> 00:01:23.240
So I'm gonna show you some examples that
today, how we deal with performance, and

27
00:01:23.240 --> 00:01:25.690
all the different considerations we
have as we go and implement that.

28
00:01:25.690 --> 00:01:29.110
>> One of the first concepts that we have
to look at is well, we have data and

29
00:01:29.110 --> 00:01:30.100
we have to store it, right?

30
00:01:30.100 --> 00:01:34.055
And we have to retrieve that information,
and one of the problems is if we can't

31
00:01:34.055 --> 00:01:37.945
get to that information fast enough,
we can see some quality greatly reduced.

32
00:01:37.945 --> 00:01:41.345
So Don, it looks like the first thing
we're gonna jump in here is a little bit

33
00:01:41.345 --> 00:01:44.395
of the hard drives or
the disks that we have to use, right?

34
00:01:44.395 --> 00:01:48.035
>> Absolutely, now we're gonna kick
off talking about disk and network.

35
00:01:48.035 --> 00:01:51.185
And I'm gonna kinda skip over CPU and
RAM, and you might wonder about that.

36
00:01:51.185 --> 00:01:52.760
We will talk about them
a little bit later.

37
00:01:52.760 --> 00:01:57.180
But when you deploy a machine,
usually RAM and CPU,

38
00:01:57.180 --> 00:01:59.300
those are kind of fixed values, right?

39
00:01:59.300 --> 00:02:04.130
If I deploy a system and it's got four
processor cores, that's just what it has.

40
00:02:04.130 --> 00:02:05.130
I'm not gonna have less cores.

41
00:02:05.130 --> 00:02:06.030
I'm not gonna have more cores.

42
00:02:06.030 --> 00:02:06.690
It's just what I have.

43
00:02:06.690 --> 00:02:09.360
And when I give it RAM,
if I give it 4 gigs of RAM or

44
00:02:09.360 --> 00:02:11.670
8 gigs of RAM that's what I have,
that's it.

45
00:02:11.670 --> 00:02:13.780
In a virtual environment,
the same way, when you spit up a VM,

46
00:02:13.780 --> 00:02:15.480
you pick those things.

47
00:02:15.480 --> 00:02:18.120
But network bandwidth,
you don't pick that, right?

48
00:02:18.120 --> 00:02:19.510
Network bandwidth is virtualized.

49
00:02:19.510 --> 00:02:23.530
It's virtualized for the guest, and the
host has some fixed network bandwidth, and

50
00:02:23.530 --> 00:02:24.920
that's what we have to worry about.

51
00:02:24.920 --> 00:02:27.390
Well, we have to worry
about it if it's our cloud.

52
00:02:27.390 --> 00:02:29.980
But if it's a public cloud
like Amazon Web Services,

53
00:02:29.980 --> 00:02:34.040
or Microsoft Azure,
you don't see the underlying bandwidth.

54
00:02:34.040 --> 00:02:34.985
You just deploy your machine and

55
00:02:34.985 --> 00:02:38.600
it;s got infinite amounts of bandwidth
available, not truly infinite.

56
00:02:38.600 --> 00:02:40.520
Same thing goes for disk IO.

57
00:02:40.520 --> 00:02:44.230
When you deploy these disks, you don't
know the underlying infrastructure.

58
00:02:44.230 --> 00:02:47.370
You don't know if it's rated zero,
rated 5, rated 10, if it's rated at all,

59
00:02:47.370 --> 00:02:49.120
you don't see that.

60
00:02:49.120 --> 00:02:50.960
You just see a virtual volume.

61
00:02:50.960 --> 00:02:53.000
And so tracking disk performance and

62
00:02:53.000 --> 00:02:55.110
tracking network performance
are really important.

63
00:02:55.110 --> 00:02:57.120
That's why we're gonna
stress those two the most.

64
00:02:57.120 --> 00:02:59.090
In a virtual environment, disk and

65
00:02:59.090 --> 00:03:03.090
network are two things that we need
to track because they're so nebulous.

66
00:03:03.090 --> 00:03:06.050
They can change so
easily from what we actually have.

67
00:03:06.050 --> 00:03:08.020
>> And
I was going to say too now discs and

68
00:03:08.020 --> 00:03:10.300
networks are going to have
different metrics you know.

69
00:03:10.300 --> 00:03:11.630
The metric isn't going to be the same, so

70
00:03:11.630 --> 00:03:14.630
when disc's on we've got quite
a few different metrics we need

71
00:03:14.630 --> 00:03:19.010
to monitor in order to make sure are we
actually getting the performance we need?

72
00:03:19.010 --> 00:03:22.570
>> Yeah, absolutely, and you know, just
using Amazon web service as an example,

73
00:03:22.570 --> 00:03:24.810
they track what are called IOPS, right.

74
00:03:24.810 --> 00:03:26.270
And IOPS is pretty common.

75
00:03:26.270 --> 00:03:27.800
Microsoft tracks them too.

76
00:03:27.800 --> 00:03:28.910
In your own environment, you may or

77
00:03:28.910 --> 00:03:34.400
may not track IOPS but IOPS just stands
for input output operations per second.

78
00:03:34.400 --> 00:03:37.720
And input/output on a disk you're
really talking about reads and writes.

79
00:03:37.720 --> 00:03:41.910
So how many reads and how many writes
are you doing per second on the disk?

80
00:03:41.910 --> 00:03:45.670
Well Amazon when they sell you service
when Microsoft sells you service

81
00:03:45.670 --> 00:03:48.840
they don't know are you going to be read
heavy are you going to be write heavy.

82
00:03:48.840 --> 00:03:50.870
What's your usage scenario going to be?

83
00:03:50.870 --> 00:03:52.140
And it's different.

84
00:03:52.140 --> 00:03:56.660
When you read from a disc the impact is
a lot less than when you write to a disc.

85
00:03:56.660 --> 00:03:59.860
You see that variation and
does impact things.

86
00:03:59.860 --> 00:04:03.450
So when we start you to the point
of service they just try and

87
00:04:03.450 --> 00:04:05.120
give you a ball park number.

88
00:04:05.120 --> 00:04:08.300
But they may or
may not living up to what it is we want.

89
00:04:08.300 --> 00:04:09.470
We my have to take action there.

90
00:04:09.470 --> 00:04:12.020
I think I showed it in another episode
where I deployed a machine like here

91
00:04:12.020 --> 00:04:16.210
I'll take this one so
if I take a machine like this guy here.

92
00:04:16.210 --> 00:04:19.260
This is a Linux machine that
I've got deployed in AWS.

93
00:04:19.260 --> 00:04:22.950
If I take a look at its configuration,
I've attached a volume to it,

94
00:04:22.950 --> 00:04:26.590
it's got a hard drive attached to it,
it'll be listed in here somewhere.

95
00:04:26.590 --> 00:04:29.150
Actually it's probably easier
just to see it under the volumes.

96
00:04:29.150 --> 00:04:30.850
So if I go under my volumes,

97
00:04:30.850 --> 00:04:33.900
here I've got a couple of hard drives
that are applied to the machine.

98
00:04:33.900 --> 00:04:39.310
And when I look at these drives I've got
an 8 Gig drive here that's listed as io1.

99
00:04:39.310 --> 00:04:42.340
And another drive that's listed as gp2.

100
00:04:42.340 --> 00:04:44.380
Right, and what are those?

101
00:04:44.380 --> 00:04:49.260
Well there's general purpose drives
that don't have io reserve for them.

102
00:04:49.260 --> 00:04:53.910
And then there's io1 drives that do
have io reserve and looking over here,

103
00:04:53.910 --> 00:04:58.880
you'll see where some of mine only
have 24 I/O per second, and that's it.

104
00:04:58.880 --> 00:05:02.010
I can do 24 reads and writes per second.

105
00:05:02.010 --> 00:05:05.010
Now, is that big number or
is that a little number?

106
00:05:05.010 --> 00:05:07.030
It depends, it's hard to say.

107
00:05:07.030 --> 00:05:09.990
Your software may immediately
load into RAM and

108
00:05:09.990 --> 00:05:13.440
do everything from RAM, and you might not
even be generating any I/O per second.

109
00:05:13.440 --> 00:05:15.970
Most of the time your server's up,
you might be at zero.

110
00:05:15.970 --> 00:05:19.800
Or you might have a database that is
constantly reaching out to that disk and

111
00:05:19.800 --> 00:05:21.810
reading data and 24 might not be enough.

112
00:05:21.810 --> 00:05:26.300
And if I'm succeeding that 24,
what happens?

113
00:05:26.300 --> 00:05:28.110
Well, my database gets slow.

114
00:05:28.110 --> 00:05:31.110
I start getting slower and
slower access as a result.

115
00:05:31.110 --> 00:05:33.150
And that's a problem, right?

116
00:05:33.150 --> 00:05:35.620
So, I might need reserved
access like this one.

117
00:05:35.620 --> 00:05:39.940
Here I've reserved 240 ios per second.

118
00:05:39.940 --> 00:05:44.250
And if I'm constantly exceeding that,
my system's gonna get slow, but

119
00:05:44.250 --> 00:05:47.060
if I stay underneath it,
I get great performance.

120
00:05:47.060 --> 00:05:50.190
But if I'm not using it,
I'm still paying for it.

121
00:05:50.190 --> 00:05:53.890
It's up to me to configure
the disks to meet that need.

122
00:05:53.890 --> 00:05:56.153
They ask you when you set up a new VM,
so for example,

123
00:05:56.153 --> 00:05:57.504
let me go back instances here.

124
00:05:57.504 --> 00:06:00.722
If I spin up an instance,
when I get to the storage page,

125
00:06:00.722 --> 00:06:02.513
it's gonna ask me about this.

126
00:06:02.513 --> 00:06:05.979
I'm just going to breeze through this
a little on the fast side here and

127
00:06:05.979 --> 00:06:07.226
get to the storage page.

128
00:06:07.226 --> 00:06:11.153
And when I get to the storage page,
Here's where it's asking me, all right for

129
00:06:11.153 --> 00:06:14.010
the operating system
partition what do I want?

130
00:06:14.010 --> 00:06:16.040
Well, we normally don't care about
that one cuz the operating system

131
00:06:16.040 --> 00:06:17.060
only does so much.

132
00:06:17.060 --> 00:06:21.020
But my data drive,
when I add in my data drive, I can pick.

133
00:06:21.020 --> 00:06:23.110
Do I want to go general purpose and

134
00:06:23.110 --> 00:06:27.660
have limited IO or do I want to
bump that up and do provisioned IO

135
00:06:27.660 --> 00:06:32.970
where now I have a specific amount of
IOs that I'm reserving and I pick.

136
00:06:32.970 --> 00:06:34.930
The way Amazon does it,
if you do general purpose,

137
00:06:34.930 --> 00:06:36.800
your IOPS are determined
by the size of the drives.

138
00:06:36.800 --> 00:06:41.050
So if I bump it up to 100 Gigs,
it's the size of the drive times three.

139
00:06:41.050 --> 00:06:43.060
So I end up with 300 IOPS per second.

140
00:06:43.060 --> 00:06:46.590
If I bump it up to a terabyte, which I'm
not sure if this one will let me do.

141
00:06:46.590 --> 00:06:47.420
It will.

142
00:06:47.420 --> 00:06:48.980
Then I get to 3,000 IOPS per second.

143
00:06:48.980 --> 00:06:52.240
Doesn't matter if I actually
use the whole terabyte.

144
00:06:52.240 --> 00:06:55.220
But what it's doing is associating
a cost with those I/Os.

145
00:06:55.220 --> 00:06:57.930
You pay per gigabyte per month.

146
00:06:57.930 --> 00:07:00.340
So now I'm paying for a terabyte and

147
00:07:00.340 --> 00:07:04.080
I get 3000 I/Os as a result,
even if I'm only using a fraction of it.

148
00:07:04.080 --> 00:07:08.340
Or I could go with Provisioned I/Os and
I could say I just need an 8 gig drive,

149
00:07:08.340 --> 00:07:12.640
I don't need a huge amount of storage,
but I want 3000 IOs for

150
00:07:12.640 --> 00:07:16.030
it, and now it's reserved and
I always get it.

151
00:07:16.030 --> 00:07:17.850
When you do general
purpose you're paying for

152
00:07:17.850 --> 00:07:21.610
what you use, when you do provisioned
IO you're paying for all of it.

153
00:07:21.610 --> 00:07:24.440
I'm paying for all of these
IOs whether I use them or not.

154
00:07:24.440 --> 00:07:26.940
So how do I know if I need to do that?

155
00:07:26.940 --> 00:07:28.860
I don't wanna pay for
it if I don't need it.

156
00:07:28.860 --> 00:07:30.990
We need to be able to monitor it.

157
00:07:30.990 --> 00:07:32.690
Whatever solution it is you deploy.

158
00:07:32.690 --> 00:07:37.190
If you do VMware vSphere and it's all
local, you need to monitor performance.

159
00:07:37.190 --> 00:07:41.290
If you do Microsoft Azure as a hybrid
where some servers are local and

160
00:07:41.290 --> 00:07:45.050
some are up in Azure,
you need to monitor it.

161
00:07:45.050 --> 00:07:47.790
If you do 100% in Amazon AWS
you need to monitor it.

162
00:07:47.790 --> 00:07:49.890
All right?
So no matter how it is you deploy this,

163
00:07:49.890 --> 00:07:53.712
you always need to be monitoring it and
that's kind of the key principle here.

164
00:07:53.712 --> 00:07:54.712
You need to use something.

165
00:07:54.712 --> 00:07:57.046
Well here I'm deployed all in AWS.

166
00:07:57.046 --> 00:07:59.004
Right, so how do I monitor that?

167
00:07:59.004 --> 00:08:00.171
I can use third party software.

168
00:08:00.171 --> 00:08:02.537
I can fire up
Solarwinds Network Performance Monitor or

169
00:08:02.537 --> 00:08:03.500
something like that.

170
00:08:03.500 --> 00:08:05.526
But Amazon is already
monitoring this stuff for me,

171
00:08:05.526 --> 00:08:06.730
cuz they're billing me on it.

172
00:08:06.730 --> 00:08:09.860
So that they've got to monitor it and
they share that data with us.

173
00:08:09.860 --> 00:08:12.490
So with them, I can use CloudWatch.

174
00:08:12.490 --> 00:08:15.811
So if I jump over to CloudWatch,
let me just kinda jump over there.

175
00:08:15.811 --> 00:08:19.330
In CloudWatch, we can start to
see a lot of these metrics.

176
00:08:19.330 --> 00:08:21.620
Amazon's tracking them anyway,
they share them with me.

177
00:08:21.620 --> 00:08:24.240
And if I look in here under metrics,
you'll see EBS,

178
00:08:24.240 --> 00:08:26.670
which is elastic block store,
there's my disk.

179
00:08:26.670 --> 00:08:30.840
And EC2, well, that's elastic compute
cloud, that's my virtual machines.

180
00:08:30.840 --> 00:08:34.650
And if I go into EC2,
I'm gonna see metrics for,

181
00:08:34.650 --> 00:08:37.460
you guys saw I only had
one machine running.

182
00:08:37.460 --> 00:08:40.230
I might have more than one here because
they track like a month's worth of

183
00:08:40.230 --> 00:08:43.520
metrics so I even have machines that
I've deleted will show up in here.

184
00:08:43.520 --> 00:08:46.730
But I can kind of track down my instance

00:19:15.960 --> 00:19:18.570
If the packet's damaged,

00:19:18.570 --> 00:19:21.000

00:19:21.000 --> 00:19:21.910

that's scaling out, adding more servers.

629
00:30:57.380 --> 00:31:00.250
But they call out scaling diagonally.

630
00:31:00.250 --> 00:31:01.540
What the heck is that?

631
00:31:01.540 --> 00:31:05.600
Scaling diagonally is where we add
hardware and servers at the same time.

632
00:31:05.600 --> 00:31:10.460
Maybe I've got a t2.micro with one CPU and
1 gig of RAM.

633
00:31:10.460 --> 00:31:16.090
And I bump it up to a t2.medium
with two CPUs and 4 gigs of RAM.

634
00:31:16.090 --> 00:31:19.310
And at the same time, add another
server that's configured the same way.

635
00:31:19.310 --> 00:31:22.360
So I'm adding more servers and
more hardware at the same time,

636
00:31:22.360 --> 00:31:24.585
I'm scaling diagonally, right?

637
00:31:24.585 --> 00:31:28.170
That's not as common, it's pretty rare and
most people don't even acknowledge it.

638
00:31:28.170 --> 00:31:29.794
But it's on the exam objectives so
you need to know it.

639
00:31:29.794 --> 00:31:32.642
But most of the time we're
scaling vertically, or up, or

640
00:31:32.642 --> 00:31:34.280
scaling horizontally, or out.

641
00:31:34.280 --> 00:31:36.280
Right, those are the two main ones.

642
00:31:36.280 --> 00:31:38.470
Scaling diagonally is when
you do both at the same time.

643
00:31:38.470 --> 00:31:39.720
>> Very good now, guys,

644
00:31:39.720 --> 00:31:43.100
we've talked about a lot of good
information that's gonna ultimately effect

645
00:31:43.100 --> 00:31:46.590
the service that you provide, or
the services that are provided for you.

646
00:31:46.590 --> 00:31:48.582
So definitely pay attention
to things like disks,

647
00:31:48.582 --> 00:31:50.120
pay attention to things like network.

648
00:31:50.120 --> 00:31:54.310
And like Don mentioned, even though we
haven't gone into too much depth on them,

649
00:31:54.310 --> 00:31:56.678
CPU is obviously gonna come into play for
us and

650
00:31:56.678 --> 00:31:59.520
we're gonna have to pay
attention to the memory.

651
00:31:59.520 --> 00:32:01.169
So, thanks to Don for
all of that information.

652
00:32:01.169 --> 00:32:03.200
You got anything else for us on this one?

653
00:32:03.200 --> 00:32:05.379
That's about it,
I know I used AWS for most of this,

654
00:32:05.379 --> 00:32:07.127
in your environment it may be different.

655
00:32:07.127 --> 00:32:10.702
But VMware V-Sphere, Microsoft's Hyper-V,
they've all got methods for

656
00:32:10.702 --> 00:32:14.290
monitoring performance, and the metrics
are usually named the same things.

657
00:32:14.290 --> 00:32:16.000
You might need to check your
vendor documentation though,

658
00:32:16.000 --> 00:32:17.950
sometimes they change
the names of the stuff.

659
00:32:17.950 --> 00:32:19.750
But what you're monitoring
really is the same,

660
00:32:19.750 --> 00:32:22.450
it's the same across all the boards
even though it has a different name.

661
00:32:22.450 --> 00:32:24.980
Well thanks for that, Don, and
thank you guys out there for watching.

662
00:32:24.980 --> 00:32:28.550
So it looks like we come to the end
of another episode here on ITProTV.

663
00:32:28.550 --> 00:32:30.400
So we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for this one.

664
00:32:30.400 --> 00:32:31.590
I've been your host West Bryan.

665
00:32:31.590 --> 00:32:32.480
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

666
00:32:32.480 --> 00:32:35.794
>> And we'll see you next time.

667
00:32:35.794 --> 00:32:42.530
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don explore the techniques that can be used to optimize performance. They talk about the best practices that can be followed to maintain optimal performance like performance baselining, vendor-specific tools as well third party management tools.
episodes.title: Optimizing Performance
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.045 --> 00:00:15.167
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.167 --> 00:00:16.202
I'm your host, Wes Bryant.

4
00:00:16.202 --> 00:00:20.701
And in today's episode, we're going to be
moving along in our Cloud Plus series.

5
00:00:20.701 --> 00:00:24.220
And today, we're going to be looking
at topics that relate to performance.

6
00:00:24.220 --> 00:00:28.700
In past episodes, we talked about
the concepts behind performance, but

7
00:00:28.700 --> 00:00:31.470
we really didn't show you
how do we implement that.

8
00:00:31.470 --> 00:00:34.097
So that's what we're going to be looking
at today, performance optimization,

9
00:00:34.097 --> 00:00:36.650
and we have have none other than Mr.
Don Pezet here to help us out.

10
00:00:36.650 --> 00:00:37.850
Don, how you doing today, sir?

11
00:00:37.850 --> 00:00:38.750
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

12
00:00:38.750 --> 00:00:42.240
Glad to be back on the show and ready to
jump in into the world of performance.

13
00:00:42.240 --> 00:00:45.392
Now like Wes said, in the last
episode it was really conceptual.

14
00:00:45.392 --> 00:00:47.630
We were talking about
these touchy-feely ideas,

15
00:00:47.630 --> 00:00:52.030
you should have good performance,
you shouldn't have bad performance, and

16
00:00:52.030 --> 00:00:54.840
that kind of stuff goes without saying,
but it was important to cover.

17
00:00:54.840 --> 00:00:56.500
It was important that we
knew the terminology, and

18
00:00:56.500 --> 00:01:01.250
we knew those concepts around just
performance in general on our systems.

19
00:01:01.250 --> 00:01:03.575
But in this episode, and then we'll
probably have more than one part,

20
00:01:03.575 --> 00:01:06.020
because it's a lot of material to cover,
what we're going to do

21
00:01:06.020 --> 00:01:08.610
is we're going to take a look at how
we actually apply that to a system and

22
00:01:08.610 --> 00:01:09.990
see some of the different solutions.

23
00:01:09.990 --> 00:01:13.220
So we're going to optimize, remediate.

24
00:01:13.220 --> 00:01:16.639
We're going to look at some issues,
see what we can do to correct them and

25
00:01:16.639 --> 00:01:19.849
improve the performance of our systems,
and do it in a hands on way.

26
00:01:19.849 --> 00:01:24.888
>> One of the things that we have to do
in any type of performance optimization,

27
00:01:24.888 --> 00:01:27.740
we need to know where
do we stand right now.

28
00:01:27.740 --> 00:01:30.400
We don't know if we have to optimize
anything if we don't know where we're

29
00:01:30.400 --> 00:01:31.230
at right now.

30
00:01:31.230 --> 00:01:34.180
And Don, we've got some techniques
that we have to implement in order to

31
00:01:34.180 --> 00:01:35.190
figure out where are we.

32
00:01:35.190 --> 00:01:37.100
>> Absolutely, and
we've touched on it very,

33
00:01:37.100 --> 00:01:41.180
very briefly in an earlier episode
where I talked about baselines.

34
00:01:41.180 --> 00:01:42.830
What the heck is a baseline?

35
00:01:42.830 --> 00:01:45.380
Well it's basically a snapshot,

36
00:01:45.380 --> 00:01:50.170
a report, that shows how your systems
perform under normal work loads.

37
00:01:50.170 --> 00:01:52.700
And the important keyword there is normal.

38
00:01:52.700 --> 00:01:55.840
We need to know what our system is
like when things are running well, so

39
00:01:55.840 --> 00:01:58.640
that when things are running bad,
we can recognize it.

40
00:01:58.640 --> 00:02:01.600
The example I give, you're just not
even thinking of virtualization.

41
00:02:01.600 --> 00:02:02.653
You go and buy a new laptop.

42
00:02:02.653 --> 00:02:05.920
The first day you get it,
you're like, man this laptop is fast.

43
00:02:05.920 --> 00:02:07.590
I love it.
It's great.

44
00:02:07.590 --> 00:02:12.510
But then two years from now, you're
saying, I hate my laptop its so slow.

45
00:02:12.510 --> 00:02:15.340
Well, is it any slower then
when you first got it?

46
00:02:16.440 --> 00:02:19.380
Maybe.
It's hard to say, right?

47
00:02:19.380 --> 00:02:20.660
We don't necessarily have hard numbers.

48
00:02:20.660 --> 00:02:21.820
We have this emotional feeling.

49
00:02:21.820 --> 00:02:23.220
Well I've had the laptop two years now.

50
00:02:23.220 --> 00:02:24.990
I've seen other people's
laptops that are faster,

51
00:02:24.990 --> 00:02:27.260
and that makes me feel
like mine is slower.

52
00:02:27.260 --> 00:02:28.890
But what if you had hard numbers?

53
00:02:28.890 --> 00:02:31.970
Like, hey, here's my disk read and
disk write speeds.

54
00:02:31.970 --> 00:02:33.210
Here's my memory IOD.

55
00:02:33.210 --> 00:02:34.460
Here's my CPU utilization.

56
00:02:34.460 --> 00:02:36.540
Here's what it was like two years ago.

57
00:02:36.540 --> 00:02:37.940
What's it like now?

58
00:02:37.940 --> 00:02:40.770
And you can compare the hard numbers,
and you can know for a fact.

59
00:02:40.770 --> 00:02:41.570
You can look at it and say,

60
00:02:41.570 --> 00:02:45.910
you know what, it's actually running at
the exact same speed it did two years ago.

61
00:02:45.910 --> 00:02:48.980
I just feel like it's going slower
versus actually being slower.

62
00:02:48.980 --> 00:02:50.410
>> So,
one of the things that we can't do, Don,

63
00:02:50.410 --> 00:02:53.370
is just rely on some kind of
subjective feeling that says,

64
00:02:53.370 --> 00:02:56.390
hey, performance is horrible
because I think it is.

65
00:02:56.390 --> 00:02:59.940
We need something that's a little bit more
concrete, something that's a little more

66
00:02:59.940 --> 00:03:03.270
tangible, and we can verify whether
the performance has actually waned or

67
00:03:03.270 --> 00:03:06.760
it's just not performing like it was,
let's say, in the laptop two years ago.

68
00:03:06.760 --> 00:03:09.870
>> Yeah, absolutely, and
once we have those hard numbers,

69
00:03:09.870 --> 00:03:12.810
it's very easy to create
alerts in your system.

70
00:03:12.810 --> 00:03:15.690
They can warn you when you
deviated from that baseline.

71
00:03:15.690 --> 00:03:17.350
But having the baseline is important.

72
00:03:17.350 --> 00:03:21.160
You've got to create a baseline profile
for your production environment.

73
00:03:21.160 --> 00:03:21.710
You have to.

74
00:03:21.710 --> 00:03:25.270
You've got to have one of this things
because otherwise you're just guessing.

75
00:03:25.270 --> 00:03:26.530
I got some calls in from the field.

76
00:03:26.530 --> 00:03:28.430
The user said the system is slow.

77
00:03:28.430 --> 00:03:30.000
What's slow to them?

78
00:03:30.000 --> 00:03:31.000
What's slow to me?

79
00:03:31.000 --> 00:03:32.470
It's different.

80
00:03:32.470 --> 00:03:35.020
We don't necessarily know, so
we've got to create that base line.

81
00:03:35.020 --> 00:03:37.810
Now the hardest part about a base
line is you're measuring stuff that's

82
00:03:37.810 --> 00:03:38.860
running well.

83
00:03:38.860 --> 00:03:41.100
When you're troubleshooting a problem,
you know what to look for.

84
00:03:41.100 --> 00:03:43.820
I've got some disk problems so
let me go grab these disk counters, but

85
00:03:43.820 --> 00:03:47.610
when things are running well, it's kind
of hard to say well what do I measure?

86
00:03:47.610 --> 00:03:49.160
What is as good indicator?

87
00:03:49.160 --> 00:03:51.080
So you've got to be familiar with that.

88
00:03:51.080 --> 00:03:54.340
Understand that whatever
virtualization platform you're using,

89
00:03:54.340 --> 00:03:58.030
whoever manufactured
that platform knows best.

90
00:03:58.030 --> 00:04:02.110
So if you're running VMware ESX,
VMware knows what you should monitor.

91
00:04:02.110 --> 00:04:05.260
And if you're running Hyper V,
Microsoft knows what you should monitor.

92
00:04:05.260 --> 00:04:09.020
If you're running Amazon AWS or
Microsoft Azure, again,

93
00:04:09.020 --> 00:04:13.210
they know what you should monitor and
what your baseline should be.

94
00:04:13.210 --> 00:04:15.170
So my first piece of advice to you is,

95
00:04:15.170 --> 00:04:17.846
if you're ready to create a baseline,
don't just jump right into it.

96
00:04:17.846 --> 00:04:18.500
Go to your vendors.

97
00:04:18.500 --> 00:04:20.990
Go to your vendor documentation.

98
00:04:20.990 --> 00:04:22.360
They all produce great guides.

99
00:04:22.360 --> 00:04:23.690
VMware is one of the best ones here.

100
00:04:23.690 --> 00:04:25.770
I've got it pulled up on my laptop here.

101
00:04:25.770 --> 00:04:28.990
This is the vSphere Monitoring and
Performance Guide.

102
00:04:28.990 --> 00:04:32.370
Via more updates that with this
with every version of vSphere.

103
00:04:32.370 --> 00:04:36.810
So this is the version six guide, but
they have a five five guide, a five one,

104
00:04:36.810 --> 00:04:38.280
a five 0, and all the way back.

105
00:04:38.280 --> 00:04:42.540
I think the first guide that I used
was the 2.0 or something like that.

106
00:04:42.540 --> 00:04:43.790
So it was a while back.

107
00:04:43.790 --> 00:04:45.540
But they've been producing
these guides for a long time,

108
00:04:45.540 --> 00:04:50.220
and what they do is they tell you
how to monitor their systems.

109
00:04:50.220 --> 00:04:54.240
How do you monitor that ESX server to
know that it's running the right way?

110
00:04:54.240 --> 00:04:56.540
What do you need to gather for
your baseline?

111
00:04:56.540 --> 00:04:59.780
And then compare that to what's
running and what you do.

112
00:04:59.780 --> 00:05:02.030
And these guides that, they're free.

113
00:05:02.030 --> 00:05:03.010
They're right on the website.

114
00:05:03.010 --> 00:05:03.680
You just go and get them.

115
00:05:03.680 --> 00:05:06.230
I'll post the link to this in
the show notes with the show.

116
00:05:06.230 --> 00:05:07.570
But what they do is,

117
00:05:07.570 --> 00:05:11.760
they break down that important
part of monitoring your inventory.

118
00:05:11.760 --> 00:05:14.260
We need to monitor
the systems that we've got.

119
00:05:14.260 --> 00:05:17.960
And as we monitor them, now we can start
to recognize when we've got a problem.

120
00:05:17.960 --> 00:05:21.760
And, be aware that there's times where
you want to monitor your host, and

121
00:05:21.760 --> 00:05:24.650
then some times where you
want to monitor your guests.

122
00:05:24.650 --> 00:05:28.350
There's some things that are very
visible from the host side.

123
00:05:28.350 --> 00:05:31.430
There are some things that are only
visible from the guest side.

124
00:05:31.430 --> 00:05:33.110
For example, network bandwidth.

125
00:05:33.110 --> 00:05:35.940
If I am monitoring network
bandwidth from the hosts,

126
00:05:35.940 --> 00:05:39.720
I am seeing the aggregated
bandwidth of all of my guests.

127
00:05:39.720 --> 00:05:42.650
So if I am running out of bandwidth
the hosts will see that, but

128
00:05:42.650 --> 00:05:46.700
it won't necessarily know which of
the VMs it is that's causing that.

129
00:05:46.700 --> 00:05:50.980
But if I monitor inside of the guests,
I can see exactly who's consuming that

130
00:05:50.980 --> 00:05:54.910
bandwidth, and I can even break it down
further to find out what application.

131
00:05:54.910 --> 00:05:57.020
So we'll normally do
a combination of the two.

132
00:05:57.020 --> 00:06:01.110
Monitoring from the inside of the guests,
and monitoring from the host itself.

133
00:06:01.110 --> 00:06:03.730
Now that can be challenging
with some platforms,

134
00:06:03.730 --> 00:06:06.810
like with ESX,
where you can't really log into the host.

135
00:06:06.810 --> 00:06:09.300
It just displays a text-based terminal and
that's it.

136
00:06:09.300 --> 00:06:12.860
So we've got to monitor it with external
software, and VMware vSphere does that.

137
00:06:13.970 --> 00:06:17.580
With Windows as a guest, though, you could
monitor right from inside of the guest, or

138
00:06:17.580 --> 00:06:18.370
Linux as a guest.

139
00:06:18.370 --> 00:06:20.660
You could monitor right from inside of it,
versus the host,

140
00:06:20.660 --> 00:06:21.630
where you may not be able to.

141
00:06:21.630 --> 00:06:24.860
So, you'll have to kind of gauge
that based on your platform.

142
00:06:24.860 --> 00:06:29.160
But they break through and show
everything, what events to monitor for,

143
00:06:29.160 --> 00:06:30.470
what alarms to create,

144
00:06:30.470 --> 00:06:33.080
what automated actions you can
create to alleviate those problems.

145
00:06:33.080 --> 00:06:35.200
It is a wealth of information.

146
00:06:35.200 --> 00:06:38.270
And if you're using VM or ESX,
you should have read this guide.

147
00:06:38.270 --> 00:06:40.330
And if you haven't,
I definitely recommend it.

148
00:06:40.330 --> 00:06:42.040
It's not a terribly long one.

149
00:06:42.040 --> 00:06:44.270
I think it's 170 pages.

150
00:06:44.270 --> 00:06:45.800
You can read it in about a day, and

151
00:06:45.800 --> 00:06:50.290
it'll tell you everything you need to
know about monitoring and optimizing ESX.

152
00:06:50.290 --> 00:06:51.930
VMware does a great job of this.

153
00:06:51.930 --> 00:06:53.140
So do other vendors.

154
00:06:53.140 --> 00:06:55.540
Maybe not as great, so for
example, Microsoft's Hyper-V,

155
00:06:55.540 --> 00:07:00.840
they've got a whole article series
called Tuning for Hyper-V servers.

156
00:07:00.840 --> 00:07:05.180
This is getting your hardware to where
it can run the most optimally, and

157
00:07:05.180 --> 00:07:08.080
then once it's optimized,
you just watch those settings.

158
00:07:08.080 --> 00:07:10.300
Any time you deviate from those
settings you know you've got a problem.

159
00:07:10.300 --> 00:07:11.750
It's very, very straight forward.

160
00:07:11.750 --> 00:07:12.650
And so they go through and

161
00:07:12.650 --> 00:07:16.660
they break all that down,
processor, memory, storage, network.

162
00:07:16.660 --> 00:07:18.310
The four horsemen, as Wes calls them.

163
00:07:18.310 --> 00:07:19.400
Those guys are right there.

164
00:07:19.400 --> 00:07:24.820
How do we tune and optimize our systems,
keep them running smoothly?

165
00:07:24.820 --> 00:07:27.310
And when you jump into some of
these things, like if we take,

166
00:07:27.310 --> 00:07:28.910
I'll do processor, I guess.

167
00:07:28.910 --> 00:07:30.520
When you start breaking in here,

168
00:07:30.520 --> 00:07:35.480
it'll show you the actual performance
counters to watch out for, and

169
00:07:35.480 --> 00:07:37.480
notice these performance
counters that they're tracking.

170
00:07:37.480 --> 00:07:40.330
They're not just tracking
percent processor time,

171
00:07:40.330 --> 00:07:41.996
which we usually monitor in a host.

172
00:07:41.996 --> 00:07:46.297
They're monitoring Hyper-V,
HyperVisor Logical Processor percent,

173
00:07:46.297 --> 00:07:50.040
total run time or, guest run time,
HyperVisor run time.

174
00:07:50.040 --> 00:07:54.830
So you can identify not that just
your CPU is high but, who it is.

175
00:07:54.830 --> 00:07:57.475
Who it is that's consuming
that CPU utilization.

176
00:07:57.475 --> 00:08:02.283
And knowing which counters to monitor
That's the real challenge with this stuff.

177
00:08:02.283 --> 00:08:05.450
How do I know exactly what I
want to monitor and gather?

178
00:08:05.450 --> 00:08:08.850
And so this little article right here,
they break it down.

179
00:08:08.850 --> 00:08:11.730
If we get down in to memory
they break it down there.

180
00:08:11.730 --> 00:08:15.290
Same thing with network and
the other ones, disc io and so on.

181
00:08:15.290 --> 00:08:18.160
Tons of different ways to monitor and
track that performance.

182
00:08:18.160 --> 00:08:22.670
So rule number one, rely on the vendor
of your virtualization platform.

183
00:08:22.670 --> 00:08:25.130
They've got guides that tell
you exactly what to monitor.

184
00:08:25.130 --> 00:08:26.500
You can build you baselines off of that.

185
00:08:26.500 --> 00:08:29.470
You can also optimized and
tune your environment based on that.

186
00:08:29.470 --> 00:08:31.950
So you're not left on your own, right.

187
00:08:31.950 --> 00:08:36.040
Now we're gonna show you in this episode
and in Part II how to actually tweak and

188
00:08:36.040 --> 00:08:38.760
tune these things even if you
didn't have these guides.

189
00:08:38.760 --> 00:08:40.930
But these guides,
they're worth their weight in gold.

Monitor it from the memory standpoint.
