00:26:19.510 --> 00:26:20.610
We'll talk about that later.

576
00:26:20.610 --> 00:26:22.740
But monitor it from
the disk standpoint also.

577
00:26:22.740 --> 00:26:24.420
I wanna know.
I wanna know ahead of time

578
00:26:24.420 --> 00:26:27.660
if that disk is running out of space so
I can take action before it actually does.

579
00:26:27.660 --> 00:26:31.350
>> Would that be something, Don, if you,
I think of some of the old little

580
00:26:31.350 --> 00:26:34.300
SSDs I have,
now we're talking production environment.

581
00:26:34.300 --> 00:26:36.070
So it is a little bit different here.

582
00:26:36.070 --> 00:26:41.620
But like a smaller SSD, where you don't
have to get the $5000 terabyte SSD.

583
00:26:41.620 --> 00:26:45.840
You can get maybe a smaller SSD and
just dedicate it to your page file.

584
00:26:45.840 --> 00:26:47.840
>> You can absolutely.

585
00:26:47.840 --> 00:26:51.340
My rule of thumb is that
generally more drives

586
00:26:51.340 --> 00:26:54.380
perform better than
fewer expensive drives.

587
00:26:54.380 --> 00:27:01.360
Right, so I can get a single four
terabyte 10,000 RPM drive, or

588
00:27:01.360 --> 00:27:06.970
I could get four one terabyte
drives that are 72 hundred RPM.

589
00:27:06.970 --> 00:27:08.210
They're slower, but I've got more of them,

590
00:27:08.210 --> 00:27:11.410
I've got more drives ready to
do work on spinning disks.

591
00:27:11.410 --> 00:27:13.800
On SSD we don't worry about
the RPMs any more, right?

592
00:27:13.800 --> 00:27:18.170
So on SSDs, still having four disks
that are able to do lookups and

593
00:27:18.170 --> 00:27:20.790
access data is gonna be
faster than having one.

594
00:27:20.790 --> 00:27:22.690
And so I'll normally try and get more.

595
00:27:22.690 --> 00:27:27.010
I know we just ordered a network,
a NAS box here, network attached storage.

596
00:27:27.010 --> 00:27:29.860
And we had that option of doing
a bunch of four terabyte drives and

597
00:27:29.860 --> 00:27:31.690
I chose to go with smaller drives.

598
00:27:31.690 --> 00:27:35.480
Smaller drives are more reliable, right,
because the technology's been proven.

599
00:27:35.480 --> 00:27:38.810
But also,
you get more disks doing the work for you,

600
00:27:38.810 --> 00:27:39.880
you get better performance out of it.

601
00:27:39.880 --> 00:27:43.530
So all things we need to consider
when we're dealing with storage.

602
00:27:43.530 --> 00:27:44.500
>> Very good information.

603
00:27:44.500 --> 00:27:47.950
Now keep in mind in this episode,
we've been optimizing performance, right?

604
00:27:47.950 --> 00:27:51.330
In our part two here we've been
looking at the disk performance.

605
00:27:51.330 --> 00:27:53.790
Don, got anything for us in this episode?

606
00:27:53.790 --> 00:27:54.740
>> We haven't touch RAM.

607
00:27:54.740 --> 00:27:55.650
We haven't touch network.

608
00:27:55.650 --> 00:27:57.640
We haven't touch CPU.

609
00:27:57.640 --> 00:28:00.550
So, in our next episode,
we're gonna tackle those guys.

610
00:28:00.550 --> 00:28:01.860
You'll see, it's much the same, right?

611
00:28:01.860 --> 00:28:02.670
You measure your CPU.

612
00:28:02.670 --> 00:28:04.050
You measure your RAM.

613
00:28:04.050 --> 00:28:08.250
And when you've got problems there,
you just to add more to your solution.

614
00:28:08.250 --> 00:28:10.250
But we'll talk about monitoring
those things we can do.

615
00:28:10.250 --> 00:28:12.530
On the network side though,
we're gonna talk about NIC teaming and

616
00:28:12.530 --> 00:28:14.575
some other technology we can
use to optimize our bandwidth.

617
00:28:14.575 --> 00:28:18.030
Definitely stuff to check out so
be sure to tune in for part 3.

618
00:28:18.030 --> 00:28:20.010
>> That's great,
I can't wait to see that information.

619
00:28:20.010 --> 00:28:23.030
But it looks like we've come to the end
of another exciting episode here.

620
00:28:23.030 --> 00:28:25.170
So we're going to go ahead and
sign off here IT Pro TV,

621
00:28:25.170 --> 00:28:26.690
I've been your host Wes Brian.

622
00:28:26.690 --> 00:28:27.560
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

623
00:28:27.560 --> 00:28:29.071
>> And we'll see you next time.

624
00:28:29.071 --> 00:28:36.700
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don continue their discussion on performance optimization. They look at memory performance and the techniques to optimizes memory. They demonstrate concepts such as memory failure, oversubscription and memory ballooning. With networking being a major dependency of cloud computing, Wes and Don will dive into network performance topic like NIC failure, replication, latency and load balancing. They explain common CPU concepts like virtual CPU count and hyperthreading as well as monitoring service performance.
episodes.title: Optimizing Performance Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.068 --> 00:00:14.658
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.658 --> 00:00:15.954
I am your host Wes Bryan, and

4
00:00:15.954 --> 00:00:19.880
in today's episode we're going to be
moving along in our cloud plus training.

5
00:00:19.880 --> 00:00:24.030
And we're actually coming back with a part
three, yes that's right, part three,

6
00:00:24.030 --> 00:00:26.115
of optimizing performance and we got Mr.

7
00:00:26.115 --> 00:00:28.440
Don Pezet on hand to help
us out on this information.

8
00:00:28.440 --> 00:00:30.080
Don, how you're doing,
and welcome back, sir.

9
00:00:30.080 --> 00:00:32.630
I am doing great, Wes, and
glad to be back on the show.

10
00:00:32.630 --> 00:00:34.280
And just to kind of recap,

11
00:00:34.280 --> 00:00:39.080
back in part one, we talked about some
of the general performance counters and

12
00:00:39.080 --> 00:00:42.220
metrics that we need to be watching in our
system for our big four components, right?

13
00:00:42.220 --> 00:00:45.520
Processor, memory, network,
and disk IO, right?

14
00:00:45.520 --> 00:00:48.820
And then in the second part,
we really just focused on disk, and

15
00:00:48.820 --> 00:00:50.030
I wanted to make sure we did that,

16
00:00:50.030 --> 00:00:52.820
that we took a deep dive in there because
disk is normally where your bottleneck is.

17
00:00:52.820 --> 00:00:56.480
So it is usually the common element
when we've got problems on the network.

18
00:00:56.480 --> 00:01:00.600
And we took a look at how to measure that
performance, and take a baseline, and

19
00:01:00.600 --> 00:01:05.370
compare it to newer activity to see if
we've had improvements or regressions or

20
00:01:05.370 --> 00:01:08.290
we're getting bad performance,
and take some actions there.

21
00:01:08.290 --> 00:01:11.320
In this episode, I want to speed
things up just a little bit because

22
00:01:11.320 --> 00:01:14.810
we're gonna take a look at CPU,
memory, and network.

23
00:01:14.810 --> 00:01:18.650
And for the most part, you'll find that
it's really the same exact activity,

24
00:01:18.650 --> 00:01:22.630
that we measure our metrics, the metrics
we talked about way back in part one, and

25
00:01:22.630 --> 00:01:26.930
then any time we have a problem,
we take new metrics and we compare them to

26
00:01:26.930 --> 00:01:29.570
the original, to that base line
to see if we've got a difference.

27
00:01:29.570 --> 00:01:31.000
There's really not much
of a difference there.

28
00:01:31.000 --> 00:01:32.820
We've already talked about the counters,
the application,

29
00:01:32.820 --> 00:01:37.020
the principle's the same, but I want to
run through a few different scenarios

30
00:01:37.020 --> 00:01:39.760
of when you might have problems
in certain areas, all right?

31
00:01:39.760 --> 00:01:44.060
So we're going to take a look at CPU,
network, and memory RAM, right?

32
00:01:44.060 --> 00:01:45.320
Kind of an important one there.

33
00:01:45.320 --> 00:01:46.710
And each of the different kind of

34
00:01:46.710 --> 00:01:48.740
pit falls that we see in
a virtualized environment.

35
00:01:48.740 --> 00:01:51.890
>> One of the first things we think about
when we think, wel, I think about memory,

36
00:01:51.890 --> 00:01:55.530
is well, do we have enough memory,
right, Don?

37
00:01:55.530 --> 00:01:59.580
How many virtual machines we have
versus how much RAM does the host have.

38
00:01:59.580 --> 00:02:02.980
And when it comes down to it, I mean,
that's not the only consideration, right?

39
00:02:02.980 --> 00:02:06.740
It's not just about how much of the RAM
you have, but it's also about how

40
00:02:06.740 --> 00:02:11.575
the machines are or are not effectively
performing with that memory, right?

41
00:02:11.575 --> 00:02:14.705
>> Absolutely, and I think I even
said this in an earlier episode,

42
00:02:14.705 --> 00:02:17.455
is that a lot of times, we can throw
money at a problem and solve it.

43
00:02:17.455 --> 00:02:20.125
And so if you're running out of memory,
you can just add more memory, and

44
00:02:20.125 --> 00:02:21.725
your problem is solved, right?

45
00:02:21.725 --> 00:02:24.375
But the reality of the story is that
there is a maximum amount of memory

46
00:02:24.375 --> 00:02:25.625
a server can have.

47
00:02:25.625 --> 00:02:28.690
And usually to get high
quantities of memory,

48
00:02:28.690 --> 00:02:30.260
you have to have a lot
of sticks of memory.

49
00:02:30.260 --> 00:02:32.380
So you'll have a lot of actual slots.

50
00:02:32.380 --> 00:02:35.830
When you take your average desktop
computer, it might have two, three, or

51
00:02:35.830 --> 00:02:38.140
four slots for RAM sticks, right?

52
00:02:38.140 --> 00:02:40.650
But when you take a server,
it may have eight.

53
00:02:40.650 --> 00:02:44.120
If it's a really high end server,
it may have 16 slots for RAM sticks.

54
00:02:44.120 --> 00:02:48.040
And if you have 16sticks of
RAM inside of your server,

55
00:02:48.040 --> 00:02:51.680
you've got a much higher
chance of having failed memory

56
00:02:51.680 --> 00:02:54.120
than if you've only got two
sticks of memory in there, right?

57
00:02:54.120 --> 00:02:55.790
It's just more common for that to happen.

58
00:02:55.790 --> 00:02:58.900
You've got more parts in the equation.

59
00:02:58.900 --> 00:03:02.170
And most of us never have to deal with
memory failure, but it does happen, right?

60
00:03:02.170 --> 00:03:04.000
And usually it happens right away.

61
00:03:04.000 --> 00:03:07.000
You install some new memory and it's dead,
dead on arrival, and that's it.

62
00:03:07.000 --> 00:03:11.527
But memory is so sensitive to things like
electrostatic discharge that it can fail

63
00:03:11.527 --> 00:03:13.890
over time and memory can run hot.

64
00:03:13.890 --> 00:03:17.130
Now in a server there's all sorts of
things that can generate heat, and

65
00:03:17.130 --> 00:03:19.938
if you create that perfect storm
of heat in inside of a server,

66
00:03:19.938 --> 00:03:23.245
it starts to cook and memory is usually
one of the first things to suffer.

67
00:03:23.245 --> 00:03:25.045
It's not very tolerant of heat.

68
00:03:25.045 --> 00:03:27.525
Your CPU actually has
pretty high tolerances.

69
00:03:27.525 --> 00:03:29.705
Your hard drives usually
have high tolerances, but

70
00:03:29.705 --> 00:03:32.265
RAM is usually the one
that's the least giving.

71
00:03:32.265 --> 00:03:35.215
And so you can have memory fail, and
that's why when you look at your servers,

72
00:03:35.215 --> 00:03:38.295
when you pick something like some
of the higher end HP ProLiants,

73
00:03:38.295 --> 00:03:39.775
they have redundant RAM.

74
00:03:39.775 --> 00:03:42.630
It's actually pretty amazing stuff
where you can have two banks of memory

75
00:03:42.630 --> 00:03:44.010
that are clones of each other.

76
00:03:44.010 --> 00:03:46.710
And if it starts picking up failures
on one, it can switch to the other.

77
00:03:46.710 --> 00:03:48.280
It's pretty neat stuff.

78
00:03:48.280 --> 00:03:50.790
There's memory that actually has
error-checking built into it,

79
00:03:50.790 --> 00:03:54.210
ECC memory, right, where it's doing
parity checks, just like with RAID.

80
00:03:54.210 --> 00:03:55.680
And that can happen too.

81
00:03:55.680 --> 00:03:59.890
The biggest challenge with all of this is
it's very hard to see it coming, right?

82
00:03:59.890 --> 00:04:02.630
I showed you a bunch of performance
counters for monitoring memory, but

83
00:04:02.630 --> 00:04:05.710
if I start to have memory failures,
performance counters don't show that.

84
00:04:05.710 --> 00:04:09.260
I mean, I might start seeing that I get
latency, that it takes longer to read and

85
00:04:09.260 --> 00:04:11.080
write from memory because
we're having to do retrys.

86
00:04:11.080 --> 00:04:13.480
So we might see suffering
in performance there, but

87
00:04:13.480 --> 00:04:17.010
if the memory has failed,
that doesn't necessarily show up, and

88
00:04:17.010 --> 00:04:19.910
that's where we have to rely
on our third party vendors.

89
00:04:19.910 --> 00:04:22.721
You know Dell has their whole
management software solution,

90
00:04:22.721 --> 00:04:24.298
you can install manager servers.

91
00:04:24.298 --> 00:04:28.073
HP has their insight software where you
can manage the servers, and they'll

92
00:04:28.073 --> 00:04:32.680
actually do hardware checks to validate
that you're not suffering from a failure.

93
00:04:32.680 --> 00:04:34.650
On a performance side, though,
we usually just see sagging performance,

94
00:04:34.650 --> 00:04:35.809
because we're having
to do a lot of retrys.

95
00:04:35.809 --> 00:04:38.260
Same thing goes for failing hard drives.

96
00:04:38.260 --> 00:04:44.460
If a hard drive fails out right,
there we go, then we might see suffering

97
00:04:44.460 --> 00:04:47.410
performance because we're running
on redundant copies of the storage.

98
00:04:47.410 --> 00:04:52.060
But if it's a mirror and one drive fails,
we probably won't notice that at all.

99
00:04:52.060 --> 00:04:55.650
So you've gotta combine your performance
monitoring with your hardware monitoring

100
00:04:55.650 --> 00:04:59.250
also, and there's a number of third
party solutions out there that do it.

101
00:04:59.250 --> 00:05:03.580
Your guest operating systems, though, and
your host operating systems like VMWare

102
00:05:03.580 --> 00:05:08.510
and Hyper-V running on Windows or
KVM running on Red Hat, they don't do

103
00:05:08.510 --> 00:05:10.910
the hardware checking because they're
not the hardware manufacturers.

104
00:05:10.910 --> 00:05:12.140
They don't have that ability to check it,

105
00:05:12.140 --> 00:05:14.430
and that's why we've got to
rely on third party software.

106
00:05:14.430 --> 00:05:15.830
>> So Don, I'm gonna jump out and

107
00:05:15.830 --> 00:05:18.550
I'm gonna throw a question at
you before we even get started.

108
00:05:18.550 --> 00:05:21.670
So with memory inconsistencies,
right, memory problems,

109
00:05:21.670 --> 00:05:23.530
I should say the inconsistencies.

110
00:05:23.530 --> 00:05:25.190
Sometimes you see memory problems.

111
00:05:25.190 --> 00:05:26.310
Maybe sometimes they're not there.

112
00:05:26.310 --> 00:05:29.610
Is this something that you would have
to maybe do a trending analysis,

113
00:05:29.610 --> 00:05:33.760
you know, over the course of time just to
kind of trouble shoot what's happening?

114
00:05:33.760 --> 00:05:35.620
>> You can, it's tough, right,

115
00:05:35.620 --> 00:05:38.800
because some of the stuff doesn't
have a correlation with performance.

116
00:05:38.800 --> 00:05:43.110
So if it's a memory error for, example,
a memory error will only show up

117
00:05:43.110 --> 00:05:46.360
when you're writing to that particular
bit of memory where there's a problem.

118
00:05:46.360 --> 00:05:48.720
And memory writes
are generally semi-random.

119
00:05:48.720 --> 00:05:51.210
They kind of write all over
the place on the memory stick.

120
00:05:51.210 --> 00:05:55.190
So you might only hit that error once
every 8 days, or once every 15 days.

121
00:05:55.190 --> 00:05:57.410
And it might not be every 15 days.

122
00:05:57.410 --> 00:06:00.930
It might happen on Tuesday, and did not
happen again until the next Monday, and

123
00:06:00.930 --> 00:06:03.120
then it happens again,
right away on Wednesday.

124
00:06:03.120 --> 00:06:04.800
It can be variations, right?

125
00:06:04.800 --> 00:06:07.340
Intermittent problems are really
hard to troubleshoot, and

126
00:06:07.340 --> 00:06:08.820
that's why we need that
third-party software.

127
00:06:08.820 --> 00:06:10.340
It's really important, okay?

128
00:06:10.340 --> 00:06:14.060
So if you wanna learn more about these,
the exam doesn't drive too much into them,

129
00:06:14.060 --> 00:06:15.810
other than the fact that you
really need to have them.

130
00:06:15.810 --> 00:06:17.800
But like HP's system insight manager,

131
00:06:17.800 --> 00:06:20.020
it is one of the most common
ones that's out there.

132
00:06:20.020 --> 00:06:21.900
Most of the vendors make it available for
free.

133
00:06:21.900 --> 00:06:25.290
So, Dell's is free, HP's is free.

134
00:06:25.290 --> 00:06:28.612
You install it, it reaches out and
it monitors all of your servers.

135
00:06:28.612 --> 00:06:31.850
It uses SNMP and agents that
are installed on the servers themselves

136
00:06:31.850 --> 00:06:34.102
to track that hardware health,
and that's really important.

137
00:06:34.102 --> 00:06:37.670
With RAM we usually only have
two things to worry about,

138
00:06:37.670 --> 00:06:40.050
one, having enough of it,
and two, hardware failures.

139
00:06:40.050 --> 00:06:41.910
It's really pretty simple, and

140
00:06:41.910 --> 00:06:45.100
having enough of it is just a matter
of monitoring performance, right?

141
00:06:45.100 --> 00:06:47.740
And we saw the performance counters
in an earlier episode, but

142
00:06:47.740 --> 00:06:48.810
we just need to check that out.

143
00:06:48.810 --> 00:06:51.090
Now, I will mention a few other
things when in comes to RAM.

144
00:06:52.450 --> 00:06:56.350
One problem is that a lot of
virtualization products out there offer

145
00:06:56.350 --> 00:06:58.460
neat ways to optimize your memory, and

146
00:06:58.460 --> 00:07:01.870
it's almost all not intended
to be used in production.

147
00:07:01.870 --> 00:07:07.990
So one of the ones I talked about
earlier was a memory oversubscription,

148
00:07:07.990 --> 00:07:11.980
where our virtual machines require
more memory than our host has, right?

149
00:07:11.980 --> 00:07:13.710
It's called memory ballooning.

150
00:07:13.710 --> 00:07:14.870
Think of a balloon.

151
00:07:14.870 --> 00:07:17.550
You can inflate a balloon and
you can deflate a balloon, right?

152
00:07:17.550 --> 00:07:19.860
So you can fill it up with
the volume of air that you need.

153
00:07:19.860 --> 00:07:21.500
Well, that's kind of how
a virtual machine is.

154
00:07:21.500 --> 00:07:23.690
When you give a virtual
machine 8 gigs of RAM,

155
00:07:23.690 --> 00:07:26.190
does it need 8 gigs of RAM right then?

156
00:07:26.190 --> 00:07:28.600
Not necessarily, if it just booted up,
it might only need 1 gig of ram.

157
00:07:28.600 --> 00:07:32.170
And then over time it might grow and
contract,

158
00:07:32.170 --> 00:07:36.390
this elasticity we have, for
just certain amounts of memory.

159
00:07:36.390 --> 00:07:39.220
So what we can do is
we can give a variable

160
00:07:39.220 --> 00:07:41.360
amount of memory to our virtual machines.

161
00:07:41.360 --> 00:07:42.390
And if you do that,

162
00:07:42.390 --> 00:07:47.280
you can actually give your VMs more
memory than the host itself has, right?

163
00:07:47.280 --> 00:07:49.237
And I know that sounds like a bad idea.

164
00:07:49.237 --> 00:07:51.001
It's not necessarily a bad idea.

165
00:07:51.001 --> 00:07:52.998
It's a bad idea in production.

166
00:07:52.998 --> 00:07:57.224
If I give a machine eight gigs of ram and
it's Fake memory, right?

167
00:07:57.224 --> 00:08:00.955
Expandable memory, then that machine could
potentially get eight gigs of ram and

168
00:08:00.955 --> 00:08:02.690
it could potentially not get it.

169
00:08:02.690 --> 00:08:05.990
It could try and get that memory and not
have it available and what's gonna happen?

170
00:08:05.990 --> 00:08:07.448
We're gonna page it out to disk, right?

171
00:08:07.448 --> 00:08:10.473
Page it to the hard drive, and
as soon as we start swapping to disk,

172
00:08:10.473 --> 00:08:12.324
we get a performance decrease, right?

separation of duties, and you don't have

00:38:50.060 --> 00:38:53.410
people with a vested interest in saying
software is secure when it isn't.

850
00:38:53.410 --> 00:38:56.020
We'll want to make sure that we have an
independent body that's actually scanning

851
00:38:56.020 --> 00:38:56.650
and studying that.

852
00:38:56.650 --> 00:38:59.590
>> So that gets us closer to
the traditional black box testing

853
00:38:59.590 --> 00:39:00.470
versus the white box.

854
00:39:00.470 --> 00:39:02.290
Don't have any information
about the system,

855
00:39:02.290 --> 00:39:04.560
or very little information
about the system.

856
00:39:04.560 --> 00:39:08.620
So you know that if they do make it in,
they've had to find out what everybody

857
00:39:08.620 --> 00:39:11.440
else could find out, and
how about the IT admin that says, yeah,

858
00:39:11.440 --> 00:39:14.930
I was gonna fix that next week if that's
the same person that's doing the testing.

859
00:39:14.930 --> 00:39:17.540
>> And it's still okay for
them to do the testing too, but

860
00:39:17.540 --> 00:39:19.890
you don't want them to be
the only ones doing the testing.

861
00:39:19.890 --> 00:39:22.620
You could have that disgruntled
internal employee anyway

862
00:39:22.620 --> 00:39:25.070
who would have that insider information
that's something to worry about.

863
00:39:25.070 --> 00:39:27.860
But you always want to
have that outside opinion.

864
00:39:27.860 --> 00:39:30.480
And it doesn't necessarily have to
be somebody outside the company but

865
00:39:30.480 --> 00:39:32.690
outside as far as the management
of that software.

866
00:39:32.690 --> 00:39:36.240
>> In optimizing and performance
we've looked at a lot of concepts.

867
00:39:36.240 --> 00:39:41.210
Remember that, go back and review the
first two portions, part one and part two.

868
00:39:41.210 --> 00:39:43.880
This is the part three we've
looked at our big four, right?

869
00:39:43.880 --> 00:39:48.850
The four horseman, CPU, we've looked at
RAM, we've looked at our hard disc and,

870
00:39:48.850 --> 00:39:52.220
well disc storage if you will, and
we've also looked at networking.

871
00:39:52.220 --> 00:39:54.130
We've also looked at the services,
you know,

872
00:39:54.130 --> 00:39:56.870
not only the resource consumption but
the services that are provided.

873
00:39:56.870 --> 00:39:58.670
Don, got anything else for us on this one?

874
00:39:58.670 --> 00:39:59.540
>> That's about it.

875
00:39:59.540 --> 00:40:01.460
Now some of the topics we talked about,
like redundancy,

876
00:40:01.460 --> 00:40:03.920
we are going to revisit in
the disaster recovery episodes.

877
00:40:03.920 --> 00:40:05.320
So be sure to check those out.

878
00:40:05.320 --> 00:40:07.170
But otherwise there is a lot to monitor,

879
00:40:07.170 --> 00:40:10.660
a lot of keep your thumb on
the pulse of your network.

880
00:40:10.660 --> 00:40:11.635
You got to keep an eye on all of it.

881
00:40:11.635 --> 00:40:13.905
Because any one piece could
cause a cascading failure.

882
00:40:13.905 --> 00:40:15.845
>> All right, well thank you for
all that information.

883
00:40:15.845 --> 00:40:19.285
It looks like we've come to the end of
another exciting episode here at ITProTV.

884
00:40:19.285 --> 00:40:21.595
So we're going to go ahead and
sign off today.

885
00:40:21.595 --> 00:40:22.985
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

886
00:40:22.985 --> 00:40:23.645
>> And I'm Don Pizet.

887
00:40:23.645 --> 00:40:27.350
>> And we'll see you next time.

888
00:40:27.350 --> 00:40:33.800
>> [NOISE]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don explore concepts related to maintaining business continuity through disaster recovery. They look at recovery time objective, recovery point objective mean time between failure and mean time to repair. They identify redundency and fault tolerance techniques such as high availability,local clustering and geolocation.
episodes.title: Disaster Recovery
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.877 --> 00:00:16.326
Welcome back to another exciting episode
here at ITProTV, I'm your host Wes Bryan,

3
00:00:16.326 --> 00:00:20.587
and in today's episode we're going to be
moving along in our Cloud Plus series and

4
00:00:20.587 --> 00:00:23.951
we're gonna be looking at some
Business continuity concepts.

5
00:00:23.951 --> 00:00:27.950
It is very, very important to make sure
that if something happens, right, some

6
00:00:27.950 --> 00:00:31.540
kind of disaster happens to your company
that your company can survive that.

7
00:00:31.540 --> 00:00:35.870
So, today's episode is gonna be
all about disaster recovery and

8
00:00:35.870 --> 00:00:38.690
we got none other than Mr.
Don Pezet here to help us out.

9
00:00:38.690 --> 00:00:39.940
Don, how are you doing today sir?

10
00:00:39.940 --> 00:00:41.100
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

11
00:00:41.100 --> 00:00:44.891
Ready to face disaster with optimism and
[LAUGH] jump into this.

12
00:00:44.891 --> 00:00:47.145
We are gonna focus a little
bit on concepts and

13
00:00:47.145 --> 00:00:50.822
theory here in the beginning but then
I want to show you guys some practical

14
00:00:50.822 --> 00:00:54.170
examples of how we can build
disaster recovery into our solution.

15
00:00:54.170 --> 00:00:58.633
And the key thing here is that when
a failure occurs inside of your cloud it

16
00:00:58.633 --> 00:01:01.134
shouldn't down your service, right?

17
00:01:01.134 --> 00:01:04.142
The whole point of having a cloud is
having all of these amazing resources at

18
00:01:04.142 --> 00:01:05.270
your disposal.

19
00:01:05.270 --> 00:01:09.180
And they are if you know how to use
them and if you take advantage of them.

20
00:01:09.180 --> 00:01:10.190
If you don't,

21
00:01:10.190 --> 00:01:13.530
your system is just as weak in the cloud
as it would be on physical servers.

22
00:01:13.530 --> 00:01:15.670
You can still have similar
points of failure and

23
00:01:15.670 --> 00:01:17.680
you've got to plan around that and
optimize your network.

24
00:01:17.680 --> 00:01:19.010
So we're gonna get
a chance to see that and

25
00:01:19.010 --> 00:01:21.260
I'll just show you a few different
examples that are out there.

26
00:01:21.260 --> 00:01:24.660
But there's tons of different ways to do
it if you just take the time to figure out

27
00:01:24.660 --> 00:01:28.040
what are the capabilities of your system,
so that's what we're gonna look at here.

28
00:01:28.040 --> 00:01:30.630
>> You know, one of the things that comes
to mind right away is well you know I

29
00:01:30.630 --> 00:01:31.880
could always pay two providers.

30
00:01:31.880 --> 00:01:35.320
I could have a single cloud provider, and
then you know if I need fail override,

31
00:01:35.320 --> 00:01:37.030
I could have another cloud provider.

32
00:01:37.030 --> 00:01:38.070
Why wouldn't that work?

33
00:01:38.070 --> 00:01:39.770
And the first thing that
comes to mind on that one

34
00:01:39.770 --> 00:01:41.780
is just the sheer expense of that.

35
00:01:41.780 --> 00:01:43.990
>> Well, and for
some people it's worth it.

36
00:01:43.990 --> 00:01:45.070
Think Apple, right?

37
00:01:45.070 --> 00:01:47.120
So Apple has their iCloud service.

38
00:01:47.120 --> 00:01:49.820
And if you use iCloud,
you just see it as one service.

39
00:01:49.820 --> 00:01:50.530
But on the backend,

40
00:01:50.530 --> 00:01:53.690
Apple doesn't have a data center
big enough to power iCloud, yet.

41
00:01:53.690 --> 00:01:55.070
Apparently they're building them, right?

42
00:01:55.070 --> 00:01:56.420
Those giant spaceship things.

43
00:01:56.420 --> 00:02:02.040
But, for now iCloud resides entirely on
Amazon Web Services, and Microsoft Azure.

44
00:02:02.040 --> 00:02:03.850
They've split it across the two providers.

45
00:02:03.850 --> 00:02:07.520
And that way if Amazon completely fails,
they just flip right over to Azure.

46
00:02:07.520 --> 00:02:08.980
And if Azure completely fails,

47
00:02:08.980 --> 00:02:11.670
they'd flip right over to Amazon and
they can disperse across both of them.

48
00:02:11.670 --> 00:02:14.860
You can achieve those, plenty of
independent companies who do that.

49
00:02:14.860 --> 00:02:19.420
Or you can do a hybrid of your own, where
part of your service runs up in Azure and

50
00:02:19.420 --> 00:02:22.580
the other part runs on your local
servers right in the facility with you.

51
00:02:22.580 --> 00:02:24.500
That's perfectly fine, right?

52
00:02:24.500 --> 00:02:27.620
You could even do it where
it wasn't that complex.

53
00:02:27.620 --> 00:02:31.320
Where 100% of your infrastructure
run in the building with you.

54
00:02:31.320 --> 00:02:36.200
But then you had replicas store up in
a cloud somewhere that you can spin up

55
00:02:36.200 --> 00:02:37.110
when needed.

56
00:02:37.110 --> 00:02:40.980
So for example Microsoft has their
Microsoft Azure Site Recovery product

57
00:02:40.980 --> 00:02:43.680
where you run all your servers and
your cloud locally.

58
00:02:43.680 --> 00:02:45.870
You have a private cloud,
your own systems.

59
00:02:45.870 --> 00:02:48.570
And then you back it up to them.

60
00:02:48.570 --> 00:02:52.150
And the cool part about this is when you
back up to them, your servers aren't

61
00:02:52.150 --> 00:02:55.240
actually running up Azure,
it's really just storing copies of them.

62
00:02:55.240 --> 00:02:58.070
And if you ever have a failure locally,
if your servers die or

63
00:02:58.070 --> 00:03:02.060
your whole facility gets destroyed,
you just reach out to Azure.

64
00:03:02.060 --> 00:03:04.930
You log into their website and
you activate your site recovery.

65
00:03:04.930 --> 00:03:05.470
And it turns on.

66
00:03:05.470 --> 00:03:08.914
All your servers come up in Azure, and
you're in the cloud, you're out there in

67
00:03:08.914 --> 00:03:12.225
the public cloud and your systems are back
on line just like that, all right.

68
00:03:12.225 --> 00:03:17.400
This is a way we can leverage cloud
services to achieve an off site back up.

69
00:03:17.400 --> 00:03:20.870
And, we've done this for years, when you
had physical service you backed the tape,

70
00:03:20.870 --> 00:03:23.520
you had the tapes, and
you shipped them offsite somewhere, right?

71
00:03:23.520 --> 00:03:24.800
And when a failure happened,
what did you have to do?

72
00:03:24.800 --> 00:03:27.011
You had to call whoever
was storing you tapes and

73
00:03:27.011 --> 00:03:29.360
say, I need to get those tapes back.

74
00:03:29.360 --> 00:03:32.810
And an hour or two later they come driving
up, and here's your tapes back, and

75
00:03:32.810 --> 00:03:34.280
now you get to start restoring them.

76
00:03:34.280 --> 00:03:36.204
But if your site was destroyed,
what are you restoring to?

77
00:03:36.204 --> 00:03:38.230
Not that site.

78
00:03:38.230 --> 00:03:39.420
You've got to go get a new building.

79
00:03:39.420 --> 00:03:40.750
You've got to go get new servers.

80
00:03:40.750 --> 00:03:41.300
You've got to get new racks.

81
00:03:41.300 --> 00:03:43.230
There's all sorts of stuff.

82
00:03:43.230 --> 00:03:47.961
So an offsite backup is good, but it's
gonna take a long time to recover, right?

83
00:03:47.961 --> 00:03:50.261
Because you've got to get a new facility,
and that's a lot of work.

84
00:03:50.261 --> 00:03:53.943
Well, you can have remote locations
that are already ready for

85
00:03:53.943 --> 00:03:57.916
you like a hot site or cold site or
whatever but those are expensive.

86
00:03:57.916 --> 00:04:02.209
Leveraging a cloud like this, we get that
protection and we get replication of

87
00:04:02.209 --> 00:04:06.648
virtual machines so we can spin-up our
VM's in the cloud in a moment's notice.

88
00:04:06.648 --> 00:04:09.900
The hardwares, they're waiting for
us, so we're not paying for it.

89
00:04:09.900 --> 00:04:12.800
Cuz with the cloud service like this,
you only pay for what you use.

90
00:04:12.800 --> 00:04:15.770
So its a great way to mix the two
technologies to create a hybrid

91
00:04:15.770 --> 00:04:16.813
a solution, right?

92
00:04:16.813 --> 00:04:20.641
Now there's challenges with this, but I'm
going to talk about it as we go through

93
00:04:20.641 --> 00:04:23.230
the series,
like how replication and so on.

94
00:04:23.230 --> 00:04:26.769
But the idea of having that offsite
backup is really, really valuable.

95
00:04:27.920 --> 00:04:31.210
The first concept I want to talk about
though when we start to use a service like

96
00:04:31.210 --> 00:04:37.900
this is what's called our RTO and
RPO, our recovery time objective,

97
00:04:37.900 --> 00:04:42.780
and our recovery point objective.

98
00:04:42.780 --> 00:04:44.480
When you have a failure on the network,

99
00:04:45.500 --> 00:04:48.280
how long does it take you
to get back online again?

100
00:04:48.280 --> 00:04:49.960
My recovery time.

101
00:04:49.960 --> 00:04:52.150
So if I've got a network
that I'm doing backups.

102
00:04:52.150 --> 00:04:56.330
Notice here, I've got kind of a full
back up happening Monday at midnight.

103
00:04:56.330 --> 00:04:59.950
And then at 6 AM we're doing
a differential back up, and

104
00:04:59.950 --> 00:05:02.180
then at noon we do a differential back up,
and

105
00:05:02.180 --> 00:05:05.160
then at 6 PM we do a differential back up,
and then at midnight we do another full.

106
00:05:05.160 --> 00:05:07.040
So that's my backup schedule.

107
00:05:07.040 --> 00:05:11.040
So I'm doing a backup every six hours,
and if I have a failure.

108
00:05:11.040 --> 00:05:13.480
So let's say that
the network goes down and

109
00:05:13.480 --> 00:05:16.660
I have a failure right
here at 23:00 hours.

110
00:05:16.660 --> 00:05:18.980
So at 11pm I have a failure.

111
00:05:18.980 --> 00:05:23.380
Well when that happens how long
does it take me to restore?

112
00:05:23.380 --> 00:05:27.330
If I've got to call somebody from
offsite to bring me my tapes, and

113
00:05:27.330 --> 00:05:31.390
then I've got to get the tapes and start
running the restore process, it might take

114
00:05:31.390 --> 00:05:36.120
me an hour to get the tapes, it might
take me an hour to prepare a new servers.

115
00:05:36.120 --> 00:05:38.670
It might take another two
hours to restore from tape, so

116
00:05:38.670 --> 00:05:42.550
now I've got a four hour window that it
took me to get those servers back online.

117
00:05:42.550 --> 00:05:46.170
That's my recovery time objective,
my RTO, all right.

118
00:05:46.170 --> 00:05:50.660
Now If I had used something like Azure's
site recovery, I have a failure.

119
00:05:50.660 --> 00:05:54.180
I log into Azure's web portal,
I activate those servers.

120
00:05:54.180 --> 00:05:56.100
My recovery time is five minutes,
ten minutes.

121
00:05:56.100 --> 00:05:59.160
Whatever it takes for
me to see the problem and then go and

122
00:05:59.160 --> 00:06:00.500
click the button, right?

123
00:06:00.500 --> 00:06:02.880
So you can shrink that RTO really small.

124
00:06:02.880 --> 00:06:05.520
Now what is your RTO?

125
00:06:05.520 --> 00:06:06.760
The short answer is I don't know.

126
00:06:06.760 --> 00:06:09.750
And the long answer might be that
you don't know either, right?

127
00:06:09.750 --> 00:06:12.700
It's not normally something
the IT guy determines.

128
00:06:12.700 --> 00:06:15.030
As an IT guy, we know the minimum RTO.

129
00:06:15.030 --> 00:06:18.570
I know the minimum amount of time it's
gonna take me to bring the system back up.

130
00:06:18.570 --> 00:06:21.470
So if I know I'm going to have to go to
tape, I know this is going to be a minimum

131
00:06:21.470 --> 00:06:23.850
of four hours and
it could be longer if I have problems.

132
00:06:23.850 --> 00:06:26.350
Maybe I have a bad tape, and
now I've got to deal with that.

133
00:06:26.350 --> 00:06:28.150
So it could be even longer.

134
00:06:28.150 --> 00:06:30.100
I just know the minimum, right?

135
00:06:30.100 --> 00:06:33.660
The maximum, that's going to be
determined by your executives.

136
00:06:33.660 --> 00:06:35.120
The people who run your business.

137
00:06:35.120 --> 00:06:36.880
So for example, I used to work for a bank.

138
00:06:36.880 --> 00:06:39.280
And we were FDIC insured.

139
00:06:39.280 --> 00:06:41.289
And the FDIC had this rule, and

140
00:06:41.289 --> 00:06:45.627
it said that your bank could not
be closed for more than 72 hours.

141
00:06:45.627 --> 00:06:50.450
And that meant three days,
we could be closed for three days.

142
00:06:50.450 --> 00:06:54.320
So if I had a failure,
if a system went down, I had three days,

143
00:06:54.320 --> 00:06:55.700
that timer started clicking.

144
00:06:55.700 --> 00:06:59.580
And if we were still closed at the end
of three days, the FDIC would come and

145
00:06:59.580 --> 00:07:00.340
take us over.

146
00:07:00.340 --> 00:07:02.407
They would take over operations
of your bank, right?

147
00:07:02.407 --> 00:07:05.150
So that was our window,
that's what we had.

148
00:07:05.150 --> 00:07:08.460
Now, I knew my RTO was
really like four hours.

149
00:07:08.460 --> 00:07:10.540
I can get the system back on very,
very quickly.

150
00:07:10.540 --> 00:07:13.618
We didn't need 72 hours, but
that was the window we had.

151
00:07:13.618 --> 00:07:18.310
So your RTO is really going to be
determined by your governing policies,

152
00:07:18.310 --> 00:07:21.310
whatever it is that dictates how
your company does business and

153
00:07:21.310 --> 00:07:23.130
it's usually the executives.

154
00:07:23.130 --> 00:07:26.270
We need to plan our backup
technologies around that.

155
00:07:26.270 --> 00:07:30.810
If your RTO is 15 minutes,
hey this is a mission critical service,

156
00:07:30.810 --> 00:07:33.290
maybe it's a hospital right, and
it's doling out medications and

157
00:07:33.290 --> 00:07:36.680
it can't be down more than 15 minutes,
can you use back up tapes?

158
00:07:36.680 --> 00:07:38.835
No you can't even use index a back
up tape in 15 minutes better yet

159
00:07:38.835 --> 00:07:39.576
restore data from it.

160
00:07:39.576 --> 00:07:42.791
So tape's just out of the picture, right?

161
00:07:42.791 --> 00:07:46.770
Azure Site Recovery though,
you could spin it up in moments, right?

162
00:07:46.770 --> 00:07:50.300
And I use Azure Site Recover, we could
use Amazon Web Services, or Rackspace, or

163
00:07:50.300 --> 00:07:51.720
any any number of
different systems to do it.

164
00:07:51.720 --> 00:07:52.828
We could use our own
private systems to do it.

165
00:07:52.828 --> 00:07:56.671
Having that replica somewhere that
we can spin up at a moment's notice,

166
00:07:56.671 --> 00:07:59.067
that's how we get a 15 minute RTO, right?

167
00:07:59.067 --> 00:08:02.282
So we've gotta plan for
that recovery time objective.

168
00:08:02.282 --> 00:08:05.269
The other concept that goes
hand in hand with this is RPO,

169
00:08:05.269 --> 00:08:07.540
recovery point objective.

170
00:08:07.540 --> 00:08:12.140
When I have a failure,
I'm gonna lose data, that happens, right?

171
00:08:12.140 --> 00:08:15.200
A failure means lost data.

172
00:08:15.200 --> 00:08:18.876
It might be very small amount of data or
it might be a very big amount of data, and

173
00:08:18.876 --> 00:08:21.683
it's up to how we've set our
backups up to determine that.

174
00:08:21.683 --> 00:08:24.459
So for example,
looking at this model here,

175
00:08:24.459 --> 00:08:27.026
I took a full backup at midnight, right?

176
00:08:27.026 --> 00:08:30.026
So nice full backup
right here at midnight.

177
00:08:30.026 --> 00:08:31.999
And then at 6 AM, I did a differential.

178
00:08:31.999 --> 00:08:33.589
And what does a differential do?

179
00:08:33.589 --> 00:08:34.901
It gets the changes, right?

180
00:08:34.901 --> 00:08:37.085
What's changed since midnight?

181
00:08:37.085 --> 00:08:38.605
And then I do a backup at noon.

182
00:08:38.605 --> 00:08:40.770
And again, it's a differential.

183
00:08:40.770 --> 00:08:43.050
So what's changed since midnight?

184
00:08:43.050 --> 00:08:47.750
And then I do a back up at 6 PM, another
differential, what's changed since noon?

185
00:08:47.750 --> 00:08:49.850
Each back up is getting bigger and

186

00:23:10.880 --> 00:23:13.210

00:23:13.210 --> 00:23:16.810
That is a good thing,

00:23:16.810 --> 00:23:17.600
The problem is,

00:23:17.600 --> 00:23:21.460
if it take five seconds to replicate, now

00:23:21.460 --> 00:23:25.660
And you see that with trades on the stock

00:23:25.660 --> 00:23:29.200

00:23:29.200 --> 00:23:32.395

00:23:32.395 --> 00:23:35.730

but it creates a delay.

501
00:23:35.730 --> 00:23:37.910
Asynchronous replication
is where I write data here,

502
00:23:37.910 --> 00:23:41.920

still replicating to the other side.

503
00:23:41.920 --> 00:23:43.750
And if I have a failure,
I could lose data.

504
00:23:43.750 --> 00:23:46.910
You can lose data with asynchronous,

505
00:23:46.910 --> 00:23:48.730
Synchronous is slower but
more reliable, and

506
00:23:48.730 --> 00:23:50.770
it's up to you to pick

00:23:50.770 --> 00:23:55.502
All right, now when I just had a single

00:23:55.502 --> 00:23:57.512
